This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

KOTTAYAM: The youth who was arrested in connection with the death of a pregnant minor and parents was remanded in judicial custody for 14 days on Monday. Jishnudas, 20, was subjected to medical examination before being sent to remand.

The autopsy of the three deceased was done on Sunday. The funeral was conducted late on the same day. Three members of the family were found dead in their house in the district on Sunday morning.

The 17-year-old girl, who was found to be pregnant, and her parents were found hanging in the house, said police. The girl was pregnant after being sexually abused and the youth was arrested in this regard.

Police suspect this, along with financial liabilities, as the reason for the family resorting to the extreme step. Jishnudas was arrested for abusing the girl, police said.

Title: Merit list for asst professor, librarian posts published
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Puducherry: The directorate of higher and technical education , Puducherry , has published the merit list of candidates selected for the posts of assistant professors, librarians and directors (physical education) on contract basis in various government and society-run colleges in the Union territory on www.centacpuducherry.in/job.

The directorate has sought the shortlisted candidates to appear for verification of their original certificates on January 17 at its office in Lawspet.

It will post the list of selected candidates at colleges as per merit and preference of the candidates after certificate verification. The candidates should report to their respective institutions for duty on or before January 20.

If a candidate fails to appear for certificate verification or to report for duty on or before January 20, the directorate will revise the merit list and select the next deserving candidate in the list for the posts after fulfilling reservation norms. The directorate could not fill up six assistant professor posts due to a case pending before the Central administrative tribunal, Chennai.

Title: Rajasthan: 36 sarpanchs, 11,035 panchs elected unopposed in phase 1
Content:
Pic for representation purpose

JAIPUR: Thirty six sarpanchs and 11,035 ward panchs have been elected unopposed after the withdrawal of candidature for the first phase of elections to 2726 gram panchayats in the state, scheduled to be held on January 17.In the first phase, 17,242 candidates are in the fray for the post of Sarpanch and 42,704 candidates will be trying their luck for the post of ward panch.State commission (SEC) secretary Shyam Singh Rajpurohit informed that for the first phase of elections, 28,797 candidates had filed 28,865 nomination papers for the posts of sarpanch posts in 2726 gram panchayats.After scrutiny of nomination papers, 28,192 nominations were found to be valid. Till the date of withdrawal, 10,914 candidates withdrew their candidature.For the second phase of panchayat polls, 911 candidates have filed nominations for the post of Sarpanch in Jaipur on Monday.

Title: NHAI relents, KWA clears manhole at Enchakkal Jn
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: After an intense face-off, the National Highway Authority of India backed down to allow the Kerala Water Authority’s sewerage division to dig up the newly widened portion at Enchakkal Junction to restore a manhole which got buried under the asphalt. KWA initiated the work on Saturday.

On the first day itself, KWA was able to clear the blockage in the manhole which had led to overflowing sewage lines in Vallakkadavu and nearby areas. “After identifying the manhole, we were able to clear the block after opening it. The issue of overflowing of sewage has been resolved. This has been troubling local residents for a while,” said a KWA official.

The State Human Rights Commission had intervened after areas such as Vallakkadavu, Karali and Enchakkal were affected. The work was delayed after NHAI asked KWA to adopt trenchless technology instead of digging up the recently paved road, which the latter rejected.

Meanwhile, traffic congestion at Enchakkal Junction, which was leading to snarls on the national highway, is likely to intensify due to the work. KWA has barricaded the middle of the junction for the work and sources said police are not planning any traffic diversions.

KWA officials said the entire work would take around two weeks to complete. “We have resolved the issue of the block. Now, we have to replace the brick manhole with a concrete one for better stability,” officials said.

In order to prevent digging in future, NHAI had suggested that KWA construct manholes of both sides of the national highway and connect them through horizontal drilling. However, KWA ignored the request citing shortage of funds

Enchakkal is only one of many traffic choke points on the national highway. The junction has direct access to two main roads – one from Vallakkadavu and one from East Fort.

NHAI allowed KWA to dig up the junction on the condition that the portion will be restored as per its standards. “Several road safety issues are caused due to the negligence of agencies like the KWA in properly restoring dug up portions on national highways. So strict guidelines have been issued for such work,” said NHAI sources, who also voiced concern over traffic congestion at Enchakkal.

ENDS

Title: On duty, transport officer crushed by truck
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Mohammad Tareef

NEW DELHI: A transport department officer was mowed down by a speeding truck just a week before his daughter’s wedding. The officer had signalled the truck to stop for checking on Mathura Road in south Delhi around 5.30am on Sunday. The truck was going from Ashram towards Badarpur.

The deceased, Gagan Sigroha (43), was the sole breadwinner of his family. His daughter’s wedding was scheduled on January 19. His family alleged that no one from the transport department spoke to them in their time of grief.

Transport department sub-inspector Radhe Shyam, in his statement to police, said that he and four constables, including Sigroha, were on checking duty from 4am to noon on Sunday. Sigroha was to go on leave for his daughter’s wedding after his shift ended.

“We had parked our car on the roadside near Mohan Estate and were checking vehicles moving from Ashram towards Badarpur. Constables Sigroha and Jagbeer tried to stop a truck bearing a Rajasthan numberplate. Instead of stopping, the driver started speeding and ran over Sigroha in his attempt to flee. Sigroha was rushed to a hospital where he was declared brought dead,” Shyam said.

Later, the transport department officers managed to stop the truck and take the driver, Mohammad Tareef, a resident of Nuh in Haryana, in custody.

Sigroha is survived by his wife, two sons and a daughter. He was a native of Ritauli village in Rohtak. He had taken early retirement from Indian Army and joined the transport department around six years ago.

Pankaj Sejwal, Sigroha’s brother-in law, said, “He was jolly man and had never hurt anyone. His daughter’s wedding was fixed two months ago, but the celebrations have been put on hold now that he is no more. We will try and carry out the mourning soon so that the wedding can take place. The invitation cards have already been distributed so we cannot cancel it at the last moment.”

Sejwal alleged that no one from the transport department visited or spoke to the family after the incident. “He died on duty . Something should be done for the safety of the people who are serving the department. Either there should be barricades or they could carry out checking along with police,” he suggested.

Recalling an old conversation with Gagan, Sejwal said, “I would often ask him how he could do such a risky job. He would reply, safe hoke rehta hoon main (I try to be safe). His words seem to be still ringing in my ears.”

Meanwhile, special commissioner (transport) KK Dahiya said, “We have a standard operating procedure in place for the safety of our personnel and they are trained in it. There are strict directions that checking of vehicles should only be carried out in well-lit areas as our personnel mostly perform their task at night. The rules also dictate that they should not conduct checking at intersections where vehicles can speed.”

Dahiya said there are 60 teams of the transport department’s enforcement wing that check and prosecute vehicles violating norms every day. Such incidents are rare as all personnel know the rules very well. He added that this accident was unusual and the police probe is expected to unravel more details.

The department on Monday prepared a proposal to grant ex-gratia compensation for Sigroha’s family. “The proposal will be sent to the government by Tuesday,” Dahiya said, adding that the department will try to provide the maximum compensation possible to Sigroha’s family.

“Our personnel are deployed day and night in arduous work. Despite the huge volume of work, we deliver results. Our personnel are very hardworking and diligent and they mark their presence despite the skeletal staff and have created fear among violators,” Dahiya said.

Title: ‘Plan to stop water from going to Pak in final leg’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Jaisalmer: The plan to stop water from going to Pakistan has reached its final stage, Union Jal Shakti minister Gajendra Singh Shekhawat said on Monday during his visit to Pokhran’s locust-hit areas.

Many physical technical study reports have come and many reports are yet to come. Consent has been received from the Jammu and Kashmir government. In the coming days, we will certainly create history and succeed in stopping water from going to Pakistan, said Shekhawat.

Under the Indus Waters Treaty signed between India and Pakistan in 1960, all the waters of three rivers, namely Ravi, Sutlej and Beas (eastern rivers) averaging around 33 million acre feet (MAF) were allocated to India for exclusive use, while Chenab, Jhelum and Sindhu waters were allotted to Pakistan.

Even today, India’s share of drinking and irrigation water is going to Pakistan and we do not have arrangements to stop it. After Modi government came to power, efforts to contain this water were started.

In regard to Namami Ganga project, he said, under the directions of PM Modi, cleaning of Ganga started and today 42% of its water has become a lifeline for the people. Apart from drinking, the water is being used for irrigation. So far, 2,600km river has been cleaned. From Gangotri to Rishikesh, the river has been made potable. Today, Ganga is included in one of the top ten clean rivers in the world, which is a matter of pride. The work is still on. Many plans have been made to stop the polluted water from being discharged in Ganga. The work can be completed only when the general public joins the movement.

Replying to Rajasthan cabinet minister Saleh Mohammmad’s allegation of breach of promise of providing rail connectivity to Pokhran, Shekhawat said he would like to ask Rahul Gandhi, Ashok Gehlot and Sachin Pilot about the loan waiver promise made to farmers before the elections. He said that Congress’ promise was to waive 100% loan but even today 60 lakh farmers are waiting for loan waiver. The previous Vasundhara Raje government had waived 3,000 crore loans and Gehlot government gave certificates of the same.

Shekhawat said that Congress’ promise of unemployment allowance of Rs 3,500, scholarship to graduate youths is still unfulfilled. Besides, an additional load of 90-95 paise per unit of electricity is weighing down the farmers. He said that farmers are crying that their crops have been damaged by locusts and Pokhran MLA should be ashamed that instead of comforting the farmers he is playing politics.

He said Congress has always misguided the people and never fulfilled their announcements. But, whatever promises BJP had made it has fulfilled. He said that in JNU students are shouting slogans to divide India and Congress is standing with them.

Title: JD(S) demands investigationinto M’luru violence videos
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Mangaluru: JD(S) Dakshina Kannada district committee president Mohammed Kunhi Vitla demanded an investigation into the video clippings of the Mangaluru violence released by former chief minister HD Kumaraswamy.

He told reporters here on Monday the evidence should be verified scientifically. He alleged the government is trying to derail the probe by making Mangaluru city police commissioner to issue statements against Kumaraswamy.

“The evidence released by Kumaraswamy contains 100% truth. Let the government, which claims it’s fake, conduct an impartial inquiry,” Mohammed Kunhi said.

He asked why an investigation into Kumaraswamy’s revelations was not ordered when all departments and officials are under the BJP government. “How can the government declare the evidence as fake even before an inquiry? Let the government take action if investigation proves it’s fake,” he said.

On Mangaluru city police commissioner PS Harsha’s video in which he indirectly countered Kumaraswamy’s claims of police atrocities, Mohammed Kunhi said the government is trying to change the direction of investigation with police help. “Why is the government, which blames opposition parties for Mangaluru violence, not ready to order a judicial inquiry?” he asked.

He added that none of the MLAs in the district were able to use funds for local area development after BJP formed the government in the state. “No new government schemes are being announced for the district. MLAs and MLCs are forced to beg for funds for local area development,” he said.

He added: “Police officials directed us to get permission for a press conference. We submitted an application at the Mangaluru North police station. However, we haven’t been allowed to hold it. Permission was granted only after we spoke to the city police commissioner,” he said.

Title: Labourers buried under wall debris
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Allahabad: Two labourers died after being trapped for hours under the debris of a wall they were trying to pull down in Babuganj village, under the limits of Lalganj police station, in Pratapgarh district on Monday morning.

According to police, the deceased were identified as Vinod Kumar Saroj (26) and Mohd Saleem (30), both residents of Babuganj.

Inspector (Lalganj) Rakesh Bharatiya said the incident occurred around 9.30am, when a group of labourers were trying demolish an old house belonging to one Nawab Hussain.

Bharatiya said the two labourers were trying to pull down a wall of the house, when collapsed suddenly, burying Saroj and Saleem under debris. Hearing their cries, the other labourers and residents rushed to the spot and rescued them with the help of police. The two were rushed to the Lalganj community health centre, but doctors declared them brought dead. The bodies have been sent for postmortem examination.

Title: Lucknow fliers stranded at flooded Dubai airport
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Lucknow: A young man from Lucknow studying in the US missed his connecting flight from Dubai early on Sunday owing to rainfall-triggered heavy waterlogging at Al Maktoum International Airport, which had a cascading effect on the departure schedules at Amausi airport.

The student was not the only one stranded because of inclement weather in Dubai. Scores of passengers from Lucknow bound for the UAE city had a harrowing experience owing to delays and diversions involving three flights on Saturday and Sunday.

“The first flight affected was Air India Express, which was scheduled for departure at 2.15pm on Saturday. It was delayed by two hours following rain and flooding alert at Al Maktoum, where only one runway was open for landing. The congestion delayed my brother’s flight from Amausi to Dubai by an hour. As a result, he missed his connecting flight to the US,” said Ankit, the young man’s brother.

According to airport officials, the second flight to Dubai was of a private airline on Saturday evening. It departed from Amausi on time, but as it reached Dubai, the pilot was asked to divert and land at Sharjah airport instead. This lead to a delay of around two hours.

“The third flight was of Fly Dubai, which departed on time at 1.35am on Sunday. As it reached Al Maktoum around 4.30am, the pilot was told to divert towards another international airport in Dubai. The diversion caused delay in landing. However, flight operations are now returning to normal,” said a Fly Dubai spokesperson.

The airline also issued an advisory through its social media account, informing passengers on Sunday morning about the inclement weather in Dubai and its impact on flights.

Arsalan Ahmad, brother of city resident Mohammad who was on a Fly Dubai flight, told TOI that the latter was stuck on board and at the airport for hours. “Later, he called me and narrated the ordeal of passengers because of the diversions. Some had panic attack while others were severly agitated over the delay,” Ahmad said.

Several passengers who were scheduled to return to Lucknow were also stranded at Al Maktoum for hours, as their flights were equally delayed. Spokesperson for Airports Authority of India Sanjay K. Narayan on Sunday said flight operations were now back to normal.

Title: Jamia Millia Islamia may go to court for FIR against police
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Jamia vice-chancellor Najma Akhtar said the university had exhausted all other options in relation to the Dece... Read More

NEW DELHI: Jamia Millia Islamia has cancelled its ongoing semester examinations and is exploring the possibility of moving court to get an FIR registered against Delhi Police over the December 15 incident on the campus.

Announcing the decision, vice-chancellor Najma Akhtar said on Monday, “The administration will explore the possibility of moving court for the registration of an FIR. We have already exhausted all other options, having given a written complaint to SHO, Jamia Nagar, with a copy to the police chief and DCP (south east). Letters have also been sent to joint CP (southern range) and DCP (crime) for registration of an FIR earlier.”

The decision to cancel the exams was taken after students gheraoed her office and raised slogans. Akhtar emerged from her office and took questions. The students not only demanded that the semester exams, which started after the winter break, be cancelled, but also action be taken against Delhi Police for entering the campus allegedly without permission and attacking the students during a protest against CAA and NRC.

Later, the university issued a separate statement. “On the demand of the protesting students, the vice-chancellor, in consultation with the deans, HoDs and other officials, has announced that the ongoing semester exams stand cancelled till further notice. A new schedule will be declared later,” it stated. This is for the second time that the university exams have been postponed. On Tuesday, a meeting of the executive council has been called to discuss these issues.

In the interaction with the VC, a student asked what action the university planned to take against Delhi Police for holding students liable for the violence. Reiterating that the police had entered the university without permission, Akhtar said: “Police is registering unnamed FIRs against the protesting students.” She said she had even written a letter to the Centre in this regard.

A team of National Human Rights Commission will visit the campus on Tuesday to speak to the injured students and eyewitnesses. “The university has already handed over all evidence to NHRC. I am hopeful that they will understand our point of view,” Akhtar said.

Responding to a question on whether she planned to go ahead with a scheduled leave on January 15, Akhtar said: “I am not going anywhere. I am with you.”

The students have also given a call for a protest termed “Jamia Chalo” on Wednesday, marking a month of the incident on the campus.

Title: SC seeks government’s reply on Bhupendra Yadav’s appointment as DGP
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Supreme Court

JAIPUR: The Supreme Court on Monday asked the state government to reply on the appointment of Bhupendra Yadav to the post of director general of police ( DGP ) and his extension of two years within a fortnight.

On a plea, both chief secretary D B Gupta and DGP Yadav, were exempted by the court to appear personally for the time being. However, the court also said both will have to appear whenever they are required.

The three-judge bench comprising Chief Justice Sharad Arvind Bobde gave the interim direction on Monday on a contempt petition by Dr. Kaustubh Dadhich, chairman of the Civil Protection Committee.

During the hearing, senior advocate Abhishek Manu Singhvi, appearing on behalf of the state government, sought a month’s time for a reply and said that the court should look into the larger issue regarding the directions given in the Prakash Singh case.

He also urged the two officers to be exempted from personal appearance in court. Amicus curie in the case admitted that there was minor irregularity in the appointment of DGP. Significantly, on the last hearing, the Supreme Court had issued a contempt notices to the CS and DPP and asked them to answer in the case.

Title: Doctors remove nearly 1kg tumour from liver of 50-yr-old man
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Puducherry: A team of surgeons from Sri Venkateswaraa Medical College Hospital (SVMCH), Ariyur, in Puducherry removed a malignant tumour weighing nearly 1kg from the liver of a 50-year-old man from Cuddalore district.

SVMCH surgical oncologist P Ravisankar said the patient approached the hospital in December last complaining of abdominal swelling and pain for the past few months.

After clinical investigations, he was diagnosed with a malignant tumour in his liver that required immediate removal through a complicated surgery.

A team of surgeons led by Ravisankar performed the surgery that extended for more than five hours on the patient and removed the nearly 1kg tumour from his liver. The patient responded well to the surgery and was discharged after a week, said Ravisankar.

SVMCH chairman B Ramachandran congratulated the team for successfully performing the complex surgery.

Title: CM urges Japanese cos to expand in MP
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Bhopal: Chief minister Kamal Nath has urged Japanese companies, operating in the state, to expand their businesses.

He said, investment friendly environment has been created in the state.

Nath also said, comprehensive changes have been made and the industrial policy has been simplified. He said during his meeting with the chief managing director of Japan External Trade Organisation (JETRO) Yasuyuki Murahashi in New Delhi on Monday.

The chief minister discussed the possibility of Japan’s investment in detail with Murahashi.

Nath talked about the wide scope of investment in solar energy, food processing, textile, garments as well as in logistics. Extending invitation to Japanese companies for investment, he said that the state government will render full cooperation to the existing companies in the state for business expansion. The chief minister also told the JETRO head that separate policies have also been framed for industries of different technologies.

He said that a special team of officials and industrialists from Madhya Pradesh will soon visit Japan to invite businesses to explore the possibility of investment in the state.

Before the meeting with the CM, the MD of JETRO and others investors were briefed on the industrialization and potential for investment in the state along with the concessions offered by the government for investment.

Chief secretary SR Mohanty ,principal secretary Industries Dr Rajesh Rajoura, principal secretary New and Renewable Energy Manu Shrivastava were among others present.

Title: Delhi high court to hear petition against closure of Shaheen Bagh road
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court on Monday agreed to examine a Public Interest Litigation (PIL), which sought its intervention to open Kalindi Kunj-Shaheen Bagh stretch of the capital.

The road is closed since December 15 due to ongoing protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

The plea was mentioned before a bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar which listed it for hearing on Tuesday. It argued that the road closure was causing huge inconvenience/hardship to lakhs of commuters everyday and they were compelled to take different routes for the last one month.

Filed by advocate Amit Sahni, the plea seeks direction to the Delhi police commissioner to re-open for traffic Kalindi Kunj-Shaheen Bagh stretch and Okhla underpass, pointing out that such blockages are meant only as a temporary measure. The Kalindi Kunj stretch is a crucial link that connects Delhi, Faridabad (Haryana) and Noida (Uttar Pradesh). Commuters who use these roads are forced to take alternative routes—Delhi-Noida-Delhi (DND) Expressway and Ashram, which is causing hours of traffic jams and wastage of time and fuel, the plea said.

“Re-opening of schools has forced children, who take that route, to leave home two hours prior to school timing but authorities have failed to take appropriate action to give relief to the residents of the locality and lakhs of commuters of Delhi, UP and Haryana, despite representations.”

Due to the heavy traffic on alternative routes, it takes 15-20 minutes for people to cross just one traffic signal at Ashram, it said, citing news reports about the additional vehicle load on Ashram Chowk. With the Kalindi Kunj road closure, an additional 1 lakh vehicles are flowing through the intersection.

The high court, on January 10, had refused to entertain another similar plea seeking directions for removal of protesters from the Shaheen Bagh road .

In December, 2019, over a plea seeking to remove physically challenged protesters from the periphery of Mandi House, the court had directed that the petition be treated as representation by the authorities and to be decided in accordance with law, keeping in mind the permissions given by the police to the protesters, effect on the traffic and inconvenience caused to the public at large.

Title: Doctor who treated Unnao rape survivor’s father dies
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR:Doctor Prashant Upadhyay, who had once treated the father of the Unnao rape survivor , has died after complaining of breathlessness. His family members said he was unwell and on Monday morning complained of breathlessness. “He was rushed to the Unnao district hospital, where doctors declared him dead,” said his relative Pawan Tiwari.

The body has been shifted to mortuary for postmortem.

Dr Upadhyay was serving as an EMO (emergency medical officer) at the Unnao district hospital when the survivor’s father was brought to the district hospital after assault on him and had medically given the go-ahead to the police to take him to jail where he had later died. The doctor was suspended on April 12, 2018, when a CBI probe began in the case and reinstated after a period of nine months.

Basically a native of Rajajipuram locality of Lucknow, he was a residing in Motinagar area of Unnao, and presently posted at the blood bank of district hospital, Fatehpur.

According to the family members, Dr Upadhyay was struggling with diabetes since the past one year.

ASP Unnao Vinod Kumar Pandey told TOI, “According to Dr Upadhyay’s family members, he was unwell. It is a case of natural death. However, as there were talks that he died under mysterious circumstances, an autopsy with the consent of his family members was conducted by a panel of doctors and the report is awaited.”

To recall, a Delhi district court on December 20 had sentenced expelled BJP MLA Kuldeep Singh Sengar, convicted for kidnapping and raping a woman in Unnao in 2017, to life imprisonment. District Judge Dharmesh Sharma had announced the quantum of sentence.

Sengar has also been asked to pay a fine of Rs 25 lakh to the survivor apart from the life sentence.

Also, Sengar was convicted in one of five related cases transferred from Uttar Pradesh to Delhi.

Dr Uadhyay is survived by his wife Garima and a six-year-old son.

Title: Men on bike hurl crude bomb on school bus, flee
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Allahabad: Two students were injured when two unidentified men hurled a crude bomb at a school bus near Habusa turn, under limits of Sarayinayat police station, in trans-Ganga area of the city on Monday.

Police said the the school bus was targeted when it was taking students of a public school back home in the afternoon. There were over 20 students on board. Suddenly, , men on two motorcycles intercepted the vehicle and hurled a crude bomb at the bus.

The explosion shattered the bus’s window panes and students on board cried for help. Over 20 students were travelling in the bus. The students stepped out of the from bus, leaving behind their belongings.

The injured students were identified as Mradul Kushwaha and Tushar. Mradul, a resident of Ramnathpur, is a student of class IX and sustained injuries on his right palm.

As Tushar only sustained minor injuries, he went straight to his house.

SSP (Allahabad) Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said accused had stopped the bus on the pretext of having a conversation with one of the students sitting inside.

“Police have been looking for CCTV footage to ascertain the identities of the accused. A police team has also been constituted to crack the case,” he added.

Title: Hyderabad: 12-year-old dies at brick kiln, two arrested
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

WARANGAL: A 12-year-old died under suspicious circumstances at a brick kiln unit at Nakkapally village under Mamnoor police station limits in the early hours of Monday.

The deceased has been identified as Dinesh Boyi, son of Tapana Boyi and Sanji Boyi. The parents of the deceased, who belonged to Odisha , are working as the brick makers in the unit.

It is alleged that he was beaten to death by two youths who are also working at the brick kiln unit.

Police have shifted the body to MGM hospital for post-mortem.

According to sources, police have already taken the two suspected youths into custody. Mamnoor Inspector Raju is investigating the case.

Title: Who is going to be the new AU VC? Only MHRD knows
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

the big question

Allahabad: With officiating vice-chancellor of Allahabad University (AU) KS Mishra retiring on January 14, all eyes are on Ministry of human resources development ( MHRD ) to appoint a new candidate to head the institution which has been reeling under a slew of controversies.

Mishra, as the senior-most professor on AU campus, is performing his duties as the officiating VC, but he would be retiring on Tuesday (January 14). AU registrar has sent a list of senior professors so that the ministry could decided on a name for the next VC.

Former AU VC R L Hangloo submitted his resignation to the MHRD on January 1 and his resignation as accepted by the President, who is the chancellor of AU, on January 3.

The President also ordered an inquiry into several administrative decisons taken by Hangloo during his tenure, from December 30, 2015 to December 31, 2019. A three-member committee was also constituted for the purpose and the panel would be headed by the University Grants Commission chairman DP Singh. Sources said that according to the list sent to the Center, SA Ansari from commerce faculty is the senior-most professor on the campus, followed by RK Tewari of JK Institute.

However, the fact that Ansari had faced an inquiry into his administrative decisions in the past has university officials sceptic about the latter’s chances. “We have sent a list of AU’s senior professors to the MHRD and are waiting for their orders, after which a new officiating VC would be appointed,” said AU registrar NK Shukla.

“AU would soon be publishing an advertisement calling applications for the post of AU VC,” he added.

The three-member committee would be visiting the AU campus this week itself. There is a possibility that the MHRD might clear the name of the new officiating VC on Tuesday itself as January 15 is a holiday.

Title: Cong MLA accuses Pondy CM, son of corruption in land deals
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Puducherry: Congress MLA N Danavelu , who called on lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi on Monday evening at Raj Nivas, accused chief minister V Narayanasamy and his son of indulging in ‘corrupt activities in land deals’ in the Union territory.

Danavelu promised to produce evidence on the alleged corrupt practices of the CM and his son to Bedi after the Pongal holidays.

Bedi in a press note later said, “He (Danavelu) was saying that he will like to produce evidence of blatant corruption in land deals being committed by HCM (honourable chief minister) along with his son. I told him he can approach the CBI office in Puducherry directly also for investigations. He said he would revisit me after Pongal and show me the evidence to be forwarded to CBI.”

Danavelu, while briefing the media on Saturday, came down heavily on the Congress government in the UT, and accused Narayanasamy and health minister Malladi Krishna Rao of corrupt practices. He had vowed that he would soon submit a list of their corrupt practices to the party high command. He claimed the local Congress unit has begun targeting him for attempting to expose the corrupt practices of the government. He alleged that corruption has been ruling the roost in almost all departments of the government and specifically targeted the health directorate claiming it failed to ensure adequate stock of life-saving medicines in government hospitals and centres.

The Congress MLA had on Thursday staged a protest picketing the Bahour primary health centre charging that the centre has not been equipped with adequate life-saving drugs and necessary infrastructure and drivers to operate ambulances.

However, Narayanasamy and Rao, while speaking to the media on Friday, refuted his charges.

Title: We didn’t get any relief for 1 hr: Survivor
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Chhibramau (Kannauj): The passengers, suffering injuries in the bus-truck collision, narrating their experience of horror and disgust claimed that they did not get any relief for complete one hour.

"The fire tenders rushed to the spot only after one hour of the mishap," said injured Laeeq Ahmad (30) and Salman (20) of Nai Basti Mukri Tola in Gursahaiganj area of the district. Their claim was supported by residents of the area.

The two, traveling in the sleeper bus, were on way to Jaipur from Gursahaiganj to deliver exporters a huge consignment of embroidered garments including costly 'lehngas' and 'dupattas'. They said the consignment worth around Rs 1.5 lakh was also devastated in the fire. "It was not only a major monetary loss to both of us, but to local artisans too, as we were supposed to pay them their part from the deal," they said.

All the rescue work was done by the locals of the area as the police initially remained silent spectator and became active only when their seniors arrived. "It was the locals who broke open the glass windows and helped us to come out," said Salman.

"We heard a terrific sound and then everything blacked out. Later, we found ourselves trapped inside the bus with leaping flames all around it until locals rescued us," said Laeeq and added, "We then started running helter-skelter in confusion. Many others who escaped were bleeding profusely.” "After boarding the bus, we were planning to go to sleep when we heard a loud bang. We cried for help and locals with bamboo and sticks, rushed near the side windows of the bus and broke open the glass by hitting them constantly and helped us escaped," they said.

Title: Muthupudur school shifted to new place
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Tirupur: The 70-year-old Muthupudur Corporation Middle School, which was shifted from the campus next to the old bus stand, has started functioning in a new building on the old market street on the backside of the KSC Corporation Boys Higher Secondary School.

The city corporation was planning to demolish the old bus stand and build a modern terminus under the smart city mission. It decided to close the school, which has 190 students, for the development work. But parents were against the decision. TOI had carried a report on the plight of the students on July 20.

Subsequently, the corporation backtracked from shutting down the school and announced that it would be shifted to a new campus. As there was lack space for classrooms and other facilities at the place, the corporation carried out construction work at a cost of Rs 63 lakh. The school was shifted to the new campus on January 4.

“We have been given the same number of classrooms we had on the old campus. But the buildings for two anganwadis, which were also functioning along with the school, and noon-meal kitchen need to be provided, besides water facility,” said an official from the school education department.

After parents expressed fear for the safety of children while crossing roads, the corporation arranged transportation facilities for the students, said K Thangavel, a parent.

The corporation will take steps to ensure that basic amenities are available in the school, corporation commissioner K Sivakumar said.

Title: Land grab of river beds, forests cause of man-animal conflict in Bijnor
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Bijnor: With villagers killing three leopards in western Uttar Pradesh over the last seven days, state government is taking a fresh look at the causes of man-animal conflict. In Bijnor, where a leopard was gunned down on January 6, encroachment on government forest land is being seen as a key reason behind big cats taking refuge amid cane and wheat fields. Bijnor revenue department has formed three teams to remove the encroachers who have sown wheat in the corridor linking Hastinapur Sanctuary with the forests in Uttarakhand.

Another leopard was shot dead on January 8 in Moradabad and the third on January 12 in Budaun.

Officials here said illegal farming on government land has resulted in destroying natural habitats of wildlife, pushing them into inhabited areas of man. They said around 50,000 bigha of government land on the bed and banks of the Ganga in the areas bordering Bijnor, Meerut and Muzaffarnagar has been grabbed by land sharks and villagers in collusion with irrigation and forest staff. They use the land for cultivating sugarcane and wheat crops.

According to SDM, Bijnor, Brijesh Kumar Singh, “Land of Khaddar area belongs to the irrigation, forest and revenue departments. Some persons have sown wheat on that land. We have formed three teams to keep a vigil on the Khaddar area and evict encroachers from government land. Some people have claimed ownership of the land and shown some papers to the effect but these documents are questionable.”

Singh said the revenue department has a list of more than 40 people who will soon be served notices for land grab.

Bijnor divisional forest officer M Semmaran said forest staff has been asked to gather details about land encroachments in Rawali and Ganj areas of Bijnor range. They are a part of Hastinapur Sanctuary, a protected zone, covering 2,073 km square area spanning Meerut, Muzaffarnagar, Ghaziabad, Bijnor and Amroha districts.The area stretches up to Balawali, almost touching Uttarakhand,

According to Sanjeev Rana, a resident of Madhusudanpur village, “Some influential people have grabbed government land in Rawali area and sown wheat crop. Besides, they have rented out some encroached land to vegetable growers. Both forest and irrigation staff are hand in glove with them. They beat drums and burst fire crackers to shoo away wild animals from the land.”

Title: Shed collapses in unit blast
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Hyderabad: A curing shed in a factory manfacturing explosives at Peddakandukur near Yadadri collapsed on Monday evening following a blast. There were, however, no casualties.

This is a second explosion in the unit in the last one year. A person had died in the -previous blast. Bhuvanagiri DCP K Narayana Reddy said the blast took place in Premier Explosives Ltd.

“The explosion occurred in the curing shed owing to formation of gases. Walls and roof of the shed collapsed. There were no casualties,” the DCP said. TNN

Title: 22k govt schools asked to update details on Prerna app by Jan 15
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Meerut: At a time when the Uttar Pradesh government is making all efforts to make full use of Prerna app, as many as 22,000 schools in the state are yet to upload the details asked for. The state government authorities have now directed these schools to update the details or face action.

“This is to bring to your notice that the details of 1.37 lakh schools have already been uploaded on Prerna app. However, details of 22,000 schools are still pending,” Vijay Kiran Anand, state project director, Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan, said in a letter.

“All the schools are instructed to complete uploading of details on the Prerna app by January 15 or face action,” said Anand’s order.

The Prerna app has been launched to keep a check on government facilities being provided at the ground level, including midday meal, school uniforms, furniture and others.

Under the Prerna app initiative, the teachers are also instructed to upload pictures of their schools and the facilities in question so that the state government authorities can stay updated and a transparent framework is made.

Title: Hyderabad News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Alwal lies in a very confusing part of GHMC and SCB. First, the area must be clearly demarcated by both bodies. The passing of buck for upkeep of the area and provision of basic civic facilities has to be stopped between both players. The most important issue is encroachment which cannot be missed by even a layman who would visit Alwal for the first time. The footpath/open space near Satya complex has been occupied by hawkers who have made it a permanent place for business. Ramps in front of shops are completely encroached upon by shopkeepers. The gradual rise in encroachments has made matters worse in small lanes and bylanes of this part of GHMC and SCB limits. Roads are okay but need a facelift with proper streetlights in pockets of the area. Civic amenities like public toilets are completely missing in this area. Hope the right department takes up the matter at the earliest.

Deepesh Surana

Residents of Lakshmamma Enclave, Blue Birds colony, Dew drops colony, Saran nagar in GHMC Alwal are suffering from issues of overflowing sewage. I request the authorities concerned to take action.

Vamshi Krishna

Sanitation is very poor in Alwal area and the jurisdiction feud is only adding to the problem . GHMC and SCB must come together and do their duty. Politicians and higher-ups must keep a close watch to check negligence.Don't turn lakes into cesspools of garbage by connecting drains to lakes.

Reynolds Das Kuntam

Several complaints of overflowing sewage have been registered on GHMC grievances portal during the last two years but no action, whatsoever, has been taken till date. Hope the authorities wake up from their slumber and initiate a permanent solution to drainage issues.

Daniel Joseph

The three lakes in Alwal - Pedda Cheruvu at Temple Alwal, Chinnarayuni Cheruvu at Macha Bolarum and Kotha Cheruvu in Old Alwal are in a pathetic condition. The garbage dumped near the lake and the drainage plants are attracting mosquitoes, dogs and pigs and gives out a foul smell. There should be atleast one STP plant installed and the lake should be cleaned thoroughly.

A Murali Krishna

Title: Ahmadabad: 54-year-old driving tutor molests 17-year-old girl
Content:
Representative image

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

AHMEDABAD: A 17-year-old girl from the Ranip area, a first year BCA student, filed a complaint at Vastrapur police station against a 54-year-old man, who works at a garage and doubles up as a driving instructor, for molesting her when he was teaching her how to drive a car on Sunday afternoon.Police officials said the accused, identified as Dinesh Chauhan, a resident of Pink City Flats in Ranip, unzipped his trousers and began masturbating in front of the girl. He had locked the car from the inside so she could not even get out.“The incident took place at around 4.30pm on Sunday, when Chauhan took the girl on her driving class. While pretending to teach her, he sat in the driver’s seat and started driving the car, telling her to observe him,” said a police official.“He suddenly stopped the car, locked the doors, exposed his private parts to the girl and began masturbating. He had also touched the girl’s private parts,” the official said.A division ACP M A Patel said Chauhan had been engaged to repair the girl’s father’s car.“When he was repairing the car, he told the girl that he would teach her how to drive. On Sunday afternoon, Chauhan took the girl to the ground behind the TV tower in the Bodakdev area. During which he molested the girl,” Patel said.Patel added that the girl had told her parents about the incident. They called the police control room and later filed a complaint with Vastrapur police.“Vastrapur police registered a complaint of molestation and under the POCSO (Protection of Children against Sexual Offenders) Act and began an investigation. Police will also try to get CCTV footage from the area. The victim will also give a statement before a magistrate, under Section 164 of the CrPC,” said Patel.Chauhan was arrested by Vastrapur police and produced before a local court, which sent him to judicial custody.Girl’s mother was there tooThe victim, unaware of Chauhan’s intentions, agreed when he offered to teach her to drive. “The girl will turn 18 in three months. So the family was looking for a driving instructor and approached the garage owner, for whom Chauhan worked. When the family was enquiring about a driving instructor, Chauhan came forward and said that he would teach her to drive,” said a police official.Chauhan had first taken the girl, to teach her to drive, on Saturday afternoon. That day, he acted normally and told her to come again on Sunday. “On Sunday, the girl came with her mother. The accused told the girl’s mother to wait near the ground. The mother waited there and he took her inside, where he molested her,” said the official.The girl’s mother initially did not know what had happened. When the girl got home, she broke down and told her mother about the incident.

Title: Delhi: Kingpin held with Rs 3-crore heroin
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The Special Cell of Delhi Police has arrested the kingpin of an interstate drug cartel and recovered heroin brought from Myanmar worth Rs 3 crore . A reward of Rs 1 lakh had been declared earlier for the arrest of Saidul Sheikh (27), who was using local suppliers in Delhi to distribute drugs.

Last year, police had arrested two members of the cartel, Baijur Rehman and Mohammad Abu Bakr Siddiqui, residents of Malda. The two accused were travelling to Delhi from north-east India. The cops were able to seize their stash of drugs but the kingpin of the cartel kept evading arrest.

DCP (special cell) Sanjeev Yadav said that Rehman and Siddiqui revealed that the consignments from Manipur were co-ordinated by Sheikh from Guwahati and were to be delivered to Delhi. “A non-bailable warrant and a reward were issued against him,” said Yadav.

Cops formed a dedicated team and laid a trap near Mujaffarpur and Malda to catch Sheikh. Finally, he was nabbed from Mujaffarpur. He was brought to Delhi to reveal the complete narcotic syndicate and to identify other associates who are still at large.

Sheikh told police that the cartel has circulated over 200 kg heroin in the past two years in Delhi-NCR. Police officers are trying to identify the other members of the cartel to establish the source of the heroin in Myanmar.

Title: 35 per cent food samples have failed purity test: Tulsiram Silawat
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Food safety officials collecting samples from a grocery store on Monday

BHOPAL: Minister for food, Tulsiram Silawat , said on Monday that 35% of the samples of edibles sent for purity test under “Shudh Ke Liye Yudh” have been found substandard or adulterated. Holding a review meeting on “Shudh ke Liye Yudh” at Mantralaya, the minister said that traders, who are found selling adulterated or substandard goods should be booked under the National Security Act (NSA). At the same time, strict action should also be taken against officials found lenient on “erratic” traders and manufacturers, including their suspension. He stressed on the need public awareness rallies in this regard.

Silawat said that the drive against adulteration should continue and people should be kept posted on action being taken against the adulterators. He said that ensuring supply of pure edibles to people is the state government’s mission and all officials involved in the campaign should take their role in “Shudh Ke Liye Yudh” seriously. The minister said that samples of food articles should be taken from all sorts of eateries selling food stuff, including luxury hotels and restaurants. The minister said that samples of all kinds of packaged food, milk, paneer and mawa should continue to be taken for testing across the country.

Silawat said that public awareness rallies should be organized under the campaign at the divisional and the district-level. Minister in-charge of the district and eminent citizens of the place concerned should be requested to attend the rallies. The rallies can be held at the divisional-level first, followed by districts. He said that such a rally should be organized on January 31 in Gwalior, 2 February in Jabalpur and February 3 in Rewa.

Commissioner, food safety , Rajeev Dubey, said at the meeting that NSA has been imposed on 41 adulterators across the state so far. Other persons against whom FIR has been lodged during the campaign are being prosecuted in competent courts.

Title: In Maoist-hit Gadchiroli, police conduct ‘doorstep delivery’ of licences, caste certificates; prep tribals for driving exam
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

GADCHIROLI: Ajay Majji recalls how in 2009, he spent half a day walking 14km, crossing a dense forest teeming with wildlife , wading through rivulets to reach the tehsil office. The man from Mirdapalli village — located at the foothills of Maoist headquarters in Abujmadh on the Maharashtra-Chhattisgarh border — needed a caste certificate made. But this January when his son, Ashish, needed to get the same document, he had help from unexpected quarters — the certificate was delivered to the family by police.

In a novel initiative, Gadchiroli police is collecting documents door-to-door and later delivering licences and caste certificates — crucial to avail any government benefits — to people. Since December 2018, 2,700 people have benefited from the scheme. The move is part of an outreach initiative called ‘Project Pragati’ that aims to “win people over”, according to police officers.

Under the project, training sessions are also being held to help residents pass online driving exam, SP Shailesh Balkawade said, adding that police officers teach tribals how to differentiate between traffic signage and how to take the online driving test. Sub-inspectors Babasaheb Dudhal and Ganesh Raykar said that this week alone, 200 people from remote Bhamragarh tehsil will be trained to get their driving licences. Officers said that helping people get driving licences would allow them to have some means of income.

To distribute caste certificates, police are also organizing ‘jan jagaran melawa’ (mass awareness campaign rallies). The latest such meet was held on January 6 when 70 tribals from Nelgunda and Mirdapalli received caste certificates. In the past few months, those from remote villages of Tadgaon, Kothi, Pendhri and Bhamragarh have been able to get their documents with police aid.

SP Balkawade said that caste certificates are required to enjoy benefits under Forest Rights Act which includes piece of land (patta) for tilling and also community rights on the minor forest produce. “In many remote hamlets, tribals could not avail any of their rights under Forest Rights Act as they did not have the required certificates. They were also deprived of other benefits like education scholarships or housing schemes. So we decided to help them out.”

In fact, even in cases where a tribal has no document, the district administration can be approached. “In case someone has no document, the tehsildar issues a ‘self-identification’ certificate which is essentially the tehsildar vouching for the person’s identity and his bona-fide status as a resident of a particular place,” Balkawade said.

Collector Shekhar Singh, encouraging the police initiative, also had ensured that the process of completing the formalities of issuing the caste certificate were made simple without requiring any documents and also free of cost for the tribal. "We have waived off the cost of Rs70 required towards issuing the certificates," he said.

Sub-divisional police officer (SDPO), Bhamragarh, Kunal Sonawane, added that tribal families are entitled to Rs20,000 as compensation upon demise of the breadwinner from natural causes and Rs4 lakhin case they die in a disaster, but they need a caste certificate to get these benefits. “The scheme was rolled out to ensure no one is deprived of these benefits.”

“We collect identification documents from families while patrolling their villages or during melawas. They are sent to the tehsil office together and once the caste certificates are ready we deliver them to the residents,” Sonawane said.

Asmita Raju Mahaka, a Madia tribal of Nelgunda, said that with the caste certificate she recently received, she would now be eligible for a piece of land. But Penta Kannake in Nelgunda was upset that he had been away when police had come to collect documents in his area. “I hope they come again soon. It’s my only hope.”

This story is from January 14, 2020

Title: DGP lauds Gadchiroli police for ‘incident-less’ state election
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Nagpur: State director general of police Subodh Jaiswal, who was on a visit to Maoist-affected Gadchiroli on Monday, is learnt to have praised the efforts of the district police in being able to conduct the state assembly election last year without any incident to dent the polling process for the first time at least the last decade.

Jaiswal is learnt to have congratulated Superintendent of police Shailesh Balkawade and his team for managing two elections in the tribal district where the Maoists oppose polling with threats and also sabotage activities.

The elections were held peacefully despite a major setback of losing 15 Quick Response Team (QRT) jawans and a civilian in a blast on May 1, 2019, at Jambhulkheda in a blast triggered by Maoists after torching 27 vehicles of a road construction company.

In the general election earlier in 2019, the Maoists had managed to trigger two blasts on polling day, and a day earlier, injuring two cops. There was also an attempt made on the returning polling party by Maoists but Gadchiroli police had managed to thwart the attempt.

Apart from managing two elections, the district police had managed to neutralize around seven Maoists and ensured surrender of 34 cadres including three cadres of Divisional Committee member ranks. They had also managed to arrest 27 cadres including seniormost leader Narmada Akka and her husband Kiran.

Title: Five drown, college-goer goes missing at sea off Chennai coast
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Five drowned and a youth went missing in five separate incidents on Sunday.

Police said S Narasimha, 22, of Mannargudi, had come to the city to attend an interview along with his cousin V Gokul, 21, an engineering student at a city college. On Sunday afternoon, the duo, accompanied by Aravind Samy of Okkiyam Thoraipakkam and Arul Kumar, reached the Elliot’s Beach. While bathing in the sea, Gokul and Narasimha were swept away by a giant wave. Onlookers pulled out Narasimha but was declared dead by paramedics of a ‘108’ ambulance team. Police said Gokul was missing. Narasimha’s body wassenttoGovernmentRoyapettah Hospital for postmortem. The Sastri Nagar police have registered a case and are looking for Gokul.

In another incident, a fisherman slipped off a boat and drowned in in Pulicat. Vignesh, 28, of Kasimedu, went to fish with his friends in the sea on Sunday night, police said. In another incident, a private firm employee drowned in the sea off Pulicat while swimming. Though his friends managed to rescue him, he was declared ‘brought dead’ by doctors at Ponneri Government Hospital.

In Kanathur, a 15-year-old schoolboy, Mohammed Ismail, was playing with four friends in the sea when he drowned. In another incident, a 27-year-old mechanic slipped and fell into Krishna Canal in Tirumullaivoyal while fishing and drowned on Sunday.

Title: A week on, AMC yet to file FIR in doo-to-door garbage collection scam
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Agra: A week has passed since a probe report revealed a scam in the door-to-door garbage collection system, but the Agra Municipal Corporation is yet to file an FIR against those involved in the fraud case.

According to the report, which was tabled in the municipal board meeting on January 6 this year, five private companies entrusted with the garbage collection in the city were paid Rs 22.65 crore without verifying their work done.

An investigation had revealed that only 10.5 % of garbage collection was done in 83 wards of the city. The report claimed that the companies produced fake bills to get payments.

It was also found that a majority of the addresses and details of residents given by the companies as evidence of door-to-door garbage collection were fake.

On basis of the probe findings, municipal board of councilors had directed the AMC administration to file FIR against the private companies.

Reacting to the matter, mayor Naveen Jain said, “I will inquire with the senior officials regarding action being taken on decisions of the municipal board concerning the garbage collection scam. FIR will be definitely registered.”

Meanwhile, municipal commissioner Arun Prakash said, “Notices have been issued to the private companies, tasked with door-to-door garbage collection. We are waiting for their response after which legal action will be taken.”

Agra (South) MLA Yogendra Upadhyaya, who had attended the municipal board meeting, said, “I had decided to wait for 10 more days, i.e. till January 16, for the AMC administration to take action in this regard. The municipal commissioner is mandated to follow the decision of the municipal board, otherwise action will be taken against him. I will pursue the matter and make sure that it reaches its logical conclusion. Those involved in the scam will go to jail.”

The additional municipal commissioner, Vinod Kumar, had headed the three-membered committee constituted by Mayor Naveen Jain to probe the door to door garbage collection. The councilors had demanded copy of the probe report, which has not been provided so far.

Title: Raj Nivas received more than 12,500 petitions in ’19, says Bedi
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Puducherry: Raj Nivas, the official residence of lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi , received 12 ,506 petitions in 2019 through various sources, including toll-free numbers (100, 1031 and 112), WhatsApp, email, open house sessions, postal services and others. Since the inception of public grievances ’ redressal system three years ago, Raj Nivas received 49,305 petitions.

Bedi, in a WhatsApp post, said her office has initiated appropriate action over the grievances, including rescuing nine Puducherry people languishing in foreign countries and bringing them back to the territory with the help of Union external affairs ministry. She thanked the ministry for its timely help.

She said her office accorded special attention to the complaints of women and senior citizens and directed the protection officers (social welfare department) to pursue their complaints immediately. She said 120 petitions related to civil disputes received in 2019 were referred to Lok Adalat. She pointed out that all departments have shown substantial improvement in their response systems over the years.

She said Raj Nivas will release an analytical booklet on the redressal of grievances by next week.

“The analysis of all trends of grievances has been done,” she said and added that her office identified mid- and long-term solutions to prevent reoccurrences of the same complaints.

“However, some issues require strong engineering, policy decisions and financial resources. But the administration is alive to public concerns. We now seek greater public support in checking financial leakages termed corruption. The CBI office is also in Puducherry. People may approach them directly as well,” Bedi said, appealing to the public to join hands with her office in curbing corruption in the territory.

She said the round-the-clock control room in Raj Nivas receives petitions from various sources, computerises and forwards the petitions to the departments concerned and gets their acknowledgement to track the complaints. The control room also tracks the time taken by the departments concerned in addressing the complaints.

Besides the control room numbers, Raj Nivas also has WhatsApp numbers (95005 60001 and 94434 60717) to receive complaints. Chief grievance redressal officer S Bascarane will review the complaints, make on-field inspections, if necessary, to ascertain the veracity of the complaints and refer complex issues to the notice of senior officers including the secretaries concerned.

Bedi urged the people of Puducherry to continue to inform the administration of any issue requiring public service intervention.

Raj Nivas will honour two officials – collector (Karaikal) Vikrant Raja and director (school education) P T Rudra Goud – during the Republic Day celebrations on January 26 for their conscientious efforts in redressing the grievances of the people.

Title: Register drone by Jan 31, or face action: Aviation ministry
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

NEW DELHI: Everyone using a drone in India will need to register with the government before the end of the month. The aviation ministry on Monday issued a public notice for “a one-time opportunity for voluntary disclosure of such drones and drone operators”.

After the January 31 deadline, anyone flying an unregistered drone will face action under IPC and Aircraft Act. The Directorate General of Civil Aviation had in 2018 issued rules to regulate the use of drones in Indian airspace which require obtaining unique identification number, unmanned aircraft operator permit and contain other requirements.

Title: NHRC begins probe into AMU violence
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Agra: A seven-member National Human Right Commission (NHRC) team arrived at Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) on Monday to probe alleged on-campus police aggression on December 15, following directions of Allahabad high court that the report has to be submitted within a month.

NHRC team leader SSP Manjil Saini told media they will stay in Aligarh for five days till Friday. On Monday, the team visited some places on campus where violence occurred on December 15, which left over 70 people, including students and security personnel, injured.

Before initiating the probe, Saini told media, “We’ll also visit the injured Morrison Court hostel for boys, in which, according to students, a room was allegedly set afire after RAF lobbed a teargas shell. We’ll also visit the library and other places.”

She added the team will meet students, administrative officials including VC, registrar and proctor, and district authorities including DM and SSP, to hear their versions of events.

University proctor Afifullah Khan informed that on Monday, the NHRC team visited Morrison Court before meeting vice-chancellor Tariq Mansoor. He said the varsity will extend all support to the team. “CCTV footage and details of injured students will be provided,” he said.

The NHRC team includes deputy registrar Khaleel Ahmad, two deputy SPs Rajbir Singh and Rajendra Singh, and three inspectors Saroj Tewari, Arun Tyagi and Manoj Dahiya.

While the stand-off between students and police was on since Parliament passed CAB, hundreds of students marched out of campus in the evening on December 15, following rumours that two students had been shot by cops at Jamia Millia Islamia in Delhi during a similar anti-CAA protest.

Title: Ramesh: ‘Kerala a women-friendly state’ claim a hoax
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala expressed concern over increasing atrocities against women and girl children in the state.

“Suicide of a victim and her family members in Kottayam sheds light on the horrendous experience that hapless victims and their families are forced to go through. Several young girls were killed in various attacks in different parts of the state in the recent times. Moral policing, physical abuse and attack on women and girl children are on a rise in the state. The government’s projection of Kerala as a women-friendly state is nothing but a hoax. Latest reports also indicate that Kerala records the highest number of suicide cases in the country,” he said.

Chennithala said government sponsored programmes such as ‘night walk’ do not yield any result on the ground. Police are in deep slumber when moral police go on a rampage. “It’s embarrassing to know that when a woman approached a police station to report harassment by a group of goons on Sanghumugham beach, she was confronted with counter questions by police as they wanted to know why was she loitering on beach in the dead of the night. The government should initiate strict action against such officials who behave irresponsibly,” he added.

Title: UP: Dog enters private hospital’s operation theatre, kills newborn in Farrukhabad
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

The incident took place at 8:30am at Akash Ganga Hospital in Awas Vikas Colony.

AGRA: In a gut-wrenching incident, a stray dog entered the operation theatre (OT) of a private hospital in Farrukhabad city and attacked and killed an infant born a few minutes ago on Monday.

The incident took place at 8:30am at Akash Ganga Hospital in Awas Vikas Colony. Ravi Kumar, who works with a private finance firm, had come to the hospital with his pregnant wife, Kanchan, who was going through labour pain.

“Initially, the hospital’s nursing staff informed us that a normal delivery will be conducted, but moments later after consulting the doctor, they told us that my wife had to go for a caesarean. So, they took her to the operation theatre, and an hour later, they informed us that operation was successful and took Kanchan in a ward, while the baby was still in the OT. They told me to wait outside,” Ravi Kumar said.

“A few minutes later, the hospital staff came out shouting about a dog’s presence in the OT. Sensing danger, I rushed to the OT and saw my baby lying on the floor covered in blood. My baby had dog bite marks on his chest and left eyes. He was lying still with no movement. The dog again attempted to enter the OT while I screamed for help for my kid,” said Kumar, who had become father for the first time.

He added, “I confronted the doctors and hospital staff for the inhuman treatment and negligence, but instead of feeling guilty they offered me money and asked me to remain silent about the incident. They told me that my baby was stillborn and the dog entered the OT by mistake.”

District magistrate Manvendra Singh said, “Our probe found that due to negligence of the hospital, the dog took away the baby and killed him. A committee comprising doctors has been formed under the city magistrate, who will investigate as to how many illegal private hospitals are running in Farrukhabad. The report will be submitted in three days to me to take further action,” Singh said.

After the incident, Farrukhabad police lodged a FIR against hospital owner Vijay Patel and other staff members under Indian Penal Code (IPC) section 304-A (death by negligence).

By the time this report was filed, DM Farrukhabad ordered the hospital to be shut down, as the probe done by deputy CMO Rajeev Shakya had also found that the hospital had no valid papers and a licence to operate.

Title: Stalker threatens girl with acid attack in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 47-year-old man lodged a complaint at Krishnanagar police station stating that one Piyush Chavda, a resident of Naroda, threatened to attack his 20-year-old daughter with acid if she married anyone other than him.

The girl’s father stated that Chavda has been harassing his daughter whenever she goes out.

The FIR also states that Chavda not only threatened his daughter, but also groped her, hit her up and abused her in her own house. Inspector V R Chaudhari of Krishnanagar police station said they registered an offence under Sections 354, 452, 323, 294(b) and 506(1) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

“The accused has fled from his house. We have formed a team to nab him,” Chaudhari said.

According to the FIR, the girl’s parents had gone to a funeral and their daughter was alone at home.

“When they returned in the evening, their daughter told him that at about 1pm Chavda had come to the house and started abusing her. He groped her and threatened to attack her with acid if she married anyone or even kill her,” a police official said.

The FIR states that when Chavda started slapping her, her cries for help drew their neighbour, Jayeshbhai. On seeing him, Chavda ran away from the house.

Title: Local panels to get 50% of forest-fire prevention funds
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Kozhikode: The state has decided to make its forest-fire prevention and management activities for the upcoming summer participatory. The forest department has issued directions that 50% of total funds allotted for forest-fire prevention be used for activities of the grassroots-level vana samrakshana samithies (VSSs), eco-development committees (EDCs) and forest development agencies (FDAs).

The move is expected to broad base the activities and add to the manpower on the ground. There are over 400 VSSs and 190 EDCs under the various territorial and wildlife divisions in the state.

Kerala witnessed 314 forest fires in 2018 affecting 1,114 hectares of land. Nearly 7,893km of fire lines were created during 2017-18 at a cost of Rs 23 crore.

“This year the head of the forest force has issued a directive to ensure that 50% of funds earmarked for fire protection be used for anti-fire activities of participatory forest institutions like VSS and EDC. The respective VSSs/EDCs will be provided Rs 500 to Rs 1,000 per hectare for undertaking fire-prevention measures in forest areas coming under them. VSS/ EDA members can become fire watchers and constitute fire gangs from among themselves,” said S R Radhakrishnan, assistant conservator of forests.

Forest department officials said this will ensure community participation, even among tribals, in forest-fire protection and also create awareness in communities about preventing fires caused by anthropogenic activities. He said the department has drawn up a fire plan and has classified the forests into three categories depending on the level of fire risk on the basis of incidents over the last five years.

A centralised control room is now functional and there were 45 fire incidents reported between December 24 and January 13 as per Fire Management Information System (FMIS), of which 43 were controlled burning carried out as part of fire-protection activities.

Meanwhile, citizen volunteer groups and environmentalists from across the state, who have come together under the Fire Free Forests collective, met authorities of the forest department and the State Disaster Management Authority (SDMA) on Monday with the plea for immediate steps to ensure the state free of fires in the upcoming summer season. The collective has called for constituting an independent fire force in the department, modernising fire prevention and control measures by deploying drones, and also increasing the allocation for fire-prevention measures.

Fire Free Forests representatives N Badusha, Anitha S , K M Sulaiman, Raheem Thalanad and Veena M were part of the delegation. They held discussions with P K Kesavan, principal chief conservator of forests and head of forest force, and principal secretary, revenue & disaster management Dr K Venu.

Badusha said methods adopted by the forest department to control forest fires are outdated and unscientific. He said involvement of district administrations, local self-government bodies and the SDMA should be ensured for fire-protection and control measures which are now mostly carried out by the department alone. “There is need for at least a fourfold increase in funds,” he added.

Title: KPP Nambiar award for Isro chairman K Sivan
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers (IEEE) Kerala section bestowed its prestigious KPP Nambiar award on Isro chairman K Sivan considering his substantial contributions towards the engineering profession. VSSC director S Somanath received the award on behalf of Sivan at a function held here on Monday.

The KPP Nambiar award is instituted to honour individuals or groups in the state for their significant contribution to the IEEE vision of advancing technology for humanity through research and technology advancement, popularizing the use of technology and applying technology for the under-served. The award is instituted in the name of its founder chair and the doyen of electronic industry KPP Nambiar.

Receiving the award, Somanath detailed various missions undertaken like Chandrayaan and also referred to future programmes like mission to Sun (Adithya), mission to Venus and upgrades on India’s Indigenous Global Positioning System.

IEEE also honoured APJ Abdul Kalam University vice-chancellor Rajashree M S with outstanding women engineer award for her inspiring work as a woman academic. In her acceptance speech, she reiterated the need of promoting research at the undergraduate level within KTU and invited the IEEE Kerala section to partner in the initiative.

T K Shahal Hassan Musaliar, chairman, TKM Group of Institutions, was bestowed with ‘Friend of IEEE for Academia’ award. Cochin Shipyard and Nissan Digital received ‘Friend of IEEE Award for Industry’ taking into account their staunch support to their respective sectors.

K P Mohandas and Suresh Nair, CTO NeST Group received ‘Outstanding Teacher’ award and ‘Outstanding Researcher’ award, respectively. Jyothi Ramaswamy of TCS received ‘Industry Contributions’ award.

S M Sameer, chair, IEEE Kerala section presided the award function.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: This 12-year-old is ready to sit for Class 12 Boards
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

12-year-old Tanishka Awasthi

BHOPAL: A 12-year-old Indore girl — Tanishka Awasthi — might become the youngest person to appear for Class 12 Boards of Madhya Pradesh Board of Secondary Education — provided her examination application is approved by the education board.

Tanishka was learning ahead of her age and since no school was willing to accommodate her in a higher class her parents decided to homeschool her, after she completed Class 4. She took her Class 10 Boards last year and scored 65% in the exams.

“MP Board does not have provision for younger students to sit for Boards. Last year we had requested the then MP Governor Anandiben Patel to allow Tanishka to take the Class 10 exams. She was granted permission and she scored 65% in the boards. As per the MPBSE rules, there should be a gap of one year between Class 10 and 12 exams ... which is why we have again sought permission to let our daughter appear in the Class 12 Boards, without taking Class 11 exams,” said Tanishka’s mother, Anubha Awasthi.

“Tanishka is very bright. She was able to solve questions of Class 7 in Class 5 itself, but schools pressured her not to skip any class. When she was in Class 8, she could solve trigonometry of Class-10 level. Three years went by like this before we could get permission for her to sit for Board exams. Last year when the MPBSE allowed her to take the exams, she passed the exams with a good percentage”, said her mother.

“While the other state boards have provisions for younger children to take board exams early, we were told that MPBSE does not have any such rules. So, if we get the permission, Tanishka will be appear for private exams of Class 12, instead of regular in March this year”, she added.

Anil Suchari, secretary MPBSE told TOI that the application of the parents to let their daughter appear for the Class 12 exams is under consideration.

“This is the first time that such a request has been made in our state. The application is under consideration and a committee will decide if the student should be allowed to take the exams. We are yet to give our decision on the matter,” said Suchari.

Title: Body of 12-year-old boy found in sack near canal in Bareilly
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: The body of an unidentified 12-year-old boy was found near an irrigation canal in Nawabganj area of Bareilly district on Monday, said police.

Police said the body was at least five days old and stashed into a sack with his hands and feet tied with a rope. The body was sent for autopsy to determine the cause of his death.

Police, meanwhile, shared information about the boy with nearby police stations to gather information about him.

Waking up to foul smell emanating from the sack on Monday morning, residents living near the canal when opened the sack, they found the body of a boy inside and alerted police.

Soon a police team, along with forensic experts, visited the spot. The body was quite decomposed, said police, adding that they didn’t find any identity evidence to identify the victim.

Nawabganj SHO Gaurav Singh told TOI, “We have shared photos of the boy and have been waiting for the response from nearby police stations. We are expecting a breakthrough, soon.”

Title: Live stream on DD’s OTT: Centre gets 3 months to decide
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image
