CHENNAI: The Madras high court has given the Centre three months to decide on amending the law to enable Doordarshan to live-stream top sports and entertainment events on its over-the-top (OTT) platforms, in addition to its terrestrial and DTH networks on free-to-air basis.

“This is a clear subject of policy decision to be undertaken by the government after examining various factors, as this will involve not only the appreciation of the substantive rights being claimed by the petitioner, but also the procedural mechanism for dissemination of transmission that may be dependent on contracts and other statutory regulations governing transmissions, the first bench comprising Chief Justice A P Sahi and Justice Subramonium Prasad said on Monday.

Leaving the issue to be assessed by the government, the bench said: “The government, therefore, should and must respond. We, therefore, direct the authorities to coordinate amongst themselves and such other necessary authorities who deserve to be consulted in the process and take an appropriate decision in the matter supported by cogent and plausible reasons, preferably within three months.”

The bench was passing orders on a PIL filed by sound engineer Aditya Modi, who wanted the government to amend the sports broadcasting law, as, at present, Prasar Bharati is not permitted to live-stream such events due to a restriction in the Sports Act. Modi contended that restricting the mode of free transmission of sports and entertainment information impinged upon the fundamental rights of a citizen to receive information through internet services, including all its forms.

Limiting retransmission to only through these two modes amounts to negating the right to free information of individuals through other modes, including OTT platform, he said, adding that citizens having access to the internet are being denied access to sports events of national importance and the like, as the Prasar Bharati is not permitted to adopt these methods due to the restriction contained in the Sports Act.

Opposing the plea, authorities, including Prasar Bharti, argued that none of the rights of citizens is affected, much less any violation of fundamental rights. There is neither any prohibition nor restriction so as to totally deprive any citizen of such free information or broadcast of sports programmes being relayed as per statutory provisions, they said.

Recording the submissions, the bench said: “There can be no gainsaying that the right to claim information through a particular electronic mode or application may by itself be not a fundamental right, but access to the internet is the norm...” They also added: “The material placed before us does not lead to any inference of arbitrariness or discrimination in the choice of mode of transmission by Prasar Bharati and the additional modes as suggested by the petitioner do not seem to have been asserted before the authorities in any form for them to respond to the same.”

Title: Patel girls, ‘bahus’ get their due at NRI-rich Dharmaj
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Dharmaj town of Anand district unveiled its initiative of adding women’s names to Patel family tree on Sunday

VADODARA/ ANAND: When former finance secretary and ICS-officer-turned politician Dr H M Patel passed away in 1993, he was survived by five daughters. His youngest daughter is Dr Amrita Patel, who went on to serve as the chairman of the National Dairy Development Board (NDDB) – India’s apex board for dairy development.

However, the community tree of Patels of Dharmaj neither mentioned her or the names of four other daughters of their family.

On Sunday, the community tree got complete with the mention of all the five daughters of Dr H M Patel as the NRI-rich Dharmaj town of Anand district unveiled its latest initiative of adding names of daughters and daughter-in-laws to the Patels’ lineage.

A majority of Patels of Dharmaj are descendants of Ranga Patel, the patriarch, who had migrated from Virol village near Sojitra, to the present day Dharmaj before 345 years.

“Veteran Motibhai Amin had last updated the community tree of Chh Gam Patidar Samaj in 1924. After that the community tree of the samaj was updated in 2018 by the Bharat Patidar Samaj. But so far, there was no tradition of putting names of daughters and daughter-in-laws in the community tree,” said Rajesh Patel, part of team Dharmaj.

The team has been organising Dharmaj Day celebrations regularly as an attempt to connect generation next of NRI spread across the globe to their roots.

“For the first time, we (Dharmaj) have taken the initiative of adding names of daughters and daughter-in-laws to family trees. We have been able to trace the family trees to our patriarch Ranga Patel,” he said, adding that names of nearly 2,000 women have been so far added.

“We have initiated this as a pilot project through online and offline modes. The next step will be updating the entire community of Chh Gam Patidar Samaj,” he said.

In Patel community, Chh Gam (cluster of six villages) refers to Bhadran, Dharmaj, Karamsad, Nadiad , Sojitra and Vaso – the villages spread in the twin districts of Anand and Kheda – broadly referred as Charotar belt of Central Gujarat .

Title: Atrocity FIR against builder, three others
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A resident of the Satellite area of city on Sunday filed a complaint alleging criminal intimidation and charges under the Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe (Prevention of Atrocities) Act against a developer, Umang Thakkar of Dharamdev Infrastructure Private Limited, and three others .

The complainant alleged that the builder and three others have been constantly threatening him over a land dispute in Vejalpur.

In his FIR with Satellite police, Teja Makwana, 62, a resident of Tulsi Ekta Society in Satellite, alleged that the accused persons’ aides rammed a truck into the boundary wall of his house. “The driver drove the truck in reverse so carelessly as if he was in an uninhabited place. As two unknown men were present there, they started screaming so the driver stopped the truck,” said Makwana in the FIR.

Makwana states in the FIR that Thakkar and his aides wanted to kill him by ramming the truck in his house and projecting it as an accident.

Makwana also said that the accused persons’ aides parked various trucks outside their house illegally and would rev their engines in such a way that it would blow smoke into their house.

Following this, he approached Satellite police and filed the complaint.

Title: Ahmedabad: Wife alleges man hid his same-sex UK marriage
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 29-year-old woman from the Walled City area lodged an unusual complaint at Danlimda police station against her husband and in-laws on Sunday. She alleged that her husband had concealed his homosexuality and same sex marriage in the UK. She also alleged that he suffered from a sexually transmitted disease and had hidden this at the time of their wedding.

Inspector V R Vasava of Danilimda police station said the accused is on the run. “The woman has submitted social media photographs of her husband’s same-sex marriage ,” Vasava said.

In the FIR, the woman has accused her husband, father-in-law and mother-in-law.

A police source said the accused had wed the woman in November 2019. Even after eight days of the wedding when her husband refused to consummate the marriage, the woman talked to her husband’s parents who took her husband to a hospital and did a medical check-up. “She has alleged that she was not informed of the result of the tests and when she inquired her in-laws and husband harassed her mentally and physically,” said the police source.

Even after the check-up her husband refused cohabitation, which increased the suspicions of the woman. She told her elder sister about the situation, but she told her that such things happened during the early days of marriage.

“When 25 days had gone by, she told her husband that she will talk to her parents. Her husband scolded her and continued to refuse to consummate the marriage,” an investigator said.

With suspicions about her husband’s sexual inclinations mounting, she checked his mobile phone. “She was shocked to find photos of her husband showing his homosexuality. She transferred the photos to her phone,” a police source said.

When she confronted her husband with the photos, he became agitated and admitted he had already married a Nigerian man at in the UK and that his parents knew about it.

The FIR says that after a few days her husband developed ulcers in his mouth. He was treated by different doctors, but his condition kept worsening.

On January 10, the woman’s parents asked her husband and learned he is also suffering from sexually transferred diseases (STD).

Title: NSUI and SCS demand medical re-examination of injured student leaders
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

AGRA: Alleging that the medical examination of the injured student leaders was not done properly, the National Students Union of India (NSUI) and Samajwadi Chatra Sabha (SCS) members on Monday demanded superintendent of the police (city) Botre Rohan Pramod to order a medical re-examination.

The NSUI claimed that its state coordinator Ankush Gautam and secretary Satish Sikarwar had fractures in their right hand during the police lathi-charge at Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University’s Paliwal Park campus on Saturday.

Later, NSUI and SCS worker met Agra University vice chancellor Arvind Kumar Dixit raising objection over the proctorial board’s decision to prohibit entry of 13 student leaders of both the organizations on campus. However, the student leaders were not unsatisfied after discussion with VC.

NSUI spokesperson Apoorv Sharma said, “We had met SP City and informed him of police taking one-sided action against NSUI and SCS workers. No action was taken against Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP), workers who were also protesting on campus. Only NSUI workers were beaten up and abused, and we have video evidence to substantiate our claims. We will go to court if police officers fail to provide us justice.”

NSUI state coordinator Ankush Gautam said, “I have swelling in both legs and am not able to move without support. State secretary Satish Sikarwar also has a fracture in his right hand. Besides, several other student leaders of NSUI and SCS are injured. After lathi-charge we were taken to the police station and later they took us for medical examination, which was not done properly.”

Talking to TOI, SP City Botre Rohan Pramod said he has taken cognizance of the issue raised by student leaders.

“Station house officer Hariparwat has been directed to call them and take the required action. In the entire matter, a case has already been registered against 40 unknown members of the ABVP, NSUI and SCS. Fair investigation will be ensured.”

On Saturday afternoon, ABVP activists had assembled at the Paliwal Park campus of Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University to stage a protest against the recent violent clashes in Delhi’s Jawaharlal Nehru University and demanded a ban on left-wing organizations on campus.

Later, NSUI and SCS members also gathered to counter the ABVP. Both sides soon started indulging in high-pitch sloganeering for around 40 minutes. Later, there was a minor scuffle between members of ABVP and NSUI which resulted in cane charge by the police.

Title: PWD says no incentives to complete work on time
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: In yet another major decision after increasing the defect liability period, the public works department (PWD) on Monday ended the practice of giving incentives to contractors who complete work on time. PWD minister G Sudhakaran said the clause 2112.2 of the PWD manual has been removed for this.

The department used to give 1% of the contract amount (maximum of Rs 4 lakh) as bonus for completing work within the contract period. The minister said when the contractor is obliged to complete work within the contract period, it is unfair to give bonus for that.

“Contractors have gained crores of rupees during the tenure of previous governments for completing works on time. The contractor, while signing the contract agreement, agrees to complete work within the stipulated period. The contract period is finalised based on scientific study. They normally get enough time to complete work during the period. So, it was decided to avoid wastage of money from public exchequer for such works. The clause 2112.2 in PWD manual has been removed. Directions have been given to revise PWD manual and standard building document,” the minister said.

Though the PWD decision would win accolades from public, it has not gone well with the contractors. The Kerala Government Contractors’ Association has decided to express their strong objection to the minister. “The decision could only destroy small-scale contractors. Has the Kochi Metro or the Vizhinjam port, taken up by high profile contractors, completed on time? The contractors do works amid various hurdles such as lack of materials, pending dues and opposition from local politicians. The bonus, though it was not a huge amount, could have been an encouragement,” said Varghese Kannampally, contractors’ association president.

Contractors said the government has revised various clauses that will affect small-scale contractors. “The government has to provide bitumen for works under Rs 1 crore. That is not being followed now. The government has also gone back from its promise of resolving issues over GST, pending dues, etc.,” he alleged.

Title: Leopard kills nilgai calf, carcass found in cane field
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Bijnor: Forest authorities have sounded an alert after a partially eaten carcass of a nilgai calf was found in a sugarcane field at Himpur village. It is believed that the herbivore was killed by a leopard.

The discovery of the carcass has frightened villagers as Himpur is just 40 km from Mohandiya area, where a leopardess has killed three people along Malan river. Forest official have set up cages with bait and installed several camera traps. While the killer leopard has been caught on camera, it has eluded capture. However, it has not attack anyone for the past 15 days since it last killed a man on December 26 .

A few days ago, on January 6, villagers had shot dead a leopard at Bhogpur village hours after it killed a schoolboy, not too far from his school. Since November 27, six people have been mauled to death by leopards in Bijnor district.

Not wanting to aggravate man-animal conflict and to ensure that both big cat and humans are safe, forest officials have advised villagers to move about in groups in the area where the carcass was found. Though no farmer has been attacked by a leopard, forest authorities have advised villagers to be careful.

With villagers reporting numerous leopard sightings at various places, the forest department has been preparing a plan to tag the leopards and track their movement on GPS map.

Title: Two killed, 16 hurt after UP roadways bus fallsinto ditch in dense fog on Agra-Lucknow e-way
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Agra: At least two persons were killed and 16 others left injured when an Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation’s (UPSRTC) multi-axle luxurious passenger bus travelling in dense fog on Agra-Lucknow expressway fell into a ditch on Monday.

The accident occurred at 6:50 am, when the bus with 37 persons and four crew members on board while heading to state capital tried to avoid collision with a truck, which had broken down on the extreme right lane. Notably, the accident took place just 3 km away from the toll plaza.

According to police, a Rajasthan-registered goods truck broke down in the middle of its journey on Sunday night. But, it was not removed from the expressway, following which the driver lost control of the bus and the vehicle fell into the ditch near milestone ‘18.6’ of Fatehabad police limits in Agra district.

One of the deceased passengers was identified as Dinesh Shakya (44) of Bhagipur village in Etah district, while the other’s identity is yet to be ascertained.

“The injured passengers have been shifted to S N Medical College. Two are in critical state,” said Pramod Kumar, additional superintendent of police (ASP), Agra rural east. “While questioning the bus driver, named Raj Kumar, he claimed that he was driving between 40-50 kmph in dense fog when he saw a truck parked on the extreme right lane. In order to avoid a collision, the driver took a quick left turn, but couldn’t stop the vehicle from plunging into a ditch,” he added.

The ASP further said, “The fog was so dense on the expressway that it took me nearly an hour to reach the accident site. It is a matter of concern for us why the truck which broke down wasn’t removed from the stretch.”

A member of private concessionaire’s expressway patrolling team, on condition of anonymity, said, “Within 15 minutes of bus accident our team along with UPEDIA patrolling team reached the accident site and started rescue operation along with the cops. Last night, we did receive information about the broken down truck and UPEDIA patrolling team immediately installed a barricade around the vehicle with safety cones. Since our cranes were busy in two other accidents, the truck couldn’t be removed. The UP roadways bus had hit safety cones before falling into the ditch.”

K P Singh, the toll manager of Agra-Lucknow expressway operated by private concessionaire, said, “Our teams always respond to any accidents or break downs promptly and clear vehicles immediately. We will probe why a crane wasn’t made available to remove the broken truck from the stretch.”

Title: Can’t afford free treatment for rare diseases: Govt to HC
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Kochi: The state government has informed the high court that it is not possible to extend free treatment to patients with rare diseases as it is too expensive. A central government policy as well as central funding is required for it, the court was told.

The submission by health and family welfare department was in the form of an affidavit in an appeal filed by the state government challenging a single bench’s directive to provide free enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) to a child suffering from a rare disease known as Lysosomal Storage Disorders (LSD). A total of 33 applications for free ERT was received from LSD patients by the government whereas it is estimated that there are 200 children requiring treatment for rare diseases in the state.

In the affidavit, government said Rs 1 crore per year is required to provide free treatment for a child with a rare disease and there are 200 children requiring treatment. Thus, the government would have to set apart more than 48% of the budgetary allocation intended for treatment of the poor to provide free treatment to the children with rare diseases alone. Budgetary allocation for free drug distribution during 2019-20 was Rs 360 crore. Of the 15 known LSDs, five are treatable. Around 80% of the children affected with Pompe disease, which is one of the five treatable LSDs, succumb due to cardio respiratory failure, the affidavit said. While the average treatment cost of a single child with a weight of 20kg would be Rs 1 crore annually, around 20 renal transplantations or five liver transplantations or eight bone marrow transplantations can be carried out using such a fund.

These are life-saving medical interventions, government points out. “While many kids are waiting for such definite interventions with proven prognosis, it is highly unethical to channelize such limited funds for ERTs often with guarded prognosis at exorbitant cost,” the affidavit stated.

It would be catastrophic for the state government to attempt providing free treatment to patients with LSD, it is up to the central government to frame a national policy or work out a PPP model through National Pharmaceutical Pricing Authority, considering the authority’s advantage of economy of scale and statutory backing, the court was informed by the state government.

Title: Varsities are nurseries of all movements, tweets Diggy
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Congress Candidate from Bhopal Loksabha Constituency Digvijaya Singh addressing media persons at PCC in Bhopal... Read More

Bhopal: In the wake of the widespread students’ protests across the country against the amended Citizenship Act, senior Congress leader Digvijaya Singh tweeted on the importance of role universities as “nurseries of all movements … where leaders are born.”

In back to back tweets, the former chief minister also took a jibe at the Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his “bhakts” (followers).

Singh’s first tweet at 7:44am read: “Universities are the nurseries of all movements, not only political. This is where leaders are born. Didn’t Duke of Wellington say: The battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton.”

In another tweet 4 minutes later, the Rajya Sabha MP, wrote: “Unfortunately, we have a leader who has Graduated, or has done Masters in “Entire Political Science”. I am still hunting for the university, which offers such a course. I would be grateful, if any of the Bhakts helps me to find that University.”

Reacting sharply, state BJP spokesman Rajneesh Agarwal, said, “University is an institution for education and intellectual deliberations. Students in some universities, with active Left following, are resorting to violence. Are there only half-a-dozen universities in the country? Among the states, it is West Bengal and Kerala that saw violence. There again there is a presence of the Leftists.”

Agarwal claimed that Singh is inspired by “Marx, Macaulay and madrasas.”

“His allegations and statements are highly influenced by the three. For the BJP, university is a place where students get higher education. They should be allowed to study, and Congress should stop utilizing Left students’ violence to their own political advantage,” said Agarwal.

Congress strongly backed the former chief minister.

“Digvijaya Singh has rightly said that universities are nurseries where leaders are born. Most of our great leaders have once been student leaders. The youth is the future of the nation. This was recognized by former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi when he lowered the age of voting to 18 years. The youth believe in our Constitution and have full faith in it. Students have always played a major role in the country’s future,” said Shobha Oza, PCC media department chief.

Title: Gujarat: ‘Tamil Nadu duo was to bring 3 pistols, cartridges’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Zafar Ali Haliq, 25, an alleged ISIS operative who was nabbed by Gujarat anti-terrorism squad (ATS) and later handed over to Delhi special cell, had confessed to senior Gujarat police officials that two other persons from the Tamil Nadu module of ISIS were to join him in Vadodara. Zafar Ali had also been involved in setting up the ISIS module in Tamil Nadu, ATS said.

A top ATS official said that Zafar Ali’s two associates were to bring three pistols and 90 cartridges to Vadodara. The duo had killed a special sub-inspector, Wilson, 57, in Kaliyakkavilai in Kanyakumari, said an ATS official.

“They had plans to recruit and radicalize Muslim youths from Jambusar , set up an ISIS module here and possibly carry out a terror attack,” the ATS official said. He added their plans were to flee to UP after the terror operation.

“They were to join their handler Khanja Moideen in UP and flee to Nepal. But the special cell of Delhi police nabbed Moideen and his two associates, before they could do anything. During their interrogation, Zafar Ali’s name was revealed. He was from Cuddalore district of Tamil Nadu, and was staying in Gorva, Vadodara,” the ATS official said. Zafar Ali was arrested from Panchvati Circle in Vadodara by Gujarat ATS on Thursday.

Title: Mahendra Singh Sisodia hits back at BJP, says proud to be Jyotiraditya Scindia’s chamcha
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Minister for labour Mahendra Singh Sisodia

BHOPAL: Minister for labour Mahendra Singh Sisodia on Monday hit back at BJP MP KP Yadav, who called him a ‘chamcha’ of senior Congress leader Jyotiraditya Scindia.

Speaking to reporters at a rest house in Ashoknagar, the minister said: “Proud that I am Maharaj Jyotiraditya Scindia’s Chamcha. What is the problem with that? Wasn’t BJP MP KP Yadav also a chamcha of Scindia when he used to run after his car?”

“Maharaj (Scindia is also present Maharaja of Gwalior royalty) gave me ticket; made my life worthwhile by making me a cabinet minister. I am fortunate to be the chamcha of such a leader. Why just chamcha, you can call me Kadhai (wok) also. Make me his chamcha and Kadhai together, and will remain so till the last moment of my life,” added Sisodia.

On Friday, at a BJP meeting attended by former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan, Yadav had allegedly called Sisodia a ‘chamcha’ of Scindia.

Speaking about himself, Sisodia said, “I will quit politics, but will never leave Maharaj Scindia.” State Congress media department chairperson Shobha Oza said the minister has given the BJP MP a befitting reply. “No one has the right to call a sitting MLA and minister a Chamcha. People have elected him and he is rightfully a representative of his constituency. How can an MP use this kind of language against any people’s representative? Therefore, the minister has given a befitting reply.”

BJP blamed it on the ruling party’s “culture”.

State BJP spokesman Rajneesh Agarwal said, “This is the Congress party’s tradition and culture. Mahendra Singh Sisodia has admitted it, which others in the party don’t. But from top to bottom and bottom to top ranks, this is how the Congress works. The Congress’ crisis is also based on the tradition of sycophancy.”

KP Yadav was earlier with the Congress. However, before 2019 LS polls , he switched sides and defeated Scindia contesting on a BJP ticket

Title: Goa: 3 Goans held with demonetised notes
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

POINGUINIM: During the interrogation of five natives of Kerala who were arrested and remanded to judicial custody at Margao on Friday on charges of attempting to smuggle demonetised Rs 1,000 notes worth Rs 1.48 crore, it was brought to light that three Goans from Candolim— Melvyn Lobo, 39, Francis Fernandes, 40 and Sanjay Khandeparkar, 38, had links to the five who were earlier arrested.

Police said that the three were brought to Canacona police station for interrogation and later booked under the same offences under Section 489-C, read with 34 of Indian Penal Code and Section 5 (a)(ii)(A), read with 7of the Specified bank (Cessation of Liabilities)Act 2017. They were later released on bail.

A vehicle allegedly used to transport the banned currency notes from Kerala to Goa on January 5 was also attached by the police. A police team is already in Kerala to find the source of such a huge consignment of demonetised Rs 1,000 notes.

Police seized Rs 1.48 crore of demonetised notes on Thursday night during a routine inspection at the Polem check post on Goa’s border.

Title: Maharashtra bamboo cover too goes down by 519 sqkm
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Photo used for representational purpose only

NAGPUR: At a time when dense forest area in Maharashtra has gone down by over 95sqkm, bamboo cover has also decreased by a mind-boggling 519sqkm, an area equivalent to five Koka wildlife sanctuaries (100 sqkm) in Bhandara.

As per Indian State of Forest Report (ISFR)-2019, the bamboo cover in Maharashtra was 15,927sqkm in 2017. It declined to 15,408sqkm in 2019, a loss of 519sqkm.

As per the report, total bamboo bearing area of the country is estimated at 1,60,037sqkm. Even as the ISFR states there is an increase of 3,229sqkm in bamboo bearing areas as compared to 2017, 12 of the 29 states in the country have shown reduction of 6,074sqkm bamboo area.

Experts have questioned the loss of bamboo cover in the state, especially when most of the paper mills have stopped purchasing it from the forest department and there is hardly any utilization for industry due to lack of units.

Madhya Pradesh has maximum bamboo bearing area of 20,000sqkm followed by Maharashtra 15,400sqkm. “The speed with which bamboo cover is being lost, the state will lose this tag. Maximum occurrence of pure bamboo has been observed in Maharashtra (810sqkm),” caution experts.

Bamboo consultant and expert Pratap Goswami said, “This time, the survey methodology has been more scientific and more accurate and hence the decrease has been evident.”

Secondly, Goswami added, “The decrease has to be matched with the working plan prescriptions to know the true picture. It should have not gone down when bamboo is not in demand from paper mills and industry. The Maharashtra Bamboo Development Board (MSBB) role is also not clear.”

However, TSK Reddy, managing director of MSBB, was quick to add, “We have nothing to do with bamboo exploitation. Our role is to facilitate farmers to grow bamboo on non-forest land. We have distributed 7 lakh seedlings free of cost to farmers.”

Sunil Joshi, chairman, Bamboo Society of India (BSI), Maharashtra chapter, said, “One of the major reasons for decrease is that forest department doesn’t have control over bamboo in their area. MSBB has also failed to give a push to grow bamboo on private lands. People are keen to grow bamboo, but they don’t know how to go about it.”

PCCF (production & management) Praveen Srivastava says, “Most of the areas under bamboo in Chandrapur, Gadchiroli and Amravati have been given away under community forest rights (CFRs) and Panchayats (Extension to the Scheduled Areas) Act (PESA) 1996. We have no control over felling in these areas. We have sought a report to know the facts,” he said.

The Centre has promulgated Indian Forest (Amendment) Ordinance 2017 to exempt bamboo grown in non-forest areas from the definition of tree, by amending Section 2 (7) of the Indian Forest Act 1927, and thereby dispensing with the requirement of transit permit for its transport and economic use.

“Under the garb of felling on private lands, there is large-scale illicit bamboo felling from forest areas. Besides, there is no regulation on felling in PESA areas. FDCM, which is into commercial exploitation, has been handed over large chunk of bamboo area. Most importantly, forest fires too are responsible for decrease in the cover,” said wildlife conservationist Prafulla Bhamburkar.

Bhamburkar warned, “Bamboo area is a major tiger habitat even outside protected areas (PAs). If bamboo vanishes, wildlife habitats will also shrink causing man-animal conflicts.”

“Bamboo is capable of thriving in an extreme range of climatic and edaphic conditions. With its wide distribution, bamboo also plays an important role in carbon sequestration, bio-diversity and soil moisture conservation. Loss of cover would mean huge environment damage,” says green activist Shrikant Deshpande.

Title: Dy CM bats for fast Hinjewadi-Shivajinagar Metro work
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Pune: Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar on Monday stressed speeding up the land acquisition process for the third Metro line connecting Hinjewadi and Shivajinagar and lobbied for early execution of the Shivajinagar-Hadapsar stretch of the mass transit system.

Pawar, who is also the guardian minister of Pune, raised the issued at a meeting held in Mumbai on various projects carried out by the Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority (PMRDA).

The NCP veteran also emphasized on good road and last-mile connectivity to the proposed airport in Purandar — a project that was announced in October 2016 but has not seen much development since then.

During Monday’s meeting, the new government made a department-wise review of the projects proposed by the previous dispensation and discussed deadlines of all the schemes executed by the PMRDA.

The deputy CM, however, did not discuss the proposed Hyperloop project connecting Pune and Mumbai during the meeting. In the past too, NCP had expressed doubts about the feasibility of the project.

While discussing the airport issue, Pawar sought details from the PMRDA officials about the city’s connectivity to the proposed Chhatrapati Sambhaji Raje International Airport. The PMRDA has to construct a road from Wadki to Pargaon Memane village in the Purandar taluka for the last-mile connectivity to the proposed airport.

The second phase of the 16-km Metro line, from the civil court in Shivajinagar to Hadapsar (16km), also came up for discussions during the meeting. This facility assumes significance for the last-mile connectivity to the proposed airport.

The deputy CM pledged to speed up transfer of 6.25 hectares of government land to put the third line of Metro on the fast track — a facility that will reduce traffic snarls at the IT hub of Hinjewadi. The 23.3km third Metro corridor between Hinjewadi and Shivajinagar is expected to become operational by 2023.

Officials said the first 8km of the third line stretch (Hinjewadi to Balewadi) was likely to be operational by the end of 2021 and the rest of the stretch by January 2023. The entire Metro corridor was initially expected to be ready in 2022, but the deadline was extended because of some issues at two stretches — University Circle and Kamgar Putla slums.

The meeting also discussed the ring road and the affordable housing project, town planning scheme, the Indrayani River project and issues related to water.

Monday’s meeting was attended by PMRDA commissioner Vikram Kumar, planner Vivek Kharwadkar and additional commissioner Pravinkumar Deore, among others.

Title: Muslim outfit holds rally against CAA
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Coimbatore: Members of the Tamil Nadu Muslim Munnetra Kazhagam (TMMK) took out a rally against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) on Monday from Anna statue on Avinashi Road to the collectorate. They also collected signatures from one-lakh people against the Act.

The protesters had come from Kuniamuthur, Ponvizha Nagar, Karumbukkadai, Azad Nagar, Saibaba Colony, Kottaimedu, Ramanathapuram and Mettupalayam. President of the Coimbatore north TMMK E Ahmed Kabeer led the rally.

District secretary of TMMK media wing A M Sirajdheen said they had conducted the signature campaign over the last two weeks. “It is a black Act and is not suitable for India, where several communities live in harmony. It seeks to single out one particular community. But here, people from various communities have been living as a family,” he said.

Title: More long weekends await travel enthusiasts this year
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Pune: Plan your mini-vacations well in advance as 2020 brings two to five more long weekends than the previous year, which had around 10 such occurrences.

Travel firms are quoting at least 12 to 15 long weekends this year, depending upon the region of stay and workplace holiday policy. Having said that, these are still lower than the 16 long weekends observed in 2018.

Long-weekend list for this year shows that employees may have to take around 5-6 leaves during the year to get full benefit of the short breaks, far less than the last year’s estimate of around 13 leaves.

The highest number of long weekends will be in April and May, for which employees will have to take a few leaves in between the breaks to make the most of the mini-holidays.

Aloke Bajpai, chief executive officer and co-founder of travel and hotel booking website ixigo, told TOI, “We saw a 25% year-on-year rise in search queries around long weekends in 2019. We expect this number to further increase this year, with 15 long weekends spread out throughout 2020.”

Rajeev Kale, president and country head – holiday, Meetings, incentives, conferences and exhibitions (MICE), Visa, Thomas Cook (India) Ltd, said the company had observed a growing demand of 22% from Pune for long weekend bookings over the last couple of years. “While destinations like Udaipur, Hampi, Goa, Gokarna, Jaisalmer, Jaipur, Coorg, Kerala, and Pondicherry are domestic favourites, short-haul destinations with easy or no visa like Dubai, Abu Dhabi, Malaysia, Bhutan, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Singapore, Thailand, and Mauritius have been gaining popularity among Puneites,” he said.

Sabina Chopra, co-founder and chief operating officer, corporate travel and head industry relations, Yatra.com, said, “While it is still early for the Holi long weekend in March, we have witnessed 35% rise in overall booking enquires from Pune as compared to last year. Preferred domestic destinations are Bedse caves, Dehna, Mahabaleshwar, Lonavla, Panchgani and Nashik. International destinations include Thailand, Dubai, or middle eastern countries. In terms of accommodations, travellers have shown interest for resorts around Koyna Wildlife Sanctuary, beach view hotels around Diveagar and Kashid.”

Anand Menon, brand leader, travel tours, leisure travel brand of FCM Travel Solutions, said, “We expect about 30% rise in bookings from Maharashtra. A trend that seems to be picking up is Slow Travel, where people are booking lazy holidays with not too many planned activities.”

Daniel D’souza, president and country head, leisure, SOTC Travel, said, “In February, the long weekend is due to the festival of Mahashivaratri, and travellers can celebrate it at Haridwar, Khajurao or Mandi for a spiritually-enriched experience. Similarly, travellers can set off to Varanasi or Mathura in March to celebrate Holi.”

Peshwa Acharya , chief marketing officer, Sterling Holidays, said the company had seen more bookings for drive-through holidays for long weekends with places like Lonavla , Karjat , Igatpuri being quiet popular.

Title: Celebrate a smoke-free bhogi, say doctors
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Coimbatore: People should stop burning tyres , rubber and plastic items , which emit toxic gases that lead to medical complications during the bhogi festival, doctors and pollution control board officials said here on Monday.

There was a 50% reduction in respiratory and eye problems reported during the bhogi last year because of the awareness programmes conducted by the Indian Medical Association (IMA), representatives said.

Addressing reporters in the city, secretary of Nursing Home Board of IMA Tamil Nadu Dr S Karthick Prabhu said that the association had created awareness on the hazards caused by burning rubber and plastic during the festival, at the behest of the Tamil Nadu pollution control board (Tnpcb). “After interacting with doctors, we found that the number of people admitted for respiratory problems and eye irritations caused by toxic gases had fallen by 50% last year,” he said. “Smoke and toxic gases cause reactive airway diseases.”

City-based pulmonologist Dr V Nandagopal said smoke and toxic gases from burning tyres, plastic and rubber affect senior citizens, children and those who had fallen ill recently and whose immune system is vulnerable. “Toxic gases and smoke cause asthma, bronchitis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and even lung cancer.”

In 2018, smog caused during bhogi led to cancellation of 20 flights in the state, Tnpcb assistant engineer P Ramesh said. “Thanks to the awareness programmes, pollution levels came down and not even a flight was cancelled last year,” he said.

Tnpcb is monitoring pollution levels at a residential area, a commercial area and an industrial area in the city. IMA has formed a team to work with Tnpcb on pollution-related issues.

Title: Students with less than 75% attendance barred from taking SSC exam
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Pune: A minimum of 75% attendance in two terms of Std X will be necessary for students to appear for the secondary school certificate (SSC, Std X) examination, this year.

The schools have been told to submit the attendance of students by February5, and according to the rules laid down by the Maharashtra State Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education, the students have to complete 75% attendance between June and October 15 and 75% in the second term from mid-October to February 5.

Secretary of the Pune division of the state board, B K Dahiphale, said, “Schools must send the attendance of students by February 15, with the defaulters’ list with a remark as 'no candidate' against their names. If the candidate falls short of the required attendance in any one term, he /she will not be able to appear for the exam.”

The notification said, school heads have been delaying the submitting of the attendance list and some of it was incomplete,. In such a situation, it was difficult for the board to take any decision against defaulters.

Hence, this year, a deadline of February 5, has been given to all schools to submit the attendance of the students who have filled the exam forms.

In the notification, Dahiphale said, “There are some students who deserve to be exempted due to poor attendance as they were undergoing some medical issues. However, if the proposals to exempt the students come late, it is not possible to exempt them even if they deserve it. Hence, we have strictly maintained that the division must receive details by February 5.”

For exceptional or emergency cases, the proposals will be considered after required proof if received after February 5, with a fine of Rs 500 after every late proposal.

Also, students whose attendance is less than 75% but more than 60% who have faced some medical emergency will also be exempted from the rule and allowed to sit for the exam after providing valid proof.

Title: VIRAL COMIC ART IN TIMES OF PROTEST
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Do you know when a piece of art is relevant? When it’s dated but still finds resonance in contemporary times. Like, for instance, searching on Twitter for RK Laxman and finding a series of tweets of users sharing cartoons of his that go as far back as the 60s with comments observing how ‘prescient’ he was, and ‘how some things never change’. Why, a cartoon of his about anti-Hindi agitations from the 60s will stun you with its contemporariness. Add some colour to it and you could easily believe that it was drawn yesterday. In the past few months, cartoons and comic art have taken on the job of conveying the anger of this country’s citizens, especially of its youth. Striking images with one-liners that drip of biting humour – making them perfect meme material – have become the language of protest and every aspiring cartoonist and graphic artist in the country is using social media as their platform to share their ideas: if it goes viral, even better.

A FEARLESS VOICE

It took Indian graphic artist and designer Orijit Sen 20 minutes to create the caricature unabashedly titled ‘Goons’. The graphic that he uploaded on January 6 on social media, shows the prime minister and home minister wielding lathis with their faces covered. Since that day, the post has been shared feverishly on various platforms.

“This is probably the most shared work of mine in recent times,” says Sen. As to how he came up with the idea, he says, “It was an immediate response to the rage I was feeling for the attack on JNU. I wanted to say that while the identity of the goons remains undetected, the people behind it were Amit Shah and Modi .” For the Goa-based artist, comic art is his medium to speak his mind fearlessly. “In today’s atmosphere, everybody is scared. But as an artist, I feel it is my job to go out there and speak up.” Courage, Sen says, “is not about lack of fear. It is instead to speak up despite the fear.” And his creating art of dissent, Sen hopes, will encourage other artists – be it musicians, dancers, poets – to stand up and speak as well.

“For me, a cartoon is protest art. That’s the reason cartoonists are always anti-establishment. Otherwise cartoonists become the puppet of the government,” says Mangaluru-based cartoonist Satish Acharya whose works enjoy immense popularity online and offline. That could be because his cartoons have a direct voice. “I draw more cartoons when people raise a dissenting voice, because I feel the voice of dissent makes our democracy more vibrant,” says Acharya.

THE GOOD AND BAD OF VIRALITY

“Two years back, I had done an illustration where I had portrayed Modi as Robocop who asked people who didn't stand up for the National anthem to ‘please stand up’. That satirical work really got popular and got shared a lot but eventually, it got people on the other side, the Sanghis , sharing it gladly too because they thought it portrayed their leader as ‘a superhero’. The purpose of the satire was completely lost and it made me wonder who I worked for,” laughs graphic artist and co-founder of Brainded , Appupen .

“My Modi-Shah cartoon was modified by the Sanghis to show them holding brooms and promoting the Swachh Bharath campaign,” says Sen. There is risk with every work that they put out admit the artists TOI spoke to. “I have received threats,” freelance cartoonist Nala Ponnappa reveals. Sen has family and friends asking him to ‘be careful because there is so much risk involved’. Acharya frets about lack of controls when it comes to free sharing. “People take the liberty to use them on their website, blogs. Sometimes even TV channels, newspapers and magazines use them without taking your permission. So, you end up losing your income opportunity.” Acharya also talks about the art work getting distorted by political IT cells. “They could add their own character/narrative/dialogue keeping cartoonist’s signature intact! This is dangerous and should be considered a criminal act,” he says.

SELF-CENSORING WORK

In these times where everyone is quick to take offense, do they, as cartoonists and comic artists, selfcensor their works? “Every artist has an in-built personal code that he uses to determine what he wants to make, so that way, yes, I do assess my work before I put it out there,” Appupen says. “I can’t touch much on pornography,” Ponnappa says before recalling advice he’d received from his mentor, Abu Abraham. “Years ago, Abu had told me, ‘Stay out of religion. I haven’t touched that subject much except maybe when it’s related to politics.”

THE GOOD OL’ DAYS

Compare comic art going viral today to pre-internet times, and the way the cartoons were created and dispensed will seem pre-historic. Freelance cartoonist Nala Ponnappa remembers opening newspapers during the Emergency to see cartoonist Abu Abraham leaving his cartoon space blank. “I was working as an architect during the Emergency. The atmosphere was different from what it is today. There was so much censorship that Abu would very often leave an empty space where his cartoon should have been. Ultimately it shows you that freedom of expression is extremely important,” Ponnappa says.

“If you drew an impactful cartoon, the best reaction you received was calls, postcards and letters from your readers. Of course, it would be even better when they called the editor to congratulate your work,” says VG Narendra, managing trustee of Indian Institute of Cartoons. But unlike today’s atmosphere of fear, Narendra admits that there was space to critique leaders. “Cartoonists would lampoon and criticize the ruling government. I remember making a rather critical cartoon of Indira Gandhi for Shankar’s Weekly and it was well received. Today, leaders do not encourage this kind of art,” he adds.

Title: BJP ‘special group’ to help Hindu immigrants get citizenship under CAA
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Dehradun: The BJP state unit has formed a “special group” to help Hindu immigrants get citizenship under the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), which is likely to be implemented by the end of the month in Uttarakhand.

The CAA came to effect on January 10 this year. The group will headed by former Dehradun BJP president Vinay Goyal and will facilitate Hindu migrants from Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh living in different parts of the hill state. “We will help Hindu immigrants fill the CAA form and furnish documents to the nodal official appointed by the central government in Dehradun,” said Goyal.

Goyal added that the process of granting citizenship to Hindu immigrants would be rolled out by January-end. “Our volunteers will hold a series of workshops. Hindu immigrants will be informed about the checklist of the documents required for filling the CAA forms,” he said.

Shankar Chakraborty, a Hindu immigrant from Bangladesh, curtrently living in Sitarganj in Udham Singh Nagar district, told TOI, “Everyone in our community is ready with all the documents required for filling up the CAA forms. We are just hoping that one nodal official of CAA is appointed in Udham Singh district so we don’t have to travel far to get these formalities done.”

“Everyone in my family is eagerly awaiting granting of citizenship, so we get new identities as Indians,” said Babu Ram, a Hindu immigrant from Pakistan.

The CAA, which officially came into effect on January 10 this year, has triggered sporadic protests across the hill state.

Title: Use ‘wall of happiness’ for a smokeless Bhogi
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Trichy: For a smokeless Bhogi festival celebration this Pongal, Trichy City Corporation has appealed to the residents to make use of the two ‘walls of happiness’ facilities in the city to place used clothes and blankets. Instead of burning the discards, the civic body has been insisting residents to celebrate Bhogi by handing over the discards at the nearest micro compost centres (MCCs) for scientific recycling.

To encourage the concept of reuse, thereby indirectly reducing waste generation, the corporation is operating a couple of ‘wall of happiness’ facilities on Allithurai Road and near Srirangam Rajagopuram. The facilities bridge people looking forward to donating the gently used clothes and the economically-backward section seeking used clothes. The corporation through the sanitary supervisors and field workers has been sensitizing the residents across 65 wards since the past week to place the gently-used clothes and blankets at the ‘wall of happiness’ facility. To avoid air pollution caused by the burning of waste, sanitary supervisors will monitor the vulnerable spots in the four zones, officials said.

“People can place clothes and blankets in the wall of happiness. This will reduce the city’s waste generation as well,” a sanitary official with Trichy City Corporation said. The civic body also maintained that people can hand over recyclable waste and plastic at any of the 31 micro compost centres of the corporation or during the doorstep waste collection.

“Tyres and other combustible waste can be used as refuse-derived fuel (RDF). We have been transporting such kind of waste to cement factories in Ariyalur where they are used as fuel in furnaces,” the officials said. Though authorities maintain that the practice of people burning waste during Bhogi has come down significantly, parts of the city near Gandhi market, Thiruvanaikoil and EB Road localities have witnessed incidents of burning waste in the open in recent years. Officials said that people in the localities were sensitized about the hazards.

Locations of the wall of happiness

Allithurai road near Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Government Hospital

Gandhi Road, near Srirangam zonal corporation office

Title: Kolkata: Now, Ballygunge Science College erupts in protest
Content:
Students of Ballygunge Science College joined the protest against CAA on Monday by creating a human chain, tak... Read More

KOLKATA: Students of Ballygunge Science College joined the protest against CAA on Monday by creating a human chain, taking out a rally and holding demonstrations on campus. Several hundred teachers, research scholars and students of the college participated in the protest that started around 2.30pm and continued till evening.Teachers and students who took part in the rally said they were protesting against the violation of democratic rights and the attempts by the government to divide the country on religious lines.“Those who assaulted students and teachers in JNU and earlier in Aligarh Muslim University and Jamia Millia University are fascists. These attacks are not only on students or teachers but also on educational institutions. No campus in the country is safe any more. The first targets of fascism have always been the intelligentsia,” said Parthiba Basu, head of the department of zoology.“These attacks are intricately linked with the programme to divide the country on the basis of religious faiths. Students protesting against this are true patriots. They are fighting for the democracy and constitution of our country. The teachers stand shoulder to shoulder with them,” Basu added.From the college, the protest march made its way to the Hazra crossing before travelling back to the campus. It was preceded by a human chain created by the participants on Ballygunge Circular Road that did not disrupt traffic movement. At the end of the march, protest meetings and demonstrations continued on the campus. Students and teachers said that despite the protesters being attacked at JNU and Jamia Millia University, the authorities of the two varsities did not act.“I took part in the rally to protest against the violence meted out to the students of JNU. It is a very unfortunate incident. The government sponsored attacks on protesting students and this should stop,” said Amit Khan, a zoology doctoral student.

Title: Youth stabbed to death 50ft from police stn
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: In a shocking murder reported in Talaiya locality on Sunday night, two brothers allegedly attacked and stabbed a 20-year-old youth over an old rivalry, merely 50 feet away from Talaiya police station. When the youngster’s friend intervened, the accused stabbed him too in the foot and fled the spot. The victim, with stabbing wounds in his chest, rushed to Talaiya police station and fell unconscious on the stairs.

Police and locals rushed the injured to Hamidia hospital in an auto-rickshaw where the victim was declared dead on arrival; his friend is undergoing treatment. SHO Talaiya HC Ladia said that deceased Rupesh Batham, 20, a resident of Bhoipura, was a fisherman. His friend and complainant Shahbaz Khan alias Kallu, 17, a resident of Jogipura in Budhwara, told the police that he had dinner at home and went out for a walk on Sunday night.

Around 11.45 pm, he reached in front of Kali Temple, merely 50 feet away from Talaiya police station, where the victim Rupesh was standing, and the friends started chatting.

Suddenly, Ishan Batham, 30, reached the spot on his scooter. He stopped and started arguing with Rupesh over an old dispute. The arguments turned ugly and Ishan started hurling abuses at Rupesh. At the same time, Ishan’s younger brother Anurag came to the spot; he started slapping Rupesh. When the locals intervened, Ishan took out a big knife and lunged towards Rupesh. SHO Ladia said that Rupesh ran towards a house to save himself, but stumbled on a stone and fell on the road. The accused Anurag grabbed his hands while his brother Ishan jumped over Rupesh and stabbed him in the chest. Rupesh started bleeding profusely, Kallu intervened but Ishan stabbed him too in the foot. When locals rushed to nab them, the accused brothers fled the spot along with the knife.

Police has registered a case against the accused on complaint filed by Kallu and arrested them. Their past crime record is also being scanned. SHO said that accused and Rupesh were relatives and had an old rivalry. The accused were searching for Rupesh for the past three days to settle an old score.

Title: 2 days after he went missing, body found dumped in drain
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Nainital: Two days after 34-year-old Vipul Mandal went missing from Sunahra farm area in Kichha block of Udham Singh Nagar district, his body was found packed in a jute bag, which was dumped in a drain.

Police said that Mandal had gone missing on Saturday while he went to relieve himself. “His family started worrying after he didn’t return home on Saturday. They then informed police. The family later found his slippers near the drain. On Monday, they started the search again and found the bag. They then informed us and when we opened the bag, we found the body in it,” a police official said. “We have sent the body for postmortem and are awaiting the report. We have found marks on his neck and therefore suspect that he was strangled to death,” he added.

Title: Loads of sugarcane arrive to sweeten Pongal festival
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Coimbatore: Truckloads of sugarcane reached the markets here on Monday, ahead of the Pongal festival .

Though wholesalers and retailers said that the business was dull than the previous years, they are hopeful of the upcoming days. “Last year, we sold at least 12 loads of sugarcane on the day it reached the wholesale market. But, this year, we managed to sell only half of that. Even though the business has started on a dull note, we hope that it would pick up in the days before the festival,” said Mohammed Nawaz, a wholesaler at Ukkadam.

The cost of sugarcane is almost same as the last year and is expected to fall further, Nawaz said. “A bundle containing 20 is sold for Rs 300 to Rs 450. They need to be sold within a day or two before the leaves wither. If not, nobody would buy,” he told TOI.

The traders buy sugarcane from Melur in Madurai, Trichy, Mettur and Sankagiri and bring it to the wholesale fruit market at Ukkadam. From there, it is purchased and sold in retail in Pollachi, Mettupalayam and at the markets in the city including those at Kavundampalayam and Poo Market at RS Puram. At retail markets, a pair of sugarcane is sold for Rs 60 to Rs 80.

The business is dull ever since the city corporation shifted the fruit market from Ukkadam to Pullukadu to provide land for the construction of the Ukkadam Flyover, retailer Badhusha Moideen said. “At Ukkadam, the market was on the main road and commuters used to buy from us. But, here, we hardly get any customers. It’s been almost a day since we started selling, but had hardly sold 10 bundles,” he said.

Title: Theft in two apartments in Chikhali
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Cash and gold ornaments, collectively valued at Rs4.72 lakh, were stolen from two flats in Chikhali over the past five days.

The burglaries were reported from Sharda Suman and Vighnaharta housing societies. In both the incidents, the suspects entered the premises after breaking the locks of the unattended flats.

On January 9, the suspects decamped with gold and silver ornaments worth Rs2.33 lakh from the flat of Siddheshwar Kore (40) of Sharda Suman Society. “The theft occurred when Kore was not at home,” an officer from the Chikhali police said.

The second burglary was at a flat in Vighnaharta Society on January 11. Mukta Jadhav (45) said she found the flat’s main lock broken when she returned home on Saturday night. “She said cash, gold and silver ornaments, collectively valued at Rs2.39 lakh, was missing from her cupboard,” the officer said.

In another incident, a person broke-into a mobile store in Raviwar Peth on Saturday and made off with Rs30,000 and five handsets worth Rs67,500.

Title: Pongal: Business dull for potters in city
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Trichy: Earthen pots, an inseparable identity of Pongal festivities, are not much in demand this time, according to potters in Trichy. With only days left for the traditional thanksgiving festival of the state, potters said the business is dull even though the price of pots has not increased that much.

As people prefer cooking the signature dishes, Ven Pongal (plain Pongal) and Sakkarai Pongal (Sweetened Pongal), of the Pongal festival in clay pots in a traditional style, usually the sales of clay pots used to pick up during the season. Apart from the permanent shops, temporary stalls would often crop up near Melachinthamani and Gandhi market localities for Pongal festival. However, the sales of clay pots have not gained steam this year. “This year’s Pongal festival is dull. Despite the copious flow of water in the Cauvery, the sales of pots have not been picked up so far,” A Rukmini, a pot seller from Melachinthamani, said. The potters have exclusively designed Pongal pots weighing from 1 kg to 3 kg. The price of a one-kg Pongal pot is Rs 120. They said that city dwellers did not arrive as expected to purchase clay pots.

It seems that college managements and private event organisers in the city who have been hosting community Pongal festival in a traditional manner have come to the rescue of the potters to an extent. “College students purchased pots in bulk quantity,” Rukmini added. The potters, however, hoped that the sales would pick up ahead of the Kaanum Pongal (January 17) as traditional games including Uriyadi (pot breaking) contest will be organized during the time.

Title: Goa gets standing committee for MSMEs to monitor, reform sector
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Panaji: In a bid to support micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) in the state, the Goa government has constituted a state-level standing committee on MSMEs that will not only monitor all initiatives, but also recommend reforms for the sector.

MSMEs in Goa said issues concerning Goods and Services Tax (GST) refunds, access to finance, and delayed release of payments by government bodies continue to dog the sector, which contributes 28.8% to the national GDP.

The state-level standing committee will be chaired by chief secretary Parimal Rai with secretaries of finance, labour, factories and boilers, transport, law, revenue, agriculture and industries departments making up the members.

Chairman of National Council of MSME, Assocham, Manguirish Pai Raikar, who recently met Union minister of commerce Piyush Goyal, discussed some of these issues with the Centre and requested the Centre to resolve the problems faced by the sector.

“A common grievance of MSME sector is delayed payment for goods or services delivered from clients, which includes government departments and public sector undertakings. The GST refunds have also been delayed for over six months and this leads to a liquidity crunch for MSMEs,” Raikar said.

He further said that banks also hesitate to disburse loans to both existing and new MSMEs and thus the lack of finance prevents MSMEs from expanding operations and could also result in loan defaults.

State government officials said that the standing committee will try and address some of these issues by discussing it with the Reserve Bank of India, whose deputy general manager will serve on the state-level standing committee.

Raikar said that government officials, who create road blocks and harass entrepreneurs, need to change their attitudes. “It is not only the ease of doing business that is important, but there is a dire need of improving the system to have ease of running the business,” Raikar told TOI.

Raikar has also raised these issues with the Union minister and high-level officials of the central government, including finance, industry, commerce, textiles, railways, corporate affairs, labour and others.

Title: Clean tap water reaches residents of Azad Nagar after three months
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Coimbatore: Three months after water contamination was reported from Azad Nagar at Karumbukadai, the city corporation and the private firm implementing the 24/7 water supply project have replaced the old damaged pipeline in the area with high-density polyethylene (HDPE) pipes.

Workers of the Suez India Private Limited, who had been trying to spot the leaks, found that the pipeline was damaged at several places. “Sewage was getting mixed with drinking water. Instead of repairing all the leaks, which was cumbersome, the corporation decided to replace the pipes,” said an official. “The pipes were damaged while carrying out underground drainage (UGD) project.”

Based on the directions of the corporation, the firm replaced the old 110mm pipeline on the 1.5km stretch with HDPE pipes. “As a part of the 24X7 water supply project, the firm had decided to replace the pipeline in the area in the fourth year of the project. But, it decided to take up the work after receiving several complaints,” the official said.

“They laid 75mm HDPE pipes for 900 metres, 110mm pipeline for 101 metres, 160mm for 420 metres and 200 mm for 30metres. Thirty-five houses in the locality have been given connection and work is on to include the rest of the houses,” he told TOI. “As of now, the locality gets water from the master reservoir in Town Hall. A proposal has been made to construct a new tank at Ukkadam near the sewage treatment plant (STP). After the construction is over, water will be supplied to the area from that tank.”

Laila, a resident of Azad Nagar, thanked the corporation for installing the new pipeline. “We used to get foul smelling water. After we escalated the issue, the corporation stopped supplying water through pipeline and arranged trucks to supply water to the area. The new pipeline was fixed just days ago. We started getting clean water two days ago.”

Title: Don’t fall for fake ‘organic jaggery, palm sugar’, say farmers
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Trichy: Traditional jaggary producers have raised apprehension about the sale of low quality jaggary as organic products. Seeking stringent steps to contain fake jaggary brands, which may have adverse health effects apart from affecting their sales, jaggary producers have sought authorities to create awareness among people.

Jaggery is an important ingredient in the preparation of sweet Pongal. Since people prefer organic items, traders too started to stock up organic varieties of jaggery (Vellam in Tamil) and palm sugar (Nattu Sarkkarai) for the Pongal festival.

Though people are willing to use organic products, they have no clue to differentiate between genuine organic products and duplicates. Utilizing the opportunity, a few traders are making money by selling sub-standard products, said organic farmers.

K N Easwarmoorthi, organic jaggery and palm sugar producer from Erode, said that nowadays ordinary jaggery contains hydrosulphate, superphosphate and 30% to 40% of white sugar. These are not good for health, he said.

“We use sodium bicarbonate in a permissible volume for purification purpose. Moreover, we are raising the sugarcane in an organic method. People should first learn to identify the right quality before buying jaggery. However, they often fall prey to a few traders who are selling sub-standard products with attractive package,” he stated.

A section of retail traders buy jaggery and palm sugar for Rs 50 per kg and sell them for Rs 75 per kg as organic products. Price of ordinary jaggery is ranging from Rs 50 to Rs 60. With little knowledge about organic jaggery and palm sugar, consumers buy those items for a higher price, he alleged.

“Since our products are high in quality, we cannot compromise on the price, which often leads to slowdown in sales,” Easwarmoorthi said.

Though people have knowledge about organic and non-organic products, those who afford to spend money alone prefer genuine products. However, others compromise the quality due to the high price fixed for the organic products, B Rajendran, a retail trader from Woraiyur, said.

The food safety officials should take stringent action against those traders who mislead consumers. The government should also spread awareness among people about these products, he added.

Title: Telecom firm staffer loses Rs one lakh to cheap vehicle bait
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A fraudster duped an employee (36) of a prominent telecommunication company of Rs1 lakh on the pretext of offering him discount on a sports utility vehicle he was keen to buy.

The fraudster told the victim to pay just Rs10 online for the registration of his cell phone number for availing the discount on the sports utility vehicle (SUV). He managed to get the details of the bank account and United Payments Interface (UPI) identity of the telecom firm employee by sending a link. Within seconds, he siphoned off Rs1 lakh from the victim’s bank account through two transactions on December 1 last year.

The victim immediately approached the cybercrime cell and lodged a complaint. A case under the relevant sections of the Information and Technology Act was registered at the Airport police station on Saturday.

Police said the telecom company employee wanted to buy an SUV. While surfing the automobile-related websites, he came across a discount offer of up to Rs2.5 lakh on the SUV.

“When he contacted the cell phone number mentioned on the site, he was provided with another number,” said an officer from the Airport police.

When the victim dialled that number, the person on the other end introduced himself as the sales executive of a car dealership. “The bogus sales executive told the victim that he needed to register his cell phone number to avail the offer. He was also told that he would have to pay Rs10 for registration,” the officer said.

When the fraudster asked the complainant about the mode of payment, the latter said he could transfer the money through a digital wallet. The bogus sales executive then sent a link on the complainant’s cell phone and told him to forward it to another number. “After the complainant followed the direction, he received another link for paying Rs10,” the officer said.

The name of the bank, UPI ID and the amount to be paid had to be filled up in the second link. “The complainant gave all the data and within seconds he received two messages from his bank about Rs1 lakh being debited from his account. He first contacted the customer care number of the bank and blocked his bank account, net banking facility and the debit card,” the officer said.

A cybercrime police probe revealed that the complainant’s money was transferred to an account in a private bank. “We are gathering details of the account holder,” the officer said.

Title: Mohan Veena finale for rumination on MS
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Pandit Vishwa Mohan Bhatt

AHMEDABAD: After his recital, Pandit Vishwa Mohan Bhatt glided backstage through clusters of fans. He negotiated the notes of adulation as easily as his fingers sweep across his slide guitar, the Mohan Veena . “You are a rock star!” one among a group of musical notables cried out to him. Even after Pandit Bhatt’s concert ended, rasikas lingered like an echoing twang.

Pandit Bhatt’s tour de force was explained by Amita Dalal, a sitarist who considers him her mentor. “Guruji opened with Nat Bhairav. Pandit Ravi Shankarji had created this beautiful raga ,” she told TOI. “It is serene and divine.” Rasikas’ rush for selfies with Pandit Bhatt was perhaps an attempt to capture that rapture for social media permanence.

Talking of endlessly self-revitalizing memories, the first baithak — on Day 12, Sunday — presented M S Subbulakshmi’s art. “MS”, as her devotees call her, is not a legend trapped in archives. In countless households in South India, and in temples across the country, she is the voice of daily mantras. She is the introduction to Carnatic music for cultural experimenters. She is the inspirer of arcane debates among the purists.

On Sunday, Dr Jayanti Ravi — a bureaucrat and musicologist — encapsulated MS’s oeuvre in one baithak. To clarify MS’s influence in the time available, Ravi needed to, in William Blake’s words, “Hold Infinity in the palm of your hand/And Eternity in an hour”. Ravi’s selection pulled off that Blakean miracle.

“We began with two lines of Venkatesa Suprabhatam,” Ravi told TOI. “That exemplified the fact that M S Subbulakshmi’s birth was a new dawn in music.” Then Ravi and her group essayed a famous daru varnam, which has lyrics, jathis (syllables delineating a talam), and sahityam ( literary element ). “We rendered ‘Maate malayadwaja’ in Khamas. Krupa danced to it,” Ravi said. “The performance was katha nritya geetam (story, dance, and song).” She said the form was chosen because the musical component in isolation might have pleased only the aficionados.

“The main piece was ‘Bhavayami Raghuramam’. It is Ramayana recounted in Sanskrit,” Ravi said. The song unravels in a raga-mala: Saveri, Natakuranji, Dhanyasi, Mohanam, Mukhari, Poorvi Kalyani, and Madhyamavati. Saveri returns for the climax.

A few other MS masterpieces followed. “We presented ‘Hari tuma haro’, ‘Madhurashtakam’, a Dhanashree tillana, and a snatch from ‘Vishnu Sahasranamam’,” Ravi said. “The concluding piece was ‘Maithreem Bhajata’.” The composition urges people to seek a life of meaning; Saptak provided a hallowed stage for pondering that counsel.

Title: Man posing as police officer threatens teacher, held
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A 34-year-old man was arrested by the Kattoor police on Sunday for posing as a cop and threatening a schoolteacher.

Police identified the arrested as G Prasanth Kothari, 34, of Ram Nagar in the city. Prasanth, who was working in an auditor’s office, was booked under Section 170 (personating a public servant) and Section 506 (i) (criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code

The arrest was made based on a complaint from S Rajeswari, 49, a teacher in a private school from Sangamam Nagar in Podanur. In her complaint, Rajeswari said she often visited a textile shop owned by Prasanth Kothari’s elder brother Pradeepkumar at Ram Nagar.

Three years ago, Pradeepkumar sought Rajeswari’s help to expand his business. She, along with a few other teachers, pooled in Rs 30 lakh and lent it to him, a police officer said. “But, Pradeepkumar faced huge loss in the business and lost all the money. He started avoiding Rajeswari. She got worried and started pestering him for money,” the officer said.

A few days ago, Prasanth Kothari called her from a new number and introduced himself as Sadasivam, a inspector of police at the Kattor police station. “He asked her to come to the station with her son. Later he called her and told her to come to the city police commissioner’s office and threatened to register an FIR against her for repeatedly ‘torturing’ Pradeepkumar for money,” the police officer said.

Rajeswari recorded the call and produced it to the Kattoor police. Based on a complaint, they lodged a case and arrested Prasanth Kothari on Sunday evening. Later, he was remanded in judicial custody and lodged at the Coimbatore Central Prison .

Title: NHAI relents, KWA clears manhole at Enchakkal Jn
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

relieved residents: The blockage in the manhole had led to overflowing sewage lines in Vallakkadavu and nearby... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: After an intense face-off, the National Highways Authority of India backed down to allow the Kerala water authority’s sewerage division to dig up the newly widened portion at Enchakkal Junction to restore a manhole which got buried under the asphalt. KWA initiated the work on Saturday.

On the first day itself, KWA was able to clear the blockage in the manhole which had led to overflowing sewage lines in Vallakkadavu and nearby areas. “After identifying the manhole, we were able to clear the block after opening it. The issue of overflowing sewage has been resolved. This has been troubling local residents for a while,” said a KWA official.

The State Human Rights Commission had intervened after areas such as Vallakkadavu, Karali and Enchakkal were affected. The work was delayed after NHAI asked KWA to adopt trenchless technology instead of digging up the recently paved road, which the latter rejected.

Meanwhile, traffic congestion at Enchakkal Junction, which was leading to snarls on the national highway, is likely to intensify due to the work. KWA has barricaded the middle of the junction for the work and sources said police are not planning any traffic diversions.

KWA officials said the entire work would take around two weeks to complete. “We have resolved the issue of the block. Now, we have to replace the brick manhole with a concrete one for better stability,” officials said.

In order to prevent digging in future, NHAI had suggested that KWA construct manholes on both sides of the national highway and connect them through horizontal drilling. However, KWA ignored the request citing shortage of funds.

Enchakkal is only one of many traffic choke points on the national highway. The junction has direct access to two main roads – one from Vallakkadavu and one from East Fort.

NHAI allowed KWA to dig up the junction on the condition that the portion will be restored as per its standards. “Several road safety issues are caused due to the negligence of agencies like the KWA in properly restoring dug up portions on national highways. So strict guidelines have been issued for such work,” said NHAI sources, also voicing concern over traffic congestion at Enchakkal.

Title: Private schools should give info under RTI, says commission
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Chennai: The Tamil Nadu State Information Commission (TNSIC) has held that private schools in the state will have to furnish information under RTI, especially those receiving financial assistance from the government.

This was the gist of an order passed by information commissioner S Muthuraj on December 2, 2019, while adjudicating an RTI application filed by M Kannan with the Srimathi Saraswathi Muthusamy Global School in Old Pallavaram.

In October 2018, Kannan had filed an RTI with the school asking for details such as number of sections in each grade, number of teachers, their qualification and remuneration, and details about the headmaster. He approached the commission with a second appeal after his RTI and first appeal went unanswered. During the hearing, he clarified that he was not a third party as children of his close relatives were studying in the school.

The school’s legal advisor Prasad Madhavan told the commission that they were a private school following EDEXCEL, UK curriculum, and hence did not come under the purview of the RTI Act. However, as a respect to the commission, he submitted the information requested by the applicant.

But Muthuraj invoked Section 19 (8) (a) to justify that the school had to give information under RTI. He said private schools were run through trusts recognised by the government. It was the government’s responsibility to ensure safety, security, health and rights of students and employees. Muthuraj said in case of aided or public schools, vital information could be obtained by parents to give a solution to issues. But in private schools, information denied would deny justice to parents.

The school in question was run by a trust and both central and state governments provided it tax exemptions and benefits. It was also under the purview of the RTE Act. Schools get subsidised power and water, vehicles registered in the trust’s name are given concession and benefits, he said.

Muthuraj said parents had every right to get information about schools in which their wards studied.
