The information includes details about management, correspondents, teaching and non-teaching staff as well as driver and attenders. Muthuraj cited Article 19 of constitution and said the school was not exempted under RTI Act.

Title: Man-eater leopard shot dead in U’khand
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Dehradun: A big cat that had mauled a 45-year-old woman of Dhari village in Tehri Garhwal last week was on Monday shot dead by a team of three shooters headed by Joy Hukil following forest department orders. The same leopard is believed to have killed three villagers in Bansi and Papdasu Rudraprayag forest division in November and December last year.

Around that time, the leopard was once shot by the shooter but the big cat had managed to flee from the spot in an injured state. The leopard was around eight-years-old, and had come to prey in the area early on Monday and had allegedly killed a cow on Sunday. Earlier, a woman, who had gone to collect fodder from the forest, was also killed by the animal.

Dharam Singh Meena, DFO of Narender Nagar forest division said, “The man-eater has been shot dead, and we have also recovered the bullet which was fired at it earlier in Rudraprayag forest division near Papdasu village in an attempt to eliminate it. It is the same leopard that had killed a woman in Dhari village. The post-mortem report also confirmed the presence of the woman’s hair in the animal’s intestine.”

Another forest official told TOI, “After the bullet injury, the leopard had become more furious and killed one more woman in Narendra Nagar. So it was best to kill it.”

Speaking to TOI, sharpshooter Joy Hukil said, “We had orders to kill the man-eater in Rudraprayag forest division and on December 10, we had received orders for Narendra Nagar forest division also. After keeping cages for trapping the big cat for the past three days, we could finally put it down on Monday morning.”

Title: Goa: Poor signage, dark, damaged roads cause accidents, says report
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Faulty road engineering, improper signage and poor road conditions threaten the lives of motorists in the state, especially at 18 accident-black spots analysed by Confederation of Indian Industry - Young Indians and Goa Institute of Management (GIM).Over a period of three months, the two organisations studied traffic blind spots and accident-prone zones and on January 9, submitted a report with recommendations to Goa Police’s traffic cell.“The traffic police of Goa have identified 62 accident prone zones, including 27 black spots, after analysing three years’ accident data. Our team made visits to some of these black zones in order to examine the problems in the areas and try to suggest some solutions,” said the Young Indians chair for road safety, Mishal Maganlal.According to 2018 data, as many as 264 lives were lost in 183 road accidents in Goa, out of which 67 were self-accidents. Additionally, an average of one person died per day in road accidents in Goa during the peak tourist months of January, February, March and December in 2018, cited by the Union Ministry of Road Transport and Highways.Maganlal said that CII-Young Indians decided to prepare the report after a meeting with deputy superintendent of Police Dharmesh Angle. Angle shared the accident data and sought recommendations. CII-Young Indians subsequently approached GIM to assist in the study.“We had two batches of students, around 15 of them, who spent over three months studying the traffic flow, signage, blind spots and road engineering,” co-chair for road safety Vaikunth Dempo said. The report will be shared with PWD so that required changes can be made. CII-YI also plans to hand out seed kits to at least 400-500 college students in the state with information about road safety and the importance of wearing helmets.“The students will be asked to plant the seeds at home next to the gate or parking area so that the plant acts as a constant reminder that they need to wear a helmet,” said Maganlal.

Title: Miraculous escape for prostesting guest teachers as tent set on fire
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Bhopal: About 200 guest faculty teachers from the state who were staging a protest in the state capital had a miraculous escape early Monday when the tent in which they were sleeping was set on fire by miscreants. Talaiya police have registered a case against the accused who remains unidentified.

Quoting the complaint, police said the accused poured kerosene on one side of the tent in which the guest faculties, who have been protesting for the past two months at Shahjehani Park in Talaiya locality, and set it ablaze early morning. Around 200 protestors including women were sleeping in the tent when the incident took place.

However, due to winter and due on the fire could not spread.

The protestors have alleged that it was a conspiracy to burn them alive when they were in their sleep. They alleged that some of them spotted four miscreants fleeing from the spot after the incident.

Senior police officers along with FSL team investigated the crime scene after the incident and recovered a bottle partially filled with kerosene from near the spot. Senior administration officials and police teams visited the spot.

SHO Talaiya HC Ladiya told TOI that complainant Surjeet Bhadouria, 42, a resident of Gwalior who is posted as guest faculty at Balaji College in Mihona town of Bhind district has stated that for the past two-month guest faculties have been protesting demanding regularisation at Shahjehani Park. He said at around 2 am on Monday when he along with other protestors were on rest in the tent put up at the park, he felt strong smell of some inflammable liquid. He told his colleague Dr Manish Kumar about it. While they were talking about the smell, they spotted that the tent material on one side caught fire. They raised an alarm and ensured all rushed out out in open under safety. By that time some part of the tent material had burnt.

Another protestor Dr JP Chouhan, who hails from Umaria and was present during the incident told TOI, that the fire doused by itself as the cloth was wet due to dew. He said they spotted four miscreants running away from the spot. The accused tried to set ablaze other part of tent too, but the fire did not start. He said that had the fire spread it would have endangered the lives of around 200 protestors present in the tent.

SHO Ladiya said that police team had visited the spot around 1.30 am and found everything all right. After the incident was reported ASP Arvind Dubey along with FSL team visited the spot and the cops recovered a kerosene bottle. The miscreant might have poured kerosene over the tent and set it afire. A case has been registered and investigations were on.

Title: Polio vaccine to be administered to 3.34L children
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Coimbatore: The department of public health and preventive medicines will conduct pulse polio vaccination camps at 1,581 centres in the district on Sunday. The drive is expected to benefit as many as 3.34 lakh children aged below five years. Last year, 3.33 lakh children were given the life-saving vaccine.

The department has set up 1,202 centres in rural areas and 379 in urban areas. Of them, 36 will function at public places such as bus stands, Coimbatore Railway Junction, airport and temples. As many as 18 mobile centres will be operational on the day.

As many as 6,536 people, including staff of the public health department, anganwadi, NGOs and Rotary clubs will assist the drive. “The vaccine is approved by the World Health Organisation (WHO) and is safe for children. All parents should give the vaccine to their children,” collector K Rajamani said.

Title: Telugu Desam Party struggles to find candidates
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The Telugu Desam Party, which was in power in the undivided Andhra Pradesh for over 17 years from 1983 to 2004, is now struggling to make its presence felt in the municipal elections in Telangana.

Though TDP national president N Chandrababu Naidu had given the green signal to party leaders from Telangana to contest as many seats as possible in the municipal polls, TDP failed to get candidates to enter the fray in all the 3,000-odd wards. Less than 400 candidates filed nominations for over 3,000 wards.

“We did not select candidates. We allowed filtration i.e., those interested to contest on TDP ticket to come forward voluntarily. This was to ensure that only loyal TDP candidates will contest and the possibility of them defecting to the ruling TRS will be thin,” a senior leader said.

Political analysts said the prospects of TDP candidates winning the municipal elections are thin.

Title: Utttarakhand to use drones to survey crocodiles, gharials
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Uttarakhand may become the first state in the country to use drones for conducting a census on crocodiles and... Read More

DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand may become the first state in the country to use drones for conducting a census on crocodiles and gharials , said forest officials on Monday. The last census of the two reptile species in the state was conducted around 11 years ago. Then, a manual count was undertaken in which 232 gharials and 123 crocodiles were said to be found. Now, the latest survey will have drones deployed for videography and photography, based on the flow of water in the river. At the same time, photographs will be clicked randomly and analysed by experts .

The survey will commence from Sharda River on the Nepal border to Ganga River in Haridwar. All the four forest circles – Western, Shivalik, Rajaji and Corbett Tiger Reserve — have a significant population of these two species of reptiles.

According to Parag Madhukar Dhakate, the head of Uttarakhand Forest Drone Force (UFDF), the estimation will begin in January end and the entire survey will be completed within 10 days.

In 2008, around 123 crocodiles and 231 gharials were found spanning an area of 6,370 sq km, though that count did not cover the entire state. The first pilot drone survey was conducted back in 2016, in only Western Circle, where 65 crocodiles were reported.

Experts feel a significant population of crocodiles and gharial will be found around Gaula, Nandhaur, Ramganga and Ganga rivers. A decent population of these two species could be found at Kalagarh and Tumariya dams, the likes of other major water bodies in the state.

Incidentally, drones are frequently used by the experts of the Doon-based Wildlife Institute of India in their advance surveys.

Title: Preservation of rights of SL Tamils is the best protection for India
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Nearly two years after his tenure as chief minister of the Northern Provincial Council in Sri Lanka , 80-year-old C V Wigneswaran continues to be drawn into the thick of politics in the island nation. The judge-turned-politician quit the Tamil National Alliance, now a small conglomeration of Tamil parties, which fielded him as the CM candidate in 2013, to form his own political outfit. In an interview with TOI, Wigneswaran expressed apprehensions about President Gotabaya Rajapaksa fashioning a "Pakistan-like dictatorship" regime and sought India’s intervention to restore the rights of Tamils. Wigneswaran was in Chennai to take part in a conference organised by the Ulaga Thamizhar Thiruvizha

Q: Tamils feel let down by the previous Maithripala Sirisena regime. Do you think they have hope in the Gotabaya Rajapaksa dispensation?

Sirisena did not look after us (Tamils) though we brought him to office. The Gotabaya government is ready to give us economic benefits but not political ones. They are on record saying the country is Sinhala Buddhist and their agenda is to further that. They are giving economic sops to buy us over, bringing in Sinhalese in the Northern and Eastern Provinces, colonising them and expropriate all the resources in these areas.

Q:Under the circumstances, would the Lankan refugees in Tamil Nadu want to go back home?

Our position is that everyone must return. We are running short of Tamils in the Northern and Eastern provinces. Their lands are being appropriated by the government for the benefit of Sinhalese. Many of the refugees had houses and properties. These were lands that were given on long lease by the Lankan government. Since the refugees had not come back, the government took over, cancelled the lease and gave it to the Sinhalese. So more and more Sinhalese colonies are being created. If the Tamil refugees come back, they may not get the same land but may be given alternate land.

Q: In the wake of the protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act, you had stated that India should give SL refugees dual citizenship.

There is no provision for dual citizenship between India and Lanka now. But, the governments can work out an agreement. It should be an option. But refugees are the responsibility of the Sri Lankan government and they should return. India can facilitate the infrastructure requirements in Lanka.

Q: So, you are happy with India’s housing programme?

Yes, but we are not happy with India’s political agenda. We want more dynamism on the part of India to help us regain our lost rights.

Q: What is the mood among Tamils there now?

One of dejection, confusion and expectation.

Q: Do you see the Provincial Council elections happening?

I have my doubts if the present government is interested in giving provincial councils power. They may have parliamentary elections and not have the provincial elections. They have not been giving provincial councils the powers under the 13th Amendment of the SL Constitution. They have also taken away the rights of the provinces, which are now controlled by the Centre. Gotabaya wants to make it a centralized government. He has put in retired army personnel in places of importance in administration. There is a possibility that he is working towards a dictatorship of some sort. We may have a Pakistan-like dictatorship soon. So, that’s why I say preservation of the rights of north and eastern Tamils is the best form of protection for India as far as its security is concerned.

Q: How do you see India-Sri Lanka relations?

India must be aware that all statements made by the Sinhalese are not genuine as far as their relationship with India is concerned. If India thinks all the assurances they have been given will be kept, I feel sorry. We have suffered by India’s non-interference in the last stages of the war. But we are part of the Indian culture. India must help preserve our rights, help get us the cooperative federalism that Narendra Modi spoke of when he was in Sri Lanka a few years ago and make sure we have control over our areas.

Q: At the conference were Tamil sentiments being whipped up?

No. No fiery speakers. If that was so, I wouldn’t have come.

Q: What about Indian politicians who used the Tamil Eelam issue for politics here?

Indian politicians should stop using our problems for their election purposes. It is true that we are bound by cultural, linguistic, religious links. But, when making use of our political problems for your political gains, you forget the effect it has on our people. Unnecessary suspicions and enmity is created in the minds of the Sinhalese, who will not accept our genuineness in wanting to be in a federal set-up. They are trying to use this as stepping stones for division in the country.

Q: But leaders like Vaiko and Seeman continue to raise the Tamil Eelam cry. Your comment?

Everybody has a political motive. In 2014, when I came here I told Tamil leaders "for heaven’s sake when you utter something, think of the consequence it has on the Tamils in Sri Lanka".

Due to the fear that Northern and Eastern Provinces would break up, Sri Lanka has brought in China into the geopolitical area. But my view is that the security of India is intertwined with the security and political future of the North and East. Unless we are in a position to look after ourselves and not become an appendage of the Sinhalese, you will not have a buffer against the ‘Silk Route’ people. So, North and East must be merged and given federal rights. India can be rest assured that Tamils will be with them under any circumstances and they will not conform to Chinese interference in the matter.

Title: Nagpur: After CAA, immigrants have no clue how to apply
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Women were seen in large numbers in a dharna against NPR-NRC-CAA by Nagpur Peace Organisation at Edgah Ground ... Read More

NAGPUR: Even as protests continue against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and National Register of Citizens ( NRC ), immigrants from Pakistan in the city are waiting for the process to acquire citizenship under the amended law to begin.

Nagpur is estimated to have 3,500 Hindu immigrants, mainly from the Sindh province of Pakistan, in addition to a few from Balochistan. They were hoping to get Indian citizenship on a fast track basis, after CAA was put in place.

“The delay has left the community anxious, especially in the wake of massive protests against CAA. Many of us are ready with our documents but have no clue where to submit them,” said one of the immigrants, requesting anonymity.

“It has been a month since the gazette was published, but no format for applying under the amended law has been put out,” said leaders of migrant communities from Pakistan. The unabating protests have heightened their worry and many have been calling up the ministry of home affairs (MHA), where officials have said it may take at least 2-3 months for the process to begin, as it was “still being worked out”.

When asked if the applications could be filed under the existing online format, the answer was that there were chances that an option for CAA may be included in the form, or a separate form may be issued.

At present, citizenship applications are routed through the collector’s office in designated districts like Nagpur. With no change intimated, the old process continues.

The matter is handled by the resident deputy collector Rajendra Khajanji here. The officer told TOI that he had not received any instructions about granting citizenship via the CAA route, and the applications were still being processed through the earlier procedure.

Under this process, the collectorate forwards the applications to the IB for clearance, on the basis of which Indian citizenship is granted, Khajanji said.

“From 2017 to 2018, 137 persons were granted Indian citizenship. Nearly 50 more cases have since been sent to to the intelligence bureau (IB) for clearance. No case was cleared during 2019,” the officer added.

BC Joshi, the director (citizenship) in the MHA told TOI that “work on the format was under way”, which would be uploaded on the website once it is ready. The officer did not give any further details.

Prior to the amendment, applications for citizenship could be filed after living in India for at least 11 years. The minimum requirement has been changed to six years under CAA.

Title: Maharashtra: Interaction of winds brings hazy mornings and warmer nights
Content:
Photo used for representational purpose only

PUNE: The night temperatures have been higher than normal but there has been a significant drop in day temperatures in parts of Madhya Maharashtra, including Shivajinagar and Lohegaon, over the last few days.Day temperatures are currently below 30 degrees celsius in Pune, Kolhapur, Malegaon, Sangli and Satara due to cloudy skies during the day. Many stations in Madhya Maharashtra, including Pune, are also reporting early morning haze due to cloud cover and a slight increase in moisture content in the air, India Meteorological Department (IMD) said on Monday.Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD Pune, said the cities in central Madhya Maharashtra are currently experiencing clouding during the day under the influence of the interaction between the partially moist southwesterly/westerly winds coming from the Arabian Sea and southerlies/southeasterly winds coming from the south of the state. This interaction is causing clouding during early day and night time.“Daytime clouding blocks penetration of solar insulation, causing maximum temperatures to drop. The moisture content in the air is also resulting in early morning haze in these cities, including Pune,” said Kashyapi.On January 9, the day temperature in Shivajinagar was a pleasant 27.4 degrees C, 1.6 degrees C below normal while that in Lohegaon was 27.6 degrees C, around 2 degrees C below normal.Day temperature further dipped to 26.1 degrees C on January 10 at the two locations, being 3-4 degrees C below normal.Similar temperatures (below 30 degrees C mark) have been recorded in the last couple of days with day temperatures on Monday being 29 degrees C for Shivajinagar and 29.5 degrees C for Lohegaon.IMD has forecast day temperatures at less than 30 degrees C till January 19 in Pune with the possibility of haze during the early morning till January 15.

Title: Dahl’s kin seek Goa CM Pramod Sawant’s help in case
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: The mother of 22-year-old Finnish national Felix Dahl, who was found dead in Canacona in 2015, has written to chief minister Pramod Sawant seeking his intervention in getting justice for her son.

In the letter ,Minna Pirhonen said that lack of investigation into the deaths of tourists by Goa police is interpreted as an attempt to cover up murders to protect the state’s tourist industry and economy. She reminded Sawant that he had said it is the state’s duty to help tourists.

“We, the family of Dahl, ask you to intervene to ensure that CBI’s investigation is made possible without delays and obstructions. That way you can improve Goa as a civilized society with a functional justice system to regain the trust of the foreign tourists,” she wrote.

Title: Man accused of raping minor gets 20 yrs in jail
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Dehradun: A special fast track district POCSO court awarded 20 years of imprisonment to a man accused of raping a 13-year old boy here on Monday. The court, on Wednesday, announced the judgment under the Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2018, within a year of the incident.

Senior public prosecutor, Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO), Bharat Singh Negi told TOI that accused Mohit Tyagi, 24, from Daak Patthar locality, was also slapped with a fine of Rs 10,000 by the fast track court special judge POCSO, additional district and sessions judge Rama Pandey.

The accused was found guilty of luring a 13-year-old boy with toffee and raping him. An FIR was lodged soon after the incident and the charge-sheet was filed against the accused within three days. The medical examination has confirmed rape by the accused, after which the court has finally convicted the man under a relevant section of IPC and section 4 of the POCSO act,” added Negi.“Tyagi had lured the child with candy and raped him. The judge has awarded him 20 years of imprisonment and Rs 10,000 fine. The judge also said that in case the accused fails to pay the fine, he would have to serve three more years in jail,” said Negi.

Title: Padma temple gears up for Lakshadeepam
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

A trial run of Lakshadeepam at Padmanabhaswamy Temple on Monday

Thiruvananthapuram: The 56-day Murajapam festival at Sree Padmanabhaswamy Temple will conclude with Lakshadeepam (lighting of one lakh oil lamps) on Wednesday, coinciding with Makar Sankranti.

Chanting of vedas marked Murajapam, a ritual held once in six years. The mantras from the three Vedas — Rig Veda, Sama Veda and Yajur Veda — are chanted in eight rounds and each round end with Murashiveli, a sacred procession.

On Wednesday, Makarashiveli, the final sacred procession, will be held at 8.30pm, during which priests will carry idols of deities in a decorated vehicle, Garuda Vahanam. Senior members of Travancore royal family will escort the vehicle. The procession, which will be attended by 72 Vedic pandits, will make three rounds of the temple.

The lamps on the temple premises will be lit by 6pm. Revolving oil lamps will be placed at each entrance of the temple. The main illumination will be on Gopuram and Shivelipura of the temple, which are decorated with hundreds of lamps made of soil and brass.

“The lighting is arranged in such a way that the reflection of the temple on Padma Theertham will be a sight to behold. In addition to over one lakh oil lamps, there will be electrical lights on the premises. Labourers from Kanyakumari were brought for the decoration work costing Rs 21 lakh,” said V Ratheesan, executive officer, Sree Padmanabha Swamy Temple.

The temple authorities distributed around 15,000 passes to the public and around 5,000 to temple employees, government staff and Travancore royal family members. To avoid late-minute rush, the people who received pass to view Makarashiveli have been asked to enter the temple by 6.30pm.

“Moolam Thirunal Rama Varma will escort the sacred procession for Makarashiveli,” added Ratheeshan.

A specially choreographed programme ‘Radha-Krishna’ by Soorya Krishnamoorthy will mark the grand finale of Sree Padmanabham, the 55-day long art festival organised as part of Lakshadeepam, at 7:15pm on Tuesday.

Title: Maintaining blood pH level is the latest trend in the West
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Nagpur: Health problems that make the body too acidic or too alkaline are usually linked to the pH of blood. Maintaining the pH balance of the blood is the latest health trend in western countries. However, Ayurveda already has the concept of ‘Amla-kshar Siddhanta’ which deals with the same phenomenon, said Vaidya (Dr) Prashant Suru, who is one of the very few practitioners of ‘Panchbhautik Chikitsa’, a branch of Ayurveda based on the core philosophy of macrocosm and microcosm.

Dr Suru and some experts of this unique branch of Ayurveda were in the city on Sunday to conduct a daylong seminar organized by Manas Ayurveda. More than 250 practicing doctors and PG students of Ayurveda attended this event.

Dr Suru said that the pH balance is th latest health trend in the US and UK and is expected to reach India soon. Ayurveda has the best solution, he claimed.

“pH scale ranges from 0 to 14. Readings are based around a pH of 7, which is neutral, like pure water. A pH below 7 is acidic while pH higher than 7 is alkaline. Human life requires a tightly-controlled pH level in the blood serum to survive. Ayurveda has the best solutions to get this balance,” said Dr Suru. He shared the nuances of ‘Panchbhautik Chikitsa’ and claimed it has the power to make Ayurveda more specific and result-oriented.

Mukund Sherekar, an expert in Ayurveda, said, “Ayurveda is not only for healing of illnesses. Keeping yourself healthy and fit by maintaining an equilibrium of the five elements is more important. Simple modifications and medicine support can bring about this balance.”

“It’s impossible to avoid health problems as the balance of nature’s five elements around us keeps changing. Ayurveda has some techniques to keep you healthy, even during the changing scenario,” he added.

The organizer of the seminar, Ambarish Ghatate, said that young practitioners were quite impressed with the presentation of the new branch of Ayurveda. Dr Mohan Yende of National Integrated Medical Association said that Nagpur being a medical hub will see more of such academic events promoting Ayurveda in the future.

Title: Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank: Fees not an issue, JNU students misled
Content:
HRD minister Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank

In an

exclusive interview

, Union HRD minister

Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank

tells TOI’s Ishita Mishra that protests against the

fee hike

in JNU are a ‘non-issue’ and are being held to create controversy. The minister also spoke on the CAA protests saying that they were ‘stoked by opposition parties’, and the abrogation of Article 370 which he said has resulted in the people of Kashmir ‘becoming free and happy.’ Excerpts

The protests against fee hike and violence that took place in JNU have been hogging the national limelight for many days now. As HRD minister, what are you doing to defuse the situation ?

But students say that JNU will be the costliest central university in the country if the fee hike is implemented?

Let us speak about the role of the university’s VC. Students have alleged that he is non-communicative and allowed violence to happen in the varsity. Is your ministry planning to take any action against him?

A sting by a news channel has found that ABVP members were involved in the violence that took place on January 5. What is your reaction to this?

There are major protests going on in the country in the wake of CAA and NRC. What was the need to bring such an Act now?

But why is the government not taking cognisance of the protests of the people? Why the stubbornness to not listen to dissenting voices?

Then why are Muslims thinking that they will be thrown out of India?

During the CAA protests, there have been reports of police excess on students in AMU and Jamia. Can’t students exercise their democratic right to protest?

There is a perception that the government is being run by just two people — PM Modi and home minister Amit Shah. How much independence do you have in running your ministry?

Some people have raised questions regarding the veracity of your PhD degree. What is your reaction to that?

What is your opinion on revocation of Article 370?

Then why such a long internet shutdown in the valley if people are happy?

First of all, let me clarify that fees is not an issue at all in JNU. I had spoken to students regarding the matter during the university’s convocation. I told them that if there is any doubt in their minds regarding the fees, we will work out a solution. Thereafter, a three-member committee was constituted which took the views of all stakeholders. Our ministry’s secretary was also involved in the process. The whole problem regarding the fee arose because UGC stopped giving funds to the university citing it to be an autonomous body. Therefore, it was decided to increase the hostel fee. Mind you, the tuition fee was not touched at all. For a single-seater room, the hostel fee was Rs 10 which was increased to Rs 300 and for a double seater room, it was raised to Rs 600.These are nominal charges for a university in a city like Delhi. This was agreed to by students also in a meeting with the education secretary. So then, why was there a need for protests on fee? I believe that the protests are not for any solution to the fee hike matter but only to create controversy and that, too, a controversy that has now culminated in violence which is very very unfortunate.This is absolutely incorrect. JNU is perhaps the only university in the country where as many as 71% students avail of scholarships. Secondly, it is among the cheapest universities to study in India even after the hike in hostel fees. This is false propaganda.What are the grounds on which action should be taken? The violence in the university took place between two student groups — one who wants to study and the other who doesn’t. This is basically challenging the university administration and disturbing the administrative and academic process. On January 3, masked people created a ruckus in the server room of the university and thrashed those students who simply wanted to study and were registering themselves. Now, my question is that who would do such a thing? Obviously, those who don’t want to study. The university administration controlled the situation but it flared up again on January 5. Now, these masked persons again went on a rampage. Interestingly, when we brought in police to control the violence inside the server room, the students resented, saying that police shouldn’t be in the university. When we removed the police, they cried that police hadn’t come to stop the violence. I want to ask these students whether they want the police in the university or not?Today, even you can go and say that you are an ABVP member and you did such and such thing. Why should anyone believe that? Has any office-bearer of ABVP been found guilty? That is a matter of investigation. Having said that, I believe that action should be taken against all those who were involved in violence and damaging public property. As far as my ministry is concerned, we will not let universities become an adda for politics or violence.The Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) hasn’t come randomly and suddenly. It was passed in the last Lok Sabha and by the time it came to Rajya Sabha, the LS was dissolved which is why it was halted for a while. I fail to understand why people are shocked that we brought CAA and NRC. It was in our manifesto. We had promised to do it and people are happy that BJP is the only party that fulfils its poll manifesto promises. CAA is an Act to give citizenship to those who have faced discrimination and violence in other countries in the name of religion. No one is being thrown out of the country, no one is losing his/her citizenship and we have made this clear multiple times.When we know what we are doing is right and for welfare of people, why should we not stick to it? BJP is the only party that is taking tough decisions that are good for the country. Congress has made a huge mistake by allowing India’s division and now the second mistake Congress and its like-minded parties are doing is misleading people on CAA.No Muslim is worried. Only Congress is worried. The opposition is doing politics on this matter by misleading people, that’s all. This Act is about giving citizenship to people and is not meant to take away people’s citizenship.I will urge the students that they should not get misled on CAA and NRC. Universities are for education, not for politics. We want our educational institutions to secure global rankings and for good atmosphere to prevail in our universities. JNU for instance is a top-ranking institution, one of the finest in the country and I will not let people sully its reputation.People who say so don’t know what they are talking about. If a suggestion from the PM is good, why shouldn’t we take it? What is wrong in that? We at the HRD ministry are working 24 hours in a day for the interest of the nation and have full freedom from the Prime Minister to work.I don’t want to comment on this. I just want to say that there are around 15 scholars across the country who are doing PhD on my works and I don’t feel I need to answer to people who question my degree.People could never think that Article 370 could be revoked. The country had two symbols and two sets of laws for far too long. This was the first time a government did what was unexpected and people of Kashmir for the first time felt that they have attained freedom. The people are happy with the freedom they have got.If people would have been unhappy, they would have protested — they don’t need internet for this. Kashmir is peaceful and even section 144 has not been imposed there. We have done so much in Kashmir after revocation of article 370 that was never done in last 70 years.

Title: Maharashtra: Robber’s transgender turn foxes cops too; he’s a man
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Police on Monday said the person arrested for robbing a college student of her gold ring and a woman scooterist of Rs5,000 was a man and not a transgender .

Sudhakar Madhukar Sawant (22), who is originally from Buldhana and living in Hadapsar, was arrested on Saturday.

Senior inspector of the Chatushrungi police station Anil Shewale said, “Physical examination revealed that Sawant was a man. He used to seek alms and rob people by posing as a transgender. He would wear sari and use cosmetics to dress and look like a transgender.”

Crime branch officials had arrested Sawant for robbing the college student on Senapati Bapat Road. The complainant studied in a college in Lavale and stayed in the hostel operated by the institute.

On Saturday afternoon, she and her friends were about to enter a mall when two persons, who liked like transgenders, approached her for alms. As she opened her purse, one of them grabbed her arm and the other snatched the ring from her finger. The duo then fled the spot.

As the student approached the police, two constables rushed to the crime spot and started checking the area for clues. They soon traced the duo to Hadapsar and recovered the ring.

The police also found some cash on Sawant. During the course of investigations, the police got to know that Sawant had also robbed a woman scooterist (34) near the Chatushrungi temple on January 4. Sawant had first abused the woman and subsequently snatched her purse containing Rs5,000. The police then filed another robbery case against him.

Shewale said, “Considering Sawant’s ways of dressing and voice, we had also thought that he was a transgender. But the physical examinations revealed that Sawant was a man. Sawant is involved in more robberies with his accomplices”.

Sub-inspector Rakesh Sarade said, “Sawant used to act as ‘bahurupi’ (cosplayer), but did not have any certificate in the art form. While acting in some plays, he had performed the roles of woman characters. This is how he learnt how to wear a sari and use cosmetics.”

He added, “Sawant shifted to Pune four years ago in search of a job. After failing to get a job, he started begging on the streets under the guise of a transgender person. He subsequently started robbing people.”

Title: 5 yrs on, 3 engg officials penalised over shopping complex project
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Five years after a proposed shopping complex project at Kuravankonam ran into trouble over allegations of graft, the local self government department ( LSGD ) has taken disciplinary action against three officials who were formerly employed in the engineering wing of city corporation when the project was being executed.

LSGD took action based on a probe report by vigilance and anti-corruption bureau and a report by chief engineer of LSGD that three officials who had been working as assistant engineer, assistant executive engineer and overseer made lapses in recording measurements during construction of piles and that the measurements were not accurate. LSGD has barred annual increment of the officials for two years.

The shopping complex, which was launched as a dream project of the corporation in 2015, erupted into controversy as the payment of contractor who did piling was delayed citing variations in measurements. As per the project, piling was recommended to provide a sturdy underground base for the foundation owing to poor strength of the soil. As per the tender, the work had to be completed at Rs 68 lakh. The soil test recommended 9.2 metres as the depth, which could vary up to 11 metres. A total of 83 piles were made and 12 had to be done after that. However, issue arose when the contractor submitted bills to the tune of Rs 80 lakh for the project, citing that use of a different technology to reduce the noise resulted in escalation of costs.

Later, the contractor also came out with allegations against three engineering officials saying his payment was delayed after he had refused to pay them bribe. The issue had then caused rift in the council with former mayor refusing to accept the recommendation by then heads of standing committees to remove the engineers associated with the project and to conduct an internal enquiry. Syam Kumar, the former ward councillor of Kuravankonam and former chairman of tax appeal standing committee, had even threatened to quit owing to mayor’s indifference to the demands of heads of standing committees.

An inspection by Kerala engineering research institute (KERI) had revealed that there were variations in depth of piles and that doubts were raised regarding composition of concrete.

VACB began probe into the irregularities following a complaint received by the department. The probe found out that the project, which received a technical sanction of Rs 68 lakh, furnished bills of Rs 69.56 lakh for the construction of 83 piles and that the estimate had to be revised to Rs 81.13 lakh.

Title: ‘Fee hike not an issue at all in JNU...students are being misled’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

In an exclusive interview, Union HRD minister Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank tells TOI’s Ishita Mishra that protests against the fee hike in JNU are a ‘non-issue’ and are being held to create controversy. The minister also spoke on the CAA protests saying that they were ‘stoked by opposition parties’, and the abrogation of Article 370 which he said has resulted in the people of Kashmir ‘becoming free and happy.’ Excerpts:

The protests against fee hike and violence that took place in JNU have been hogging the national limelight for many days now. As HRD minister, what are you doing to defuse the situation ?

First of all, let me clarify that fees is not an issue at all in JNU. I had spoken to students regarding the matter during the university’s convocation. I told them that if there is any doubt in their minds regarding the fees, we will work out a solution. Thereafter, a three-member committee was constituted which took the views of all stakeholders. Our ministry’s secretary was also involved in the process. The whole problem regarding the fee arose because UGC stopped giving funds to the university citing it to be an autonomous body. Therefore, it was decided to increase the hostel fee. Mind you, the tuition fee was not touched at all. For a single-seater room, the hostel fee was Rs 10 which was increased to Rs 300 and for a double seater room, it was raised to Rs 600.These are nominal charges for a university in a city like Delhi. This was agreed to by students also in a meeting with the education secretary. So then, why was there a need for protests on fee? I believe that the protests are not for any solution to the fee hike matter but only to create controversy and that, too, a controversy that has now culminated in violence which is very very unfortunate.

But students say that JNU will be the costliest central university in the country if the fee hike is implemented?

This is absolutely incorrect. JNU is perhaps the only university in the country where as many as 71% students avail of scholarships. Secondly, it is among the cheapest universities to study in India even after the hike in hostel fees. This is false propaganda.

Let us speak about the role of the university’s V-C. Students have alleged that he is non-communicative and allowed violence to happen in the varsity. Is your ministry planning to take any action against him?

What are the grounds on which action should be taken? The violence in the university took place between two student groups — one who wants to study and the other who doesn’t. This is basically challenging the university administration and disturbing the administrative and academic process. On January 3, masked people created a ruckus in the server room of the university and thrashed those students who simply wanted to study and were registering themselves. Now, my question is that who would do such a thing? Obviously, those who don’t want to study. The university administration controlled the situation but it flared up again on January 5. Now, these masked persons again went on a rampage. Interestingly, when we brought in police to control the violence inside the server room, the students resented, saying that police shouldn’t be in the university. When we removed the police, they cried that police hadn’t come to stop the violence. I want to ask these students whether they want the police in the university or not?

A sting by a news channel has found that ABVP members were involved in the violence that took place on January 5. What is your reaction to this?

Today, even you can go and say that you are an ABVP member and you did such and such thing. Why should anyone believe that? Has any office-bearer of ABVP been found guilty? That is a matter of investigation. Having said that, I believe that action should be taken against all those who were involved in violence and damaging public property. As far as my ministry is concerned, we will not let universities become an adda for politics or violence.

There are major protests going on in the country in the wake of CAA and NRC. What was the need to bring such an Act now?

The Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) hasn’t come randomly and suddenly. It was passed in the last Lok Sabha and by the time it came to Rajya Sabha, the LS was dissolved which is why it was halted for a while. I fail to understand why people are shocked that we brought CAA and NRC. It was in our manifesto. We had promised to do it and people are happy that BJP is the only party that fulfils its poll manifesto promises. CAA is an Act to give citizenship to those who have faced discrimination and violence in other countries in the name of religion. No one is being thrown out of the country, no one is losing his/her citizenship and we have made this clear multiple times.

But why is the government not taking cognisance of the protests of the people? Why the stubbornness to not listen to dissenting voices?

When we know what we are doing is right and for welfare of people, why should we not stick to it? BJP is the only party that is taking tough decisions that are good for the country. Congress has made a huge mistake by allowing India’s division and now the second mistake Congress and its like-minded parties are doing is misleading people on CAA.

Then why are Muslims thinking that they will be thrown out of India?

No Muslim is worried. Only Congress is worried. The opposition is doing politics on this matter by misleading people, that’s all. This Act is about giving citizenship to people and is not meant to take away people’s citizenship.

During the CAA protests, there have been reports of police excess on students in AMU and Jamia. Can’t students exercise their democratic right to protest?

I will urge the students that they should not get misled on CAA and NRC. Universities are for education, not for politics. We want our educational institutions to secure global rankings and for good atmosphere to prevail in our universities. JNU for instance is a top-ranking institution, one of the finest in the country and I will not let people sully its reputation.

There is a perception that the government is being run by just two people — PM Modi and home minister Amit Shah. How much independence do you have in running your ministry?

People who say so don’t know what they are talking about. If a suggestion from the PM is good, why shouldn’t we take it? What is wrong in that? We at the HRD ministry are working 24 hours in a day for the interest of the nation and have full freedom from the Prime Minister to work.

Some people have raised questions regarding the veracity of your PhD degree. What is your reaction to that?

I don’t want to comment on this. I just want to say that there are around 15 scholars across the country who are doing PhD on my works and I don’t feel I need to answer to people who question my degree.

What is your opinion on revocation of Article 370?

People could never think that Article 370 could be revoked. The country had two symbols and two sets of laws for far too long. This was the first time a government did what was unexpected and people of Kashmir for the first time felt that they have attained freedom. The people are happy with the freedom they have got.

Then why such a long internet shutdown in the valley if people are happy?

If people would have been unhappy, they would have protested — they don’t need internet for this. Kashmir is peaceful and even section 144 has not been imposed there. We have done so much in Kashmir after revocation of article 370 that was never done in last 70 years.

Title: Now, Goa sets its sights on Chinese tourist market
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Some people in China have never heard of Goa, says a TTAG member

PANAJI: Goa tourism, which has not met much success in discovering a new tourist market in the past one decade, is eyeing China, which is a huge outbound market.

During its recent participation in the Chengdu International tourism expo, the Goa delegation discovered the state stands a chance to win a new market. It is planning to take up promotional activities in China after government approval. “We are considering it a potential new market,” said secretary, tourism, J Ashok Kumar. He added that the modalities have not been worked out yet.

Savio Messias, president, travel and tourism association of Goa (TTAG), who was part of the delegation, said, “While we will see how to to lure the Chinese visitors touring the Golden triangle (New Delhi, Agra and Jaipur) to the land of sun, sand and sea, others, who have never heard of India and Goa, can also be targeted,” he said.

Though India has been offering the e-visa option to Chinese travelers, the number of tourists from China has not increased on expected lines.

In 2018, 2.5 lakh Chinese tourists visited India. However, the state tourism department’s website has no record of Chinese visitors to Goa. Messias said during the tourism expo in Chengdu, they realised that there are Chinese people who are not aware of the existence of Goa. “It is sad that India has not figured in the list of top ten destinations of the world for China, while a small country like the Maldives and a country like New Zealand, which is not a great travel destination, have found favour with Chinese travelers,” he said.

Chinese travelers visit Sri Lanka and Kerala, Messias said, and this means Goa also stands a chance at attracting them. China’s tourism market has been growing significantly, since the last decade, he added. Goa tourism will have to explore new markets if it wants to remain relevant as an international tourist destination. With the number of tourists from Russia and the UK dwindling year on year, Goa has not been able to make significant headway in holding the attention of European travelers, though a charter from Poland was restarted this season.

Title: Telangana cops suspend internet to check rumour-mongers
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

A total of 13 houses and 26 vehicles were set ablaze in a clash between two communities in Bhainsa on Sunday

HYDERABAD: The police recommended for suspension of internet services due to the rumour-mongering among the members of both the communities after clashes between them in Bhainsa on Sunday.

Local rumours were spread by some miscreants ranging from killings to vandalising religious places. Due to these rumours, the situation was becoming worse as the already charged-up members of both the communities were getting more agitated and marching to the roads to intensify the violence.

On the recommendation of Telangana police, all service providers suspended internet services and sent a message to all the mobile phone users through a message.

Internet services are suspended in the following districts - Adilabad, Nirmal, Manchiryal and Asifabad districts, which were part of erstwhile united Adilabad district.

“Data alert: Dear customer, as per the government instruction, internet services have been temporarily stopped in your area,” is the message mobile phone service providers sent to a phone user. The decision to suspend internet services was taken to avoid spread of rumours.

Sources in Telangana police said that the situation had been volatile in Bhainsa, an area which is considered by police as very sensitive ever since the notification for municipal elections was announced.

Since most of the forces were stationed at Nirmal as preparations for election bandobast duties, it took some time for the police to react to the situation with full force.

Title: With plastic kites banned, cloth and paper ones fly high
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

NAGPUR: Flying vibrant and colourful kites with your family or buddies under the morning sun while you chill out on a rooftop is among the chief pleasures of Makar Sankranti . The joy of snapping others’ kites in the air is unmatched and the euphoria a common sight on this festival of kites in the city.

This year it is being celebrated on January 15. Apart from flying kites, on this day Til-Gul (sweets made of sesame seeds and jaggery ) are also exchanged.

Markets are flooded with colourful kites catching fancy of many. As plastic kites are banned, apart from the traditional paper ones, kites made of cloth are also becoming popular. These kites come in different sizes and rates vary from Rs 2 to Rs 150.

Pratik Borkar, a kite seller from the city, has displayed a variety of kites in his shop for upcoming festival. “We have over 10-15 types of kites in our shop. Right from Rs 2 to the most expensive one, all are paper-made,” he said. About the most popular type, he added, “Goladar’ is the most sold kite in my shop. Children also purchase small kites in different shapes.”

From ‘Delta’ kites which are triangular shaped to ‘diamond’ one, which are easily recognizable from the sky, all are very popular. Himanshu Shahu from Mahesh Patang Store expressed his views about the ban on plastic kites, “Initially, we did order plastic kites, as they are cheaper and are sold in bulk. But afterwards, I returned the complete stock.”

Cloth kites are the new trend. They are made of material used for making parachutes. “People are buying cloth kites, which are available in different shapes and vibrant colours. The most expensive one in my shop is for Rs 150,” Shahu added.

Apart from the traditional, multi-colour kites, kites with printed faces of Bollywood stars and cartoon characters are liked by the children. Jitender Shahu from Jitendra Patang store said, “There is a wide variety of kites in the market. I have kept all the colourful and printed ones in my shop and we are not selling any plastic ones.”

Sellers expressed their concern about plastic kites and are backing the decision to ban them. Not only at the prominent markets, but everywhere only paper kites are being sold even if that means selling less. “We are selling paper kites at the cost of plastic ones. Flying kites will always be done. Every year people come to our shops and get their favourite kites,” said Praful Kamdi, a kite seller.

Many people make kites at home using paper. The exercise usually involves the whole family and is a great way to bond.

Title: Minor cyclist’s death: Culvert gets railing, father awaits action on ‘negligent babus’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Bhopal: Two days after a 12-year-old bicycle-borne Varun died in a freak accident after falling in Upper Lake from a culvert near Judicial Academy in Ratibad area, the administration on Monday afternoon fixed new railing rods on the culvert.

But the devastated family feels this step should have been taken earlier. The deceased boy’s family — in a state of shock after the incident — said that the boy could have survived had there been railing on the culvert.

His father burst into tears and said that he lost his child due to negligence of the officials responsible for maintaining the road. Appropriate action should be taken against them, he said.

An eerie silence prevailed in Sewania Goud village where Varun resided with his family. Deceased Varun Gour, 12, son of Rajendra Gour, was a student of class 6 at a private school. He was the youngest among four siblings. Rajendra, who works as a mason, told TOI that Varun was a good student. He loved his bicycle and did many modifications to it on his own. Varun and his elder sister Lucky joined karate classes at SAI stadium merely five days before the incident. Siblings, along with three other friends, including Preet Dhangar, 13, used to walk to SAI stadium in the morning.

Lucky told TOI that on the day the incident took place, it was too cold, so she skipped the karate class. Only Varun and Preet went to the stadium on their bicycles. While returning, when Varun reached the culvert near Goragaon, his cycle bumped and he fell into the Upper Lake along with his cycle. Preet tried to pull up Varun from the culvert twice but failed. As Varun was drowning, he called for help, but by the time the boy was fished out by a passerby, Arvind Maran, it was too late .

Rajendra said that he was sleeping when the incident took place. Preet called on Varun’s eldest sister’s phone and informed her about the incident. As the girl had left home for college, she informed Varun’s mother about it. As soon as she heard the news, she ran towards the culvert on foot. By that time Arvind Maran had fished out Varun. Together they rushed the boy to a hospital where he was declared dead on arrival.

Varun’s grandfather Mohan Singh Gour, who resides in Salaiya Silvani, couldn’t control himself and burst into tears. Continuously staring at Varun’s bicycle which was fished out from the lake on Monday, he said that he lost everything with Varun’s sudden death.

Title: Continuing the protests not justified: MHRD minister Ramesh Pokhriyal
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Ramesh Pokhriyal

NEW DELHI: Union human resource development minister Ramesh Pokhriyal on Monday said that the fee-related matter of JNU had been sorted out and continuation of agitation by students was not justified.

A press statement released by the ministry stated that the fee-related matter had been sorted following several rounds of discussions with representatives of JNU students and teachers. The ministry had earlier set up a high-powered committee following an assurance by Pokhriyal to look into the matter.

Taking into consideration the spirit of recommendations of the HPC, various meetings were held by the HRD secretary with representatives of students/teachers and JNU administration on December 10 and 11, 2019, and certain mutually agreeable agreements were arrived at. JNU later issued a statement saying that the students were not being asked to bear the cost of service and utility charges proposed for the winter session, which was their basic demand. The revised hostel room charges, however, will remain applicable with 50% concession for BPL students, it added then.

The ministry said that of the 8,600 students, more than 5,000 have already registered for the winter session. It appealed to the students to call off their agitation.

Title: Two months on, Punjab yet to let private centres dispense buprenorphine
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: Struggling to spread the cover of its de-addiction programme, the Punjab health department is sitting over its two-month-old decision to allow private centres with outpatient facility to dispense drugs covered under the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act, 1985.

To widen the availability of treatment at affordable rates, the health department in November divided de-addiction centres for treatment of substance-use disorder into two categories — one with indoor facility, and the other without an indoor facility. This allowed facilities without indoor facility to dispense buprenorphine , which, at present, is dispensed by private centres with indoor facility and government-run out-patient opioid-assisted treatment (OOAT) clinics.

Rules were framed and later communicated to civil surgeons in all districts. However, the department has not started accepting applications for allowing such centres to register. The delay has led to resentment among psychiatrists, who have spent time and money to fulfil norms in the rules.

Dr Satish Thapar, a Bathinda-based psychiatrist, is among many doctors who, in anticipation of implementation of new rules, invested in infrastructure. “I rented a space and have so far spent Rs 4 lakh,” said Dr Thapar. “I am not sure what is going to happen and what is holding the government back.”

As per rules, centres must have one full-time psychiatrist and counseller, and they must have a separate room for the doctor and dispensing with storage facility. Other infrastructural requirements include one room for counselling patients, OPD with a capcity of more than 50 patients per day, a waiting area with provision of drinking water and a rest room. There should be adequate space for storage of equipment and medicines as per the manufacturer’s guidelines.

Association of Psychiatrists (AOP) Punjab president Dr Rupinder Kapur expressed surprise over the delay behind a patient-friendly step taken by the government. She said it was appreciated, but should be implemented at the earliest. “The department, for some unforeseen circumstances, is dragging its feet on starting OPD clinics’ registration under OOAT programme. It has been almost two months since the minutes of meeting and rules were circulated by the department,” said Dr Kapur.

Punjab health minister Balbir Singh Sidhu said they were reworking the modalities to ensure that there was no misuse of controlled drugs. “The new rules will be implemented only after reworking the modalities,” said Sidhu.

Title: Road accidents in Banyan City fall by 41% in five years
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: The number of vehicles on the roads of Banyan City have increased over the years, but the number of road accidents have consistently dropped in the last five years.

The figures released by the traffic branch of city police suggest that the number of road accidents including the fatal ones have come down by 41% since 2015.

Figures looked really promising in accidents where the victims suffered only minor injuries. However, the number of accidents where the victims were grievously injured didn’t register much improvement.

While the fall in number of road accidents may bring some cheer, the death of 969 people during the same period raises a serious alarm.

“The drop in the numbers is a result of our constant efforts to bring down the number of road accidents in the city,” said a police official. “After studying the spots where repeated road accidents had been taking place, we held traffic drives at those spots so that the situation can improve,” the police official added.

Senior police officials said that the support from industrial organizations, schools, universities and other institutions for conducting traffic drives also contributed to the efforts. “Over the years commuters’ habits have changed. Even in absence of traffic police at the junctions, people wait at the red lights and wear helmets and seat belts obediently,” said Amita Vanani, assistant commissioner of police (traffic).

The high number of spot collection of fines from those driving on wrong sides, over-speeding, jumping red lights have also seem to have worked in decreasing the number of accidents. Traffic police penalized 79,645 commuters for driving on wrong side, over-speeding and jumping red light and collected a fine of Rs 1.1 crore in 2019 alone.

Title: K Chandrasekhar Rao and Jaganmohan Reddy discuss national issues in marathon six-hour meeting
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Jaganmohan Reddy with K Chandrasekhar Rao and KTR at Pragati Bhavan

HYDERABAD: After nearly five months, chief ministers of Telangana and AP — K Chandrasekhar Rao and YS Jaganmohan Reddy — met at Pragati Bhavan on Monday and held a marathon six-hour meeting.

Sources said among other things, they also discussed national issues. Citizenship Amendment Act, NRC, NPR, river inter-linking, three capitals of AP and cash-for-vote scam came up for discussion. While the chief ministers decided to sail together on key issues, highly-placed sources said they also discussed about the strategy to be adopted with the BJP-led NDA government. Many of the non-BJP governments have already opposed CAA and NPR.

The AP government had announced that it would not implement NRC, while the Telangana government has not officially come out with its stand on NRC. The YSRC government had voted in favour of CAA in Parliament, but later announced that it would not support NRC. On the other hand, TRS had voted against CAA and is facing pressure from AIMIM to oppose NRC and NPR.

Sources said the chief ministers are believed to have felt that it would be better to take decisions together keeping in mind interests of both the states. They had worked closely on resolving bifurcation issues soon after Jagan took over as CM.

Sources said Jagan also briefed KCR on three capitals issue and reason behind his decision. He is believed to have told KCR that ongoing agitations on the capitals’ row were sponsored by TDP. The chief ministers also discussed the cash-for-vote case pending in Telangana. TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu and others are facing charges for his alleged role in the case.

According to an official press release by the chief minister’s office, both the chief ministers decided to adopt a give and take policy in all the matters pertaining to both the states for the benefit of people. They resolved to supply Godavari water to the Krishna river basin. The CMs also discussed about Schedule IX and X of the AP Reorganisation Act and spoke to respective chief secretaries over phone and asked them to hold a meeting at the earliest.

“During the six-hour long discussions, the CMs discussed national issues, states’ and local political situation. There was a lengthy discussion on diversion of Godavari water to Krishna basin,” the press release said.

Title: Scholarship: Centre urged to pay Rs 1,400 crore
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: Claiming to be reeling under financial crunch, the Punjab Unaided Colleges Association (Puca) has urged the Union government to release Rs 1,400 crore of the post-matric scholarship (PMS) scheme pending since 2015. There are about 16,000 unaided colleges in Punjab, in which about 3 lakh students belonging to marginalised community are studying, according to Puca .

A Puca delegation met Union minister of state for commerce and industry Som Prakash, who is the MP from Hoshiarpur . Puca president Anshu Kataria said Rs 415.60 crore of PMS for 2016-17, Rs 538 cr for 2017-18, and Rs 437.19cr for 2018-19 were due till now. “This totals to around Rs 1,400 crore, which is due towards the central government. This has created a financial crunch in colleges of Punjab,” he said.

The minister assured the delegation that he would discuss this matter with Union minister for social justice and empowerment Thawar Chand Gehlot and get the pending amount released as soon as possible.

Former MP Sher Singh Ghubaya, who was part of the delegation, said the Centre had stated that scheme was under 60:40 sharing pattern while the Punjab government had rejected the idea. “This confusion may adversely affect the career of the students as well as the colleges,” Ghubaya said.

Title: Clean septic tanks at night: Bicholim locals
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Bicholim: Citing inconvenience due to the cleaning of septic tanks of public pay toilets at the Bicholim KTC bus stand during the day, residents have requested the contractor to undertake the work at night. The complaint stated that due to the work, the residents as well as passengers at the bus stand, have to bear with a foul smell.

“A nightsoil tanker is supposed to be engaged at night as it emanates a foul smell. Hence, we have requested the contractor to undertake the work at night to avoid inconvenience,” a shopkeeper said, on condition of anonymity.

Title: Punjab: Jobless youth to get Rs 1,000 skill training allowance per month
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

CM Amarinder Singh

CHANDIGARH: Unemployed youth who undergo skill development training will also be given monthly allowance of Rs 1,000. Under the ‘Mera Kamm, Mera Maan’, a skilling and employment initiative of the Punjab government, provision has been made for giving monthly financial support, albeit with riders.

To help unemployed youth enhance their skills to meet the market requirements, the Punjab government will facilitate them in enrolling in government-run industrial training institutes (IITs), polytechnic colleges and Punjab skill development training centres for free in their chosen field . The department of employment generation and training has prepared a draft of the scheme and circulated to all the departments for feedback.

As per the laid down condition, the allowance will be paid only for those months for which the candidate has cumulative attendance of at least 80% and passed the regular periodic exams. The allowance of those failing to meet the condition will be stopped and will resume only after both the conditions are fulfilled by the candidate. The amount will be directly deposited in the bank account of the beneficiary.

Those interested in availing the benefit of the scheme will have to fulfil the conditions required for getting admission in these institutes against vacant seats. Only one member of a family will be entitled to avail the benefit of the scheme at a given time.

The district bureaus of employment and enterprise (DBEE) have been entrusted with responsibility of registering interested applicants and then coordinate with the institutes to facilitate their admissions for skilling. On successful completion of the training, DBEEs will also help the beneficiaries get employment.

Employment generation and training secretary Rahul Tewari said the scheme would be first rolled out on a pilot basis for construction workers and their wards. “In phased manner, the government will roll out the scheme for other sections of society too,” he added.

Punjab is grappling with a high rate of unemployment and creating job avenues was a major Congress poll promise in the 2017 assembly elections. The poor skill level of the job seekers in the state has been highlighted by industry. A large number of jobs in the five job fairs organised by the government so far have also gone abegging for the same reasons, posing a challenge to ‘Ghar Ghar Rozgar’, a flagship scheme of the government.

Title: Current troubles threatening Indian finances: Richard Thaler
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Kolkata: Current troubles in India are “threatening the country’s economy”, though they were not unique to India, said Nobel laureate and behavioural economist Richard H Thaler at IIM Calcutta on Monday. Delivering the Amitava Bose Memorial Lecture at the premier management institute, Thaler said protests were happening worldwide and countries should figure out how to deal with them since they were pulling the respective economies back. “But I don’t pretend to know the answer,” said the economics Nobel winner of 2017.

“Protests are happening everywhere. Chile is affected and San Diego is suffering in terms of tourism. France has been affected and so has been India,” said the professor of behavioural science and economics at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business. We are living in the riskiest of times, he added. “Brexit was madness. Democracy is fragile right now. As an investor, I am nervous. But I don’t know what to do. I guess we can only hope for the best,” said Thaler, while answering a question at the end of his lecture.

In his lecture titled “Doing economics in the 21st century: When economists need to stop and think twice”, Thaler pointed out that economic theories and models were often based on the incorrect assumption that people acted optimally in given situations. “Economists need to first examine who they are studying and what expertise they have. How often do their subjects engage in the activity being studied. And whether they are actually optimizing the benefits at their disposal or going for what they find is good enough for them,” said Thaler.

To stress his point, the Nobel laureate cited the instance of cardiac patients in USA, not more than 35% of whom take medicines to prevent a heart attack. “It’s not known what makes them do it. Do they believe they know better than their doctors? Or, is it because they can’t find time to take medicines? Similarly, firms, too, often don’t optimize their operations. But badly run firms can last decades. So, every economic paper should be as behavioural as it can be,” observed Thaler.

He said ‘nudges’ were required to help people choose the best possible option but they may or may not work. “The best example of a nudge is the Google map which gives you the shortest possible route from one place to another. It helps you to get there but can’t force you to accept its suggestion,” he said.

Was immigration responsible for slowing down economies? Not really, felt Thaler. “The US economy is chugging along nicely even as president Trump is lambasting immigrants. The economy of Chile is the strongest in South America despite immigration being an issue there,” he said.

Title: K Chandrasekhar Rao and Jaganmohan Reddy discuss national issues in marathon six-hour meeting
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Jaganmohan Reddy with K Chandrasekhar Rao and KTR at Pragati Bhavan

HYDERABAD: After nearly five months, chief ministers of Telangana and AP — K Chandrasekhar Rao and YS Jaganmohan Reddy — met at Pragati Bhavan on Monday and held a marathon six-hour meeting.

Sources said among other things, they also discussed national issues. Citizenship Amendment Act, NRC, NPR, river inter-linking, three capitals of AP and cash-for-vote scam came up for discussion. While the chief ministers decided to sail together on key issues, highly-placed sources said they also discussed about the strategy to be adopted with the BJP-led NDA government. Many of the non-BJP governments have already opposed CAA and NPR.

The AP government had announced that it would not implement NRC, while the Telangana government has not officially come out with its stand on NRC. The YSRC government had voted in favour of CAA in Parliament, but later announced that it would not support NRC. On the other hand, TRS had voted against CAA and is facing pressure from AIMIM to oppose NRC and NPR.

Sources said the chief ministers are believed to have felt that it would be better to take decisions together keeping in mind interests of both the states. They had worked closely on resolving bifurcation issues soon after Jagan took over as CM.

Sources said Jagan also briefed KCR on three capitals issue and reason behind his decision. He is believed to have told KCR that ongoing agitations on the capitals’ row were sponsored by TDP. The chief ministers also discussed the cash-for-vote case pending in Telangana. TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu and others are facing charges for his alleged role in the case.

According to an official press release by the chief minister’s office, both the chief ministers decided to adopt a give and take policy in all the matters pertaining to both the states for the benefit of people. They resolved to supply Godavari water to the Krishna river basin. The CMs also discussed about Schedule IX and X of the AP Reorganisation Act and spoke to respective chief secretaries over phone and asked them to hold a meeting at the earliest.

“During the six-hour long discussions, the CMs discussed national issues, states’ and local political situation. There was a lengthy discussion on diversion of Godavari water to Krishna basin,” the press release said.

Title: Dissident Akalis to rally in poll-bound Delhi this Saturday
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Shiromani Akali Dal president, Sukhbir Singh Badal

AMRITSAR: To mobilise inactive Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) leaders and strengthen their support base, dissident Akali veterans who have already sounded a bugle against the party leadership, particularly the Badal family, are set to show their strength by holding a rally in poll-bound Delhi on January 18.

The pretext is to celebrate the 99th foundation anniversary of SAD, which was formed in 1920. The move comes at a time when senior Akali leadership is camping in Delhi to persuade its Punjab ally, BJP, for seat sharing in Delhi. To portray that the present leadership of SAD had deviated from the principles of the party’s foundation, the organisers of Delhi event are describing themselves as ‘Samuh Akali Parivar (whole of Akali family)’, as it would include various factions of SAD.

The function has been named Safar-e-Akali Dal (journey of Akali Dal). “Time has come when we have to bring more Taksali leaders, who have been ignored and living in oblivion, to the fore for the resurrection of SAD,” president of religio-political outfit Jag Asra Guru Ott (JAGO). Manjit Singh GK, a former ally of Badals, told TOI on Monday.

During the 2015 Delhi assembly elections, SAD and BJP were alliance partners with the former contesting on four seats on its own symbol and two on BJP’s symbol.

Manjit, who is also the former president of the Delhi Sikh Gurdwara Management Committee (DSGMC), claimed that the January 18 function would set the course for rejuvenation of the old SAD. Sewa Singh Sekhwan , secretary general of SAD (Taksali), which is one of the invitees to the January 18 function, said, “Reports of SAD alliance with BJP in Delhi are one-sided. BJP is yet to make its position clear and will weigh the political leverage it will have after forging ties with SAD for the Delhi polls or the alliance would prove to be a burden.”

When asked about the progress about discussions with BJP over seat sharing in Delhi, party spokesperson Daljit Singh Cheema expressed ignorance. He said the party’s in-charge of political affairs for Delhi, Balwinder Singh Bhunder, was negotiating with the saffron party.

Bhunder couldn’t be contacted for comment. Sources informed that dissident Akalis were also in a bid to rope in some prominent BJP face during their January 18 function in Delhi. However, the same couldn’t be confirmed.

Title: Punjab: Rain forces SAD to shift Maghi conference venue
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

The open ground near Malout bypass in Muktsar, where SAD holds a rally every year on the occasion of Maghi, on... Read More

BATHINDA: The Congress and the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP), like last year, have decided not to hold any political conference on the occasion of Maghi in Muktsar, but the Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) is going ahead with its function on Tuesday, with a last-minute change in venue due to bad weather.

The party was pitching its tent and stage at the open ground on Malout bypass when rain lashed the region on Monday. SAD president Sukhbir Singh Badal , who took stock of preparations, decided to shift the venue to a resort on Malout Road, after obtaining clearance from the police, said a party spokesperson.

Muktsar SAD MLA Kanwarjit Singh Barkandi said the stage which was being set up for the rally was wet and the party decided to change the venue as more rain was predicted. “Acting on the directions of party president, we decided to shift the venue to a marriage palace,” he said.

A party functionary, who did not wish to be named, said the gathering would be important as it would be the first political conference of SAD without former leader of party in assembly Parminder Singh Dhindsa and his father, Rajya Sabha MP Sukhdev Singh Dhindsa . “It will be interesting to see how we mobilise workers and what do leaders speak at the rally,” said the functionary.
