Union minister Harsimrat Badal already set the tone for the rally on Monday, attacking Parminder. "If the SAD is a group of sycophants, Parminder must make it clear whether he too was a sycophant. Till recently, he was very much with us and singing paeans to us,” she said.

Title: Vadodara: 3 acquitted after 40 years as ‘bhajia’ seller disowns his complaint
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: Almost four decades after they ransacked a ‘bhajiya’ stall and robbed the owner of Rs 250, three persons were acquitted by a local court as the complainant himself turned hostile during the trial.

The court of additional chief judicial magistrate acquitted Jayanti Parmar, Dileep Parmar and Mohan Parmar after stall owner Rajendra Thakor retracted from his allegations last week.

It was in November 1981 that the trio had gone to his ‘bhajia’ stall in Bakrawadi locality in Navapura and asked him to give food on credit. When Thakor refused, the three got agitated and started hurling expletives at him. They allegedly ransacked his stall and robbed his daily cash collection. Following a complaint lodged by Thakor, city police station had arrested them and they were released on bail later. The chargesheet was filed within a month.

During the trial, none of the three appeared in the court despite repeated summons. Therefore, it was decided to go ahead with the trial without them.

The public prosecutor submitted the complaint and the statements of material witnesses as the key evidence in the case. The court considered the evidence against the trio, but when it came to examination of Thakor, the prosecution’s case collapsed.

When the public prosecutor examined Thakor, he did not support the case. Thakor flatly denied that the three had ransacked his stall and abusive language. He also refuted his own allegations of the trio robbing him of Rs 250.

The court stated that as the complainant himself admitted that no such incident took place and the accused too remained away from trial, the case has not been proven.

Title: HC to state: What is corporates’ role in lake revival?
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: The high court on Monday asked the government to explain private parties’ role in maintaining and developing Bengaluru’s lakes.

The court was hearing a batch of petitions on the state of water bodies in the city.

Environmentalist Leo Saldanha said in a newspaper advertisement last month, the chief minister had requested corporates to take up maintenance and development of lakes as part of their corporate social responsibilities. This amounted to privatisation, he argued, but a division bench headed by chief justice Abhay Shreeniwas Oka said it does not seem to be so.

The court directed the government and BBMP to extend logistical support (except money) to the Environment Support Group (ESG), which is undertaking a survey of waterbird habitats in the city along with the Birdwatchers’ Field Club.

To properly assess the extent of shrinking of lakes/wetlands across the state, the court sought a map prepared by Survey of India in 1972, data available with Karnataka State Remote Sensing Applications Centre and reports submitted by the Lake Development Authority, which is now merged with the minor irrigation department.

Title: Punjab: Now, robots to clean sewer lines
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Punjab hopes to end manual scavenging with the move

CHANDIGARH: To put an end to manual scavenging , the Punjab water supply and sanitation department has decided to employ robots for cleaning sewerage in the state.

Water supply and sanitation minister Razia Sultana said the project would be started from Muktsar Sahib on the auspicious occasion of Maghi on Tuesday. Punjab would now become the seventh state in the country to adopt this technique, with Muktsar becoming the first district in state. Two machines worth Rs 90 lakh each would bring a much-needed upgrade in this mammoth and difficult task, said Sultana.

The machines are carbon-bodied robots which are waterproof and equipped with sensors to ascertain toxic gases inside pipes. “These have been designed as per human needs and with a view to assist our workers and are easy to operate,” she said.

In the first phase, the hi-tech robotic machine, ‘Bandikooto’, designed by Jenrobotics Company of Kerala would commence human-free sewerage cleaning in Muktsar Sahib, which would save employees from dangers of grave problems caused by physical cleaning of sewerages and by exposure from toxic gases. The use of technology would also speed up cleaning, she said.

Title: In Pathankot, ‘Sunny Deol missing’ posters surface
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

People with posters of Sunny Deol ‘missing’, in Pathankot on Monday

CHANDIGARH: Posters declaring BJP MP from Gurdaspur Sunny Deol ‘missing’ have been put up at various places in Pathankot district , including the railway station. Posters read ‘Gumshuda ki talash MP Sunny Deol’.

In response to these posters, Deol said in a video message on his Twitter handle on Monday that it was the act of his rivals. “I have learnt that my rivals are talking some senseless things about me,” said Deol. Wishing people, a Happy Lohri, the MP promised his voters to bring some big projects to the Gurdaspur constituency. Deol said in the video that the traffic issue in Pathankot city would be addressed soon through the narrow-gauge elevated project as the central government had sanctioned funds for it.

He said, “I have been able to do such things because of the strength of faith you reposed in me. I will bring some big projects in the future because your faith is my strength.”

Reacting, Congress MP from Anandpur Sahib Manish Tewari said on Twitter: “Not surprising same thing happened to his father Dharmendra in Bikaner. Gurdaspur missed the chance of a good man @sunilkjakhar representing them again. Would have added to @INCIndia’s strength in Parliament.”

The actor had appointed a writer Gurpreet Singh Palheri as his representative to “attend meetings and follow important matters” in July last year, leading to sharp criticism from various quarters.

Title: SAD: Congress, Sukhdev Singh Dhindsas in collusion
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Sukhdev Singh Dhindsa

CHANDIGARH: The Shiromani Akai Dal (SAD) on Monday said Congress ministers going out of the way to help suspended Akali leaders Sukhdev Singh Dhindsa and his MLA son, Parminder Singh Dhindsa , proved that they were being used as pawns by chief minister Amarinder Singh .

The SAD said it showed Congress’s attempt to weaken the Panthic party. SAD senior vice-president Balwinder Singh Bhunder and general secretary Prem Singh Chandumajra said the closeness between the Dhindsas and the CM had become apparent during a recent dinner meeting between them. “Now, with Congress ministers taking on the job of spokespersons for the Dhindsa family, it is clear they are working according to a game plan in collusion with each other,” said the Akali leaders.

They added the Dhindsa faction, which comprised Sukhdev, Parminder and Sukhdev’s son-in-law Tejinderpal Singh Sidhu, was being supported by the Congress with the sole aim of splitting Panthic votes. Bunder and Chandumajra said SAD leaders left the Dhindsa family because of their autocratic nature and inability to make the party win in their area. A day after SAD suspended Sukhdev and Parminder, Punjab ministers on Sunday targeted SAD chief Sukhbir Singh Badal , claiming that the party had been reduced to “personal fiefdom” of the Badals. The ministers included Tript Rajinder Singh Bajwa, Sukhbinder Singh Sarkaria and Gurpreet Singh Kangar.

Title: Gujarat: ‘Chinese thread used to snare birds at Nalsarovar’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Forest officials have recovered some 60 spools of Chinese threads. These threads were sold for the Uttarayan f... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Chinese nylon threads are not only used to fly kites, but also used to snare birds in Nalsarovar — the only Ramsar site in the state. Forest officials have recovered some 60 spools of Chinese threads. These threads were sold for the Uttarayan festival .

Deputy conservator of forest, Nalsarovar, Brijash Chaudhari said that the Chinese thread spools were sold in Shahpur village in Viramgam taluka. Chaudhari said the sale of Chinese thread was already banned by the state government, but in villages on the periphery of the Nalsarovar the thread was used to set bird snares.

Chaudhary said that acting on a tip-off, officials had raided Ronak Mobile shop and recovered the Chinese thread. No arrests were made as there was no one present in the shop at the time of the raid and seizure of the goods. A case has been registered, Chaudhary said.

A senior forest official said the modus operandi was simple. In the night the locals flew around 10 kites together, and one of them rousted out the birds. When the birds took sudden flight at night, they were snared in the kite threads. The injured birds were then eaten or sold.

Forest officials said this is the first time that such a large number of Chinese thread spools have been recovered. This is the third poaching-related case reported from Nalsarovar lake this year. In the earlier two incidents, birds were recovered from the residents.

Title: 5 held; 2 cops sent to behaviour training
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Two cops of Valiyathura police station who reportedly lectured a young woman as to why she should keep off beaches at night while receiving a complaint of moral policing were sent for a seven-day behavioural training course at the police training academy.

Valiyathura police also recorded the arrest of five men who had allegedly harassed and verbally abused the 24-year-old woman and her two friends at Shangumugham beach late on Saturday.

The accused were Nahas, 24, and Suhaib, 26, of Puthuval Puriyadam, Vallakadavu; Mohammed Ali, 27, of Kurisumoodu Vila, Vallakadavu; Anzari, 27, of Manikkavilakom, Poonthura, and Antony, 40, of Kannanthura. Sreelakshmi Arackal, who came to the beach with her two friends, was subjected to moral policing and her Facebook post describing the incident went viral. The post also mentioned the police officers questioning why Sreelakshmi was at the beach at night.

According to Valiyathura station house officer inspector Anil Kumar S, the accused were all identified with visuals submitted by the complainant and were picked up from their residences at around 11pm on Sunday. “A case invoking multiple sections including outraging the modesty of a woman has been registered against the accused. Two officers, ASI Salahuddin who was in charge of GD and civil police officer Suresh Kumar who was on sentry duty have both been sent for a behavioural training for their response to the complainant,” the officer said.

Sreelakshmi said that she is happy that the police acted on the complaint and recording the arrest in such a short span of time. “I was called in to the station to identify the men who were taken into custody and confirmed all five as those who were involved in the moral policing at the beach. Eventhough I am not sure, I think there were two more men in the group of people who harassed us. But it is reassuring to know that the arrests were made without much delay,” she said.

Women and child development department secretary Biju Prabhakar praised the boldness showed by Sreelakshmi in handling the situation and filing a complaint at the police station. “Women in our society should take a leaf out of the boldness shown by Sreelakshmi and react like this against such atrocities. Parents of girls living in close proximity to the locations of the accused should think twice before marrying their daughters to men like them. Night week is still being organised across parts of the state at least once in a week and this will be expanded statewide by March 8. More women should come out at nights without fear like Sreelakshmi which will help nab more of such perverts and help reclaim freedom for women in public spaces,” Prabhakar said in a post he shared on Facebook.

Title: Seven booked for cheating former WCL employee of Rs 42.72 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Seven persons , including two couples, have been booked for their alleged role in duping a retired employee of Western Coalfields Limited (WCL), Pradeep Bose, to the tune of Rs42.72 lakh over seven years.

The persons named in the First Information Report (FIR) have been identified as advocate Dhananjay Dhodarkar, his wife Sonali, Arun Shrivastav, Jayashree Bagul (wife of a senior police inspector), Dinesh Madavi, his wife Sumitra, and Ravindra Govindwar. They have been slapped with charges of cheating, criminal breach of trust, and forgery among others.

Police said Bose had approached Shrivastav of Royal Developers to purchase an apartment. Shrivastav had asked Bose to approach his legal adviser Dhodarkar. It was Dhodarkar who asked Bose to book an apartment at a scheme of Royal Developers at Kachipura. It’s learnt that Bose was later directed by Dhodarkar to buy an apartment at Tilak Nagar instead of Kachipura since that scheme was not working out.

Dhodarkar, trying to convince Bose, had also said that he was also a member along with his wife Sonali and others including the Madavi couple at the Tilak Nagar scheme. Bose was made to cough up substantial amount in cash and cheque, promising him that the scheme would soon start and the apartment would be handed over to him.

Dhodarkar and others also prepared fake documents to collect cash from Bose. It was after spending considerable amount that Bose realized that he was being cheated since the documents were fake and questionable. He approached Ambazari police station where an offence was registered.

Title: Three accused remanded to police custody for eight days
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: Three persons arrested in connection with the death of six persons due to a blast at Aims Industries Pvt Ltd near Gavasad village in Padra taluka were remanded to police custody for eight days by a local court.

The director of the company Satyakumar Nair, plant manager Akash Agrawal and operator-cum-supervisor Raju Rathwa were presented before a local court on Monday. While seeking their remands, police informed the court that the interrogation of the trio is necessary as the main accused Siddharth Patel, who is the owner of the company, and his son and director Swetanshu Patel are on run.

Police also said that the trio’s custody is also necessary to know the technicalities of the bottling of gases. Whether the company possessed necessary licenses and permissions or not will also be investigated, police said.

Meanwhile, police continued their search for the two accused who are on run.

The blast at the factory on the morning of January 11 had killed six persons on the spot and critically injured four persons.

Title: Telangana: 19 injured in Bhainsa as row over bike noise triggers clash
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Police take stock after two groups clashed in Bhainsa in Nirmal late on Sunday night

HYDERABAD: Nineteen people, including eight police officers, were injured after two groups clashed late on Sunday night in the communally sensitive Bhainsa town in Telangana ’s Nirmal district . The rioting was triggered after some residents clashed with youths revving up their bikes in the middle of the night. It soon led to widespread violence in which 13 houses and 26 vehicles were torched.

The violence did not abate on Monday, especially at Korbagalli and surrounding areas, believed to be the epicentre of the violence. Police lathi-charged the rioters at least half-a-dozen times to stop the sporadic clashes on Monday afternoon. As many as 60 people were taken into custody till late evening on Monday. Officials added that internet services were suspended across Nirmal, Adilabad, Mancherial and Asifabad districts as wild rumours on social media kept the embers burning.

“Eleven civilians and eight policemen were injured in the clashes and stone-pelting. We have registered six FIRs for different offences. The situation is now under control and the vigil will continue,” inspector general of police Nagi Reddy, who is in Nirmal, told TOI on Monday evening.

It all started around 9.45 pm on Sunday when some residents objected to a bunch of young men riding bikes without silencers at Korbagalli area. The argument led to a scuffle which resulted in two groups coming face to face. Cops claim that the situation was about to de-escalate and the groups decided to stand down when an unidentified person threw a stone at one of the groups, triggering heavy stone pelting at around 10.30 pm. Pitched battles continued for nearly three hours, according to the police.

Senior officials said that by the time the police reached the spot, the situation was serious with both sides refusing to relent. SP C Shashidhar Raju also rushed to stop the stone-pelting. Police teams from districts adjoining Nirmal too were rushed to the town with DGP M Mahendar Reddy monitoring the situation from Hyderabad. Section 144 of CrPC was declared from Monday till Wednesday.

AIMIM president and Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi on Twitter called the incident “targeted violence” and demanded that “every miscreant is immediately brought to justice, so that criminals think twice before participating in such activity. Those who have had to face loss of property must be compensated immediately. Every complaint must be registered along with FIRs,” he tweeted.

The Telangana BJP, in a statement, demanded that chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao make a statement on the violence and also sought a judicial enquiry.

Bhainsa had seen its worse communal clashes in 2008 in which six people died. The violence had started after a religious procession was taken out in the town.

Title: Barodians ready to chant ‘Kai Po Che’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Kite enthusiasts seen thronging the multi-coloured stalls on Monday

VADODARA: Eyes on the sky and strings in hand , the streets in Banyan City’s old and new parts were filled with revellers the whole day on Monday. People of all ages were seen thronging the multi-coloured kite stalls located in every nook and cranny of the city getting armed for the battle of the skies on Tuesday.

Colourful kites and their enthusiasts can’t wait to adorn the sky in vibrant hue on Uttarayan day from the morning.

Families, friends and all gear up for the grand festivity on every possible rooftop, which also turn into table tops for foodie Barodians with the elaborate spread of various types of chikkis, undhiya, jalebi and sugarcane to be abundantly devoured after every kite avenged, or lost. Young and old alike love to relax with the kites and enjoy the season’s first fun-filled festival.

“I am just setting up music system that will literally blare from our rooftop. Uttarayan is no longer just about kites, its also a mini Diwali of sorts and hence we too have kept fire crackers handy to burst in the evening,” said Sanjay Patel, a resident of old city area.

Another old city resident Maulik Shah has invited all his families and friends on his rooftop to enjoy mouth savouring ‘undhiyu’ and jalebi.

“After a day full of kite flying and screaming ‘Kai Po Che’ , we society members will have a dinner get-together with ‘sev usal’,” said Kimali Agrawal, a resident of Samta. There were some scenes of traffic jams at some junctions where stalls selling masks, accessories apart from kites were set up in the city.

Title: Swap shop: Corpn rakes in Rs 73,000
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Chennai: Corporation commissioner G Prakash on Monday honoured members of the public who volunteered to make the ‘ swap shop ’ a success, by issuing them ‘Swachh volunteer’ identity cards. The commissioner said that following the positive response for the Besant Nagar ‘swap shop’, the civic body will set up similar ‘shops’ ahead of festival seasons to promote reuse . Monday saw more patronage than the first day of the ‘swap shop’, officials said. The civic body ended up selling 6,716 items, bringing in a revenue of Rs 73 ,590.

P Jayanthi, a resident of Valmiki Nagar in Thiruvanmiyur, who was among the five volunteers who were honoured by the civic body chief on Monday told TOI that the idea to set up a swap shop was floated among residents about three weeks ago by Alby John, regional deputy commissioner. “In Adyar zone (Zone 13), we have vibrant residents’ welfare associations where waste segregation and other civic issues are constantly discussed. Residents met corporation officials again when Elliot’s beach was declared litter free on January 6 and then things started rolling.”

While in some areas, resident volunteers arranged for items to be collected in local community halls, some like Jayanthi undertook door-to-door collection along with corporation staff. Corporation officials said the volunteers also helped in fixing prices. TNN

Title: 290 take part in mountaineering competition at Osam hills
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

RAJKOT: A total of 290 enthusiasts participated in mountaineering competition at Osam hills in Patanvav of Rajkot district on Sunday.

Of the participants, 134 were women. Participants had to climb 1,100 steps and trek for several metres to cover a total of four km in the contest.

According to a release issued by the state government, Vijay Sabaria from Kalsar village of Chotila taluka in Surendranagar district bagged the first prize in the men’s category by completing the competition in 10.41 minutes. In the women’s category, Jharana Vansh from Delwada village of Una taluka in Gir Somnath district stood first by completing the track in 12.27 minutes.

All the participants at the event were in the age group of 14 to 18 years. In the men’s category, Ravi Bhatia from Junagadh came second and Azbal Bhalia from the same town stood third.

In the women’s category, Kinjal Gabu from Rampara taluka came second, while Payal Olakiya from Rajkot stood third.

The cash prizes given to the winners included Rs 12,500 (first prize), Rs 10,000 (second prize) and Rs 7,500 (third prize).

Title: BJP, Congress slam Naveen Patnaik government over failure to appoint OBC panel
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

CM Naveen Patnaik

BHUBANESWAR: The opposition BJP and Congress on Monday slammed the Naveen Patnaik government for not appointing the OBC Commission to protect the interests of other backward classes. The criticism comes two days after the state cabinet recommended to the Centre to conduct the socio-economic caste census as part of Census 2021. Both BJP and Congress questioned the motive behind the move saying, lack of Naveen’s commitment for the backward classes is reflected from the fact that the OBC Commission was not appointed.

“If the government actually wanted development of the OBCs, it would have appointed the OBC Commission. After staying in power for two decades, Naveen suddenly remembers the OBCs and demand SECC,” said BJP state general secretary Prithviraj Harichandan at a press conference. “While the Centre and many other states have extended 27% reservation to the OBCs, the BJD government in Odisha has failed to do so. There is no OBC reservation in education in Odisha while it is 11.5% in jobs,” he added.

The Narendra Modi-led government had accorded constitutional status to National Commission of Backward Classes last year. Speaking to reporters at Congress Bhawan, spokesperson Satya Nayak said, “The Naveen government had not constituted the OBC commission despite a direction from the Orissa high court in 2011. The state government had also submitted an affidavit in the HC in 2012 to form the OBC commission within six months. However, the same is yet to be done.” Nayak added that Naveen’s suggestion for SECC is to lure the OBCs ahead of the municipal elections later this year.

The BJD, however, defended the government’s move. Jagannath Sarka, minister for ST and SC development, minorities and backward classes welfare, said the process to form the OBC commission is already on. “It will be done soon,” he added. BJD spokesperson Sasmit Patra said, “If the socio-economically backward castes are enumerated, the data will help for any move for their development and welfare. The opposition should not politicise such an issue meant for people’s development.”

Title: Scuffle over CAA in Sundargarh town
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

The group demanding the withdrawal of CAA was led by district Congress leaders and comprised mostly of party w... Read More

ROURKELA: A rally against the contentious Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) in Sundargarh on Monday was disrupted allegedly by members of a fringe Hindu outfit, forcing police to intervene to prevent the situation from spiralling out of control.

The group demanding the withdrawal of CAA was led by district Congress leaders and comprised mostly of party workers. Senior Congress leaders, including former MLA George Tirkey and former Talsara MLA Prafulla Majhi, were at the forefront of the rally, which started from Nari Kalyan Kendra and was to end at the collector’s office after covering a large part of Sundargarh town , the district headquarters.

At 1 pm, when the rally was near the collector’s office, some youths from Hindu Ekta Manch, a fringe saffron outfit, allegedly taunted minority community members who were part of the Congress-led group. The heated exchange of words soon gave way to pushing and shoving between the two groups, prompting police to intervene. The anti-CAA rally, however, was allowed to continue and it ended as planned in front of the collector’s office.

Benudhar Tripathy, former district Congress Committee president, lodged a police complaint against the attackers.

A member of the Hindu outfit, on condition of anonymity, claimed they were forced to react when anti-national slogans were raised by the Congress workers. “Two youths in the anti-CAA rally were shouting things like ‘we will snatch independence’,” he said.

This was denied by a Congress delegation that met Sundargarh SP Soumya Mishra in the evening to submit a memorandum against the youths of the saffron outfit. “The rally was part of Congress’s nationwide protest programme against CAA and NRC. It was peaceful. No anti-national slogan was raised,” said former MLA Tirkey. “We met the Sundargarh SP and sought appropriate action against the culprits,” he added.

Police said they were on alert to prevent any escalation of tensions. “We are examining Congress’s complaint. No FIR has been filed by either group so far, but we are keeping a close watch on the developments,” said R N Barik, additional SP (Sundargarh).

Title: Andhra Pradesh Capital: End of Amaravati plan? Andhra Pradesh government to repeal CRDA Act
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Andhra chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy

AMARAVATI: The AP government has decided to repeal the Capital Region Development Authority ( CRDA ) Act which was brought in to build the new capital Amaravati. This would nullify the Amaravati master plan envisaged by the previous TDP regime.

The CRDA will be replaced by the erstwhile urban development board — Vijayawada-Guntur-Tenali-Mangalagiri Urban Development Authority (VGTM UDA). The VGTM UDA will now draft a new master plan for the entire area and not exclusively for the capital city.

The state government has also decided to offer additional land compensation to the Land Pooling Scheme (LPS) farmers. The government would grant 200 sq.yard of additional land to all those who gave land for the capital city. The LPS farmers would now get 1,600 sq yard instead of 1,400 sq yard as promised in the principal Act.

Similarly, the government had decided to grant annuity amount for three more years than the promise made in the CRDA Act. Farmers would now get annual lease amount for 13 years instead of 10 years earlier.

According to sources, repealing of the CRDA Act would help in growth in the existing capital city area as zonal restrictions in the Act had prevented farmers from going for development of their plots.

The state government has decided to offer additional sops without directly holding discussions with farmers who are staging protests in the capital city area. The high-level committee which met on Monday, however, appealed to farmers to send their representations to CRDA commissioner before January 17.

According to the draft bill, CRDA Act shall cease to exist and its jurisdiction shall vest in the VGTM Urban Development Authority to be constituted under the Metropolitan Region and Urban Development Authorities Act, 2016, which shall comprise such areas as deemed necessary and which are hitherto within the jurisdiction of APCRDA.

The state government shall be deemed to be the guarantor for all loans availed by CRDA and transferred to VGMTUDA. All the employees of CRDA would also be shifted to VGTM UDA.

Title: Gahiramatha readies for second dolphin census
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Altogether 270 dolphins were sighted in Gahiramatha in 2015

KENDRAPADA: Nine teams of forest personnel will conduct dolphin census on January 19 in the water bodies of Gahiramatha marine sanctuary and its nearby areas in Kendrapada district. Dolphin census in Gahiramatha was conducted for the first time in 2015.

“In 2016, 2017 and 2018, the forest department cancelled the dolphin census due to bad weather. In 2015, we spotted 270 dolphins in the water bodies of Bhitarkanika National Park and Gahiramatha marine sanctuary,” said Bikash Ranjan Dash, the divisional forest officer of the park.

The forest personnel had sighted 58 Irrawaddy dolphins, 23 bottlenose dolphins, 123 Indo-Pacific humpback dolphin and 50 Indian Ocean humpback dolphin, 15 pan tropical spotted dolphins and one finless porpoise.

The 2015 dolphin census revealed that Bhitarkanika was home to state’s largest population of dolphins as then there were only 144 Irrawaddy dolphins in Chilika, said the forest officer, adding that Gahiramatha had more number of dolphins due to its large area. “In 2019, we counted 126 dolphins in the water bodies of Gahiramatha marine sanctuary. The sighting of dolphins depended upon the weather condition on the day of census,” he said.

Dolphin has been included in Schedule I of Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act 1972 in Appendix I of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species ( CITES ), in Appendix II of the Convention on Migratory Species (CMS) and categorised as endangered on the International Union for the Conservation of Nature’s (IUCN) red list, said the forest officer.

Title: Firing by PSI: Absconding cop denied bail
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: A probationary sub-inspector of Makarpura police station who has been on run for over seven months now in connection with the firing of three bullets at a man in Tarsali, was denied anticipatory bail on Monday.

S V Chudasama had sought bail on the grounds that the complaint was wrongly registered against him and he had already registered an attempt to murder plaint in connection with the same incident that took place on June 3.

Chudasama claimed that the firing took place accidentally when the injured person Simit Prajapati was trying to snatch his gun during a melee.

The additional public prosecutor R S Chauhan argued against Chudasama’s bail application and said that Chudasama had got into a brawl with Prajapati outside the latter’s father’s paan shop following which he took out his gun and fired three rounds at Prajapati. Two bullets hit him on lower abdomen and thigh. He further argued that the investigating officer had searched for him at several places, but Chudasama was nowhere to be found.

While turning down the cop’s bail plea, the court of additional sessions judge K M Sojitra upheld Chauhan’s arguments and also took into consideration that bullets fired from his gun had hit Prajapati in two places.

According to the case details, on June 3 night Prajapati and Chudasama had got into an altercation as the cop was fighting with the former’s father. Prajapati later alleged that during the brawl, Chudasama pulled out his gun and fired at him thrice.

On the other hand, Chudasama had alleged that while passing by Tarsali on his bike, he saw liquor was being sold at the paan shop and so confronted the owner and two other people there. The three persons got agitated at Chudasama and started to beat him up. They also tried to snatch his gun. It was during this melee that the gun fired accidentally and the bullets hit Prajapati.
