Title: Students lock up college principal for seven hours
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Kozhikode: Students of the Sree Narayana Guru College at Chelannur locked up the college principal for around seven hours on Monday demanding revocation of the principal’s decision to dismiss a guest lecturer.

The students alleged that the principal was engaging in moral policing and that the guest faculty in the college, Mohammed Sahil, was dismissed for allowing boys and girl students to sit together in the classroom.

The students locked up principal V Devi Priya in her office from 11am till 6pm demanding revocation of the dismissal of the lecturer.

The students alleged that the principal took action against Sahil for allowing boys and girls to sit together in the first year postgraduate English class during a group activity in the classroom. “The principal came to the class and objected to boys and girls sitting together and reprimanded the teacher in front of the students. It was not an isolated incident. There have been other incidents of the principal objecting to boys and girls sitting together in the past as well,” said Vishnu M K, general secretary of the college union.

Meanwhile, principal Devi Priya denied the allegation that the guest faculty was dismissed for allowing boys and girls to sit together. “Such charges are totally baseless. I have not objected to the students sitting together. The teacher was terminated because of insubordination and rude behaviour towards the principal when inquired about his lack of class control in UG and PG classes,” she said, adding that the decision to dismiss the teacher was taken in consultation with the college management and that there was no need to discuss the matter with the students as it was an administrative matter.

Police removed the protesting students around 6pm. The college authorities have given two-day holiday for the college in view of the protests.

Title: Highest ever water bird count recorded at Mahanadi census
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

CUTTACK: A record number of birds — 28,569 to be exact — were counted during the 5th River Mahanadi (Banki to Jobra) Odisha Water Birds Census, conducted by Wild Orissa under the aegis of Asian Water Birds (AWC) on Sunday.

The AWC is an annual exercise — and part of the International Water Birds Census — which is coordinated by the Bombay Natural History Society nationally and Wild Orissa in the state.

Secretary of WO and AWC’s Odisha coordinator, Monalisa Bhujabal, said 71 species were seen during the census, which covered a 50km stretch of the Mahanadi from Banki to Jobra. “The 2020 census figure of 28,569 water birds is the highest ever. The species diversity of 71 is also the highest we have found during the bird census. The last high was 58, recorded during 2018,” Bhujabal said.

Many rare and endangered bird species were recorded during the census, including Black Bellied Tern, Oriental Darter, Great Thick Knee, River Lapwing and River Tern, said Bhujabal added.

Convener of WO’s Bhubaneswar Regional Chapter, Suchitra Sahoo, supervised the census, in which more than 60 volunteers participated. Twelve census units counted the water birds on the Mahanadi, as well as on the wetlands and water-bodies on either side of the river bank, which form part of the Mahanadi riverine ecosystem.

“The data is being analysed in detail. The preliminary findings show that the Mahanadi ecosystem is extremely rich in avifaunal diversity and needs to be protected under the appropriate legal system. There is an immediate need to scale up the importance of this stretch of the Mahanadi under international monitoring systems,” AWC’s Odisha coordinator said.

An official release issued by WO on Monday said the result of the census would be used to promote national water bird and wetland conservation and international cooperation along the Central Asian Flyway and the East Asian-Australasian Flyway.

River Mahanadi falls within the Central Asian Flyway, which is the shortest flyway for migratory birds in the world. It lies entirely within the northern hemisphere and connects a large swathe of the palaearctic with the Indian subcontinent.

Title: Punjab Cabinet call on resolution today
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Amarinder Singh

CHANDIGARH: The Punjab council of ministers would on Tuesday deliberate on introducing a resolution against the controversial Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) in the special session of the state legislative assembly on January 16 and 17.

Discussions will be held on the line to be followed to oppose the exercise of National Population Register (NPR) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC). Chief minister Amarinder Singh has already declared that he would not allow implementation of CAA in the state. Kerala legislative assembly had passed a resolution to voice its opposition to the citizenship legislations on December 31.

In a meeting at New Delhi on Monday, Congress-led opposition parties passed a resolution to work towards withdrawal of the controversial CAA and put an immediate stop to NPR.

Title: Safety, a blind spot for budget schools
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: The recent incident of an eight year-old student coming under the wheels of his school bus has raised multiple questions on how “budget schools” may be compromising on safety.

Budget schools is a term broadly applied to unaided private schools that cater to the lower economic strata and charge an annual fee of around Rs10,000-12,000.

One of the blind spots for such schools that operate on a bare minimum is transportation safety due to the absence of departmental scrutiny plus, unfortunately, the financial aspect of it.

“Instead of the normal Rs40,000 cost of the bus services, budget schools avail it for Rs20,000,” said Santosh Jog, president of School Bus Owners’ Association. “Bus owners make it financially viable by plying their vehicles at three different schools on the same day rather than being embedded with a single institution,” he said, adding that they strongly discourage membership for such bus companies in their association.

“The bus is then perpetually running from one place to the other picking up students from every by-lane and hence they don’t care about keeping a conductor or ensuring that a teacher is accompanying the bus,” said Jog.

He said all their members follow the guidelines strictly and have CCTVs installed as well.

There are safety guidelines issued by the court and also separately by CBSE which say that every bus must have a conductor as well as a teacher on board. If an incident occurs and neither of the two are on board, then the principal has to take responsibility according to the Headmasters’ Association ( Nagpur district ). Madhusudhan Mude, president of Headmasters Association (Nagpur district), said, “The reason for an accident is part of the investigation, but for schools, the immediate responsibility is to ensure compliance of the guidelines. I strongly feel that principals must be held accountable if they cannot ensure the presence of their teachers in these buses.”

He agreed that budget schools need to be supervised more aggressively.

The traffic police have already ramped up their action against violators. Chinmay Pandit, DCP (traffic) said, “We will be proceeding with a two pronged approach. First, will be action against violators while the second will be to create awareness. On Monday itself we took action against 215 violators. Now we will be interacting with schools and fleet owners to ensure that they are aware of the guidelines.”

There are just over 1,500 schools in the city with an overwhelming majority of them being budget schools. They run in congested by-lanes or residential areas with no playgrounds, proper safety or qualified teachers. But they cater to the aspiration of the lower economic class to send children to English medium schools. The downside is compromise on safety features, especially with transportation by bus. Parents can't afford to pay more and schools in turn can't provide value added services.

Title: Partap Singh Bajwa says he won’t back Captain Amarinder Singh if biggies go scot-free
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Captian Amarinder Singh

CHANDIGARH: Reacting to Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh ’s statement that he would want to continue in the saddle for another term, Congress Rajya Sabha member Partap Singh Bajwa on Monday said he would not support any such move until convincing action is taken in the sacrilege incidents. Capt Amarinder’s party colleague also advised him to pass on the baton is case he didn’t intend to take control and rein in the bureaucracy in the state.

Bajwa said he wouldn’t want to share the dais with the CM if the state government under him failed to act against those behind sacrilege but Amarinder still decided to run for another term. “The big names involved in sacrilege have to be taken to task,” he said. Commenting on Amarinder’s announcement not to quit politics until every family gets a job, Bajwa said such a task had not been achieved “even in a country like Switzerland, and Punjab cannot think of doing it any time soon”.

The former Congress state president also made a case for the Congress government renegotiating the power purchase agreements (PPAs) with the private plants in the interest of the consumers.

“Today, Akali Dal has begun targeting the Congress on the issue because we did not act for three years. If the chief minister of a state wants, it is not possible that the terms of the agreements cannot be reworked. There should be a white paper on the issue along with a technical audit. Otherwise, power consumers will have to face many more hikes,” he said.

“I am no fan of AAP’s ideology, but I appreciate Arvind Kejriwal managed to renegotiate the power tariff in Delhi. The Akali Dal has got a chance to accuse the Congress because did not act. The economically weak Dalits are worst affected by the higher tariff. Why hasn’t finance minister Manpreet Singh Badal put his foot down for renegotiating the purchase agreements?” he said. “The Punjab Assembly is set to meet this week and I would appeal to my party colleagues that they would take up the issue of power tariff in the session,” he added.

Title: Public works department eyes green technology for building roads
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: The public works department is considering a plan to adopt a pollution-free green road concept as part of which several stretches of roads in the state will be constructed in a sustainable and environment-friendly manner.

Under the plan, the works department here will collaborate with the CSIR-Central Road Research Institute (CRRI) in New Delhi, which will provide the BitChem ColdMix Technology that will be used in road construction in the state.

Experts said BitChem ColdMix is a technology that ensures zero pollution as it requires no heating. It is an energy-efficient and eco-friendly method of road construction that helps mitigate carbon footprint and also prevents adverse effects on the health of workers.

The move comes after CRRI director Satish Chandra recently wrote to chief minister Naveen Patnaik requesting him for a large-scale adoption of CRRI-BitChem ColdMix Technology to build pollution-free green roads in the state.

“Owing to no heating during black-topping activities, the technology helps secure the social impact of removing drudgery for the road construction workers by eliminating health hazards and providing a pollution-free construction,” Chandra had written about the BitChem ColdMix Technology.

He had further said this simple construction mechanism also enhances the speed of construction and presence of additives leads to longer durability compared to conventional hot-mix technology.

“We propose large-scale adoption of this innovative technology to all the states. This can be made a success by engaging in a long-term technology management agreement with CRRI and our technology partner M/s Bitchem,” Chandra had written.

A senior works department official said that they will go for the implementation of theis technology on a pilot basis, following which a large-scale adoption of the technology will be made. “We will first assess the outcome and then go for a larger-scale replication of the technology in the state,” the official added.

Road expert Sayed Maqbool Ali too said ColdMix is an innovative technology that will help construct roads in an eco-friendly manner.

“The state should consider the adoption of the green technology in large scale,” he added.

Title: North Gujarat student will study on vultures’ ecological impact in Poland
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Jill Patel

PALANPUR: A MSc final year student of Life Sciences in Hemchandracharya North Gujarat University has gone to Poland to further her studies on disappearing vultures and the dis-balance this has created in the socio-ecological sphere.

Jill Patel has left for Poland on Friday as part of student exchange programme after a MoU was signed with Polish Academy of Sciences. Her doctoral thesis on ‘Ecological Service Provided by Vulture’, based on particularly the funeral customs of the Parsi community, who dispose of their dead at the “Tower of Silence” for vultures to feed.

Jill is studying on how the community is being inconvenienced after the bird species started to dwindle in numbers rapidly.

Her guide Nishith Dharaiya, assistant professor of life sciences at the university had trained her for three months, while in Poland Jill will be guided in her research work by professor from the Polish Academy of Science, Nuria Selva, for another three months until March end.

The researcher will be given free accommodation and other facilities like institute fee, lab fee by the Polish government for her research work.

Dhariya, who had done research on sloth bears in North Gujarat, told TOI: “Jill was selected for the thesis on merit basis both by the local guide as well as the Polish guide, Selva. The aim of her study is to rethink on an alternative to the age-old Parsi ritual in view of declining population of vultures. We have also contacted around 80 people including priests in south Gujarat where the community thrives in large numbers for their perspectives in our study.”

Title: No valid licence, 10% cut from accident victim compensation
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Chennai: An accident claims tribunal in the city fixed 10% liability on an autorickshaw driver who was killed in a road accident for driving without a valid licence at the time of the accident. Rahul, 19, was killed as a truck rammed his autorickshaw. After making the cut , the tribunal directed the firm with which the truck was insured to pay Rs 17.41 lakh as compensation to Rahul’s family. In their appeal for compensation, Rahul’s parents said their son was driving his auto on Muthukumarasamy Salai in Chennai when a rashly driven truck rammed it, killing Rahul on the spot. The accident happened in December 2016. The family moved the tribunal seeking a compensation of Rs 60 lakh. The insurer of the truck contended that Rahul did not possess a valid licence at the time of the accident and hence said it cannot be held liable to pay compensation. After perusing the submissions, the tribunal noted that the accident happened only due to the rash driving by the truck driver. After computing various factors such as Rahul’s young age and his future prospects, the tribunal arrived at Rs 19.35 lakh as compensation. Of this amount, the tribunal fixed a 10% liability on the deceased and directed the insurance firm to deposit Rs 17.41 lakh to the family.

Title: Maximum fine for littering now Rs 5 lakh in Ahmedabad
Content:
6,000 odd CCTV cameras powered by special artificial intelligence which can detect littering without a human ... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Hold back litterbugs ! Before you toss that Re 1 worth of candy wrapper onto a public space, it should be clear that it may cost you a bomb. Fines for littering has been raised to Rs 5,000 and will go up to Rs 5 lakh — depending on the severity of the offence.Watching you are civic body’s 6,000 odd CCTV cameras powered by special artificial intelligence which can detect littering without a human interface and so will 48 teams of Jet (Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC)-City police Joint enforcement team ) autorickshaws sputtering on city roads in search of their next litterbug. On the AMC’s crosshairs are residential societies and industrial estates in the city’s immediate vicinity where problems of illegal dumping on public roads is quite rampant.The Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation has decided that industries and business organizations that litter on the roads will be penalized with heavy fines. The fine will vary upon the nature of business and the area. If an individual was caught littering, spitting on the road or easing himself in the open the fine will be in the range of Rs 100 to Rs 500.Municipal Commissioner Vijay Nehra said that the stringent fines are for those commercial establishments, shops, malls, cinema halls that litter once the area is cleaned. Even those residential societies that throw their garbage which is collected outside their societies will also be liable to pay heavy fines up to Rs 5 lakh.Nehra said, “In the morning, that is from 7-10am the areas are cleaned and they look clean till 11am. Later, the garbage is dumped on roads again by commercial establishment, and such establishments will be fined heavily. Moreover, roadside vendors also leave leftovers on the streets and will be fined,” said Nehra. The city looks dirty only because of these 2% people and hence there is a need to penalize them he said.Citing an example, a senior AMC officer said that if a doctor throws his bio-waste on the road the doctor will be charged anything in the range of Rs2-5 lakh, but if a small businessman throws his waste outside his shop he will be fined Rs5,000. If a bungalow scheme in Satellite dumps its waste in the open till the time AMC vehicle comes, such society will be fined heavily and up to Rs 5 lakh.

Title: Ahmedabad: One day before Uttarayan, 480 IMFL bottles seized
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A day before Uttarayan , city crime branch seized Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) worth Rs 1,68,000 from an MUV near Odhav after a car chase. However, crime branch said two other SUVs, which tried to intercept the private cars in which the cops were travelling, managed to give them the slip.

Crime branch officials said the IMFL was being brought from Rajasthan for listed bootlegger Devendra Parihar alias Bansi. “We have registered a case against Bansi, the two persons, including one Vishal who fled from the car, and those who were in the two SUVs.

Crime branch officials said their team was on patrol on Sunday night, when about 1am they received a tip-off that an MUV without a registration number plate and carrying liquor is coming from Dehgam side.

“We laid a watch near Dehgam Circle. After a while we saw an MUV matching the description approaching Dehgam Circle. We signalled the driver to stop. The driver slowed the vehicle and suddenly sped off towards Odhav. We gave a chase in private cars. After a while two SUVs, also without registration number plates, started following the police cars and tried to intercept them,” said a crime branch official.

Crime branch sources said the crime branch teams continued the chase. “The MUV suddenly stopped as two of its tyres burst. Two people came out of the car and fled by jumping over the wall,” said a crime branch official. “We reached the car and found a mobile phone lying on the dashboard. The phone was on and the person on the other side was yelling ‘Bansi speaking, where have you reached?’ Then he suddenly said, ‘Run Vishal, run Vishal.’ We found 480 bottles of IMFL in the back of the car.”

Crime branch officials said they are hunting for Bansi and the others who had fled from the spot.

Title: Online complaints on mobile app of civic body a big hit
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: The ‘Bhubaneswar me’ app’s online grievance section has proved to be very popular with the people.

The number of complaints it has received online is higher than those the Bhubaneswar Municipal Corporation (BMC) has got offline.

The BMC has received 11,634 complaints, of which nearly 7,000 have been received online. The remaining have been registered on BMC’s toll-free landline number or through applications.

The BMC had launched the online grievance redress app in August 2018. People were not conversant with it initially but grievances started coming in from early 2019. Most complaints are related to street lights, parking, sanitation, planning, construction and holding tax.

“Of the 11,634 grievances, we have resolved 10,774. The remaining have been sent to various sections for resolution,” said a BMC officer. “Since the app has been integrated with all smart city-related apps and web portals, all concerned officers can see the complaints,” the officer added.

BMC officials said grievances received through applications or on the toll-free number were also recorded on the online platform. Citizens get an acknowledgement on their mobile number soon after a complaint is registered online.

“Earlier, we would have to go to the BMC office even for small matters. Now, all we need to do is download the app and post the complaint,” said Sitakanta Tripathy, a retired government employee of Sailashree Vihar.

Echoing a similar sentiment, resident Tribikram Chayani said, “I had posted a complaint about garbage being left unattended in our locality. I even posted a picture. The complaint was sent to the ward officer and then the sanitary inspector, who addressed it.”

Title: Form panel for Guru’s 400th birth anniversary
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

PM Narendra Modi

CHANDIGARH: Punjab CM Amarinder Singh has urged PM Narendra Modi to form a national-level committee to oversee the year-long 400th birth anniversary celebrations of ninth Sikh master Guru Teg Bahadur, on the lines of the 550th anniversary celebrations of Guru Nanak Dev.

In a letter to the PM, Amarinder said the state government planned to celebrate the historic occasion in a befitting manner with a series of programmes through the year, beginning April 2020. He said that Punjab government was already in the process of drawing up a detailed proposal for the commemoration of this mega event and the same would be shortly sent to the Centre.

The 400th birth anniversary of the ninth Sikh Guru is in April 2021, and the state government had already decided to commemorate the occasion with year-long celebrations beginning April 12.

Title: Rights over hukamnama sacrilegious
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

CHANDIGARH: The Badal family treated the live telecast of gurbani from Golden Temple as yet another business and pressurised the Shiromani Gurdwara Prabandhak Committee (SGPC) to give rights to the channel which they own, Punjab panchayats and rural development minister Tript Rajinder Singh Bajwa said on Monday. “Claiming rights over hukamnama (daily verse) and Sarb Sanjhi Gurbani telecast live from the Darbar Sahib amounted to sacrilege and it called for action as per the Sikh code of conduct against the culprits,” the minister added.

The private television channel, allegedly owned by Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) president Sukhbir Singh Badal and his family, had committed brazen sacrilege by claiming exclusive rights over hukamnama that is telecast live from the Golden Temple, Bajwa said.

Bajwa questioned the authority of the SGPC to hand over telecast rights as its duty was to carry it to every corner of the world and not authorise any other agency that would be interested only in profits.

Title: 120-year-old tehsil office picture of government neglect
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

A part of the tehsil premises has turned into a grazing ground for goats and cows

KENDRAPADA: Hundreds of rare and valuable documents, land records, journals, books, palm leafs and other papers have become brittle with age and are gathering dust in the 120-year-old tehsil office at Rajkanika in Kendrapada district.

Built in 1900 by Rajendra Narayan Bhanjadeo, the then king of Kanika, the century-old tehsil office is spread over two acres and was conceived to store land records and other documents. Bhanjadeo owned large tracts of land in Kendrapada, Bhadrak, Cuttack , Balasore and other districts of the state during the Raj era.

After Independence, the government abolished the estates of the Raja of Kanika and acquired the tehsil office as per the 1952 Odisha Estate Abolition Act. But thanks to the alleged negligence of the state government, the tehsil building in Rajkanika lies in a dilapidated condition.

“Though the building has its own unique architecture, it cannot withstand the vagaries of time without proper care. It used to be regarded as a treasure house of Rajkanika history, but it’s now a pale shadow of its former glorious self,” Subharansu Sutar of Rajkanika said.

A part of the tehsil premises has turned into a grazing ground for goats and cows. “The building is crumbling owing to the neglect of the district administration,” Kaliprasad Nayak, a retired teacher of Rajkanika, said.

When contacted, tehsildar (Rajkanika) DSS Joshi, said, “The tehsil office is not in good shape. The district administration had recently decided to build a new building at Rajkanika by demolishing the old one.”

The building serves as reminder of the history of Kendrapada. “It is time the government renovated it. We will oppose its demolition,” Mrutunjaya Samal, a lawyer, said.

Title: HC: Sculpture grads must get priority for sthapathi posts
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Chennai: Right to employment is a fundamental right and when a special institution is created for a specific purpose, it is the duty of the state to make way for adequate employment opportunities for graduates of such institutions, the Madras high court observed on Monday and directed the government to give ‘first priority’ to graduates from Government College of Architecture and Sculpture while filling the posts of engineers, draftsman and sthapathis.

The posts are for the newly constituted renovation and conservation wing under the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments (HR&CE) department.

Justice R Mahadevan passed the order on a plea moved by D V Murugan seeking direction to the authorities to appoint the sthapathi degree holders from Government College of Architecture and Sculpture, Mamallapuram , in the post meant for assistant engineer in every zonal office or alternately make provisions for appointment of such graduates as sthapathis as done in Andhra Pradesh in each division taking into consideration the number of temples in a particular division under the HR&CE department.

Allowing the plea, the judge said: “The knowledge in civil engineering alone is not sufficient to cater to the needs of renovation of temples including sculpting. Whereas, the students from the sculpting college or any other institution covering the field, who are also taught architecture and design with thorough knowledge in sculpting, would be eligible to be appointed in the HR&CE department.”

The appointment of such successful candidates as sthapathis would lessen the financial burden on the exchequer as they would be in a position to carry out minor repair work on their own with less role from third parties and they could perform twin functions of an engineer and that of sthapathi, Justice Mahadevan added. The court also directed the state to finalise and bring to life the Tamil Nadu Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments engineering and subordinate service rules in three months.

Title: BJP readies list of new dist chiefs
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: BJP is finalising the names of its district presidents. State committee member V V Rajesh will take over as president of the Thiruvananthapuram committee, the party’s most coveted district unit in the state.

After being suspended from organizational duties of the party for a brief period, for allegedly leaking to the media an in-house inquiry report that placed party general secretary M T Ramesh in the dock, Rajesh was reinducted into the state committee after P S Sreedharan Pillai replaced Kummanam Rajasekharan as the state chief. Regarded as a staunch loyalist of former state president and now union minister, V Muraleedharan, Rajesh is also in the good books of the RSS leadership. He was at the forefront of the Sabarimala agitation and enjoys a rapport with leaders and cadres, cutting across group lines.

The faction led by Muraleedharan and P K Krishnadas is all set to claim victory when presidents to 12 committees are announced, following consultations with the RSS leadership. Kannur and Kasaragod committee chiefs are yet to finalized, purportedly for want of the stamp of approval from the RSS.

In Pathanamthitta, where BJP has made deep inroads in recent years, Kulanada Ashokan is due to retain his post. In Thrissur, K K Aneeshkumar, the party’s district general secretary, will assume the office. BJP state secretary V K Sajeevan will be the new president in Kozhikode. In Kottayam, incumbent N Hari, who faced allegations of vote trading during the Pala bypoll, will continue to occupy the office. There is no clarity on the next chief of the Ernakulam committee. BJP may announce the list of presidents in a day or two. The state president is expected to be named in another week with party general secretary K Surendran having emerged as the frontrunner. Earlier, it was set to be announced by January 15. The full-time national president of the party could be named by January 26.

Title: Coimbatore to get 15 feeder ambulances
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Coimbatore region’s 108 operations is all set to get 15 feeder ambulances in the next three months. These are covered stretchers which will be attached to bikes, and will enable quick extractions from very narrow lanes in small villages or even extremely muddy roads where an ambulance cannot enter or will get stuck.

108 authorities in Coimbatore confirmed that the state government and GVK EMRI have decided to introduce the feeder ambulances as a pilot project. “These ambulances have already been tried in north India and in Andhra Pradesh and we have got positive feedback from them,” said an official. “The vehicles are as narrow as a hatchback car, making it easier to drive into extremely narrow lanes in rural areas and small villages.”

The feeder ambulances may drive the patient all the way to the closest government hospital for first aid treatment or to a rendezvous point and then transfer the patient to a full-fledged ambulance.

Of the 15 feeder ambulances, seven have been allocated to Coimbatore, five to the Nilgiris and three to Tirupur. 108 operators in the district believe this will make extractions faster. “At present, if the lane is too narrow for the ambulance to enter people carry the patient on a stretcher to the vehicle, and this takes time,” says manager Selvamuthukumar. “If it is successful and we see good benefits, the state government may sanction more such vehicles,” he said. “While bike ambulances don’t have stretchers attached, these feeder ambulances do.”

Additionally, some of 108 ambulance vehicles will be fixed with upgraded mountain rescue stretchers. These will be used in cases where even bike ambulances or feeder ambulances will not be able to enter. “The old stretchers have a flat base and straps which help only patients with suspected spine injuries. The new stretchers will be like dollies, where the base is slightly more flexible and will have railings on all four sides, so the patient will not roll off and will be comfortable when being carried down,” said Selvamuthukumar. All the four stretchers assigned to Coimbatore have been allocated to Valparai.

Title: New building at Gangadhar Meher University to tide over classroom shortage
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

SAMBALPUR: A new academic building is set to come up on the premises of the Gangadhar Meher University ( GMU ) to solve the problem of shortage of classrooms in an ever-growing varsity.

UC Pati, deputy registrar of GMU, said, “The university has been facing problems owing to the shortage of classrooms for a very long time. The number of departments has increased. Four new departments were opened recently. However, there aren’t enough classrooms in the varsity. But the new academic building will help resolve the problem to some extent.”

The work of the building, which will house 15 classrooms for the students of the institution, has already begun. The ground plus two-storey building is being constructed over an area of 756 square metres. A target has been set to complete the construction of the new academic building within a year. Estimated to be built for around Rs 2.64 crore, the work of the building is being executed by the Central Public Works Department (CPWD).

Pati said the Rashtriya Uchachatar Shiksha Abhiyan (RUSA) has sanctioned Rs 27.5 crore to the GMU for various development work of the institution. The new academic building is being constructed from the funds sanctioned by the RUSA. At present, there are about 40 classrooms in the varsity, which offers 26 PG coures, 27 UG courses, 10 PhD and 19 MPhil courses apart from the self-financing ones. The student strength of the varsity is around 5,500.

Pati further said, “An administrative block has also been proposed to be constructed on the premises of the institution. The offices of the vice-chancellor, registrar, deputy registrar and some other officials of the varsity, which is functioning from the existing building, will be shifted to the administrative building once it is complete. The varsity will get 15 more rooms. These rooms could also be used as classrooms.”

Title: 120-year-old tehsil office picture of government neglect
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

A part of the tehsil premises has turned into a grazing ground for goats and cows

KENDRAPADA: Hundreds of rare and valuable documents, land records, journals, books, palm leafs and other papers have become brittle with age and are gathering dust in the 120-year-old tehsil office at Rajkanika in Kendrapada district.

Built in 1900 by Rajendra Narayan Bhanjadeo, the then king of Kanika, the century-old tehsil office is spread over two acres and was conceived to store land records and other documents. Bhanjadeo owned large tracts of land in Kendrapada, Bhadrak, Cuttack , Balasore and other districts of the state during the Raj era.

After Independence, the government abolished the estates of the Raja of Kanika and acquired the tehsil office as per the 1952 Odisha Estate Abolition Act. But thanks to the alleged negligence of the state government, the tehsil building in Rajkanika lies in a dilapidated condition.

“Though the building has its own unique architecture, it cannot withstand the vagaries of time without proper care. It used to be regarded as a treasure house of Rajkanika history, but it’s now a pale shadow of its former glorious self,” Subharansu Sutar of Rajkanika said.

A part of the tehsil premises has turned into a grazing ground for goats and cows. “The building is crumbling owing to the neglect of the district administration,” Kaliprasad Nayak, a retired teacher of Rajkanika, said.

When contacted, tehsildar (Rajkanika) DSS Joshi, said, “The tehsil office is not in good shape. The district administration had recently decided to build a new building at Rajkanika by demolishing the old one.”

The building serves as reminder of the history of Kendrapada. “It is time the government renovated it. We will oppose its demolition,” Mrutunjaya Samal, a lawyer, said.

Title: Congress members block road in Rayagada over leader’s death
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

KORAPUT: Suspecting foul play and demanding an impartial inquiry into the death of Congress leader Purusottam Gamang, the party’s district unit observed a road blockade from 6 am to 2 pm at Bangi Chhack under Ramanaguda police station limits in Rayagada district on Monday.

“We suspect foul play in the death of Purushottam Gamang and demand the state government for a probe by either a special investigation team (SIT) or Crime Branch. If our demand is not met, then we will raise the issue in Parliament for a CBI inquiry,” said Saptagiri Ulaka, Koraput MP (Congress).

Gamang died in a road accident hours after the Rayagada district and sessions judge Soma Sekhar Jena declared his election as chairperson of Rayagada zilla parishad as null and void on December 24. While going to Gunupur from Rayagada in his motorcycle, Gamang met with an accident near Tandikana chhack, about 50 km from Rayagada, around 8 pm on December 24 and sustained head injuries. He was admitted to Ramanaguda hospital and subsequently to Gunupur hospital, where he died.

The motorcycle that Gamang was riding did not have a scratch even though it is said he died in a road accident. “If the case is not handed over either to the SIT or Crime Branch, then we will observe Rayagada and Koraput district bandhs in the coming days,” said Congress MLA from Jeypore Tara Prasad Bahinipati.

Taramani Gamang, mother of Purusottam, said her son has been murdered in a pre-planned manner. “My son has been murdered and I suspect the involvement of influential persons in it. I will fight till I get justice,” she said.

As a fallout of the road blockade, traffic came to a grinding halt between Rayagada and Gunupur while shops and markets remained open. Gamang was elected ZP chairperson in March 2017. BJD’s Gangadhar Puala, a contender for the post, had challenged it in the district court.

The district and sessions court annulled the election in December 2018 and Gamang approached the Orissa high court against the ruling. In September 2019, the high court directed Gamang to present his side in the Rayagada district and sessions court which again nullified the election on December 24.

Title: IRSE official’s tender fraud touches Rs 100 crore
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A railway contract fraud, involving South Central Railway project director (bridge works) M Ravindranath Reddy, an Indian Railway Service of Engineers ( IRSE ) officer, appears to be bigger than what CBI initially suspected. A back of the envelope calculation put it over Rs 100 crore, sources said.

So far, CBI has found that Rs 103 crore worth of railway projects were handed over to an ineligible company, Krishi Infratech, while Reddy was working as chief engineer in South Western Railway in Bengaluru.

CBI sleuths, who raided his official quarters in Hyderabad and Bengaluru on January 9, had booked three separate FIRs. In two of the FIRs, Ravindranath Reddy has been named as prime accused.

In the first FIR booked for cheating, criminal conspiracy and Prevention of Corruption Act, CBI named Ravindranath Reddy, Sherfuddin and P Mohanan — both deputy chief engineers— and Krishi Infratech partner M Suryanarayana Reddy as accused. In the FIR CBI alleged, “The fraud is about tenders released for construction of road over bridges, road under bridges and station buildings and foot over bridges between 2011 and 2018. Though Krishi Infratech was ineligible, norms were flouted to give contracts.”

The railway officials reportedly split the tender for the work worth Rs 76 crore into two for Rs 38 crore each and accommodated Krishi Infratech, which had eligibility to take up work up to Rs 50 crore. Also, Rs 54.2 crore was paid against the contract value of Rs 37.6 crore to Krishi. Similarly Rs 48.8 crore was paid against contract value of Rs 38.4 crore, though there was ample scope for inviting fresh tenders. The company was paid revised cost even before approval from the competent authority.

In the second FIR, which pertained to awarding contract for the Mysore-Ramanagaram doubling work, apart from Ravindranath Reddy, the agency had named Bhansode, a deputy chief engineer, and Suryanarayana Reddy as accused.

The eligibility criteria was that bidders should have completed execution of 19,640 cubic metres blanketing in similar work. The officials reportedly issued a false work completion certificate in June 2011 and ensured Krishi Infratech was eligible for the bids. The company failed to submit bank guarantee and the IRSE official showed undue favour by allowing a backdated bank guarantee. An additional Rs 1.43 crore was paid wrongfully, the FIR stated.

In the third case, CBI booked executive engineer Ghanshhyam Pradhan for having assets worth Rs 2.25 crore disproportionate to his known sources of income. CBI officials found that funds were transferred from the accounts of Krishi Infratech and Suryanarayana Reddy. He was looking after high-value work, including track doubling projects, between 2010 and 2019.

Title: Lal Darwaza bus stop to get heritage look
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Ahmedabad: The Ahmedabad Municipal Transport Service which has a fleet of 800 buses on road has decided to add 100 more CNG buses.

These will be acquired under the Chief Minister Urban Bus Service- CMBUS and will identify new areas where AMTS buses do not reach. The Lal Darwaza bus station will get a heritage look.

The AMTS on Monday cleared the Rs 498.20 crore budget for the year 2020-2021. It stated that bus stations currently near busy crossroads will be shifted to other locations to ease off congestion near the crossroads.

The AMC has also proposed to marginally increase the daily income per bus from Rs 3,230 to Rs 3,244. The AMTS budget mentioned that private operators have 606 buses on road and another 100 acquired under the CMBUS project will also be added to the fleet.

the AMTS stated many information technology projects have been implemented and this year the Automatic Vehicle Location system will also be implemented for all buses.

The AMTS has also decided to upgrade Vasna, Naroda, Millatnagar and Shreenath depot. These depots will now be upgraded and will have concrete roads.

Title: Drive to fill up nearly 8,000 police vacancies soon: HM
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Amravati: Assuring that state government was committed to maintaining law and order, Maharashtra home minister Anil Deshmukh said a recruitment drive to fill up nearly 8,000 vacancies will be launched soon to strengthen the police force.

Deshmukh was speaking at the 51st death anniversary function of JD Patil alias Babasaheb Sangludkar at Smt Kokilabai Gawande Mahila Mahavidyalaya in Daryapur on Monday.

Advising rural youths to focus on various competitive exams besides preparing for police recruitment, Deshmukh expressed concern over increasing number of student suicides and urged parents not to burden their children with undue expectations.

Stating that stringent laws for curbing atrocities against women were under active consideration of the government, Deshmukh said steps would also be taken to end illegal moneylending and Naxalism.

State’s women and child development minister Yashomati Thakur said stringent measures would be initiated to clamp down on child labour practices and ensure child security. She also assured comprehensive steps to tackle malnutrition.

Former deputy speaker of assembly Sharad Tasre was in the chair while Daryapur MLA Balwant Wankhade, ZP chairperson Jayantrao Deshmukh, former minister Ranjit Deshmukh and former MLA Amar Kale were also present on the occasion.

Title: Proposed Christ statue triggers row in Karnataka
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

KANAKAPURA: The Sangh Parivar on Monday demanded that the Karnataka government reverse its decision to allot land for a 114-foot-high statue of Jesus Christ in Kapalabetta by January 25 or face further protests.

Congress MLA DK Shivakumar had laid the foundation stone for the statue on December 25.

Hundreds of Hindu Jagaran Vedike workers took part in the “Kanakapura Chalo” march amid heavy police deployment on Monday. They also submitted a memorandum to the government.

After the march, the Sangh Parivar passed a resolution: “If you (state government) don’t act by January 25, we will step up our protest and won’t stop till we succeed.”

The resolution wants work at Kapalabetta halted, cases against officials who allowed construction before the pasture land was allotted to the trust, and a strong anti-conversion law in the state.

Title: 4 held for bid to attack councillor’s husband
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Chennai: A four-member gang that tried to attack the husband of Thiruvalangadu union councillor in Tiruvallur was nabbed by residents on Monday. The residents gave the assailants a sound thrashing before handing them over to police. Police identified the arrested as Vishnu, 22, and Nitheshkumar, 19, of Rajapadmanabapuram, and Iyyappan, 22, and Abdul Razzaq, 19, of Perumpakkam.

Jeeva won the councillor post in the recently concluded local body polls. Since the panchayat union president post was reserved for women, Jeeva was in fray for the post. Jeeva’s husband has been trying to garner support for her election as president, police said. Rivals may have engaged henchmen to eliminate Jeeva’s husband to have a better chance at winning the president’s post, police said. On seeing the four men near Kosasthalaiyar riverbank on Sunday, villagers caught them and thrashed them as they allegedly possessed weapons. They informed police and handed over the suspects. Police have registered a case and launched a probe. TNN

Title: City outskirts witness real estate boom
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The proposal to set up the executive capital in the outskirts of Visakhapatnam has resulted in a real-estate boom towards Vizianagaram and Bhogapuram, way beyond GVMC limits and outside the district.

Sources in CREDAI disclosed that there was a major real estate boom in these areas, even more than the outskirts of Visakhapatnam. They pointed out that plots in areas beyond Visakhapatnam district towards Vizianagaram and Bhogapuram were not only more affordable, but also far closer to the area earmarked for building the executive capital.

Chilukuri Srinivas, vice-president, CREDAI, said, “It is quite natural for real estate boom to occur in these areas. Colonies within GVMC limits have been built choc-a-block and most of the projects are apartment projects. But beyond Tagarapuvalasa, towards Bhogapuram and Vizianagaram, there are many large gated housing site projects which are still affordable. Hence, the boom.”

Srinivas added that the boom in these areas was touching a100% mark after the executive capital proposal was made. “ If you take the 7km stretch just beyond Tagarapuvalasa, where Visakhapatnam district ends and Vizianagaram district begins, the hike in the last one month has been 100%.

The rate per square yard towards Bhogapuram has gone up from Rs 10,000 to Rs 15,000. However, towards Vizianagaram town, the jump is 100 per cent from close to Rs 10,000 up to Rs 20,000.” Explaining the reasons for the incredible jump in rate per square yard, Srinvas pointed that a plot of land will always have better value than an apartment, which is one of the reasons many are willing to invest in plots.

He added that people would prefer to buy a plot of 200 square yards for Rs 20,000 per square yard, rather than a 1,000 square-feet apartment for the same price in Madhurawada area. “Vizianagaram and Bhogapuram would be far closer to the administrative area, rather than much of the present city of Visakhapatnam,” he said.

The number of VMRDA approved layouts are also on the rise, sources in the Engineering department pointed out. There are close to 100 approved gated housing communities towards Vizianagaram and Bhogapuram.

Title: Meet between farmers, mining cos on ore transportation inconclusive
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Bicholim: A meeting between mining company officials and farmers, held on Monday in the office of the Bicholim deputy collector, to resolve the issue of transportation of mining ore through Mayem village, remained inconclusive.

Mayem farmers had opposed ore transportation through the village and had demanded compensation for damaged farms. They also threatened to stop it till their demands are met.

While mining company officials claimed the Mayem road is demarcated as district road and they are well within their rights to use it to transport ore, the farmers showed a Central government circular that clearly states that any road that goes through a village should not be used for mining ore transportation.

Title: Goa government circular eroding autonomy of panchayats
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

The circular issued on January 7 requires builders to approach block development officers for occupancy certif... Read More

PANAJI: Congress on Monday insisted that the government was trying to undermine local self-governing bodies by curtailing the powers of panchayats in issuing construction and occupancy licences for housing or commercial projects.

Party office-bearers had a meeting to discuss the issue where they demanded that the panchayat department withdraw their January 7 circular.

The party’s panchayat raj cell had convened a meeting of sarpanchs, deputy sarpanchs and panchas of village panchayats in Goa at the Congress house to discuss the latest circular.

Several panchas said that the government was trying to weaken the autonomy of panchayats in the garb of garbage management.

Spokesperson Tulio de Souza said the circular, initiated by panchayat minister Mauvin Godinho, will increase corruption, both at the state government level as well as at the panchayat level. “This circular must be scrapped as this circular is the murder of self-governance,” said de Souza.

Panchas said that the government had never discussed the move to involve block development officers and the director of panchayat in the process to grant occupancy certificates and construction licences.

“All the panchayats will come together and lock our offices and submit the keys to the panchayat director,” Chinchinim – Deussua panchayat member John Bedo Pereira said.

Meanwhile, Goa Congress Panchayat Raj Sanghatna, chairman, Joseph Sequeira, blamed the government for not assisting panchayats in garbage management.

Title: New session begins in JNU. But it doesn’t
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

JNUTA members raise slogans against the VC, blaming him for the violence that erupted on the campus

NEW DELHI: Confusion prevailed on JNU campus on Monday as teacher and student bodies rejected the university administration’s call to resume classes.

The JNU Teachers’ Association (JNUTA) said that there was no question of starting the winter session when virtually no exams were held in the monsoon semester. The administration, in turn, issued a notice to the teachers for not carrying out their duties. As a result, even as all schools opened, there were no classes. JNUSU, too, issued a boycott call.

In the morning, JNUTA members raised slogans against vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar, blaming him for the violence that had erupted on the campus on January 5. They alleged that Kumar was involved in several discrepancies and called for his ouster, a demand they again raised at a meeting with MHRD later in the day.

Bikramaditya Choudhary, a teacher, said: “When exams for the monsoon semester have not taken place, how can there be a question of starting the winter session?”

Earlier in the day, the administration came out with an advisory and urged teachers to resume classes in the interest of students. It claimed that 12 deans and seven chairpersons of special centres had appealed to students and teachers to “refrain from any activity that would hinder the conducive atmosphere in the functioning of the university”. However, there was no clarity on the identity of these deans and chairpersons.

Dean of School of International Studies, Ashwini Mohapatra, a member of the breakaway JNU Teachers’ Federation, claimed that classes did not happen even though a few students did turn up.

The administration said the appeal was issued after two JNUTA office-bearers announced a “non-cooperation” plan. “The above call for non-cooperation not only goes against the efforts of the administration for restoration of normalcy on campus and resumption of academic activities, but also reflects the intention of JNUTA to disrupt normal functioning of the university (sic),” it said, adding the new semester had begun with registration of more than 5,000 students.

JNUTA, however, said that “it rejects totally the advisory issued by the administration and the warnings issued to it against organising assemblies around the academic complex”. “Teachers need no lesson on their duties or their norms of conduct from those who are guilty of using thugs to terrorise the university community and yet pretend they are governing an institution of higher learning,” it said.

Title: Battle of Badangpet: 158 in fray for 32 wards
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Political parties and independent candidates in Badangpet are gearing up for municipal election scheduled on January 22. A total of 158 candidates are fighting for the 32 wards under Badangpet Municipal Corporation which is spread over 74.59 square km and houses a population over two lakh.

The newly formed corporation, as of now, has five officials who have been deputed from various state government departments and 170 outsourced employees. There are 98,038 voters under the civic body with 132 polling stations assigned by the state election authorities. Once the elections conclude, the former gram panchayat will get a mayor who will also head the newly formed standing committee.

All major political parties including TRS, Congress and the BJP have filed their candidates ahead elections. Some candidates have filed nominations as representatives from the AIMIM. Whether the candidates were given the Form-Bs by the party will be revealed on January 14.

Political parties have already set up party offices in the municipality with flex banners and wall posters seen all over. According to corporation employees, once the mayor is elected, they would brief him about the issues face by residents regarding water supply and sewage network. “The Hyderabad Metropolitan Water supply & Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) will look after the water supply in the corporation,” said an official.

“A total of eight villages together constitute the Badangpet Municipal Corporation. Four villages have been handed over to the HMWS&SB. The remaining four will also be handed over to them in due course,” said an official from the corporation. The five lakes which fall under Badangpet are Komatikunta (Almasguda), Sunnam Cheruvu (Nadergul), Kurmalguda Cheruvu, Beera Cheruvu(Nadergul), Marram Cheruvu(Nadergul). Verification revealed all five lakes are polluted.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Son of Congress heavyweight joins AAP
Content:
Vinay Mishra, son of former Congress MP Mahabal Mishra, was welcomed into AAP fold by CM Arvind Kejriwal on Mo... Read More

NEW DELHI: After five-time Matia Mahal MLA Shoaib Iqbal, Congress’ Vinay Mishra , a young functionary from west Delhi who is son of former party MP Mahabal Mishra , and Ram Singh Netaji from Badarpur joined Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) on Monday. Welcoming them with AAP caps, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal said they were joining the party to work together for a better Delhi. The new entrants said they were impressed with AAP’s governance.“I am happy that these leaders are joining us to work together to create a better future for Delhi. I am sure that the day is not far when all 2 crore people of Delhi will join AAP, though that would be just a formality as AAP already resides in their hearts,” Kejriwal said, adding that the newly inducted functionaries would strengthen the party.Singh, who was elected as an Independent MLA in 1998 and as a BSP candidate in 2008 from Badarpur, had unsuccessfully contested on a Congress ticket in both 2013 and 2015. Mishra had lost from Palam as a Congress candidate in 2013 and could manage to poll only a little over 19,500 votes.People were fed up with the politics of BJP and Congress because both parties did not deliver on their promises and had elected AAP five years ago, said Kejriwal. “AAP has stayed true to the promises made in its manifesto and won hearts of all. Whether a supporter of BJP, Congress or any other party, AAP has gained a place for itself in every heart because of its sincerity. AAP has managed to touch and transform their lives with its work and this time they will vote for AAP, irrespective of personal party affiliation,” the AAP national convener claimed.Some other functionaries who also joined AAP included Jai Bhagwan Upkar, BSP councillor of Rohini-C; and Rajkumari Dhillon, a former Congress councillor of Hari Nagar.Mishra, who has his roots in Bihar, said AAP’s work in unauthorised colonies and hospitals and on education had impressed him the most. “I have seen how people from UP, Bihar and other states had to struggle to get medical treatment, education and other facilities here. The condition of unauthorised colonies improved only after AAP came to power.”Singh, known to have a stronghold in Badarpur, said, “Everyone in Delhi has witnessed the hard work of Kejriwal and his government. Everybody is excited about AAP’s model of development. After a long stint in Congress, I want to be part of a system that delivers tangible welfare for Delhiites.”Miffed with Singh’s induction, Badarpur MLA Narayan Dutt Sharma demonstrated outside deputy CM Manish Sisodia’s house on Monday night.

Title: Badangpet: Home to defence scientists but it still lacks water
Content:
Bad roads, scarcity of drinking water, poor sewage networks and lack of a good transport system are the chief ... Read More

HYDERABAD: Once a village bearing a deserted look, in a span of eight years, areas under the Badangpet Municipal Corporation have now become home to several central government employees. Their major concern though is that the municipality still lacks basic infrastructure. Bad roads, scarcity of drinking water, poor sewage networks and lack of a good transport system are the chief complaints of residents in the area.“After re-carpeting roads, authorities are have simply filled the corners up with granite blocks which has irked commuters. Poor illumination, unattended garbage and a bad sewage network are the other problems which haunt residents,” said G Gyaneshwar, a resident. Many also complain that open plots are being used to dump garbage.“We receive water only once a week,” said R Anita Gupta, a resident of Badangpet’s Beerappa Colony. Verification by TOI revealed that even in gated communities, residents face a severe water scarcity problem. Many still don’t have drinking water supply and are dependent on borewells.“There is a school in this area, yet piles of garbage dot this stretch. This has put the health of our children at stake,” said a central government employee. With DRDO, DLRL and Adavanced System Laboratory (ASL), residents in the area include officials, scientists and other employees of these corporations along and their families.For civic elections, their demands are an improvement in civic infrastructure and basic amenities.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Son of Congress heavyweight joins AAP
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Vinay Mishra, son of former Congress MP Mahabal Mishra, was welcomed into AAP fold by CM Arvind Kejriwal on Mo... Read More

NEW DELHI: After five-time Matia Mahal MLA Shoaib Iqbal, Congress’ Vinay Mishra , a young functionary from west Delhi who is son of former party MP Mahabal Mishra , and Ram Singh Netaji from Badarpur joined Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) on Monday. Welcoming them with AAP caps, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal said they were joining the party to work together for a better Delhi. The new entrants said they were impressed with AAP’s governance.

“I am happy that these leaders are joining us to work together to create a better future for Delhi. I am sure that the day is not far when all 2 crore people of Delhi will join AAP, though that would be just a formality as AAP already resides in their hearts,” Kejriwal said, adding that the newly inducted functionaries would strengthen the party.

Singh, who was elected as an Independent MLA in 1998 and as a BSP candidate in 2008 from Badarpur, had unsuccessfully contested on a Congress ticket in both 2013 and 2015. Mishra had lost from Palam as a Congress candidate in 2013 and could manage to poll only a little over 19,500 votes.

People were fed up with the politics of BJP and Congress because both parties did not deliver on their promises and had elected AAP five years ago, said Kejriwal. “AAP has stayed true to the promises made in its manifesto and won hearts of all. Whether a supporter of BJP, Congress or any other party, AAP has gained a place for itself in every heart because of its sincerity. AAP has managed to touch and transform their lives with its work and this time they will vote for AAP, irrespective of personal party affiliation,” the AAP national convener claimed.

Some other functionaries who also joined AAP included Jai Bhagwan Upkar, BSP councillor of Rohini-C; and Rajkumari Dhillon, a former Congress councillor of Hari Nagar.

Mishra, who has his roots in Bihar, said AAP’s work in unauthorised colonies and hospitals and on education had impressed him the most. “I have seen how people from UP, Bihar and other states had to struggle to get medical treatment, education and other facilities here. The condition of unauthorised colonies improved only after AAP came to power.”

Singh, known to have a stronghold in Badarpur, said, “Everyone in Delhi has witnessed the hard work of Kejriwal and his government. Everybody is excited about AAP’s model of development. After a long stint in Congress, I want to be part of a system that delivers tangible welfare for Delhiites.”

Miffed with Singh’s induction, Badarpur MLA Narayan Dutt Sharma demonstrated outside deputy CM Manish Sisodia’s house on Monday night.

Title: MMC cancels Mt Abu jaunt after criticism
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Margao: Following criticism from several quarters over the scheduled jaunt to Mt Abu, Rajasthan, by the councillors of the Margao Municipal Council ( MMC ), the chairperson, Pooja Naik, on Monday declared that the study tour has been cancelled as per the advice of Fatorda MLA Vijai Sardesai.

In a press statement, Naik said that the decision was taken “keeping in mind that our councillors should as far as possible avoid the exercise of going on tours at the cost of the tax payers”.

Naik even exhorted her fellow councillors to emulate Sardesai in not misusing the tax payer’s money. “Even in the past, the Fatorda MLA when a minister in the cabinet had not used a government vehicle and other perks. I request our councillors to follow suit and rethink the study tour which was meant to study ‘development of green spaces and parks’ under AMRUT scheme in Mt Abu,” Naik said.

Earlier in the day, a few Margao residents led by Savio Coutinho of the Shadow Council for Margao wrote to the director of municipal administration (DMA) and the MMC chief officer, questioning the logic of organising the tour at the fag-end of the council’s tenure.

Title: Telangana: Withdrawal deadline today, rebels stand their ground
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: While the deadline for withdrawal of nominations for the municipal elections ends on Tuesday, rebels from various parties, especially TRS , are unrelenting. Despite ruling party MLAs giving a try to convince the rebels, their efforts have failed to bear fruit.TRS working president KT Rama Rao held meetings with ministers, MLAs and party in-charges in the last couple of days, they could not succeed in convincing the rebels to withdraw from electoral fray. Following this, not only TRS even other political parties also have not issued Form-B to declare official candidates .For instance, as many as 134 TRS candidates filed nominations for 49 wards in Kamareddy municipality. In speaker Pocharam Srinivas Reddy’s Banswada constituency, 80 aspirants are in the fray from 19 wards. In Rajanna-Sircilla district, represented by KTR himself in the assembly, 276 candidates filed nominations hoping to get a chance to contest on the TRS symbol.Sources in State Election Commission (SEC) said that about 250 nominations had been withdrawn in the past two days. On an average, three to four nominations had been filed from each ward and each party, especially TRS.As many as 25,000 candidates have filed nominations in 130 local bodies. Parties have to submit Form-Bs before 3 pm on Tuesday.The rebel problem is not confined to TRS alone. Even Congress is facing a similar situation. In Kamareddy municipality, Congress has not declared official candidates as 115 nominations were submitted in 49 wards. “In some municipalities and wards, both Congress and BJP strategically have not issued Form-B as TRS rebels seek to contest on behalf of their parties,” sources said.Interestingly, some TRS aspirants have also filed nominations as representing from other parties like All-India Forward Bloc in municipalities like Kollapur where 57 candidates are contesting for TRS against the total of 20 wards. Both TRS MLA B Harshwardhan Reddy and ex-minister Jupally Krishna Rao’s groups have been fighting for political supremacy in the constituency.Sources said that in many places like Nizampet, Peerzadiguda, Boduppal and Badangpet municipal corporations, rebels have started campaigning without even waiting for Form-B.

Title: The race to improve response time
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

In a field where every minute matters, six months after GPS navigation systems were fitted into 108 ambulances in the district, the response time has come down by 1 minute and 13 seconds, shows data from the service operated by GVK EMRI. They say the 108 avasaram app introduction and usage has also helped in reducing the response time, because the location can easily be locked in and mapped.

However, authorities are now attempting to bring the time down by another 2 minutes. The response clocked in by 108 ambulances in the city since November till this week has been 14 minutes. This is one minute and 13 seconds lesser than the 15 minutes and 13 seconds being clocked in by the service even in September and October.

“The GPS that was fitted in all the vehicles six months ago and more people downloading and using the avasaram 108 app helped, because the location is easily locked and drivers just need to reach the location,” said Coimbatore manager of 108 ambulance Selvamuthukumar. “Earlier, we had to ask people for landmarks and directions, which used to delay us,” he said. “The app, when opened by the user, directly transmits the location to our centre in Chennai, from where the location is sent to the vehicle’s GPS.

While the avasaram 108 app is only available in google play store, even non-smart phone users or those without internet can transmit their location with a technology called dual tone multi-frequency. The location reaches the ambulance’s GPS directly.

“Despite technological advances, our response time is at least 5 minutes lesser than what 108 achieves in Chennai, which is 8 minutes, 48 seconds. This year, we are aiming to bring down our response time to 12 minutes. The difference in timing is also because of the work on bridges going on in the district, including at Kavundampalayam, Trichy Road and Aathupaalam,” said Selvamuthukumar. “It makes a difference because Mettupalayam Road and highways beyond Aathupaalam see a lot of road accidents.”

Title: 25-year-old held, 2 flee after gang attacks cop
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Chennai: A three-member gang attacked a sub-inspector on patrol near Pulianthope on Sunday night when the police officer was checking vehicles .

Sub-inspector Sathyamoorthy of the Pulianthope police station was posted for patrol in Kannigapuram when three men alighted from a vehicle and began verbally abusing him. They later attacked him. Sathyamoorthy managed to nab one of them. Police identified the man as Muthukumar, 25, of Kannigapuram. He revealed the identity of the two who escaped – ‘bomb’ Saravanan and Raji. Sathyamoorthy said the attackers were drunk at the time of incident.

Police have launched a hunt for the culprits.“We are checking CCTV camera footage in the locality,” said an investigation officer.

The Vepery police registered cases under seven sections of the IPC, including voluntarily causing hurt, rioting, using obscene words, assault on a public servant and preventing him from discharging his duty.

Earlier, a policeman was attacked in Gummidipoondi on Saturday when he tried to prevent a gang from attacking a labourer. TNN

Title: Hyderabad leads office space leasing after Bengaluru
Content:
In a report, CBRE South Asia said that Hyderabad’s office space has gone up in extended IT corridor and was ma... Read More

HYDERABAD: While Bengaluru continued to dominate office space leasing activity across the country, Hyderabad came out on top in adding new office space in 2019. Experts point out that Hyderabad has seen unprecedented growth in commercial leasing activity in last few years.Thanks to strong demand, attractive rentals and infrastructure push, the city has emerged as a major location for global investors. In a report, CBRE South Asia said that Hyderabad’s office space has gone up in extended IT corridor and was mainly driven by higher demand from IT/ITeS firms.According to Anshuman Magazine, chairman and CEO, CBRE India, the office sector growth was driven by demand from MNCs and local companies in Bengaluru and Hyderabad.Total leasing activity grew by over 25% in 2019, while rental values remained stable. New office space supply also rose to 52 million sq ft in 2019 from 35.7 million sq ft in 2018. In fact, gross leasing activity in 2019 touched a historic high of 61.6 million square ft, experts said.Bengaluru, Hyderabad, NCR Delhi and Mumbai dominated office space leasing accounting for 75% of overall space take-up. Annual space take-up increased in all cities except Kochi. Bengaluru continued to be the market leader with gross absorption of 15 million sq ft in 2019, while Hyderabad witnessed 9.5 million sq ft of gross absorption.Special Economic Zones accounted for one-third of leasing activity, mainly in Bengaluru and Hyderabad. Interestingly, a quarterly dip in supply and leasing activity was observed at 5% in the last quarter of 2019. Addition of office space supply in quarter IV reduced by more than 50% to 7.8 million sq ft in NCR Delhi, Pune, Hyderabad and Chennai.The real estate sector attracted both institutional investors and developers, with nearly $1.5 billion worth capital pumped in Quarter-IV of 2019. Hyderabad dominated in overall quarterly investments followed by Chennai and Mumbai.Overall investments in 2019 in the real estate sector reached $6.1 billion, out of which over 40% was in office sector. Mumbai dominated investments in office in 2019, followed by NCR Delhi and Hyderabad. “In the coming years, the real estate sector is expected to offer vast development and investment opportunities. Office stock is expected to grow to a billion sq ft by the end of 2030,” Anshuman Magazine said.The CBRE report also said that NCR Delhi and Bengaluru dominated large-sized deal closures in the last quarter of 2019. “However, a few large deals were also reported in Hyderabad, Chennai and Pune by tech firms, BFSI corporates and flexible space operators,” it added.

Title: Telangana: Rangoli comes in handy for TRS to drive ‘car’ around
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

A competition was organised at Lakkaram Tank Bund in Khammam where the TRS symbol was depicted in a decorative... Read More

HYDERABAD: Rangoli during Sankranti is being extensively by the ruling TRS to campaign for its candidates in the municipal polls. In Nalgonda and Khammam , women cadres of the party are portraying the car symbol of the party in rangoli done in front of their houses.

With Sankranti on Wednesday, a competition was organised for locals at Lakkaram Tank Bund in Khammam wherein the TRS symbol was depicted in a decorative huge rangoli on Sunday.The Lakkaram Tank Bund, which is a big tourist attraction, was opened in 2018.

“Publicising the car symbol in rangoli also benefits us as we can reduce the campaign costs,” transport minister Puvvada Ajay said while appealing to all the women cadre to showcase the car symbol in the rangoli traditionally done in front of the houses as part of the festival.

For TRS cadres, the idea is more than a suggestion as a ‘car’ displayed as part of the festivities will also give the candidates the assurance about which way the votes will swing. Rangoli will be used in all the five municipalities to campaign for the party in the elections.

Ajay credited IT minister KT Rama Rao with giving the idea for using rangoli as a campaign tool. He asked all the leaders of TRS in the municipalities to go from house to house telling the TRS cadre to display the car symbol’ in the rangoli. “This show of TRS symbol will give us an advantage over opposition parties,” he said.

It is not just the car symbol, the women cadre have also been advised to publicise the schemes implemented by the TRS government in the rangoli. In Nalgonda, at the instance of energy minister G Jagadish Reddy, TRS cadres on Monday displayed rangoli with the party symbol in front of their houses.

Title: Inaugurated on Jan 9, Khau Galli to be operational from Jan 26: NMC
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Nagpur: Four days after inaugurating Khau Galli at the hands of city MP and Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari, the BJP-ruled Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) said the food street located on banks of Gandhisagar Lake will be ready for Nagpurians from January 26.

There are 32 stalls and they were allotted to interested parties through draw of lots. A press release issued by the NMC said the stall owners will need shutters, counters and display boards and to make all these available will take some time. “NMC will provide wash basins, drinking water and separate electricity meters to all the stalls and this is the reason for the delay in opening of the Khau Galli,” the release stated.

Earlier in the day, a delegation of Maharashtra Navnirman Sena (MNS) activists met municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar and expressed displeasure over inaugurating the incomplete Khau Galli. Though the NMC has now claimed to start the food street full-fledged from January 26, MNS workers said it will take almost a month to complete the works.

Title: Back to roots: NRIs on campaign trail
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: With municipal polls around the corner, NRIs are going all out to help political parties in their campaigning. With some landing in the city over the weekend, others are helping out on social media right from where they are.

“Our team met minister K T Rama Rao last week and was asked to start campaigning,” said president for TRS wing in Australia Nagender Reddy Kasarla. He said that about 12 people from a core team had landed in the city from Australia and more would arrive closer to the polls. Since their arrival last week, the core team has met a slew of TRS party members.

Not Just Australia, but from the US and UK too teams were strategising for the polls. “Many of us are planning to come and help out with the polls,” NRI TRS UK vice-president, Naveen Reddy, said and added that those who cannot come are taking the battle online.

“There are at least 50 active members on social media. What we are primarily focusing on is counter anti-TRS propaganda and bringing out the ground reality of how the government's schemes have worked,” Naveen said adding that they are providing statistics to dismiss attacks.

Supporting the BJP in the US is the Overseas Friends of the Bharatiya Janata Party (OFBJP). “While not many of our members are going to be travelling to India, they are very active on social media,” said OFBJP president Krishna Reddy. He said they were preparing short videos to speak to highlight the difference the party can make.

“Members are also calling their family and friends to support BJP candidates, especially NRIs who have lived in areas which are going to polls,” said Krishna Reddy.

Title: Congress: K Chandrasekhar Rao met YS Jaganmohan Reddy with eye on civic polls
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

HYDERABAD: Congress has charged Telangana chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao with inviting his Andhra Pradesh counterpart YS Jaganmohan Reddy for talks at Pragati Bhavan on Monday with an eye on the January 22 municipal polls .

All India Kisan Congress vice-president M Kodanda Reddy said through this meeting KCR wanted to please the fans and followers of former chief minister late YS Rajasekhara Reddy in favour of the ruling TRS in the polls. He also demanded that KCR explain to the people the reasons behind the meeting of two chief ministers without any senior IAS officers.

“There are YSR fans and followers and KCR wants these votes to be cast in favour of the TRS. But, Jagan should introspect as his father was a true Congressman,” Kodanda Reddy said.
