Title: Digambar Kamat joins protesters in opposing CAA in Margao
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Agitators on Monday held a sit-in protest at Lohia Maidan, Margao, demanding immediate revocation of the CAA

MARGAO: Agitators on Monday held a sit-in protest at Lohia Maidan, Margao, demanding immediate revocation of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) “since it violates the basic secular character of the Indian Constitution”.

Leader of opposition Digambar Kamat , told the gathering that the act was an attempt to target people of a particular religion and urged people to oppose it. “The Constitution of India bears no link with citizenship and religion. With this act, the Constitution has been amended to link citizenship to religion. For the first time people had to take to the streets to protest against an act. Our party stand is clear – we won’t allow the act to be implemented,” Kamat said.

State Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) convener Elvis Gomes, in his address, said that the CAA aimed at dividing the people along religious lines and expressed his party’s resolve to staunchly oppose it. “The people of India have decided not to allow this to happen, whatever be the price they may have to pay for it,” Gomes said.

Speaking further, Gomes expressed fears that genuine citizens would be deported on account of the act. “BJP, in the past, tried to cancel holidays of Good Friday, St Xavier’s feast and Id. That was the beginning of the attempt to bring in this Bill. Sometimes we fail to recognize the moves,” Gomes said.

Condemning the police crackdown on students at JNU, Gomes said, “It is the duty of the government to provide good education to students, but here we find the police beat up students. We don’t want CAA, NPR of NRC; we want our students’ careers to be secure.”

Demanding that the Union government “take care to preserve the secular character and spirit of the Constitution,” the gathering resolved to “continue our fight firmly to preserve the secular fabric of India where all citizens, irrespective of religion, cast, creed, region and political affiliations have equal rights to live and prosper.”

Title: CAA agitation equivalent to that of freedom struggle: CM
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Kannur: Those in the forefront of the agitation against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ) are the ones who have realized that the Constitution of India and secularism are facing threat, said chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan .

Inaugurating the public meeting in Thalassery on Monday, against the CAA, organized under the aegis of Constitution Protection Committee, he said that this agitation is equivalent to that of the freedom struggle, and no law that is against the Constitution would survive.

Observing that the National Population Register (NPR) is the first step towards National Citizenship Register (NCR), he reiterated that NPR would not be implemented in Kerala. “There is no need for misunderstanding in this connection,” he said adding that the power of joint fight against such laws is very strong.

“Though opposition parties initially agreed to the joint struggle, they later retracted from it,” he said adding that some people have a narrow mentality.

“There will not be any enumeration with the aim of implementing NCR and there is no need for any worry about it,” he said adding that no community will have to face any issue in the state in the name of CAA. “Everybody who has born in Kerala would get birth certificate,” he said.

Criticizing the BJP and the RSS over the CAA issue, he said that the Sangh Parivar had always opposed secularism in India, and their effort is to transform India into a religion-based country. “They have no role in the freedom struggle and now they are humiliating the Constitution of India,” he said. “The RSS has not imbibed the culture of India and followed Nazism as their policy,” he said.

In the same way as they have divided Kashmir by scrapping the special status given to the state, the effort is on to divide other states as well, alleged the chief minister adding that there are protest all over the world against CAA. All India Sunni Jamiyyathul Ulama general secretary Kanthapuram A P Aboobacker Musliyar, who presided over the function, said the BJP claim that Muslims had some misunderstanding about the CAA is wrong.

“We have no misunderstanding and our understanding is right,” he said adding that the CAA is against Indian Constitution and the aim is to transform India into a nation belonging to a particular community.

Title: Low price of jaggery dampens ‘Pongal’ spirit among producers
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Erode: Jaggery producers in Erode district are busy churning jaggery expecting a large demand during Pongal festival and the subsequent month. But they are apprehensive whether they could realise profit from sales as the production cost is above the current market price of jaggery.

More than 600 cottage units are working round the clock in Andhiyur, Modakurichi, Bhavani, Mullamparappu, Kavindapady, Arachalur, Perundurai and Ammapet areas in the district. “Between Diwali and Pongal, all jaggery units will remain busy,” M Gunasekaran, a jaggery producer told TOI. Big producers would produce at least 3,000kg per day, while small units would make 800kg per day, he said

During Pongal, the production would be doubled, jaggery unit owners said. “During non-festival seasons, each unit will produce one tonne of jaggery a day. There are three production cycles. Demand would be at its peak during January and February,” they said.

However, the busy outlook is hiding the struggle the producers are facing this year. “Usually we used to source sugarcane from local farmers. But in the past five years, the number of sugarcane farmers in the district had dwindled and so we are procuring sugarcane from other districts including Salem, Dharmapuri and Namakkal districts,” T Malaravan, another jaggery producer from Bhavani, said.

“We procure sugarcane at a cost Rs 3,000 per tonne from farmers. Adding transportation cost, labour charges and other raw material expenses, the production cost of converting one tonne of sugarcane is Rs 4,800,” Malaravan said. From one tonne of sugarcane, a unit will produce 80-90kg of jaggery.

The current market price of 30kg of jaggery is Rs 1,250. “But we have to sell the produce above 1,700 per 30kg to realise profit. With only two days for Pongal, we don’t know how much the price would rise,” M Gunasekaran, a producer from Bhavani, said.

To avoid such situation in future, the jaggery producers urged the state government to distribute ‘nattu sarkarai’, which is produced from jaggery, instead of white sugar in the ration shops. The cottage units will benefit from such move, they said.

Title: LIFE LAID BARE ON PAGE
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

I’ve been a comedian for 15 years now. Self-respect walked out of the door a long time back!” As a comedian, Papa CJ is used to coming up with one-liners. But when he sat down to write his first book, an autobiography titled Naked , he realised that there was more to writing a book than coming up with jokes. “Self-discipline was my biggest challenge,” he says about the most difficult thing writing entailed. “Motivating someone who can get on stage to write his story down in book form is not an easy task. Eventually what motivated me was the fact that the medium of print gave me the opportunity to create a richer experience for my audience by including anecdotes from life and layers of emotion that a stand-up comedy stage may not have,” he says. Edited excerpts from an interview he gave TOI:

Writing truthfully or facing a thousand strangers, what makes you more nervous?

Writing truthfully for sure. I do have experience with sharing my life and being publicly vulnerable. With my stage show Naked, I opened myself up in ways that I never thought I’d have the courage to do before. Yet, while doing that, my audience was still in the room in front of me, where I could see them and if need be adapt my performance, albeit in a tiny way, to effect some degree of control on how they processed what I presented them. With the book, I didn’t have that. Also, an autobiography is a daunting venture for a first-time author because readers will be judging the quality of my work as well as the quality of my life. I have tried to be as honest and vulnerable as I can in a medium that I have little experience with. However, early feedback from readers has been quite heartwarming so my nerves are a lot more settled now.

You have been doing the stand-up gig for long. How do you ensure the sameness doesn’t get to you?

For starters, stand-up isn’t the only thing I do. I’m a motivational speaker and executive coach. I also undertake various charitable initiatives under my Happiness Project . I run interesting customised corporate training modules including ‘A Comedian’s Guide to Marketing and Content Strategy’. And if you’ve seen my stand-up, you will know that a large part of it is unscripted crowd interaction. There are times where I’ll go on chatting with the crowd for 45 minutes without telling the audience one pre-written joke. It also makes it special for the audience because they enjoy the spontaneity and know that it is a unique experience exclusive to them and no other audience in the world will ever see that show.

Stand-up comedy has become an aspirational career for youngsters today. Does this change in perception of stand-up make you happy? What do you remember about your early days about how people perceived stand-up?

When I started doing stand-up comedy an aunt asked me, “Son, what do you do?” I said, “Aunty I’m a stand-up comedian. I tell jokes.” She said, “Son, even I tell jokes but what do you do for a living?” This was more than ten years ago and stand-up has received greater recognition as a credible profession since, which does make me happy. However, if you’re going to go the distance in this profession it’s best you start caring less about other people’s perceptions about it. You won’t last long unless you have both a love for doing it and a very thick skin.

Do you think Indian stand-up comedy has a long way to go to make itself felt in the international scene? Is it going in the right direction?

Off the top I don’t know why going international needs to be a criteria for measuring success. I believe we should be allowed to create our own definition of what success means to us and chase those ideals as opposed to parameters defined by somebody else. As regards the stand-up comedy scene in our country, it is at an early stage of evolution. Over time not only will comedians evolve as they traverse their inner journeys but audiences will also evolve and demand more and better. That being said we already have a vast pool of talent, some very good, who are working hard and making a name for themselves both domestically and internationally.

For a country with diverse languages, do you think regional comedy is something that Indian comedians should look at if they want to make it big?

Oh absolutely! If you try and fit a certain mould that isn’t authentic to you, it is quite possible that you will be unhappy or unsuccessful or both. The beauty of our country is that the size and diversity allows for comedians to be succeed in any language and any genre. They can be true to themselves and comfortable in their skin and no matter what form that may be, there is a large enough audience for that. My friend Praveen Kumar’s incredible success when transitioning from English to Tamil is a superb example of the same.

Would you say longevity of career is the biggest challenge for a stand-up comedian? In these times of Netflix specials and YouTube videos, how do you ensure that you are not overexposed?

You are right in that comedian’s do face the challenge of deciding how much content to put out there. They need to put enough to become popular but not so much that they have nothing fresh to perform when the audience comes into the room. They also need to realise that millions of hits on a three-minute online video will not teach them how to entertain a live audience for an hour. You can only learn that by doing it repeatedly on stage. Fortunately the online challenge is not one I’ve have to deal with a lot. My passion has always been live stand-up so I don’t really put a lot of content online. I also encourage my audiences to come watch the real thing live instead of surfing comedy porn.

Title: Bharathiar University’s physical education programme derecognised
Content: COIMBATORE: The National Council for Teacher Education (NCTE), a statutory body under the Centre that recognises physical education programmes in higher education institutions, has withdrawn recognition to the Bharathiar University’s department of Physical Education for conducting Bachelor of Physical Education (B.P.Ed) course from the next academic session.The decision, NCTE said, was taken a meeting held from January 7 to 9 in New Delhi. The minutes of the meeting said the council had sent a show-cause notice in April last year and the final show-cause notice in October. “The institution did not submit its reply/representation in response to the final notice. Hence, NCTE decided to withdraw the recognition granted to Bharathiar University Department of Physical Education, for conducting B.P.Ed. course with effect from the next academic session.”Sources pointed out to a NCTE communication in 2015 that said the department consented to come under NCTE’s new regulations and sought to intake 100 students in the programme. For this, it had sought the list of additional staff appointed and approved staff list. It had also directed the university to display all details of the department. Lapses in these could have led to the NCTE action.BU vice-chancellor P Kaliraj said the university had sent a performance appraisal report to NCTE in December. “The deadline was December 31 and we had sent it on December 18. But the documents reached another section of NCTE and there was some confusion because of that. We would explain it to the authorities and get it sorted out,” he told TOI.

Title: Turmeric-based tech to kill cancer cells gets US patent
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: A potentially breakthrough cancer-fighting technology involving a molecule extracted from turmeric has won Thiruvananthapuram ’s Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute for Medical Sciences a US patent.

According to Lissy Krishnan, head of Sree Chitra’s research team, delivery of “curcumin” directly to the affected tissues rather than through conventional oral or intravenous methods enables it to target malignant cancer cells while sparing the healthy ones around them.

Turmeric has proven anti-cancer properties and curcumin, a molecule extracted from it, is easily absorbed by the body and aids blood clotting, Krishnan said. At Sree Chitra, research funded by the Indian Council for Medical Research focused on processing curcumin to form a easy-to-use wafer configuration. When applied to body tissues, the curcumin present in the wafer is released into tissue fluids.

Human albumin, or rich proteins present in the fibrin clot produced from heavy bleeding, binds albumin receptors to cancer cells, thereby permitting its entry into the cells. Simultaneously, the fibrin clot is removed by the body’s natural clot breakdown mechanism without any adverse effect.

“The fibrin wafer is targeted for implantation into the affected site after surgical removal of cancer tissue for killing any remaining malignant cells that have the potential to cause recurrence of cancer or spread to other parts of the body. In addition to drug delivery, the fibrin wafer can promote blood clotting at the surgical site,” said Asha Kishore, director of Sree Chitra.

The institute is ready to transfer the technology for future development of curcumin as an anti-cancer treatment through animal and clinical trials. “The US patent adds value to our efforts to transfer technology and boosts the industry’s confidence in exploring validation and trials with international markets in mind,’’ Kishore said.

Title: CCP waste fire takes 12 hours, 48,000 litres of water to douse
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

The loss was estimated at Rs 40 lakh. Fire personnel helped save property worth Rs 60 lakh

Panaji: A major fire broke out the city’s wet garbage facility at Patto on Monday which took fire fighters 12 hours and 87,000 litres of water to douse.

A two-year-old earth moving machinery, an organic waste converter, crates and other equipment were gutted in the fire that continued right through the day and was doused only after 7pm. The loss is estimated at Rs 40 lakh. Fire personnel helped save property worth Rs 60 lakh.

The Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP), which manages the facility, said that a call was made to the fire services at 6.50am. CCP commissioner Sanjit Rodrigues said that it is suspected that the fire started much earlier, in the early hours, but as the security guard was missing there was no one to alert the fire authorities on time.

“We are taking the matter up with the security agency. We were forced to take this agency by a government circular. We will now review these arrangements. We complained to Panaji police and the security guard is being questioned over whether there was any sabotage or aspects related to this, which need to be investigated into by the police,” Rodrigues told reporters.

Mayor Uday Madkaikar said an emergency number was given to the security guard in the event of a fire. “If it was seen on time then it would have been put out,” he said.

Fire personnel on arriving had to cut open the locked gate. Till noon 48,000 litres of water were used to douse the flames, which refused to die down due to the methane in the wet waste legacy dump at the site.

Sources said the CCP stopped the process of converting the wet waste into compost for around a year, resulting in the legacy dump being created.

“Waste of the past one-and-a-half month has been excessive due to back-to-back events in the city, right from the International Film Festival of India, Serendipity, New Year and Lokotsav. The waste has increased tremendously. We are working under tremendous pressure to treat this waste and we need this facility to be up and running,” Rodrigues said.

The corporation was aware of methane generation due to excessive heat these days and it was taking measures, Rodrigues said.

Waste from the site was being moved to other decentralised facilities in Panaji, he said.

The facility at Patto, which is managed by the Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP), handles around 30 tonne wet waste daily, which is collected from commercial establishments, including hotels, restaurants and guesthouses. CCP sends 10 tonnes of wet waste to the plant at Saligao every day.

“Now that we have got the environment clearance (EC) for the Bainguinim plant, we appeal to the government to complete all the other formalities,” Madkaikar said.

Last year, major fires had broken out at the Sonsoddo and Taleigao garbage dumps, which raged on for days.

Box

When asked about the cause of the fire, CCP commissioner Sanjit Rodrigues said an enquiry is on by the fire services and police. “We would not go into the cause of the fire as we are working to prevent further escalation of the fire. We will wait for leads to come from the fire and police,” he said.

Title: Delhi high court seeks AAP government, police stand on request to preserve data
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Delhi high court (PTI photo)

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court on Monday sought the stand of Aam Aadmi Party government and Delhi Police, along with social media entities like WhatsApp, Google and Apple, on a plea by three professors from Jawaharlal Nehru University seeking to preserve data, CCTV footage and other evidence relating to the January 5 campus violence.

On its part, Delhi Police informed the court it had asked the JNU administration to hand over the CCTV footage of the violence, but was yet to receive any response from the varsity.

Justice Brijesh Sethi issued notice and listed the matter for Tuesday after being informed by standing counsel Rahul Mehra that police force had written to the varsity for preserving footage of 135 CCTVs installed in the premises. Mehra informed the court that police is taking steps to preserve evidence, including footage, and has sought from the administration the footage between January 3 and January 6.

The cops also communicated with WhatsApp to preserve data, including messages, pictures, videos and phone numbers of members of two groups — ‘Unity Against Left’ and ‘Friends of RSS’ — on the social networking platform on which the attack was allegedly coordinated.

The court is hearing a plea filed by Ameet Parameswaran, Atul Sood and Shukla Vinayak Sawant seeking directions to Delhi Police commissioner and the state government to ensure there is no damage to CCTV footage.

Senior advocates Rebecca John and Akhil Sibal, appearing for the academics, sought an urgent interim relief in the form of a direction that WhatsApp preserve the data of the groups as the administrators of these groups could delete material evidence. The court, however, said it can pass an order only after hearing the parties for which it issued notice seeking the stand of the three entities.

However, police neither responded to such requests nor did it reach out to them, despite clear and cogent material provided to the investigating agency, the plea claimed.

Title: Jana Sena pins hopes on local body polls
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Jana Sena ’s flag will fly high in the upcoming local body elections, party state general secretary T Siva Sankara Rao said on Monday.

Speaking to the media alongside Bolisetty Satyanarayana (general secretary - environment), Sanakara Rao took a dig at the erstwhile TDP government as well as the YSRC government. “Chief minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy made tonnes of false promises before the elections. But now the people of Andhra Pradesh have realised that Reddy could not deliver the promises. False police cases are foisted against those questioning the misdeeds of the YSRC government and its inability to fulfil promises,” said Rao.

Rao further alleged that the chief minister created rivalry amongst the three regions of Andhra Pradesh by his “cheap trick” of proposing three capitals. “It seems that he is not even satisfied with it and is encouraging his party leaders to use abusive and foul language against Jana Sena president Pawan Kalyan. Even after attacking Jana Sena leaders and activists in Kakinada on Sunday, they tied to book police cases under section 307 on women leaders of Jana Sena. Kakinada MLA slandered Pawan Kalyan, but police did not register any case against the MLA and they allowed the MLA to use his goons to attack Jana Sena cadre with sticks and rods,” alleged Rao.

Title: NCW notice to TN college for expelling four girl students who consumed liquor
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Chennai: In the wake of a complaint against expelling four girl students of a college for consuming beer during a house party in Nagapattinam district, National Commission for Women (NCW) has issued a notice to the college asking it “to look into the matter and take appropriate action as per law”.

In a letter to the principal of Dharmapuram Adhinam Arts College in Mayiladuthurai , Shyamala S Kundar, member of the commission, citing the complaint by All India Private Colleges Employees Union (AIPCEU) which alleged harassment/indecent representation of women, said, “The action taken in the matter may please be communicated within 30 days from the date of receipt of the letter.”

The students in college uniform were seen celebrating the birthday of one of the girls at her house in Sitharkadu village. The incident came to light when a clip of the celebration was circulated on social media. After disciplinary enquiry, the college administration expelled all four students.

“The punishment is severe and it could end their education. Instead of reforming the students with lighter punishment, the college has taken an extreme step which has jeopardised their future. It amounts to harassment of women,” said K M Karthik, founder of AIPCEU and the complainant. He said the commission is considerate of the fate of the girls and sought a reply within 30 days.

“The entire matter was blown out of proportion. If boys drink and socialise it wouldn’t be an issue at all. It only became an issue as girl students consumed drinks. It was not done on the premises of college for it to take action,” said Sudha Ramalingam, senior advocate and social activist. “This is not the way to treat the students. The college could have reformed and educated them on the evils of drinking. But, to expel them is too harsh a punishment and it’s not for any educational institution to handle students like this. Students should be handled with compassion, caution and care. The intervention of national commission for women is good enough,” she said.

Title: Too many inmates, too little staff in state jails
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Andhra Pradesh prisons are understaffed by at least 24 per cent and central prisons in the state are overcrowded by 10 per cent. The problem of overcrowding in central prisons in the state continues to persist, as per the latest National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) data on prisons in India 2018.

Andhra Pradesh has four central prisons at Vizag, Rajahmundry, Nellore and Kadapa, which together held 4,212 prisoners in 2018 — 4,049 male and 163 female (both convicts and under-trials) with an occupancy rate of 110.44 per cent against its capacity of 3,814. In 2017, the four central jails in the state had 4,690 prisoners and 4,126 in 2016.

The overall occupancy rate in all the jails (central jails, sub-jails, district jails, women’s jails, open jails, altogether 105 jails) in Andhra Pradesh is 79.5 per cent in 2018. A total of 6,988 prisoners, including 414 female inmates were in various prisons in the state against its capacity of 8,786.

Superintendent of Vizag Central Prison S Rahul said convicts account for 40 per cent of central jail population, while undertrials and remand prisoners’ account for 60 per cent. Over 2,370 convicts were lodged in the central jails and a few other jails in the state. A majority of the convicts (1,574) were sentenced in murder cases while 163 had committed rape.

Senior advocate K Muralidhar said some undertrial prisoners involved in ganja transportation and a few other cases were struggling to get bail due to various reasons and so were stuck in prison.

Members of Visakhapatnam Bar Association (VBA) said overcrowding in the jails is also a violation of human rights as it is the responsibility of the government to provide reasonable space in the prisons.

Apart from over-crowding in prisons, staff shortage of staff at all levels of the system too is a cause for concern.

As per National Crime Records Bureau, the sanctioned staff strength in state prisons in 2018 was 2,646, but the actual strength was 1,997 (649 vacancies).

Title: JNU violence: Don’t feel safe on campus, teachers tell HRD officials
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

NEW DELHI: Members of JNU Teachers’ Association (JNUTA) on Monday met the MHRD officials and reiterated their demand about the revocation of hostel fee hike and the ouster of vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar from his position.

The JNUTA presented to the MHRD a dossier on the alleged “misgovernance of JNU under the VC and explained how the incidents of January 5 were the culmination of the long history of such misgovernance.”

“An atmosphere of fear and insecurity prevails in the university, which cannot be removed as long as the VC continues to be the in-charge,” they claimed.

The teachers said that the mob violence targeted specific teachers and their families. “Teachers do not feel safe on the campus and fear that if the VC continues in office, we might witness in the days to come even worse than what was unleashed. It is not possible for teachers to pretend that things are normal and start regular activities on the directives of a VC and an administration in whom they have absolutely no faith.” The dossier also drew attention of the ministry towards a ‘public inquiry’ conducted in October 2017 “where comprehensive evidence had been presented on seven different charges against the VC. These covered violations of statutory provisions, undermining the integrity of the faculty selection process, gross errors in admission processes leading to massive seat cuts, harassment of teachers and denying them their rights, among others.”

JNUTA said the MHRD has promised to consider the views and concerns of the association and to continue the discussion with it. “The JNUTA can only express hope that there will be a speedy resolution of its concerns.”

MHRD officials said that they met the JNUTA members “and had a meeting with them where the latter raised their past concerns about the VC. We were under the impression that the strike will be called off as discussed in the previous meetings, but we heard that the strike has been called back again. We hope that the situation normalises in the campus.”

Title: DGP denies reports of filing cases against CAA protests
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: State police chief Loknath Behera has denied reports that the state police have been instructed to slap charges on those who are protesting against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ). He said that media reports in this regards are untrue and that there is no such instruction to police officers.

The clarification of the state police chief follows reports about the police taking action against several such protests on charges of using loudspeakers and causing disruption in public roads. The CPM Kozhikode district secretariat had come up with a statement against a police officer in Elathur police station who had taken an announcement vehicle into custody which was part of the constitutional protection forum that was inaugurated by the chief minister himself.

The district secretariat had come up with a statement demanding that the officer had committed violation of fundamentals of the constitution, and strict action should be initiated against him.

Title: Govt fulfilled poll promises: Srinivas Rao
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The government conducted Sankranti Sambaralu in Visakhapatnam in a grand manner. Minister for tourism M Srinivasa Rao was the chief guest.

Shilparamama, where the festivities were held was a riot of colours. The main attraction was Bommala Koluvu and the colourfully dressed Haridasulu, accompanied by their decorated bulls.

Speaking on the occasion, minister Srinivas Rao said, “This Sankranti is truly special as the YSRC government led by chief minister Y S Jagan Mohan Reddy has kept all promises it has made. Today, the public feels secure and taken care of, thanks to the welfare schemes launched under the leadership of Y S Jagan Mohan Reddy.” In Vizianagaram, Sambaralu festivities were rustic with bullock cart races, kolatam and the recital of kirtanas by Haridasulu. Speaking on the occasion, the endowments minister, Vellampalli Srinivas, led celebrations at Ananda Gajapathi auditorium in the district headquarters. TNN

Title: Pollution level set to soar this Bhogi in Chennai
Content:
One’s elation shouldn’t spell another’s agony. These women at Dr MGR Janaki College of Arts and Science for Wo... Read More

CHENNAI: Don’t forget to carry your mask when you step out for a morning walk on Tuesday as the city burns waste, including tyres and plastic, to celebrate Bhogi. Experts say pollution level, particularly PM2.5, is likely to be more than double the normal levels.Besides leaving people sick, smoke from fires could delay flights and increase road accidents. On the day of Bhogi in 2019, although the pollution levels were nearly three times the normal in some areas, the average pollution levels across the city were less compared to the same day in 2018. “Awareness messages and drive against plastic were largely responsible for decline in pollution levels in 2019,” said Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board chairman A V Venkatachalam.Track the pollution level in your cityThis year, with plastic back in most households, the levels of pollution could be higher. “We have made all attempts to stop it through awareness campaigns,” he said. Posters urging people to avoid burning waste were put up in 25 places across the city. “We expect a smoke free Bhogi in 2020,” he added.The board has also been working with AAI, Chennai corporation and IMA to spread awareness on the ill effects of burning waste, he said.However, environmental activists said adequate preventive programmes haven’t been initiated. “They arrested people who burst cracker on Diwali. Why can’t they do the same with people who burn tyres and other substances that release carcinogenic substances,” asked K Swetha, who volunteers for Exnora.City doctors, meanwhile, have geared up for crowded out-patient clinics. Pollution increases risk of hospitalisation for people with lung diseases. Pulmonologists like Dr Raj B Singh of Apollo Hospitals encourage morning walkers and pet owners to continue their brisk walks but they warn against intense activities that makes people gasp for air.Studies have shown that when levels of pollution spike, so does the number of deaths, including those from heart failure, asthma and lung diseases. Researches have shown that air pollution may adversely affect birth weight. A recent study done by researchers at the Sri Ramachandra Institute of Higher Education and Research showed that birth weight comes down by 4g when pregnant women are exposed to per 10 microgram /m3 change in particulate matter 2.5 (tiny particles that easily enter airways in the lungs).

Title: TN cuts road accidents, gets Centre award
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Chennai: Tamil Nadu has received an award from the Centre for ‘Best Performance in Road Safety’. Defence minister Rajnath Singh presented the award to state transport minister M R Vijayabaskar on Monday.

The state witnessed a 32% drop in road accident deaths in 2018, compared to the previous year, according to official data. This was after topping India’s state-wise accident chart twice in a row in 2016 and 2017.

The government attributed the decrease to coordinated efforts by various departments and regular reviews by State Road Safety Council headed by Nithin Gadkari, Union road transport and highways minister (MoRTH).

Besides strict enforcement by police in terms of wearing helmets, seatbelts and monitoring patrol vehicles, strengthening emergency care by establishing more trauma care centres, ambulances and responder bikes helped in bringing down deaths.

“Phenomenal levels of commitment by the health team and the introduction of emergency mobile app capturing GPS & GIS for reaching the accident spot faster have also helped in reducing response time,” said a MoRTH official.

Speaking to the media after the award ceremony, Vijayabaskar said it’s impossible to reduce accidents overnight and efforts will continue to cut fatalities further in 2019-20. Nearly one-third of road accidents are reported on national highways.

“Identifying and eliminating black-spots, installing speed-breakers and signage at such accident-prone stretches have drastically reduced the fatalities in the last three years,” said a National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) official.

Plans are underway to install automated number plate recognition systems and speed monitoring cameras along highway stretches for better compliance with road safety rules. A pilot project is expected to come up on Chennai-Trichy highway.

As far as Chennai was concerned, a major change introduced in 2017-18 was the e-challan system. Fines collected digitally were linked to the government database ‘VAHAN’ and it helped in nabbing repeat offenders, said traffic police.

Title: Police shut ground as Lokotsav car park fills up
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Panaji: Parking provisions at D B ground were inadequate for the large number of visitors attending the 10-day Lokotsav . Traffic police had to shut access to the ground for cars on Monday evening due to lack of space.

Traffic police and wardens managed the flow of traffic on D B Road and after complaints from residents and local corporator Soraya Pinto Makhija, they stopped vehicles parking inside residential lanes and on the footpath. Traffic police put up no parking signs and erected barricades preventing cars and bikes from obstructing the smooth flow of traffic.

Mayor Uday Madkaikar said the parking provisions at D B ground are insufficient and not enough to cater to 200 four-wheelers as shown in the organisers parking plan.

The corporation is yet to issue permission to the festival, he said, adding that the toilet provisions are also not enough to cater to the vendors from 900-odd stalls and visitors.

Traffic wardens are stopping people from parking inside lanes opposite the festival after an ambulance couldn’t reach a patient at Landscape Pinto Park during the festival last year.The patient had to be carried up to the ambulance on the main road.

Makhija, in a letter to the corporation, had requested that all exhibitions especially 10-day festivals be held outside city limits where there is ample parking space and where residents will not be inconvenienced.

Title: Over 50% boats idle as catch dips
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Visakhapatnam: With over 50% of fishing boats staying idle for the past one month due to low availability of catch, seafood lovers will soon likely have to spend more money at restaurants for their favourite dishes.

Usually the fishing harbour remains busy between November and March as it is the peak fishing season. But, in recent times a decline in the availability of catch in the Bay of Bengal has affected business.

Speaking to TOI, president of Dolphin Boat Operators’ Welfare Association, Ch Satyanarayana Murthy, said “This fishing season has not been encouraging.

Of the over 700 fishing boats in Visakhapatnam, more than 380 boats are anchored at the jetties. And it seems the situation is not likely to change before the annual fishing ban kicks in. The boat-owners are in no position to bear the losses.”

“We have to invest at least Rs 2.5 lakh for each voyage, which involves ice, diesel, food grains and labour charges among other inputs, lasting for 15 days. However most of the boat owners have incurred losses between Rs 50,000 to Rs 70,000 for each voyage due to low availability of export quality fish and prawn and high input cost,” said M Ramu, said a boat owner.

Some of popular variety of fishes, which have witnessed a price rise, include, seer fish (konam in local parlance) and silver pomfret (Chanduva). Silver pomfret or white pomfret, which is a species of butterfish, costs around Rs 1,200 a kg and that of Seer (konam) is Rs 800 or more depending on its size. The price of tiger prawn has increased to Rs 1,200 per kg from Rs 1,000 a kg, a buyer said.

Title: Steel boxes replace plastic ellu-bella pouches this year
Content:
A women buys steel cups at Nagarathpet near Avenue Road for Sankranti on Monday

TimesView While shunning plastic for steel boxes is a welcome gesture, it is a small step in the big battle against the global plastic crisis. The problem needs to be approached from all angles. Manufacturers should stop making plastic and users should be directed to eco-friendly alternatives. A major educational campaign needs to be undertaken on campuses to make sure everybody understands how plastic is choking the earth.

Rush for sugarcane, sweet potato and fresh turmeric

Festive makeover for reusable boxes

BENGALURU: The ban on single-use plastic and awareness created about its environmental impact are being felt this Sankranti , with many women seeking steel alternatives for distributing ellu-bella mixture.While plastic boxes are colourful and affordable, there are many who have switched to steel dabbas and cotton pouches to pack the tasty Sankranti mixture. Wholesale merchants of stainless steel products said the demand for small steel boxes has risen; they are available from Rs 30-Rs170 per piece, depending on the size.The festival is celebrated with ellu-bella (sesame-jaggery, groundnut, coconut mixture), sugarcane and fruits, as samples of harvest reaped and shared among friends and relatives.Bharat Singh, a wholesale dealer from Avenue Road, said plastic is no longer preferred to pack food products. Rupali Itgumpalli, a homemaker from Hebbal, prefers steel boxes. “As a custom I give the Sankranti mixture to 13 women and prefer steel to plastic boxes as steel lasts longer,” Rupali said.Vikas Jain, proprietor of M Bhawarlal’s Inc, member of a wholesale steel merchants’ association, said: “Many buyers prefer steel over plastic boxes/pouches. Many are making a conscious choice to stop using plastic products,” he added. However, for many like Sadashivanagar resident Anupama Harish, what matters is ellu-bella than the container. “It is more of packaging these days than the content inside. Butter paper pouches are cheap and best as they are also compostable. What matters is the sesame-jaggery mixture,” she says.On the streets of Malleswaram market, Gandhi Bazaar and DVG Road, many shops are selling cloth bags/pouches and cane baskets for the harvest festival.Markets in the city were bustling with festive shoppers ahead of Sankranti. Bundles of sugarcane lined the streets of Jayanagar, Basavanagudi, Banashankari, Malleswaram and several other areas saw many takers. People were also shopping for sweet potato and fresh turmeric plants that are considered auspicious for the festival.Sri Lakshmi, a homemaker from HSR Layout, stores all containers and boxes that land at her home to give them a makeover during Sankranti.“I don’t buy new boxes for the festival. Instead, I reuse the containers from my collection. It could be ice-cream dabbas, cookie boxes, yoghurt cups, sweet boxes, carton boxes which I embellish as attractive ellu bella boxes,” she said. Lakshmi has given the Sankranti touch to over 40 such boxes from her collection.

Title: High-level panel in midst of finalising safeguards to protect identity and heritage of Assamese people
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

NEW DELHI/GUWAHATI: Even as protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act continue in Assam, a high-level committee is in the midst of finalising measures and initiatives to provide constitutional, legislative and administrative safeguards to protect the identity and heritage of the Assamese people, as required by Clause 6 of Assam Accord.

The committee, headed by Justice (Retd) Biplab Kumar Sharma, on Monday met home minister Amit Shah to discuss issues related to its charter or terms of reference. It is said to have briefed him on the deliberations of the committee so far and its plans ahead.

“We have apprised the home minister about the progress of our work. The home minister has given a few suggestions. We hope to submit our final report within next 15 days,” Sharma told reporters here.

The committee with more than a dozen members was set up as per the Clause 6 of the 1985 Assam Accord. The committee’s charter is to provide constitutional, legislative and administrative safeguards, as may be appropriate, to protect, preserve and promote the cultural, social, linguistic identity and heritage of the Assamese people.

According to its terms and conditions, the committee is tasked with assessing the appropriate level of reservation of seats in Assam legislative assembly and local bodies for the indigenous people. It is also expected to recommend the appropriate level of reservation in employment under the government of Assam for the Assamese people.

Asked whether the panel could finalise the “definition of Assamese”, the retired judge said they were yet to take a decision on it and hope to come to a conclusion soon. “All members of the committee will soon meet to finalise the report and all remaining issues to be resolved,” he said.

The base date for defining an Assamese has been the most contentious and difficult part over the years. In 2015, former assembly speaker Pranab Kumar Gogoi had suggested in the House that 1951 be taken as the basis for the definition of Assamese, but that did not get to see light of the day. Few suggest that the definition of an Assamese is hidden in the contents of the Accord itself. According to the Accord, “For purposes of detection and deletion of foreigners, 1.1.1966 shall be the base data and year.” It says, “Foreigners who came to Assam after 1.1.1966 (inclusive) and up to 24th March, 1971 shall be detected in accordance with the provisions of the Foreigners’ Act, 1946 and the Foreigners’ (Tribunals) Order 1964 and their names will be deleted from the electoral rolls in force for a period of 10 years after which their voting rights will be restored. All others who came to Assam on or after March 25, 1971, will be expelled as illegal foreigners.”

The meeting took place four days after Assam chief minister Sarbananda Sonowal met the home minister and discussed with him various aspects of the Assam Accord's Clause 6, under which the central government had promised to provide constitutional safeguards to the indigenous people.

The committee is said to have completed its deliberations and discussions with various stakeholders in Assam.

All Assam Students’ Union chief adviser Samujjal Bhattacharya said, “The constitutional safeguards are our right, which are long due, for taking the burden of lakhs of illegal Bangladeshi migrants from 1951 to 1971 (Accord cutoff date). But we will never accept the Citizenship (Amendment) Act.”

Title: Chennai: 2-year-old child kidnapped from Central railway station
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A 2-year-old child who was sleeping with her mother at MGR Central railway station on Sunday night has gone missing. Police suspect the child might have been taken away by a friend of the woman’s third husband.\

Investigation officers have identified the suspect through CCTV camera footage from the station. The complainant, Marjina, 21, recognized the man from the video as her third husband’s friend.

The man had been roaming around at the station for the past five days.

A police team led by Chennai Central railway station inspector Thomas Yesudasan is tracking the suspect to rescue the child and nab the kidnapper. The team has collected the suspect’s photograph from the CCTV camera footage and circulated to all police WhatsApp groups.

Investigation officers said the kidnapper would return soon with the abducted child as he stays at a platform and doesn’t have a house in the city. The police team is searching the roadside dwellings and conducted combing operation to nab the accused whose name, as told by Marjina’s husband, is Rasheed.

Police said Marjina married Azhar Ali five years ago and the couple had two daughters, Ajitha and Rejitha. Later, she separated from Azhar Ali and started staying with another man. They later married. She stayed with her two daughters.

However, Marjina didn’t continue her relationship with her second husband. She soon married Hameed. The couple started living at a platform near Chennai Central railway station with her two daughters. Hameed, who worked as a coolie, introduced his friend Rasheed to Marjina five days ago. He often met her in the absence of Hameed.

Marjina has claimed that Rasheed demanded she live with him and proposed to her several times. She refused to accept his proposal.

Investigation officers said Rasheed might have kidnapped Marjina’s daughter Rejitha. Further investigations are on.

Title: CCP dumps wet waste at Carambolim, locals protest
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Panaji: Old Goa locals along with panchayat members of Carambolim were up in arms on Monday after dozens of CCP trucks were found dumping what looked like wet waste and burnt garbage in a private property at Old Goa, close to a private hospital.

The incident came just hours after CCP’s waste treatment plant at Patto in Panaji caught fire .

Angry residents immediately protested at the site and stopped the trucks even as others rushed to the Old Goa Police station.

Panaji mayor Uday Madkaikar also rushed to the spot to pacify the locals. “It is not garbage. It is compost. A man has been purchasing fertilizer from us and he agreed to let us dump it in his property,” he said.

Residents said that an official complaint will be filed with the Carambolim panchayat with a demand for action to be taken against the plot owner for allowing waste to be dumped in his property.

“Local residents told us that there is a water tank close to that place and wells,” local Samir Volvoikar said.

Madkaikar said that CCP was ready to shift the waste if the garbage began to emit a stench.

Title: Patkar for nationwide anti-CAA, NRC action
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Narmada Bachao Andolan leader Medha Patkar on Monday called on the people protesting against Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and subsequent introductions like National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) and National Population Register ( NPR ) to work together to build a nationwide resistance.

Patkar, who inaugurated the anti-CAA rally organised by the Kerala Samsthana Janakeeya Prathirodha Samithi at Gandhi Park on Monday evening, said she is proud of the students who are refusing to give up their battle against the ‘unconstitutional’ bill.

“Protests against NRC should not be confined to the National Register of Citizens, rather we should be ready to uphold a national resistance against communalism, capitalism, casteism and corruption of all forms ...Whenever an administration uses force against its own people, it betrays fear. The present administration is not even ready for dialogue. Not even a single meeting or a dialogue with other political parties was considered before the implementation of such an amendment,” she said.

Patkar said she is proud of the people resisting and protesting against the enactment of the controversial bill. “Even as Amit Shah claims to have already implemented the Act, people from various sections have risen in protest. It is unfortunate that someone who swears by the Constitution of India comes up with an Act that disrupts the entire democratic framework of our nation. They want all the people to stand in their courts and prove their citizenship. I salute the brave youth of our nation and under your leadership we are ready to move forward. I am proud of the women who have come forward. They have shaken patriarchy, caste and communal creeds,” she said.

Title: Titles on self-motivation, time mgmt are in good books of readers at fair
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Chennai: Books on self-motivation and time management are selling like hot cakes at the ongoing book fair in Nandanam. Working professionals and entrepreneurs search for books of leading international and Indian authors.

Distributors and publishers observed that attitude, leadership, self-development, public speech and time management are the popular subjects among those looking for titles on motivation. V Kiran of a book distribution agency that has set up a stall at the fair said about 65% of titles in English were on self-motivation. “It has been the trend in the past and we are witnessing the same this year as well,” he said. While almost every stall selling English books has a considerable number on self-motivation, Tamil publishers have books penned by leading authors and civil servants.

V Surya of a publishing firm said employees mostly from IT firms are looking for books on time management. “Some specify this subject. During the four days, about 25% of books sold from our stall were on managing time,” he said.

IT employees stressed that such titles are required to improve their skills to establish their position in the competitive field. T S Ananth, an employee with a leading software company, who was spotted that the book fair on Monday said time management was essential in their profession. “Work pressure could drive employees to explore these books to improve their performance even as demand from the human resources department is on the rise,” he said.

Some see these books as a tool to encourage themselves. Balachandar, a private school teacher from Puducherry, who is preparing for civil service examinations said he visited the fair only to buy motivational books. “My peer groups are discouraging. But, these books are refreshing and enhance my confidence to fulfill my dreams,” he added.

Title: ABVP: Probe chain of events from October 28
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: ABVP has demanded that Delhi Police’s inquiry into the violence on JNU campus be expanded to cover incidents from October 28 last year when the students’ strike against the hike in hostel fees was first called.

Addressing mediapersons at Press Club on Monday, ABVP released eight videos that purportedly showed the involvement of students affiliated to the Left in the violence that broke out on the campus on January 5. “ABVP has submitted all raw video evidence to police and demanded a fair and detailed inquiry into the chain of incidents starting from October 28. We categorically demand strict punishment to all those found guilty of violence,” Nidhi Tripathi, ABVP national general secretary, said.

ABVP has sought to highlight that the campus was simmering with tension much before the actual violence broke out. “The Left abused the sentiments of the students. For the last two and a half months, classes have been disrupted at JNU. The Left is not allowing exams to take place. Most unfortunately, students were attacked when they tried to register for the next semester,” Siddarth Yadav, Delhi state secretary of ABVP, said.

Among the students named by ABVP in the violence were Aparajita D Raja, daughter of CPI leader D Raja, and Amutha Jaydeep. The outfit also put on display some videos that it had released earlier to again name JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh, its general secretary Satish Yadav, AISA activist Chunchun Kumar, Dolan Samanta and Geeta Kumari.

Raja and Jaydeep, who are seen together in the video, dismissed the allegations, saying ABVP was trying to change the narrative of the violence to portray it as a “clash”. Raja said: “The video is only of six seconds and it shows Jaydeep carrying a stick and throwing it away. ABVP is, as usual, lying and distorting (facts). One thing is clear — the violence was planned, provoked and carried out by ABVP.”

Jaydeep added: “I have seen the video... What happens before and after it has not been shown. Has anybody’s head been broken because of me? During a march from T-point towards Periyar, they (ABVP members) started throwing stones. We were trying to figure out what was happening. When I saw a person with a stick, I snatched it from him and threw it away.”

The others named by ABVP have already dismissed the allegations.

Title: Practice of flood irrigation criticised
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Aurangabad: The tendency among some farmers to excessively irrigate agricultural land came under sharp criticism.

“Make it a point to irrigate only crops. The practice of ‘flood irrigation’ — that irrigates entire farms — is bound to reduce yield and cause loss of water,” said U P Singh, Union secretary for the water resources ministry.

Addressing farmers at a special workshop, he said drip and micro-irrigation, along with sprinkler technology, should be adopted by every farmer. “Different water resources, including underground water, are depleting rapidly due to an increase in consumption. Agricultural irrigation accounts for around 89% of water use in country. The remaining 11% is for drinking requirements and industrial use. It is time to develop adequate water literacy,” he said.

Union minister of state for water resources Rattan Lal Kataria pointed out that compared to China, Brazil and the US, India consumes at least 2-3 times more water.

Title: Cabinet to decide on amended MV Act fines: Mauvin
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Panaji: Citizens will soon learn if they must pay higher penalties for traffic violations under the new amended Motor Vehicle Act as the state cabinet is set to take a decision on it. Transport minister Mauvin Godinho said that after the cabinet takes a decision, the transport department will implement the amended act.

Godinho had said that the amended act, which has provisions to impose higher penalties for traffic violations, will be implemented from January 2020. “I have left it to the wisdom of the cabinet about what we should do. Whether to lower the rates or go as per the original proposal of the new M V Act which are higher,” he told TOI. “The proposal will be placed before the next cabinet,” he added.

He also said that three states, including Gujarat and Uttarakhand, had lowered the rates, after which the Union government approached the attorney general of India for an opinion. He added that the attorney general of India gave a very strong opinion and said that states have no power to bring change in central acts and they have to implement the act in its original form.

Godinho said that the attorney general’s opinion also stated that the Union government has power under the Constitution to direct states to implement central acts.

While the legislation has come into force in other parts of the country, the Goa government deferred its enforcement after the public raised a hue and cry over the terrible road conditions across the state.

Title: Kerala: Five arrested for attack on BJP state secretary
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

KOTTAYAM: Police filed case against five people in connection with the attack on BJP state secretary A K Nazeer . Police from Nedumkandam station arrived at Amrita Institute of Medical Sciences (AIMS) in Kochi to record Nazeer’s statement on Monday. Nazeer was admitted in AIMS after being attacked allegedly by SDPI activists in the compound of a mosque in Nedumkandam in Idukki around 7pm on Sunday. Nazeer went to the mosque after attending a pro-CAA public meeting.

According to hospital authorities, his health condition is stable. He said in his statement that the five people whom he could identify had attacked him and kicked his back.

Nazeer was attacked in the compound of the mosque in Nedumkandam on Sunday. The BJP had taken out a march in the town ahead of the meeting. There was a clash between some CPM and BJP workers during the march. Later on, Nazeer inaugurated the meeting. After the meeting, he headed to the mosque in the locality to pray. A group stopped him from entering the mosque. Following the intervention of elderly people in the mosque, he was allowed to enter the mosque. He was attacked by SDPI activists once he came out, said the police.

Nazeer was injured and was initially taken to a private hospital in Kattappana and was later shifted to AIMS. Following the incident, BJP and SDPI activists clashed in Nedumkandam town. There was heavy stone pelting in the area by either groups.

Meanwhile, BJP protesting the attack on its leader kept away from an all-party meeting held in Nedumkandam on Monday afternoon.

Police charged around five cases in connection with the attack.

Mohammed Sali, president of the Juma Masjid said that the Juma Masjid is not interested in making the issue complex taking into consideration the current situation in the region. “Any faithful can come to the mosque. But we can’t allow attack on the mosque,” said Sali.

SDPI district leader Sharafudin said that SDPI has no connection with the attack on the BJP leader. He added that action will be taken if any of its workers are found to be involved with the incident in the police probe.

Title: Thousands stranded due to landslide on Manali highway
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Chandigarh-Manali highway was blocked at Aut after a landslide

MANALI: Thousands of people, including tourists, were left stranded due to a landslide near Aut in Mandi district of Himachal blocked Chandigarh-Manali national highway at about 2pm on Monday afternoon. The incessant rain triggered landslides in Mandi and Kullu districts along the national highway -- which has seen huge mountain cutting for its widening – with huge boulders rolling down on the highway making driving very risky.

As all attempts to resume traffic movement failed till night, Mandi administration and police have decided to keep highway closed for the night and reopen it in the morning. A large number of tourist vehicles including nearly 40 tourist buses that left Manali for Delhi have also stuck on both sides of the landslide. The vehicles are now being stopped at Mandi and Kullu. Unfortunately, the bypass road via Kandi-Katola is also blocked with snow.

The whole mountain face near Aut has been sliding down for over a year now with boulders lying along the highway but authorities are not clearing them. Neither have the authorities cautioned travellers.

Mandi SP Gurdev Chand Sharma said the highway had got blocked at Banala near Aut following a landslide. “Machines were moved to the spot. Police were informed that it will take nearly two hours to clear the debris. Police are present at the spot to ensure public safety,” he said.

The Aut-Sainj road that was blocked due to flood in Pagal nullah on Sunday was again rendered impassable on Monday. The road is being maintained by a hydel project management and residents allege that the area is being ignored and no machines are deployed to clear the debris unless the hydel unit vehicles get stuck there.

Mahesh Sharma, a resident of Sainj village, said hundreds of villages get cut-off after floods in the Pagal nullah. “Nobody cares for our plight. This nullah brings tonnes of debris in any season and blocks road, apart from posing a threat to our lives. Government should find a permanent solution to this problem,” he said.

Kullu police on Monday night received information that a vehicle fell into the Beas on Manali-Kullu bypass road, but neither did they find any vehicle, nor did they receive any casualty report. But search was being conducted till late night with help of search lights.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Parties may bet big on those who switched camps
Content:
Devinder Sehrawat

NEW DELHI: With less than a month left for the Delhi assembly election, all three prime players — AAP, BJP and Congress — have as frontrunners several aspiring candidates who have shifted loyalty in recent times. All three parties are in the last stage of finalising the candidates for the February 8 polling.Newly inducted into AAP, both Shoaib Iqbal, a five-time MLA from Matia Mahal constituency, and Ram Singh Netaji, who had won from Badarpur twice, are keen to contest from their strongholds. Both of them have come from Congress. Another Congress functionary, Parlad Singh Sawhney, who had won from Chandni Chowk in 1998, 2003, 2008 and 2013 before losing in 2015, is also said to be the frontrunner for the seat in his new party, AAP. He joined the party in October.Former AAP minister Kapil Mishra is reportedly the frontrunner for the BJP ticket from Karawal Nagar while speculation is rife that he may be fielded from New Delhi constituency against chief minister Arvind Kejriwal. Mishra was expelled from AAP after he had turned rebel and joined BJP last year. Two more former AAP MLAs, Anil Bajpai of Gandhi Nagar and Devinder Sehrawat of Bijwasan, are also in the race for BJP tickets from the respective seats. Ex-AAP leader Gugan Singh, who had contested from North West parliamentary constituency, is also a BJP hopeful at Bawana after joining the party recently.Former Delhi minister Raj Kumar Chauhan, who had represented Mangolpuri assembly constituency multiple times, switched to BJP from Congress last May and is now the party’s likely candidate there.For Congress, former AAP MLA Alka Lamba and ex-BJP MP Udit Raj are the frontrunners for Chandni Chowk and Mangolpuri seats, respectively. While Raj had joined Congress after BJP denied him a ticket in the 2019 Lok Sabha elections, Lamba returned to the party after a long confrontation with the AAP leadership.All parties are minutely analysing the strengths and weaknesses of the aspirants to field the most winnable candidate in every constituency. While AAP is trying to keep Delhi, its only political stronghold, BJP is eyeing a comeback after 21 years. Congress, on the other hand, is hoping to feature in the assembly tally after a decimation in the 2015 elections.All three parties are treading cautiously as choosing recent entrants is unlikely to go down well with those already associated with them, said a source, adding that every vote may prove crucial in case of a tight contest at any seat.AAP is likely to release the list of its candidates this week. The outcome of multiple qualitative and quantitative surveys being conducted in all 70 assembly constituencies will decide the fate of its 61 sitting MLAs. “Most of our MLAs have worked well but wherever we need to change the MLAs, we will do it,” Kejriwal recently said. AAP is assessing the performance, public connect and opinion, and winnability of each MLA, said a source.In Video: Delhi polls: Parties may bet big on new entrants
