Title: Goa: Dhangar women, kids left in lurch after men held for tiger killings
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Making a case for the Dhangar families, the panchayat members urged the deputy collector to look into the plig... Read More

(By: Afaq Khan)

VALPOI: Days after the arrest of four men from the Dhangar community in Dongurli-Thane, Sattari, for the death of four tigers, the village panchayat on Monday demanded that medical facilities and police protection be provided to their families. The Dhangars belong to the Scheduled Tribe community.

Sarpanch of Dongurli-Thane Prajita Gawas, who visited the Dhangar families along with other panchayat members, submitted a memorandum to the deputy collector of Sattari Mangaldas Gaonkar requesting him to help them.

Since the arrest of the four men, who were the heads and sole earning members of the two families living there, the women and children find themselves without income and security.

“In one house there is an 80-year-old woman who is very ill, in another there is a girl suffering from high fever. However, without the men of the family they find it difficult to seek medical treatment,” Gawas said.

Panch Nilesh Parwar said that as the community lives in the midst of a forest, they are always exposed to danger and with no male members to protect them “children have stopped going to school for the past few days”. One child had to skip her Class XII preliminary examination, he said.

Making a case for the Dhangar families, the panchayat members urged the deputy collector to look into the plight of the families.

Deputy collector Mangaldas Gaonkar heard the grievances of the panchayat members and assured them that he would look into the matter. He ordered health and police officials to provide the Dhangar families with assistance.

On Monday evening a team of health officers visited the families. “Our team examined all members of the two families. Four people had fever. We gave them medication and took their blood samples for investigation,” said health officer Dr Gajanan Naik.

“We advised the daughter-in-law of one aged, bed-ridden patient to admit her in hospital but she refused saying she has no one to stay with her mother-in-law in hospital,” Naik said, adding that the woman has a daughter and cannot leave her behind alone while she accompanies her mother-in-law to hospital.

“We gave her some medicine and asked her to report to us about her mother-in-law’s health status,” he said.

Title: Officer to be appointed for Smart City project only
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Aurangabad: Chief Minster Uddhav Thackeray has issued a directive to the municipal commissioner and the divisional commissioner to looking for a dedicated officer to implement the Smart City project in the city

Aurangabad MP Imtiaz Jaleel had demanded an officer due to the slow progress of the project.

MP Jaleel, who is also a member of the urban development committee of the central government, have repeatedly expressed concerns at different levels about the slow pace of works under the project in Aurangabad.

As per the letter given by him for the chief minister’s meeting held on January 9, Jaleel said that of the 100 smart cities selected in India, Aurangabad is amongst the worst 20 mainly due to the delay in the utilisation of funds. “Of the Rs 290 crore funds available under the project, only Rs 61 crore has been utilised so far,” Jaleel said.

He said that the Aurangabad municipal commissioner has to take care of other civic issues cannot give enough time as the CEO of Smart City project SPV (Special Purpose Vehicle) i.e. Aurangabad Smart City Development Corporation Ltd. (ASCDCL).

“The chief minister has directed municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey and divisional commissioner Sunil Kendrekar to look for an officer who will enthusiastically work for the Smart City project. He will be appointed as the additional CEO of ASCDCL,” Jaleel told TOI.

Therefore, the MP has asked the CM to appoint a dedicated additional CEO for the Smart City project, who will work only for the project. Jaleel had also expressed dissatisfaction at the projects being undertaken by ASCDCL. He said that the appointment of a dedicated officer will improve the quality and pace of the project implementation.

Title: Unhappy with poor water supply, residents lock tank
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Aurangabad: The residents of Pundalik Nagar, led by local corporator Meena Gayke, locked the gate of elevated storage reservoir (ESR) in the area on Monday after the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) delayed the supply of water and shut it after 15 minutes. The lock was opened only after the water supply was restored in about an hour.

Incidentally, the AMC supplies water to Pundalik Nagar ward from its ESR in Pundalik Nagar once in six days for 45 minutes. According to Gayke, the AMC delayed the supply of water on Monday.

“People had been waiting for water for five days and when the supply finally started, it was delayed by an hour. Moreover, the supply was stopped after 15 minutes. Some houses did not even receive water,” Gayke said.

The corporator along with the residents then stormed the ESR and locked its gate. “With the festival of Makar Sankrant on Tuesday, it was insensitive on the part of AMC to stop the water supply within 15 minutes. Therefore, people expressed dissent at their irresponsible move,” the corporator said.

Incidentally, the problem of contaminated water also persists in the area. In July 2019, the residents had held the civic officials hostage for four hours after no heed was paid to their repeated complaints of contaminated water. Subsequently, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele and the then municipal commissioner Nipun Vinayak had to intervene.

Asked about the matter, Raju Sandha, the head of water works department, said, “The water supply was interrupted because of a power cut at the ESR. However, we resumed the supply after electricity was restored.”

About contaminated water supply in the area, Sandha said that efforts are on to address the problem. “The drainage department and the water works department are carrying out civil works to solve the water contamination problem of Pundalik Nagar,” he said.

Title: Goa government colleges to get economics, language labs
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: After setting up smart classrooms in government colleges, five more will get commerce and economics laboratories and four will get language labs, all at a total cost of approximately Rs 3 crore.

These labs will enable teachers to make use of open source educational software to make learning interesting.

Students will be able to play games through which they will learn workings of systems like share market dealings in the commerce and economics lab, officials of the directorate of higher education (DHE) said.

While the commerce and economics labs will come up in the government colleges in Quepem, Margao, Pernem, Khandola and Sakhali, the language labs will be established in the state institutes in Pernem, Khandola, Sakhali and Quepem.

The language lab will have content in Sanskrit, Marathi, Konkani and English, where students can use open source educational software to learn things like articulation, pronunciation, etc, with the help of animations. Vocabulary, for instance, can be improved using a flash card game, DHE deputy director Renji George Amballoor said.

“International standard modular work stations will be provided in the colleges to use the open source educational software. The work of establishing the labs will begin next month. With these labs we are empowering students as well as teachers. In economics, for instance, all the data sets will be available to teachers through these labs using which they can carry out further research,” DHE officials said.

Already, the state government has set up virtual and smart classrooms in government colleges in Quepem, Borda, Khandola and Sakhali at a cost of around Rs 4 crore. Officials said that work order has been issued to set up virtual and smart classrooms in the remaining three government institutes, officials said.

“The smart classrooms have equipment like high definition cameras. Once all colleges have the virtual and smart classrooms, one resource person will be able to deliver a lecture at one institute and it can be watched by students in all the government colleges. The students cannot only watch, but also interact using the equipment with the resource person,” Amballoor said.

Funds allotted by the central government under the Rashtriya Ucchatar Shiksha Abhiyan (RUSA) were utilised to provide the virtual boards and smart classrooms.

Title: Group IV malpractice: Top rankers quizzed
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Chennai: Following allegations of malpractice in group IV exam, Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission ( TNPSC ) on Monday held an enquiry with more than 40 toppers who wrote the exam from centres in Rameswaram and Keelakkarai in Ramanathapuram district .

Some candidates said three committees quizzed them separately during the day. Candidates from outside the district but who wrote exams in Rameswaram and Keelakkarai were questioned by the committees on why they chose the centres.

TNPSC released the rank list for group IV exam recently. In the list, it was found that many candidates among the top 100 ranks wrote their exams in Rameswaram and Keelakarai. These candidates were allegedly from different districts but had still chosen to write the group IV exam from one of these centres.

A candidate near Chennai, who was called for enquiry, said she went to Rameswaram for the death ceremony of her child who had passed away a few months back, and wrote the exam there. Many candidates concealed their face while entering the TNPSC office to avoid media glare. The enquiry which began in the morning went on till evening.

Some candidates, who failed to qualify for the next round, were also called for enquiry. They were asked about suspicious activities at the exam centres on the day of the exam. When contacted, TNPSC officials said they can’t share information about the enquiry at this stage.

More than 13 lakh candidates appeared for the group IV exam conducted by the TNPSC at more than 5,500 venues across the state on September 1, 2019. The results were announced on November 12 last year, which was the shortest time taken for group IV exam.

Among the top 100 candidates, 35 were from two centres, raising suspicion on exam malpractice. TNPSC, while announcing that a detailed enquiry would be conducted into the allegations, acknowledged that of 57 candidates shortlisted from Rameswaram and Keelakkarai centres, 40 were from other districts. It also assured a fair probe into the allegations.

“It is not just group IV exam alone. Even in group II-A exam many candidates from these two centres got into the top 100. In group IV exam, the answer sheets were sent after a delay of one week. There could have been a nexus between exam officials and unscrupulous elements during the exam. TNPSC should probe all angles and should take strict action if it finds anyone had cheated in the exam,” said a trainer for competitive exams.

Title: Goa government seeks SC nod to start handling dumps
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: The state government on Monday approached the Supreme Court seeking permission to handle the ore dumps.

“An application for dump mining has been filed before the Supreme Court,” said chief minister Pramod Sawant. “We are hopeful of a positive outcome in reviving the industry.”

Mines director Ashutosh Apte told TOI that the application has been filed based on the SC-appointed central empowered committee report on dump handling. “We want the apex court to take a decision on the report, and accordingly we will come out with a dump policy and guidelines,” Apte said.

According to the concessionaires’ declaration, around 800 million tonnes of iron ore dumps are lying in the state, the expert committee report stated.

The CEC had recommended that the SC direct the state government not to carry out extraction of overburdened dumps outside approved mining lease areas till an environmentally sustainable scheme of mining for the removal of mineral from overburdened dumps was prepared. This scheme, the CEC said, would have to be considered along with relevant information regarding the ownership of the dumps and realistic assessment regarding mineral available (grade-wise) in such dumps. It would then have to be approved by the statutory authorities, the CEC said.

In November 2019, the state had filed a review petition in the Supreme Court against the February 2018 order suspending mining operations. The state had also prayed for fast-tracking the hearing in the matter.

Earlier, Sawant had said that a dump policy would be finalised by the end of January 2020.

Mining came to a halt in the state in March 2018, after the apex court quashed the second renewal of 88 mining leases.

Waste management minister Michael Lobo had said that if dump is handled through a corporation, then the state treasury would benefit. Every month, the state government borrows money by selling security bonds. “If we auction the dumps, we will immediately get Rs 1,500 crore,” Lobo had said.

During the finance consultation meeting held by Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, Sawant said that the state lost around Rs 1,400 crore in revenue every year due to the stoppage of mining.

Title: Decks cleared for Gadisar Lake revamp
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Jaisalmer: The Rajsthan High Court has paved the way for beautification and conservation of Gadisar Lake in Jaisalmer.

The court has warned Jaisalmer Municipal Council (JMC) that development and beautification work should be done in such a manner so that the catchment and water flow area of the lake do not get affected. On Sunday, district collector Namit Mehta visited the lake and told officers that in coming days the lake will be turned into a beautiful place for which JMC has to implement a special plan. tnn

Title: Trap for bull nets leopard at Padampura village in Ajmer
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Ajmer: A two-year-old female leopard was trapped and tranquilised at Padampura village, around 15km from here, on Monday and taken to Ghooghra forest nursery where she will be treated and released back in Tatgarh forest.

It was a major success for the forest department to catch the leopard alive. The villagers had actually set up a trap to catch a bull which was destroying their crops outside the village. On Monday morning, villagers heard voice of leopard and when they went out, they saw that a leopard was caught. Team of forest department was informed.

Divisional forest officer Sudeep Kaur along with his team reached the spot and veterinary doctor Arvind Mathur was called. They then tranquilised the animal and brought it out from the trap. According to the vet, the leopard had some injuries which will be treated.

Sources said the sighting of leopard was reported from many places such as Bhinai, Jawaja, Baghsuri and nearby region. Official sources said there are a few leopards in Tatgargh Raiyala reserve forest along the border of Ajmer, Rajasmand and Pali. These felines often venture out to residentials areas in search of food. In the last week, 32 sheep and a calf were killed in different places.

Title: Heavy rain, dense fog in isolated pockets: Met department
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

A car lies buried under tree brances following a spell of rain in Chandigarh

CHANDIGARH: Light to moderate rain lashed parts of Punjab and Haryana on Monday. The weather department predicted that similar conditions will continue in coming days.

Thunderstorm accompanied with hail has been forecast at few places in Punjab and Haryana, with chances of heavy rain at isolated places till Thursday. Amritsar and Patiala received 28mm and 17mm rain, respectively, on Monday, while Ambala in Haryana recorded 8.7mm rain.

Gurdaspur was the coldest in both states, with a low of 6°C. Amritsar, Ludhiana and Patiala in Punjab recorded a minimum of 10.2°C, 9.1°C and 8.9°C, respectively. In Haryana, Karnal was the coldest with a low of 6.8°C, while both Ambala and Narnaul were at 8.5°C. It was 12.7°C in Sirsa, 7.8°C in Bhiwani and 11.8°C in Hisar.

Title: Rajasthan: ‘Modi government seeking Rs 45,000 crore from RBI proof of failing economy’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

CM Ashok Gehlot

JAIPUR: Rajasthan chief minister Ashok Gehlot on Monday said it was a matter of concern that the Centre was planning to seek another interim dividend from the RBI to meet its expenditure commitments and alleged that the NDA government was “completely ruining” the economy.

“Reports that the government is planning to seek another interim dividend from the RBI to meet its expenditure commitments is a matter of concern. The government took away a large amount from the RBI earlier, too,” Gehlot tweeted.

“The NDA government is completely ruining the economy even as common people are increasingly facing financial hardships,” he added.

According to news reports, the government has asked for an additional Rs 45,000 crore from the RBI as interim dividend to make up for its revenue deficit. It has been a major bone of contention between two former RBI governors and the government which resulted in their early exits.

The Union government had asked for Rs 1.76 lakh crore from the RBI as dividend to the Centre. Of this amount, Rs 1.48 lakh crore was given for the current financial year (2019-20).

According to the report, the RBI makes profits largely by trading currency and government bonds.

Title: Proposal to give lake to real estate firm for rejuvenation riles RWAs
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Residents fear any development work at Doddakallasandra Lake will pose a danger to the many birds and butterfl... Read More

BENGALURU: Resident welfare associations around Doddakallasandra Lake in South Bengaluru on Monday filed an objection before the Karnataka Tank Conservation Development Authority ( KTCDA ) against the latter’s proposal to enter an MoU with a real estate firm to rejuvenate and develop the water body.

Residents fear that the realty firm would concretise and commercialise the biodiversity rich water body area. KTCDA is an umbrella body for the conservation and development of tanks in the state.

RWAs of Narayana Nagar 1st, 2nd and 3rd Blocks, Soudhamini Layout, Silicon City and New Bank Colony raised their concerns before KTCDA director Shiva Swamy, who told them that the MoU is yet to be signed and he would look into their concerns.

Though the 21-acre lake is rich in biodiversity, it is in need of rejuvenation as desilting, bund construction and other works need to be carried out.

The residents alleged that the firm in question is building a huge residential complex in the vicinity of the lake and untreated water is being released into the waterbody.

NR Somashekar, a resident of Narayan Nagar and secretary of the area’s RWA said, “We don’t want the lake area to be concretised in the name of development. Till now, we have ensured that not even a jogging track is built around the lake. On weekends we bring our children here to watch birds and butterflies . We need the lake to be rejuvenated as it has started stinking and become a breeding ground for mosquitoes. But it doesn’t mean that it should be handed over to a private builder.”

Raghavendra B, who resides close to the lake and is a member of Peoples' Campaign for Right to Water – Karnataka, said, “We want KTCDA to hand over the lake’s maintenance to the local custodian, in this case BBMP. If that is done, we can chip in with suggestions and other activities as we believe BBMP is more approachable.”

A representative of the real estate firm, however, refuted the charges that it was polluting the lake. “We have a 2,000 KLD sewage treatment plant within our premises and only treated water is being released into the lake,” she added.

A lake of butterflies

According to a report released by ActionAid Association, an NGO in December last, Doddakallasandra Lake is home to rich biodiversity including 70 species of birds and 37 species of butterflies besides rich flora. Tiny Grass Blue, one of the smallest species of butterflies, as well as Blue Mormon, which is one of the larger species are all found here. The Oriental Darter and Black Headed Ibis, two bird species which are in the Red List of International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) are also found around the lake.

Title: More snowfall in Himachal Pradesh, open roads are also slippery
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

MANALI: Higher hills of Himachal received another spell of snow, while remaining parts were lashed by rain on Monday. Entire Lahaul valley received heavy snowfall and administration has ordered to close the schools for two days.

With some areas receiving heavy snowfall and white blankets of snow forming several layers, the Himachal Pardesh Disaster Management Authority has warned about avalanches in districts of Kullu and Lahaul-Spiti. Both the district administrations have asked people to stay alert.

Lahaul-Spiti district headquarter Keylong has received 60cm snow since Sunday evening. Koksar has received over 75cm snow. Solang, which was covered with nearly 75cm snow, has received 15cm more snow on Monday. Kalpa in Kinnaur also received 15cm more snow. Manali town received some traces of snow in the evening but snowfall had restarted in the late evening. The residents of Shimla city received some relief from slippery roads and pathways due to the rain but upper parts of the district received some snow.

The conditions are worst in Lahaul valley where all roads are blocked and electricity and phone networks have been crippled. The residents are hearing roaring sound of movement of snow avalanches but nobody can see them in almost zero visibility.

Keylong sub-divisional magistrate Amar Negi confirmed, “All roads are blocked and power supply is affected partially. The accumulation of blanket of snow on old hard snow has increased chances of avalanches. We have alerted residents to take extra precaution.”

Many roads in state were still closed due to recent snowfall and the fresh snowfall has again blocked more roads in the state. The electricity supply was crippled in Shimla, Kullu and Lahaul-Spiti.

According to Shimla meteorological centre director Manmohan Singh , the western disturbance that hit Western Himalayas on Sunday brought snowfall and rain to the state and another western disturbance is likely to hit the state on Wednesday. “The minimum temperature in the state has increased by 1 to 2 degrees C in last 24 hours. At minus 6 degrees C, Keylong was coldest in the state,” he said.

Heavy machinery busy in Shimla district

Upper reaches like Narkanda, Khadapathar, Dodra-Kawar and Kufri of Shimla district received heavy snow from 4 pm onwards on Monday. Administration has deployed machineries at main hot spots and will be working during night hours also to ensure all roads are kept open. All roads in Shimla city are open for vehicular traffic. As many as 25 various heavy machineries are on standby for clearance of roads.

Shimla to Theog road is open for light vehicles but has become slippery due to fresh snowfall near Fagu. The main road from Shimla to Chopal has been blocked again and while Shimla-Khadapathar opened for light vehicles but it is slippery at shady areas. Main road from Shimla to Rampur is open and Narkanda-Oddi is also clear but slippery. At most places, earth moving machines are busy clearing blocked roads.

HRTC buses are plying normally in Shimla city. Buses towards Rampur, Kumarsain and Kinnaur are plying via Basantpur. In Theog, around 51 distribution transformers are affected. In Chopal, 157 distribution transformers are down in affecting power supply and in Rohru are hit. Similar is the situation in Rampur, in Kumarsain and in Dodra-Kawar.

Shimla deputy commissioner Amit Kashyap said normal supply of vegetables, milk and bread was maintained. He said that adequate stores of essential commodities were available across the district.

Title: Will bridge gap between common man & police, says new Meerut IG Praveen Kumar
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

MEERUT: UP’s inspector general (IG) of police (law and order) Praveen Kumar has been appointed IG of Meerut range in the recent reshuffle carried out by the state government. Outgoing Meerut IG Alok Singh has been made police commissioner of Noida under the new system introduced by the Yogi Adityanath-led BJP government. The capital city of Lucknow will also have the commissionerate system of policing.

Apart from crime control, IG Kumar stressed on transparency in the department and public participation to bridge gap between police and common man. “We will stress on bridging the gap between a common man and police, and also on solving the grievances of the people with transparency. Also, we will work on community participation to ensure communal harmony in the area. We will also impart role at supervisory level to ensure there is no corruption in the investigation of cases so that there is an increased faith in police and in criminal justice system,” IG Kumar told TOI.

As IG (range), he will be monitoring law and order in four sensitive districts of Meerut range-- Meerut, Hapur, Bulandshahr and Muzaffarnagar . All these districts saw massive violence during anti- CAA protests last year. Kumar has till now held the post of inspector general (law and order) and was stationed in Lucknow. He was promoted to the post last year where he had been serving as DIG (law and order). A 2001 batch IPS officer, Kumar has held several prominent postings, including senior superintendent of police (SSP) in Lucknow in 2014.

He will now be working closely with his senior Meerut ADG Prashant Kumar and five SSPs in the zone to tackle law and order in state’s most crime-prone region.

Outgoing IG (zone) Singh was promoted to the rank of ADG last year and was handed over the freshly carved out post of police commissioner in Noida. Hailed as a sincere officer with a knack for solving complex cases, IG Kumar’s talent would be put to best use in Meerut range.

Title: Economist gives up JNU emeritus professorship
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Amit Bhaduri

NEW DELHI: Economist and Jawaharlal Nehru University professor emeritus Amit Bhaduri on Monday accused vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar of playing a pivotal role in “a larger and more sinister plan” of destroying the atmosphere of freedom of expression in the varsity. As a mark of protest, he returned the honour of emeritus professorship.

Mincing no words in his criticism of the JNU administration, Bhaduri in his letter to the vice-chancellor said, “I have learnt from friends and witnessed through public channels with alarm, and now with increasing disgust, how your handling of situations as the administrative and academic head of JNU has led to its steady deterioration paving the way for its intellectual disintegration.”

Bhaduri’s letter comes after 302 Indian and foreign academicians called for Kumar’s resignation in a signed statement that his position was untenable.

Saying it would be immoral on his part not to register his protest against “this larger, sinister scheme of throttling dissent unfolding at the university”, Bhaduri said that since his association with JNU from 1973, it had passed through various phases of justified or unjustified student unrest, competent or incompetent handling of situations by the administration, and even temporary shutdown of teaching.

However, Bhaduri said the present situation was different. “What is different now is not only incompetence of handling of situations by authorities, but a deliberate attempt to throttle the free atmosphere of debate and discussion for which JNU was known all over India. It was a matter of pride for its faculty and students that they were exposed to a whole range of ideas. This was something that did not happen anywhere else, and I would say from experience in very few academic institutions in the world,” he added.

Holding Kumar responsible for the current situation in the campus, Bhaduri said, “You seem determined on imprinting your administration’s narrow-minded worldview and shut other windows of ideas to the students, which you as the head of JNU also appear to be a pivotal part.”

The economist stated that returning the honour was purely symbolic as he and other emeritus professors “have already been locked out several months ago from the room allotted in JNU”.

“In practical terms, it means little. Yet, I do hope that my returning the honour that was bestowed on me by the university sends you the right message of my deep concern at your leadership, which is leading the premier institution of learning to its systematic disintegration,” Bhaduri added in his letter.

The JNU VC said: “I’ve not yet seen such a letter in my office. We appreciate contributions made by our emeritus professors. However, I wouldn’t like to comment on the merits of their decision.”

Title: Goa: Special cell to speed up pension papers of college teachers
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The directorate of higher education (DHE) has formed a separate cell ‘ Sevarth ’ to help ready pension papers of teachers and staffers of Goa University and affiliated colleges on the last day of their service itself.

Officials found that there were many undue delays in processing pension papers of teachers and other staffers of the Goa University and the 34 government and aided colleges. Officials said that several complaints were also being received, with some matters going to court.

Starting from September 2018, the cell has started maintaining data of employees of GU and affiliated colleges set to retire in the coming four years. This helps officials of the cell to prepare the pension papers in advance.

“DHE is possibly the only government department with such a cell. Even across the country very few departments will have such cells. The cell employees’ job is to exclusively coordinate with the accounts department to ready the pension papers of those about to retire. On the last day of the employee, the director of higher education or his nominee, reaches the institute and hands over a memento and the pension papers to the retiring staffer,” said DHE official.

In June last year, the Goa Human Rights Commission had issued notices to the state director of accounts, director of education and state education secretary for delay in processing nearly cases of retired school teachers’ pension papers. The Goa government also initiated inquiry after reports of many pensioners, including teachers, waiting for their pensions for years.

Similarly, in 2017, a petition was filed with the Goa Human Rights Commission over the alleged suicide of a peon, who had retired from the High Court of Bombay at Goa, and had been struggling to get his pension papers cleared.

Title: Rajasthan: Class VIII girl abducted and raped in Jhalawar

This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

Title: Mock drills in schools prep students for emergencies
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ), in collaboration with the government of Japan and the United Nations Development Programme ( UNDP ), is implementing a disaster preparedness project in municipal schools in the city.

The project, which has already covered nine schools in Vizag city and one school in Srikakulam district, aims to enhance tsunami preparedness and awareness in these institutions.

While the initiative in the ten schools focuses on tsunami preparedness under the ‘Partnership for strengthening school preparedness for tsunami in the Asia Pacific region’ project of the UNDP and the government of Japan, the ongoing project in other schools will cover all disasters.

The project extends support to the schools in preparing a disaster management plan and conducting mock evacuation drills. The GVMC has successfully completed mock drills on tsunami preparedness at all eight schools.

According to the GVMC officials, the project is currently being implemented in another 12 schools in the city. “The project will sensitise children and the school community on issues of disaster preparedness, life-saving skills and safety measures. As part of the programme, the schools will get a disaster management plan and committees including students will be formed. Students and teachers will be given practical guidance on evacuation drills and on preparing effective preparedness plans. Later, they will participate in mock evacuation drills. We are planning to replicate the initiative in all schools in the city,” said a GVMC official.

According to experts, factors such as rapid urbanisation, climate change and decreasing green cover have led to an increase in incidence of natural disasters, such as cyclones and intense storms. This in turn compounds the vulnerabilities of communities, particularly those living near the seashore. An effective preparedness plan and students and teachers trained in mitigation measures can minimise damage during a disaster, said officials of the civic body.

Meanwhile, the state school education department plans to make ‘school safety curriculum’ a part of the two-year diploma in elementary education. The curriculum is expected to help trainee teachers gain an understanding of school safety measures and translate into effective classroom training for students and make schools more resilient to disasters.

Title: Cops suspended for manhandling photojournalist
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Margao: South Goa SP Arvind Gawas on Monday suspended two policemen, driver Ujesh U Naik and constable Mahendra Gosavi, in connection with the manhandling of senior photojournalist Soiru Komarpant.

In his complaint , Komarpant said he was clicking photographs at the KTC bus stand, Margao , as part of his professional duties, of a brawl between two groups in police presence, when he was stopped by the police from taking the photos. He was held by the collar, pushed inside the police van and taken to Fatorda police station, he said.

Title: Vigilance squad to curb dumping of garbage
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has dedicated 14 waste collection vehicles manned with a vigilance squad member to keep a check on roadside dumping across the city.

For door-to-door waste collection, the AMC has hired Bengaluru-based agency P Gopinath Reddy that is responsible for collecting waste from households from 6am to 12pm and from market areas, hotels and marriage halls from 6pm to 10pm.

According to the waste collection agency, it has 100% door-to-door coverage. However, the city still witnesses dumping of waste on roads by residents and commercial waste generators. Burning of waste at several locations is also a cause of concern.

The initiative has taken based on civic chief Astik Kumar Pandey’s instructions and is being held under the guidance of solid waste management head Nandkishore Bhombe.

According to sanitation inspector Vishal Kharat, maximum dumping of waste occurs during the evening hours. “The time for running the vehicle is decided based on the dumping. There are 8 vehicles from the airport to railway station route, 4 on Baba Petrol Pump to Harsul T Point route and 2 from Cidco Bus Stand to Harsul T-point road. These vehicles run on both sides of the road,” he said.

“The objective is to change the habit of the people who dump waste on roads. As soon as someone dumps waste on the road or is about to do so, the vehicle will catch them and the vigilance squad member on the vehicle imposes penalty for waste dumping,” he added.

Title: Mob vandalises GMCH ward after patient’s death
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Aurangabad: A mob comprising 70 to 80 people damaged the doors and windows of the medicine ward and allegedly attacked security guards at the Government Medical College Hospital (GMCH) on Monday after a patient died while undergoing treatment there.

According to Meenakshi Bhattacharya, head of the department of medicine at GMCH, a patient admitted to the hospital was diagnosed with high blood pressure and ischemic heart disease. “The patient’s condition became critical on Sunday. He was then shifted to the Intensive Coronary Care Unit (ICCU). We had informed the relatives that the patient was critical from the time he was admitted. His kidney functions were deranged and urination had stopped,” she said.

The doctors said the patient had a minimum of 15 people with him from the time of admission and this continued even after he was shifted to the ICCU. “At 3pm, the attending doctor informed me that the patient’s condition had deteriorated further, and 15 people had entered the ICU,” Bhattacharya said. “A few moments later, the patient passed away and the hospital declared him dead,” she added.

According to the hospital staff, around 70 to 80 people gathered in the corridor of the medicine ward and some of them started breaking the glass doors. “The mob tried to physically assault three-four security guards. One guard was even punched in the ear. The diagnosis and treatment of the patient were going on properly. The patient had stopped medication for the past one month, which had led to the deterioration of his condition. Relatives were informed about the condition from the beginning,” Bhattacharya said.

The mob broke three glass doors. The hospital administration said that they will seek compensation for the attack on security guards and damage to property.

Begumpura police station inspector Sachin Sanap told TOI: “The process of scanning footage from CCTV cameras installed in the ward is underway. Depending on the suspects’ role, we will book them under sections 353 of the Indian Penal Code, apart from relevant sections of the Prevention of Damage to Public Properties Act.”

Title: New rules notified for liquor licence
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Jaipur: The government on Monday notified amendments to the excise policy wherein restaurants and hotels without getting commercial conversion approval will be eligible to apply for temporary seasonal liquor licences for six months, which can be extended.

The hotels are exempted from submitting maps.

As per the amendments, restaurants and hotels will be given licence for six months with payment of 75% of existing licencing fee. The period can be extended by paying remaining 25% of the fees. tnn

Title: JD(S) to expedite merger talks with LJD
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The Janata Dal (Secular) state unit will resume negotiations with the Loktantrik Janata Dal ( LJD ) regarding their proposed merger after January 17. The decision was taken at the JD(S) state committee meeting held here on Monday.

The meeting witnessed heated debates over the issue with a section of leaders raising doubts over lack of transparency in the process. According to sources, Thiruvananthapuram district committee chief Firoz Lal and Kannur district president P P Divakaran demanded transparency by taking into confidence district president and state committee members regarding the merger talks. Divakaran said all those who had taken the lead to form JD(S) when the party was split should be included in the talks. It was decided that the final decision would be taken only with the concurrence of the state committee.

State president C K Nanu told the leadership panel that a committee comprising minister K Krishnankutty, MLA Mathew T Thomas, A Neelalohitadas and him is leading the talks. He said MP Veerendra Kumar and MV Sreyams Kumar of LJD had already held discussions with JD(S) national president H D Deve Gowda. Krishnankutty told the committee that Gowda entrusted the panel to negotiate with LJD leadership when he met them at Kottakkal on December 24.

Sources said a few leaders also raised questions over the demand by LJD for eight district president posts. Leaders including Thomas said discussions should be transparent and JD (S) should demand more positions during merger.

The national leadership of JD(S) has asked state leadership to reach a consensus within the party and reach an agreement with LJD before submitting the merger formula to them.

Title: Policeman’s son key accused in Kota youth’s murder
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

KOTA: Son of a police inspector posted in Shahabad police station of Baran district is the alleged key accused in the murder of a 25-year-old youth Manish Gautam who was stabbed to death during a party on Sunday evening at Karneshwar Mahadev picnic spot under Anantpura police station area of the city.

Jayesh Rana is the son of inspector Hari Prasad, who is currently posted as circle inspector at Shahabad police station in Baran district.

Two other youths, identified as Sunil and Karan, have also been mentioned in the FIR as accused for the murder.

“Jayesh Rana, who is currently pursuing nursing course in Kota, was not invited to the birthday party but barged in along with two of his friends Sunil and Karan and got engaged in a scuffle which soon blew out of proportion,” said Devesh Bharadwaj, the circle inspector of Anantpura police station.

“Jayesh Rana, in fit of rage, stabbed Manishsthat punctured his heart,” he added. Manish was immediately rushed to a private hospital where the doctors referred him to MBS Hospital where he was declared brought dead,” said Bharadwaj.

The three accused absconded after the crime and efforts are underway to nab them, he said.

Manish Gautam (25), a native of Khatawada village in Bundi district who lived at Mahavir Nagar –III in Kota city and working in a coaching institute, had gone to attend one of his friend’s birthday party at Karneshwar Mahadev picnic spot on Sunday evening. Around 25-30 other friends were also present where a dispute between Manish Jayesh Rana had erupted.

Police handed over the body to family members on Monday morning, he added.

Title: I-T proceedings against Karti Chidambaram: Madras high court declines hearing, judge recuses
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Karti Chidambaram

CHENNAI: Multiple attempts made by counsel for former Union minister P Chidambaram’s son Karti Chidambaram and his wife in the Madras high court to stall income tax proceedings did not earn them any reprieve, as at least three different benches declined to offer any hearing.

It was a case of faux pas before Justice P Rajamanickam, where senior advocate K T S Tulsi made a mention and sought an urgent hearing of the pleas moved by Karti and his wife. The judge agreed to hear the case as lunch motion.

However, when Justice Rajamanickam commenced his hearing in the afternoon, Baskar and M Sheela, standing counsel for the tax department, raised several objections and said, “Even the crime numbers mentioned by the petitioners are incorrect. They must be amended first. Moreover, the cases are not pending before the additional chief metropolitan magistrate court in Egmore, as claimed. They are pending before the special court for cases against MPs and MLAs.”

Recording the submissions, Justice Rajamanickam wondered how the plea can he heard by him as he is not the portfolio judge. To this, senior counsel Nalini Chidambaram said they made a representation before the chief justice who directed the registry to list the matter before this court.

To this, Justice Rajamanickam asked: “If so, where is the order passed by the chief justice. Without such an order, how can I entertain the plea? The petition has been listed before this court since you made an urgent mention. I was not aware of the facts of the case. That apart, standing counsel for the department are raising several objections which have to be rectified.”

The court then directed the registry to post the matter before the chief justice to decide further course of hearing.

Then, Karti’s counsel again made a mention before Chief Justice S P Sahi’s bench seeking an urgent hearing on Monday, a day before the special court is scheduled to hear the plea. However, noting that he can’t take a decision without going into any note or order passed by Justice Rajamanickam, the chief justice asked counsel to make a representation to the registrar (judicial), who would forward it to the office of the chief justice for appropriate orders.

Earlier in the morning, Justice Anita Sumanth recused from hearing the plea moved by the two after Sheela and Baskar submitted that documents seized from Advantage Strategic Private Limited were the basis for the cases initiated against them and that the judge had represented the company when she was an advocate. Concurring with the submissions, Justice Anita Sumanth directed the registry to forward the plea to the chief justice for posting before another court.

The judge also turned down Tulsi’s submission that she should at least adjourn the matter till Monday with an interim injunction against the special court from framing charges.

Title: PFI west UP coordinator arrested for role in December 20 violence
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representational Image

MEERUT: Police force along with heavy contingent of Rapid Action Force (RAF) and Provincial Armed Constabulary (PAC) conducted raid in a minority-dominated area in the city to arrest Popular Front of India (PFI’s) west UP coordinator.

According to Lisari Gate circle officer Dinesh Shukla, “Tahir is an active member of extremist and Islamic fundamentalist organisation PFI. We had an intelligence input that he came back to Meerut after getting trained in Delhi to incite local population against CAA. He was also involved in the anti-CAA protests in Meerut on December 20 and was recognized from CCTV footages.”

The arrest was made on Sunday night from Lisari Gate area of Meerut city.

Notably, half a dozen members of PFI are already behind bars in Meerut and Shamli alone for their involvement in the recent anti-CAA violence. Out of these, four were from Shamli and two from Meerut. According to police sources, they had distributed controversial pamphlets in their respective areas. These pamphlets had allegedly incited local population to indulge in violent protests soon after Friday prayers on December 20.

At least 16 people had died in several districts of Uttar Pradesh when protests turned violent and clashes ensued between the protesters and police force. State police later claimed more than 250 cops were injured while 57 suffered gunshot wounds.

In fact, Uttar Pradesh police also said that PFI was actively involved in the recent violence. Uttar Pradesh DGP OP Singh said, “We have ample proof of their involvement. We arrested 25 PFI members for their negative role in the statewide protests, including state president Wasim. In fact, we have written to Union home ministry to ban this organisation.

According to police sources, PFI is successor to National Development Front, a Muslim organisation set up in Kerala in 1994 which merged with PFI in 2006. Since its inception, the organisation has been accused of various acts of religious extremism and is often seen as an offshoot of banned outfit Students Islamic Movement of India.

Title: Union minister inspects insect-hit areas in Barmer
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Union minister of state for agriculture Kailash Choudhary visits locustaffected areas in Barmer on Monday

JAISALMER: Union minister of state for agriculture Kailash Choudhary visited the locust-affected areas in Barmer on Sunday and Monday and took stock of the situation.

He also met the farmers and assured all possible help. He said that the Centre had issued compensation for the farmers and arrangements have been made for machines and pesticides to stop locust attack in future. Centre was keeping a watch on the locust-affected areas.

Kisan Sangh tehsil president Ladhuram Vishnoi said that a lot of damage has been caused to crops due to locust attacks and farmers should be given special package. Farmers in Baytu said that locusts were continuously eating their crops and there was no arrangement to kill locusts sitting on trees.

Addressing the media in Barmer, Choudhary said that the state government did not get Girdawari done on time and the department employees too did not help in controlling locusts. He said that in Gujarat, the farmers got immediate relief. The government along with locust control department has made arrangements to destroy locusts. Choudhary said that small groups of locusts are present at 15-20 places in western Rajasthan that will be destroyed in next 2-3 days.

Title: Cover construction sites, ensure proper waste disposal: AMC
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Aurangabad: Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey has issues directions to ensure that construction sites in the city are covered with net to prevent dust pollution. Pandey has also directed for appropriate disposal of construction and demolition waste. TOI had published a report on November 26 about the rampant violation of Construction and Demolition Waste Management Rules,2016.

The city engineer has issued a letter to deputy commissioner and head of anti-encroachment department Ravindra Nikam, head of solid waste management cell Nandkishore Bhombe, ward engineers and ward officers of Zones 1 to 9 in this regard.

“Public notices have been issued in local newspapers to notify property owners and those involved in construction activities to put up a net at the sitesunder construction and take other necessary measures for dust mitigation. Action should be taken against those not following these directives,” the letter states. The city engineer has also sought a report for actions taken against the violators.

The letter also states that action should be taken against those using public spaces for storing or dumping construction material and debris. Incidentally, the city sees a significant number of constructions for personal and commercial purposes. The air quality action plan of Aurangabad submitted by the AMC to the Central Pollution Control Board recognizes the construction and demolition activities as major source of air pollution.

The failure of authorities to keep a check on the violators is hampering the city’s air quality and therefore proving hazardous to health. Homoeopathic practitioner Kishor Pathak had stated that the dust pollution is leading to cases of conjunctivitis, silicosis, allergic rhinitis and allergic pharyngitis.

The measures taken by AMC on dust mitigation has been welcomed by environment experts. Pathak said though a lot needs to be done, the step taken by the civic body is a good beginning to control pollution.

Title: 400 farmers oppose Greenfield project
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Nashik: A section of farmers on Sunday opposed giving their land for the proposed Greenfield township project to be developed under the Town Planning scheme by the Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation Ltd (NMSCDCL).

Around 400 farmers have opposed the Greenfield project. Some of these farmers met on Sunday and decided to oppose the project. “We have decided to form a committee that will decide the further course of action against the project,” a farmer said.

The NMSCDCL has proposed the Greenfield township project over 750 acre in Makhmalabad area of the city, while the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) is the planning authority of the project.

The NMSCDCL has offered the land in 45:55 ratio where farmers will get 55% of the land they give for integrated development of the area. The land given by the farmers will be equipped with modern amenities, green belt, water supply, sewage supply lines, wide roads, parking spaces and host of other facilities.

In September last year, the General Body of the NMC had given approval to the proposal of the civic administration to develop TP scheme-based township project known as Greenfield project.

Thereafter, NMSCDCL had declared its intention of developing the new township project based on TP scheme on 750 acres in Makhmalabad areas of the city.

Last week, the smart city officials along with municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game gave a presentation to farmers about the proposed township.

“The 400 farmers, who are opposing the project, own around 50 hectare of the total 750 hectare proposed for the township project. The remaining farmers have given their consent to give their land,” an NMC official said.

Title: Panel headed by retired judge to organize jallikattu events in Madurai
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has constituted a committee headed by a retired district judge to organize jallikattu at Avaniapuram and Alanganallur in Madurai district this year. The court also directed that the committee would monitor the Palamedu jallikattu.

On Monday, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran passed the order while hearing a batch of petitions filed before the high court Madurai bench seeking inclusiveness of representatives from people belonging to all the communities in the jallikattu organizing committees and petitions with regard to dispute in organising jallikattu events at Avaniapuram, Alanganallur and Palamedu.

The judges appointed a retired principal district judge C Manickam as the chairman and appointed the district collector T G Vinay, Madurai city commissioner of police S Davidson Devasirvadham and corporation commissioner S Visakan as members of the jallikattu organizing committee to conduct jallikattu at Avaniapuram on January 15. The judges also appointed a 16-member advisory committee comprising the residents of Avaniapuram to assist the committee.

Similarly, the judges appointed the retired judge, district collector, south zone IG K P Shanmuga Rajeswaran and assistant director of town panchayat as members of the jallikattu organizing committee to conduct jallikattu at Alanganallur on January 17. The judges also appointed a 35-member advisory committee comprising the residents of Alanganallur to assist the committee.

The judges further directed that apart from the 35 members of the advisory committee, a person G Angusamy who filed a petition seeking to include his name may also be included as the member.

The additional advocate general K Chellapandian submitted that a committee named ‘Grama Pothu Mahalinga Swamy Madathu Committee’ has been formed to conduct jallikattu at Palamedu on January 16. The same committee has conducted jallikattu in 2019.

Taking cognizance of the submissions, the judges appointed Manickam as the chairman and appointed the district collector, south zone IG K P Shanmuga Rajeswaran and assistant director of town panchayat to organise and supervise jallikattu at Palamedu.

Title: Aishe Ghosh among four JNU students quizzed for January 5 violence
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

JNUSU chief Aishe Ghosh after her meeting with officers from Crime Branch

NEW DELHI: Two teams from Crime Branch on Monday went to Jawaharlal Nehru University to question four students allegedly involved in the violence on January 5. The students, who were identified from CCTV footage, included JNU Students’ Union president Aishe Ghosh , Pankaj Mishra, Prashant Kumar and Vhaskar Vijay Mech .

The special investigation team reached the JNU campus around 11am and first called Mishra and Mech. Ghosh was quizzed at the end. Police used systematic ways to question the students. They asked about the sequence of events and the identity of the masked attackers seen by them. Ghosh was also questioned regarding the events preceding the January 5 violence.

“I told the SIT that will meet them at the JNUSU office. They asked me to tell them about my experience on January 5 and what evidences I had. I told them that I was ready to share my experience. The team told me that other high-ranking police officers will speak to me in the coming days,” Ghosh said.

Sources said Ghosh was shown CCTV footage recovered from Periyar hostel and asked to identify the people accompanying her. Police said she might again be called after her claims are verified. She was also questioned about the violence at Sabarmati hostel and asked to narrate the sequence of events.

Ghosh was among seven of the nine suspects from Left-backed students’ organisations. They have been opposing the hike in hostel fees and had called for a boycott of the semester registration process.

Following the questioning, the students said the officers were “professional and cordial” and that it was an informal meeting. “I was worried since morning as I was going to be quizzed by Crime Branch. But it was a good meeting and they were cordial. I’ve been asked to submit my statement soon,” said PhD student Prashant Kumar.

Mech, a School of Arts and Aesthetics student, who met the SIT in the administrative building, said, “I have to submit my statement on the questions posed by them. I talk about it after that.” Their statements would be corroborated after which police will come to a conclusion.

JNUSU said that police also met some students who had got their medico-legal cases done after the January 5 violence. They will meet more students in the coming days.

Notices were also sent to the residences of three students who were identified after a sting operation by a TV news channel. Their mobile phones were found switched off ever since the programme was telecast. The students — Akshat Awasthi, Komal Sharma and Rohit Shah — were not found at the addresses submitted by them in their universities.

Title: Suspected ISI agent nabbed near Srikakulam
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: A suspected Inter-Services Intelligence ( ISI ) agent and three others were arrested by police at Kanchili in Srikakulam district on Sunday night. All four were handed over to Vizag cops on Monday morning.

According to sources, main suspect Syed Ashraf is a driver by profession and was allegedly carrying a mobile used by one Saleem, who is reportedly a wanted terrorist under the UAPA (Unlawful Activities Prevention Amendment Act). All four were travelling in a lorry when they were apprehended by Srikakulam police, who acted on inputs provided by their Vizag counterparts.

“We came to know that they are accomplices of Saleem, who is wanted in UAPA cases in Bangalore and Tamil Nadu , are in AP. Intelligence inputs informed that Saleem had used the mobile of Ashraf in Chittoor a few days back,” a police officer involved in the operation said. He added cops were tracking the four for the past two days, and apprehended them at Kanchili area. All the four have been brought to Vizag where their interrogation is on.

Title: Fair value of land may rise 20% as Goa eyes revenue growth
Content:
The new price for sale and registration of properties will come into force soon

PANAJI: The state government is likely to revise the fair value of land by 20% under the Goa Stamp (Determination of True Market Value of Property) Rules, 2003. The new price for sale and registration of properties will come into force soon. A file in this regard has been referred by the revenue department to revenue minister Jennifer Monserrate.With the enforcement of new rules, property buyers will have to shell out more for execution of sale agreements and deeds thereby generating more revenue for the state.A senior government officer said that once the file is approved by the minister, it will be referred to the cabinet before a notification is issued.Another senior government officer said that as per the rules, it was mandatory for the government to revise the fair value every year. However, last revision in the prices was done in 2013.The officer also said that as of now there is no proposal to fix minimum price for the execution of sale deeds for flats. “We have not touched stamp duty for executing agreements or deeds of sale,” he said.The new rates will not apply to purchases made by mundkars and tenants from landlords under the Goa, Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act, 1975 and the Goa, Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act, 1964.In land acquisition matters, the rates fixed as fair values are the broad guiding factors in determining the compensation to be paid by the acquisition officer.In 2013, taluka-wise minimum rates were fixed on base values and applicable to settlement zone up to an area of 1,000 sq mt. Depending on the zone and area involved, the base values were changed from a minimum of Rs 20 to over Rs 7,000 per sq mt. These rates are likely to remain the same, said a government officer.As per the notification of 2013, the applicable for Taleigao was increased from Rs 2,000 to Rs 4,000, while in Bambolim and Bainguinim, it was fixed at Rs 3,000 per sq mt. The same rate was made applicable to land tracts in Chimbel, St Cruz and Cujira. With the new rates, the byuers will have to pay an additional amount of Rs 700-800 per sq mt in these areas.Interestingly, the rate fixed for ward number 17 and 18 in Panaji was Rs 3,000 per sq mt, while it was Rs 5,000 in most of the other wards. Here the prices will go up by Rs 600-Rs 1,000 per sq mt, respectively.For Bardez, the rate has been fixed at Rs 3,000 in areas such as Sangolda, Guirim, Moira, Assagao and Salvador do Mundo, while it was Rs 5,000 in Candolim, Calangute and Nerul. In Aldona and Socorro it was Rs 4,000. The buyers will have to bear additional Rs 600-Rs 1,000 per sq mt in these areas.There is variation in land rates for Salcete taluka. The rate has been fixed at Rs 5,617 per sq mt in Navelim area, while it is Rs 3,427 per sq mt in Nuvem. A 20% hike will force buyers to bear additional burden of Rs 800-Rs 1,000 per sq mt.Sernabatim was the most expensive locale with land value being fixed at Rs 7,750 per sq mt. The new value for land would increase by Rs 1,500 per sq mt. Likewise, in Varca, Benaulim and Colva, the new rate would be in the range of Rs 700 to Rs 1,600 per sq mt.In Ponda, it varied between Rs 500 per sq mt to Rs 1,500 per sq mt. Here the higher rates will be in the range of Rs 100 to Rs 300 per sq mt.In Mormugao taluka too, there is no consistency in land value rates. In the coastal areas of Arossim, Cansaulim, Velsao, Pale and Chicolna, the rate was fixed at Rs 500 per sq mt, while in Quelosim was at Rs 350 per sq mt. The additional burden would be be in the range of Rs 70-Rs 100.In ‘developing’ areas of Cortalim and Sancoale, the rate was fixed at Rs 1,200 per sq mt, and Dabolim and Chicalim it was Rs 1,500 per sq mt. A change in the value would mean a rise of Rs 300 to the existing prices.

Title: Met forecasts light showers, temp may dip further
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Meerut: After a brief respite, city residents woke up to foggy and cold-wave like conditions as the temperature dipped to 7.2 degree Celsius on Monday. The maximum temperature settled at 16.2 degrees. There seems to be no respite for the days to come as the weatherman has forecast thunderstorm and hail from Tuesday onwards.

Neighbouring Saharanpur witnessed snow-like hailstorm after which residents here came together to get pictures clicked. While the maximum temperature was six notches below normal temperature, the minimum temperature did not deviate from the normal temperature. The city also recorded 0.2mm rainfall on Monday.

“The maximum and minimum humidity levels recorded here on Monday were 97% and 6% respectively. Meanwhile, rainfall and thunderstorm are predicted in the city in the days to come, due to high humidity levels and western disturbances,” said Brij Mohan, meteorological department in-charge of Meerut.

Meanwhile, doctors have advised elderlies and children to stay indoors and avoid going outside as much as possible. “At a time when the temperatures are dipping and rainfall is predicted, elderlies and kids should try to remain indoors at most times to ensure that they do not fall ill. In fact, in case of fever or any throat infection, people should see a doctor and not delay the treatment,” said Dr Raj Kumar, Meerut chief medical officer.

Title: ‘Want detailed report on UP neta saga’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Panaji: Protocol minister Mauvin Godinho on Monday said that he will seek a detailed report from the protocol secretary about how Lucknow resident Sunil Kumar Singh, claiming to be UP ’s cooperative minister, managed to take the state for a ride for almost 12 days. Further, he said he will ask the secretary for a list of measures that need to be taken to avoid such incidents.

“I will ask the protocol secretary to report to me how the incident happened, who was negligent and what steps should be taken to see that such an incident is not repeated,” he said

The minister told TOI that the procedure for giving a person the status of state guest includes the protocol department receiving a request from the said state for the same.

A police team which has gone to Lucknow, UP, also verified that the letter, which was sent to the Goa protocol department, was not sent by the UP government.

Meanwhile, Singh’s police custody, ends on Tuesday.

It all started with an e-mail that the protocol department received, requesting for a reservation for Singh in the state-run Circuit House. Without verifying the e-mail, the department considered him as a state guest and reserved a room for three days.

Title: Rajasthan: Pink locusts from Pakistan swarm desert districts, hit Rabi crops
Content:
Pink locusts spotted in Anoopgarh tehsil in Sriganganagar on Monday

JAIPUR: The menace of pink locusts, the most destructive of the species, is continuing in the desert districts of Rajasthan. On Sunday evening, a fresh swarm of pink locusts entered Anoopgarh tehsil in Sriganganagar and some areas of Barmer from the Bhawalpur region of Pakistan with the gusty winds, forcing farmers to guard their Rabi crop using traditional methods like beating trumpets and utensils on Monday afternoon.The Locust Warning Organization (LWO), an agency under the ministry of agriculture, has issued warning to local administration to use anti-locust pesticides in their respective areas.“Since morning, the operation has been going at several places in Anoopgarh and the area will be declared ‘cleaned’ by Tuesday afternoon,” said K L Gurjar, director of LWO, over the phone from Anoopgarh.Gurjar is camping in the affected area since yesterday and coordinating the operation which includes spraying chemicals in both cropped and crop areas. “The operation in Sriganganagar has been comparatively easier as farmers are more resourceful. They have come forward and taken part in it by using sprinklers and tractors. So, the area was cleaned within a day,” said Gurjar.On Monday afternoon, the control room in Jodhpur was alerted about another fresh swarm entering Barmer from Pakistan. “The latest update is that the pink variant, numbering a few lakhs, have come in some 8-10 groups. The nearest available patrol team has been rushed to make an assessment and the clearing operation will begin at sunrise on Tuesday. I am hoping that in a day or two, we will declare the area cleaned,” said Gurjar. The farmers in this area are less forthcoming, according to him, and the LWO has to channelise all its resources to destroy the locusts.The pink locusts, spotted in the last one week, are a major cause of concern. They are more resilient than the regular yellow locusts, have stronger wings and can fly for longer duration. These locusts are posing danger mainly to wheat, mustard and barley crops.

Title: Visakhapatnam: Tight security for Republic Day celebrations
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: The Republic Day Celebrations will be held on RK Beach Road in the city under tight security.

A force of more than 2,500 personnel, including anti- Maoist Greyhounds, anti-terrorist Octopus and other armed forces would keep vigil in the city.

This is the second time the city is the venue for a ceremonial event—Independence Day celebrations were held in 2015 on Beach Road.

On Monday, collector V Vinaychand, GVMC commissioner G Srijana, and VMRDA vice-chairman Koteswara Rao reviewed the arrangements for Republic Day celebrations.

Various departments would join the parade with around 30 tableaus. Over 10 contingents including that of Army, Navy, CRPF, SPF, contingents from Telangana, Odisha , Armed Reserve Force, NCC cadets, Red Cross volunteers would be part of the parade.

The programme would start around 8 am and conclude around 10.30 am. Governor Biswabhushan Harichandan, chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy, the high court chief justice, chief secretary and DGP will attend the event.

Title: Opposition resolution on CAA must have made Pak happy: Ravi Shankar Prasad
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

NEW DELHI: Slamming resolution of opposition parties against the Citizenship Amendment Act, Union minister Ravi Shankar Prasad on Monday said Pakistan must be happy over the move and asserted that the new law exposes Islamabad's “barbaric treatment” of minorities.

“Opposition unity stands exposed as major parties like SP, BSP, TMC and AAP kept away (from a meeting convened by Congress chief Sonia Gandhi ). The resolution is neither in national interest nor in the interest of security. It is also not in the interest of those minorities who fled neighbouring countries to escape persecution,” Prasad told reporters.

Congress and 19 other opposition parties passed a resolution on Monday, demanding that the amended citizenship law be withdrawn and process of National Population Register (NPR) immediately stopped, asserting that it was all part of an “unconstitutional package” that targeted poor people, SC/STs and minorities.

Prasad said Congress is ready to stoop to any level against Prime Minister Narendra Modi . “Today Congress stands with the gang of tukde-tukde and urban Maoists. I am making an unambiguous allegation that Congress is inciting violence in the country,” he said.

The minister said Congress should explain what is the reality about the state of the minorities in Pakistan and Bangladesh. “Rahul Gandhi and Sonia Gandhi should explain whether most of the people facing persecution on religious lines in Pakistan and Bangladesh were poor and Dalit or not?” he asked.

Prasad said opposition is making baseless allegations that the bill was passed in a hurry as he added, “The bill was debated in both Houses for two days after which it was passed through voting. Now it is being alleged that the bill was passed in a huff.”

Taking a dig at the absence of several key opposition parties from Monday’s meeting, he said, “The so-called resolution was passed after meeting of 19 parties. However, BSP, SP, AAP and TMC were not present in the meeting and their absence exposes the opposition unity.”

BJP leader GVL Narasimha Rao took a dig at P Chidambaram for opposing CAA, saying that the former finance minister had brought his level of intellect at par with that of Rahul Gandhi .

Chidambaram asked the Prime Minister to have a televised Q and A session over the CAA. The former Union minister alleged that Modi is reluctant to take questions over the Act, which has triggered widespread protests across the country.

"Sonia Gandhi, Rahul Gandhi and Chidambaram are telling lies about CAA and misleading people and country," he added. "When Pakistan is being exposed in the world for persecuting minorities, those opposing CAA are furthering Pakistan's point of view," Rao said.

Title: Delhi: Registration can’t paper over cracks, road to assembly may pass via infra
Content:
Residents of Gharoli in Mandawali Fazalpur appear satisfied with the efforts put in by AAP government

NEW DELHI: Lofty promises no longer stir up emotions in most residents of unauthorised colonies in the city, cannon fodder as they have been for different political parties for decades. Unsurprisingly, in the run-up to the latest assembly , too, the netas are in a mad scramble to take credit for giving that final push for a legal stamp to these areas.And while the grant of conveyance deeds of houses to a handful of residents by the Centre has triggered a war of words between AAP , BJP and Congress , the residents themselves are wary of celebrating early, as TOI found on visiting some of these colonies in south, east and north Delhi.In east Delhi’s Kondli, congested lanes, broken roads and overflowing drains serve a reminder, if ever one was needed, that large swathes of Delhi are yet to be put on the development map. For some residents, a renewed hope to finally be able to call the homes they have been living in as rightfully their own is enticing, but the overwhelming sentiment is in favour of getting at least the basic infrastructure .RD Sharma, a resident, can’t hide his disappointment as he recalls a visit to a helpdesk set up by DDA to facilitate the conferment of ownership rights. “They are just sharing information about the documents required for getting the conveyance deed. Also, ownership rights don’t mean that the area has been regularised. Unless that is done, we can forget about any planned development,” he says. While many residents are not clear about the process, others are not sure exactly how much ownership rights will benefit them.Sharma’s neighbour points to the badly damaged stretch to ask if they don’t even deserve proper roads. Encroachments are rampant and, as Sharma says, the “illegal” tag associated with the area has kept any kind of planned activity at bay. However, he commends the work done by AAP government in the recent times. “Internal roads are better and even sewer lines have been laid,” he says.In nearby Gharoli Dairy Farm, poor sanitation raises a stink. Shashi Kala, a longtime resident, says even a hint of rain causes drains to overflow. “It’s difficult to believe that we live in the national capital,” Kala asserts. Go a little further, however, and residents of Gharoli in Mandawali Fazalpur appear satisfied with the efforts put in by AAP government. Hazi Irshad, for one, says he is least bothered about the ownership rights. “Regularisation has nothing to do with the pace of development. Our roads are in a better shape and water and power supply is regular now,” he says.Anand Sharma (name changed), a resident of Mayur Vihar Phase I, on the other hand, argues that allowing illegal construction and, then, demanding their regularisation for vote politics is turning city into urban sprawl. “I welcome DDA’s move to set a cutoff date for approving documents for ownership rights.”At the other end of the city, in south Delhi areas like Sangam Vihar, Ambedkar Nagar, Deoli and Tughlaqabad, which bet heavily on AAP in the 2015 assembly election, the mood is more upbeat. Residents acknowledge that they have seen development on a par with other areas: roads are smoother, water supply has improved and CCTV cameras are being installed.For many residents approached by TOI, the announcement of “regularisation” by the Centre doesn’t hold much water. Kiran Gupta, a resident of Madangir, says she isn’t even sure if the promises will materialise into anything. “I bought forms under the Rajiv Gandhi Awas Yojna a decade ago. Did anyone keep their promise? At least now I am saving thousands of rupees every month in power and water bills,” she said. In the last five years, she claims, concrete roads have been built and the drainage system improved.Not far away, in Shiv Shankar Market of Ambedkar Nagar, we catch up with Kusum Devi who is busy with her weekly shopping. “This road has been rebuilt twice in the last five years. My daughter studies in Class XII in a government school and the infrastructure there has also improved by leaps and bounds,” she claims.Ram Singh, a resident of Duggal Colony close by, says most families continue to buy bottled water but this is mostly because of a general fear of contamination. “During monsoon, the drains start overflowing. While the situation has improved, there are still pain points,” Singh explains.Rajdeep Paswan, a fruit vendor and resident of Sangam Vihar, is clear about where his preferences lie. “We like (Narendra) Modi at the Centre and (Arvind) Kejriwal in Delhi. Our water woes have been virtually resolved,” Paswan said. “You may feel that things are bad right now, but you should have come here five years ago,” he signs off emphatically.
