My daughter studies in Class XII in a government school and the infrastructure there has also improved by leaps and bounds,” she claims.Ram Singh, a resident of Duggal Colony close by, says most families continue to buy bottled water but this is mostly because of a general fear of contamination. “During monsoon, the drains start overflowing. While the situation has improved, there are still pain points,” Singh explains.Rajdeep Paswan, a fruit vendor and resident of Sangam Vihar, is clear about where his preferences lie. “We like (Narendra) Modi at the Centre and (Arvind) Kejriwal in Delhi. Our water woes have been virtually resolved,” Paswan said. “You may feel that things are bad right now, but you should have come here five years ago,” he signs off emphatically.

Title: Land scam interim report likely next week
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The three-member special investigation team ( SIT ) probing tampering of government land records would submit its interim report next week.

The SIT chief Vijay Kumar had earlier said it would submit the report on January 11. Vijayakumar said: “We have prepared the report and we will submit it on next Monday.” The government has given three months’ time to the SIT complete the report, he said.

The SIT began its probe by accepting petitions from people in 13 mandals within the vicinity of the city. It received 2,434 petitions of which 1,563 came under its purview.

Title: Auto rickshaw stand owner sets himself ablaze over ‘harassment by cops’; SI suspended, probe ordered
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Meerut: A 32-year-old auto rickshaw stand owner set himself ablaze after allegedly being misbehaved by a few policemen, who he said were extorting money from a driver.

Ashwini Lodhi, 28, was rushed to a Delhi hospital with 50% burn injuries on Sunday evening. Soon after the incident, a sub inspector was suspended for dereliction of duty and a probe was instituted under a DSP-rank officer.

“With 50% burn injuries, Lodhi has been referred to higher centre in Delhi. His condition is critical,” SSP Meerut Ajay Sahni said.

On their part, local police said that Lodhi was running an illegal auto stand in the area. “On Sunday afternoon, local policemen were trying to manage traffic near Maliyana flyover in TP Nagar police station. When they slapped a fine on an auto rickshaw driver, a commotion broke out and several drivers, including Lodhi, gathered and protested,” a police officer said.

But the drivers and Lodhi said that they were protesting against local police’s extortion.

Later, peeved over alleged misbehavior by the policemen, Lodhi poured some flammable substance on his body and lit it near Maliyana flyover.

Lodhi was rushed to a city hospital from where he was referred to Delhi. A sub inspector posted at the local police outpost under TP Nagar police station was suspended for dereliction of duty.

Investigation under DSP Chakrapani Triapthi was also set up and the statement of Lodhi was recorded.

According to sources, in his statement, Lodhi claimed that he took the extreme step due to harassment of the auto drivers in the name of challans.

“We have received a complaint from the deceased’s brother. FIR is yet to be filed. Investigation is already on under a DSP-level officer,” Meerut SP (City) Akhilesh Narayan Singh said.

Title: HC relief for man in drugs case
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court has granted a six-month anticipatory bail to a man who claimed to have reasonable apprehension of being arrested by Jalgaon police in connection with the seizure of over 31 kg of marijuana around three months ago.

Jillapeth police station in neighbouring Jalgaon district arrested Vicky Sonawane and Tanveer Tadvi from a bus stand and bags containing the marijuana were seized from them. During interrogation the accused claimed that got marijuana from a person called Fakira. Police then launched a hunt for a man identified as Fakira Masum Tadvi.

Worried over being arrested, Tadvi approached lower court which rejected his bail plea, following which he reached out to the HC seeking anticipatory bail citing that he has reasonable apprehension of being arrested mere on basis of his first name and he was not the same person the police are looking for.

Representing Fakira, lawyer Joydeep Chatterji, contested that the investigation officer did not identify if the person named by the arrested accused and also if the applicant in the case is the same person.

Jalgaon police, meanwhile, contested that the applicant in the case remained in touch with the arrested accused forcing them to believe that he is the same Fakira they have been looking for in the registered case.

HC justice RG Avachat, while granting bail, said: “The arrested accused did not give full name of any person from whom they had brought marijuana. The first name of the applicant only tallies with the name disclosed by the accused. Only this much material is grossly inadequate to curtail liberty of the applicant by taking him in custody.”

The court added that the investigation officer has made no investigation to find whether the applicant in fact did sell narcotics like marijuana.

“With a view to give the investigating officer full liberty to make investigation to find as to whether it is the applicant from whom the accused had brought marijuana, I am inclined to grant the applicant anticipatory bail for a duration of six months,” the court ruled.

Title: Rajasthan seeks Centre aid to fight locust menace, says it is doing enough
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Locust Warning Organization is carrying out anti-locust operations in the state

JAIPUR: Refuting the Union ministers’ allegations of casual approach in handling the locust attack, Rajasthan government has asked the agriculture ministry to provide logistic support to its agency Locust Warning Organization (LWO) for effectively carrying out anti-locust operations in the state.

The LWO is handling operations from Sriganganagar to Gujarat border with just 35 vehicles while the state has claimed to have provided 450 tractors for spraying chemicals in the affected areas. Even the LWO is not getting real-time assistance on the movement of locusts and forecast from the Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO), confessed LWO officials.

The incessant attacks by locusts in Rajasthan since May 23, 2019 have become a matter of tension between the Centre and the state.

Union Jal Shakti minister Gajendra Singh Shekhawat and Union minister of state for agriculture Kailesh Chaudhary have blamed CM Ashok Gehlot for delay in providing assistance including financial help to farmers and logistical support on time.

“The state already has surplus funds under the State Disaster Relief Fund (SDRF) but they are yet to grant any help to farmers. Second, I have learnt that cooperation with the central machinery in reaching out to the affected areas is minimal. Gujarat government has prevented the tragedy on time as they coordinated with the central government in the better manner,” said Chaudhary over the phone.

Claiming that the state has provided full assistance to the central government, Lalchand Kataria, agriculture minister of the state, said even the central government officials on the ground are admitting the humongous support received from the state.

“I am a farmer and don’t want to engage in politics over locust attacks in the state. The state has done it best as per our understanding and ability to deal with the problem,” he said.

Defending the delay in carrying out assessment of crop damage, Kataria said everything was done on time. “The assessment of crop damage has already been completed of the vast affected areas and information is being uploaded on the portals. The amount will be disbursed in the coming days,” said Kataria.

He also cleared that the state provided 450 tankers, mostly hired on rent to expedite work. “Those blaming must know that the state is providing chemicals for free to the farmers. The scale of locust attack is very huge and the Centre should appreciate efforts made by the state as we appreciate their efforts,” said Kataria.

The minister added that the state had deputed agriculture department officials to complete the Girdawari report on loss of crops latest by Wednesday.

Title: Petition seeks fixed gallery for jallikattu at Alanganallur
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has issued notice to the state government on a plea which sought to construct a permanent gallery for the public to witness jallikattu at Alanganallur in Madurai district.

In the petition, G Thirumurugan, a resident of Ramanathapuram district, stated that since several people across the state participated in the pro-jallikattu protests in 2017, lakhs of people thronged Madurai to witness the sport which was conducted after the ban was lifted. He stated that apart from this people from across the country and even foreigners came to witness the jallikattu events in Madurai.

Since several people come to witness the world famous event conducted at Alanganallur, people faced hardship. He stated that he had submitted a representation to the authorities concerned to construct a permanent gallery at Alanganallur, however, no steps were taken so far.

Hence, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to construct a permanent gallery. When the petition was heard on Monday, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran issued notice to the state government and adjourned the case to a further date for hearing.

Title: Jaipur airport ban on kites, lanterns
Content:
File photograph of people releasing a lantern on Makar Sankranti

JAIPUR: Flying kites and lanterns is fun and part of the tradition of celebrating Makar Sankranti. But it has now become a threat to air traffic. On Monday, the Airports Authority of India (AAI), Jaipur, issued an advisory urging people not to fly kites or lamps within the 5km periphery of the airport.In the advisory, the airport authority has stated that kites and ‘manjhas’ can be dangerous for flight operations. “The air traffic control is constantly asking pilots landing here to be careful during the festival when kites dot the sky. Also, the trend of releasing gas lamps can prove to be dangerous,” said a senior official of the air traffic control.Speaking to TOI, Jaideep Balhara, director, AAI, said, “In 2018, we had a case in which the engine of an aircraft developed a snag after getting caught in ‘manjha’ strings while landing in Jaipur. The lanterns too create problems in the evening.”The air traffic control is also alerting pilots asking them to “be careful of lanterns as the festival is on”.“We have issued an appeal in which we have urged people not to fly kites and release lamps within the 5km periphery of the airport,” said a senior official.“We have issued an appeal in which we have urged people not to fly kites and release lamps within the 5km periphery of the airport,” said a senior official.Some airports, including Ahmedabad and Delhi, have banned lantern kites within 10km of the airport. In 2018, the civil aviation ministry too had proposed a ban on such lanterns. Many incidents have been reported in 2018 and 2019 when kites and lanterns caused problems for pilots during landing and take-off.The restriction is in accordance with the amendment to the Aircraft Rules, 1937. “No person shall fly a lantern kite or a kite from a place located within ten kilometres from the aerodrome reference point of any aerodrome in India,” a draft notification of the civil aviation ministry, released in 2018, stated.A senior air traffic control (ATC) official said flying kites can pose a security threat to airport operations.

Title: Nothing to do with JNU unrest: IIT faculty on director’s email
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

V Ramgopal Rao

NEW DELHI: An email dated December 19, 2019 from V Ramgopal Rao , director, Indian Institute of Technology , Delhi, to his colleagues went in circulation on Monday, after it was linked to the current state of Jawaharlal Nehru University .

While Rao could not be contacted for his reaction, senior faculty members at the IIT said that the mail was written 18 days before the JNU violence and was not connected to the unrest in the neighbouring campus.

Rao, in his email to his colleagues in different departments, had encouraged them to recruit the faculty members leaving JNU, especially if they held distinguished track record.

Rao wrote: “I am receiving many feelers from senior Jawaharlal Nehru University faculty showing a willingness to move to IIT Delhi, considering the deteriorating situation in JNU. I am told that some of them are also applying to other institutions given the impression that IIT Delhi doesn’t encourage lateral movement into higher positions. It will be a pity if we lose out on such good people because of any of these reasons/perception. I leave it to your judgment how you wish to deal with this. Institute will be very open to recruitment of senior faculty who have a distinguished track record.”

Speaking on the condition of anonymity, a dean who is also responsible for the recruitment process, said that as a general rule IITs does not recruit people from outside at senior levels.

“We usually recruit people from outside at the assistant professor level. We do not recruit too many people at the associate and professor levels from other institutions. That iso the norm here unlike other places. So there was a general message sent that there are people in Council of Scientific and Industrial Research labs and in other institutes, including JNU, who would like to move to IIT because of our facilities and better equipment, which have been bolstered by the Institute of Eminence tag. In that context, he asked us to consider,” the dean added. “This has nothing to do with JNU. It was written way before that.”

Title: Rajasthan: Mayawati skips Sonia Gandhi meeting over ‘betrayal’ of Ashok Gehlot
Content:
Mayawati

JAIPUR: Accusing the Congress of betraying the Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) despite giving outside support to the government in Rajasthan , party supremo Mayawati on Monday did not attend the Opposition meeting called by United Progressive Alliance (UPA) chairperson Sonia Gandhi Mayawati also appealed to the Centre to make amendments to the controversial Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC).In a series of tweets in Hindi, Mayawati said, “Despite giving outside support to the Congress in Rajasthan, they made the BSP MLAs join their party for the second time, which is betrayal.”“Thus, participating in the opposition meeting called by the Congress will be demoralising for the BSP. So BSP will not attend the meeting,” she said.Her remarks came ahead of the opposition meeting convened by Sonia Gandhi on the issue of CAA, NRC and attacks on students in Jamia Millia Islamia University, Aligarh Muslim University and Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU). In a big jolt to BSP supremo Mayawati, all six members of the Rajasthan Assembly belonging to Bahujan Samaj Party, joined Congress in September last year.Similar thing had happened during the previous Congress government. Gehlot poached all six BSP MLAS and inducted three ministers of state and three were made parliamentary secretaries equivalent to ministers of state.Lamenting at the central government over the controversial CAA, Mayawati appealed to the government to take it back.“The BSP is against the CAA and the NRC. BSP appeals to the government to roll back the divisive and unconstitutional Act. Even the politicisation of the students in JNU and other varsities is unfortunate,” the BSP chief added.

Title: ‘Extend date for filing objections to new wards’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Left parties requested district officials on Monday to extend the deadline for filing objections against the draft on ward delimitation prepared by the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) to January 27 instead of January 17.

At a meeting with district collector V Vinay Chand and GVMC officials, Communist Party of India (Marxist) leader RKSV Kumar said the state government had recently increased the number of wards in the city to 98. “Consequently, the GVMC completed the delimitation process and published a draft. The ward reorganisation process was done in an unscientific manner. There was no mention of names of various major colonies and areas in the draft. The number of wards was determined based on the 2011 Census. But the city witnessed a growth in population in the last nine years. Several city dwellers will leave for their home towns for Sankranti. We demand the officials extend the deadline to January 27,” said Kumar.

Communist Party of India functionaries also submitted a representation to GVMC additional commissioner G Somannarayana, requesting the public be given more time to submit their objections on the new boundaries of 98 wards. CPI leaders K Satyanjaneya, G Rambabu and others were present.

Title: Panchayat polls in Amaravati region on hold
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

MLA Ramakrishna Reddy and his supporters were detained during a rally in favour of decentralisation at Penumak... Read More

AMARAVATI: In a surprising move, the government has decided not to hold elections to village panchayats in the capital city area. The decision to put the elections on hold was taken after finalization of reservations. Sources said panchayat raj principal secretary Gopalakrishna Dwivedi advised the state election commission (SEC) not to go ahead with the issuance of election notification.

Stating that the government is planning to create a new municipal corporation for Amaravati, the principal secretary urged the SEC to put the elections on hold. The government might make an announcement on upgrading the capital city area into a municipal corporation in the next assembly session. As per the original schedule, the SEC was scheduled to issue notification for elections to mandal parishad territorial constituencies (MPTCs) and ZPTCs on Jan 17.

The move is being seen as a measure to calm local villagers who have been protesting for the last 27 days against the proposal to shift the capital city from Amaravati. Upgrading it into a urban civic body is likely to help the area witness rapid development as the government can tap funds from the urban development ministry. The state is planning to pool funds for taking up underground drainage, roads, sewage treatment system and other developmental works in the capital city area by making it a municipal corporation.

The move will also give an upper hand to the ruling YSRC in pushing opposition TDP into a corner for not making the capital city area into an urban civic body in the last five years while making tall claims to build a world-class city.

The SEC has also been asked to delay the release of election notification for a few other village panchayats which are proposed to be merged with the nearest municipal towns. While Dachepalle, Gurazala and Nizampatnam would be upgraded to nagar panchayats, Bethapudi, Navulur, China Kakani, Atmakur and Yerrabalem villages would be merged with Mangalagiri municipality. Praturu, Vaddeswaram, Penumaka, Ippatam, Mellempudi, Chirravuru, Gundimeda and Undavalli would be merged with Tadepalle municipality.

Meanwhile, the capital city area continues to reverberate with protests as farmers staged dharnas in almost all the villages on Monday. Police had set up dharna camps in many areas, including vacant sites owned by farmers. Women from capital area villages like Venkatapalem and Krishnayapalem visited the place where Prime Minister Narendra Modi had laid the foundation stone for Amaravati and performed pujas seeking divine intervention to stop the shifting of the capital.

Women from Ananthavaram village performed prayers at Sri Venkateswara Swamy temple. They said the SVBC chairman lost his job after making unsavoury comments against the area’s farmers and women.

Siva Swamy, the seer of Siva peetham in Tallayapalem village near Thullur, visited the dharna camp in Thullur and said he would perform a special yagam for the welfare of farmers, for which he would invite seers from about 153 peethams across the country. “The capital city should stay in Amaravati as it’s a divine place. The yagam would be held at the place where the PM had laid the foundation stone,” he said.

TDP national general secretary Nara Lokesh also visited Bapatla and met farmers who were arrested during the ongoing agitation for Amaravati. He also participated in a round-table meeting organized by the Amaravati JAC and later went around the town to collect donations for the ‘Amaravati movement’.

This story is from January 14, 2020
