Title: Local panels to get 50% of forest-fire prevention funds
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Kozhikode: The state has decided to make its forest-fire prevention and management activities for the upcoming summer participatory. The forest department has issued directions that 50% of total funds allotted for forest-fire prevention be used for activities of the grassroots-level vana samrakshana samithies (VSSs), eco-development committees (EDCs) and forest development agencies ( FDAs ).

The move is expected to broad base the activities and add to the manpower on the ground. There are over 400 VSSs and 190 EDCs under the various territorial and wildlife divisions in the state.

Kerala witnessed 314 forest fires in 2018 affecting 1,114 hectares of land. Nearly 7,893km of fire lines were created during 2017-18 at a cost of Rs 23 crore.

“This year the head of the forest force has issued a directive to ensure that 50% of funds earmarked for fire protection be used for anti-fire activities of participatory forest institutions like VSS and EDC . The respective VSSs/EDCs will be provided Rs 500 to Rs 1,000 per hectare for undertaking fire-prevention measures in forest areas coming under them. VSS/ EDA members can become fire watchers and constitute fire gangs from among themselves,” said S R Radhakrishnan, assistant conservator of forests.

Forest department officials said this will ensure community participation, even among tribals, in forest-fire protection and also create awareness in communities about preventing fires caused by anthropogenic activities. He said the department has drawn up a fire plan and has classified the forests into three categories depending on the level of fire risk on the basis of incidents over the last five years.

A centralised control room is now functional and there were 45 fire incidents reported between December 24 and January 13 as per Fire Management Information System (FMIS), of which 43 were controlled burning carried out as part of fire-protection activities.

Meanwhile, citizen volunteer groups and environmentalists from across the state, who have come together under the Fire Free Forests collective, met authorities of the forest department and the State Disaster Management Authority (SDMA) on Monday with the plea for immediate steps to ensure the state free of fires in the upcoming summer season. The collective has called for constituting an independent fire force in the department, modernising fire prevention and control measures by deploying drones, and also increasing the allocation for fire-prevention measures.

Fire Free Forests representatives N Badusha, Anitha S , K M Sulaiman, Raheem Thalanad and Veena M were part of the delegation. They held discussions with P K Kesavan, principal chief conservator of forests and head of forest force, and principal secretary, revenue & disaster management Dr K Venu.

Badusha said methods adopted by the forest department to control forest fires are outdated and unscientific. He said involvement of district administrations, local self-government bodies and the SDMA should be ensured for fire-protection and control measures which are now mostly carried out by the department alone. “There is need for at least a fourfold increase in funds,” he added.

Title: Rajasthan: Mayawati skips Sonia Gandhi meeting over ‘betrayal’ of Ashok Gehlot
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Mayawati

JAIPUR: Accusing the Congress of betraying the Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) despite giving outside support to the government in Rajasthan , party supremo Mayawati on Monday did not attend the Opposition meeting called by United Progressive Alliance (UPA) chairperson Sonia Gandhi .

Mayawati also appealed to the Centre to make amendments to the controversial Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC).

In a series of tweets in Hindi, Mayawati said, “Despite giving outside support to the Congress in Rajasthan, they made the BSP MLAs join their party for the second time, which is betrayal.”

“Thus, participating in the opposition meeting called by the Congress will be demoralising for the BSP. So BSP will not attend the meeting,” she said.

Her remarks came ahead of the opposition meeting convened by Sonia Gandhi on the issue of CAA, NRC and attacks on students in Jamia Millia Islamia University, Aligarh Muslim University and Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU). In a big jolt to BSP supremo Mayawati, all six members of the Rajasthan Assembly belonging to Bahujan Samaj Party, joined Congress in September last year.

Similar thing had happened during the previous Congress government. Gehlot poached all six BSP MLAS and inducted three ministers of state and three were made parliamentary secretaries equivalent to ministers of state.

Lamenting at the central government over the controversial CAA, Mayawati appealed to the government to take it back.

“The BSP is against the CAA and the NRC. BSP appeals to the government to roll back the divisive and unconstitutional Act. Even the politicisation of the students in JNU and other varsities is unfortunate,” the BSP chief added.

Title: Law student detained for threatening to end life
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Aurangabad: A law student from Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Law College was detained by police for threatening to commit suicide.

The student was upset as his pleas for getting power and water supply to the student hostel was not being heard by the college administration. He had threatened self-immolation and accordingly put kerosene on himself on the college premises but was stopped by fellow students present at the spot.

Following this incident, a team from Cantonment police station reached the spot and took the student, Pratik Mhaske, in preventive detention.

Cantonment police station inspector Manoj Pagare said, “After learning about a student trying to immolate himself, we detained him before summoning his parents from Sindhkhedraja of Buldhana. He was counselled before we handed him over to parents.”

Talking to TOI, Pratik said, “The hostel building has exceeded its stipulated lifespan, but the college administration has moved 45 students in this hostel. We have been requesting basic facilities including power and water supply, but our request is being turned down citing that the structure is too old for granting fresh funds.”

Similar views were also expressed by other law students, who unanimously maintained that the issue was raised with the college administration and several letters have been shot to the state secretariat, but in vain.

Despite repeated attempts, calls made to college principal Niranand Behera went unanswered. Sources confirmed that as the hostel has exceeded its stipulated life span. “The issue is being raised by students for past several months, but it was only after one of the students residing in the hostel went to take an extreme step, the college administration took the issue seriously.”

Title: Rural SP pulls up PWD for bad quality residential quarters
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Aurangabad: Aurangabad superintendent of police Mokshada Patil, taking note of visible fault lines in the newly-constructed residential quarters meant for policemen in Pachod, has pulled up the public works department and sent a letter, warning them of action.

The officer has also demanded safety audit of the two buildings that are yet to be occupied by the policemen and their families.

“During regular inspection of Pachod police station, the quarters were also visited only to witness visible fault lines. Seemingly dangerous, we have written to the PWD to give us safety audit report as they are the technical agency for the same,” Patil said.

Sources informed that SP expressed her serious displeasure over the quality of work as the structure has started to give-in.

During one of her recent visits, the officer noticed cracks on the walls and water stagnation due to uneven surface in the basement of the buildings.

Accordingly, Pachod police station’s assistant inspector Atul Yerme sent a letter stating that the two buildings comprising eight apartments each have developed cracks within and outside the structure, with some windows having only iron frames while the others have glass shields.

“Drainage lines have not been covered, while tiles fitted on the stairs are coming out. Paver blocks have not been installed in the open space and plaster on the exterior walls has started coming out. The septic tank is also not covered properly,” the letter read.

A total of Rs 2.13 crore has been spent for the construction of these two residential apartments. When contacted, Yerme said that following the letter from the SP, PWD has started carrying out the repair work.

“We cannot risk the lives of the families of our men. After the safety audit report is received, a call about it will be taken by the superintendent of police,” he said.

Title: ‘File counter on plea seeking indirect polls for Kovilpatti union’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Madurai: The state government has been directed to file a counter on a plea which sought to conduct indirect election for Kovilpatti panchayat union in Tuticorin district as the election was cancelled citing that the returning officer suffered from chest pain.

In his petition, M Ponnuthurai, a resident of Pandavarmangalam in Tuticorin district said he was the DMK candidate who contested in the election for ward 12 councillor of Kovilpatti panchayat union. Since he was declared as the winner, he became eligible to participate in the indirect election which is conducted to elect the posts of chairman and vice-chairman. While there are total of 19 wards in the panchayat union, there are 11 DMK councillors and eight AIADMK councillors.

When all the candidates assembled to take part in the indirect election on January 11, an order was passed by the assistant returning officer postponing the election citing that the returning officer was hospitalized as he fell ill.

Hence, the petitioner moved the Madras high court Madurai bench challenging the order postponing the election.

When the petition was heard on Monday, senior counsel Veera Kathiravan who appeared for the petitioner stated that after the indirect election was notified, a habeas corpus petition was filed before the court alleging that an independent candidate who was elected as councillor in Kovilpatti panchayat union was abducted. He noted that the court had imposed a cost of Rs 25,000 on the petitioner for filing a false case after the person who was said to have been abducted came to the court and informed that he left the town to avoid political pressure and was not abducted.

The counsel further submitted that since the DMK has majority of councillors in Kovilpatti panchayat union, the ruling AIADMK is taking steps to prevent the conduct of indirect election in a free and fair manner.

He stated that the police with the support of the ruling party are registering cases against the opposition party members by making false allegations. When all the elected representatives were present to participate in the indirect election for Kovilpatti, it was postponed.

The additional advocate general K Chellapandian submitted that the election was postponed as the returning officer was hospitalised after he fell ill during the election.

Taking note of the submissions, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran directed the state government to file the counter and adjourned the case to January 28 for further hearing.

Title: Jaipur: Rival gang kills goon who was sarpanch poll aspirant
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: History-sheeter Vijaypal Singh, who reached his hometown Nadbai to contest the upcoming sarpanch polls from Behramda gram panchayat, was allegedly killed by shooters of a rival gang in Nadbai late on Sunday night.

Within 12 hours, Bharatpur police arrested the four accused belonging to the rival gang.

The two gangs had clashed several times earlier for supremacy in the village. But this time around, the old rivalry turned bloody leading to Vijaypal’s murder , who had more than 24 criminal cases registered against him. Singh was a history sheeter of Shipra Path police station.

“Vijaypal Singh’s brother Jaipal Singh had filed an FIR on Monday mentioning that Rohtan’s gang attacked and killed his brother,” Bharatpur SP Haider Ali Zaidi said.

Jaipal said his brother Vijaypal had come to Manjhi village from Jaipur on January 7. “On Sunday, Vijaypal and Jaipal were talking to a sweet shop owner in Nadbai. Around 7pm, Rohtan, Kapil, Yogendra, Omveer and Shankar, all residents of Manjhi, and Akash, a resident of Bhatawali, and two others attacked Vijaypal with iron rods, lathis and before gunning him down,” sources said.

Police rushed him to a hospital in Nadbai from where he was referred to Bharatpur hospital, where he died while undergoing treatment.

Police registered a complaint under Sections 147, 148, 149 (rioting, armed with a deadly weapon or anything which if used as a weapon may cause death), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), section 341 (punishment for wrongful restraint), under IPC section 302 (punishment for murder), 120-B (criminal conspiracy to commit an offence punishable with death and 3/25 of Arms Act.

On the directions of DIG Bharatpur range, police barricaded the main roads leading to Alwar, Haryana and UP.

The police constituted seven quick response teams and launched a search for the accused. They took help of dog squad and the cyber cell.

Police received information that the accused were hiding in an agriculture field and nabbed main accused Rohtan and Yogendra.

When police questioned him, they came to know that other accused Mohit and Himanshu were hiding in nearby areas.

They searched the jungles of Barbara, Gehari and Harnera and combed the area before arresting Mohit and Himanshu.

Police have seized arms and the motorbike used in the incident.

Title: Consumer stores to house supermarkets, rooftop restaurants
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Jaipur: New supermarkets and rooftop restaurants are proposed in consumer stores to augment income by increasing businesses of institutions through linkages.

Rooftop restaurants would be opened in cooperative sector at Bikaner, Jaisalmer, Jodhpur and Udaipur, registrar of cooperatives Niraj K Pawan said on Monday.

Pawan said Gram Seva Sahkari Samitis (GSSS) and Kray Vikray Sahkari Samitis (KVSS) will develop mandi yard to increase their income.

He said in the first phase, those cooperative societies having land will be issued licences for mandi yards. In this regard, he directed agriculture and cooperative department officers to hold meeting at the district level.

In another development, cooperative department principal secretary Naresh Pal Gangwar said the premium of PM Crop Insurance Scheme of farmers, who had availed the crop loan from cooperative banks, will have to be deposited by January 15.

Gangwar said premium of approximately 10 lakh farmers who had taken farm loans for Rabi season or those whose credit limit has been approved, will be sent to the company concerned.

Addressing cooperative department officers through video conferencing from the secretariat, Gangwar said he directed the managing directors of cooperative banks to get crop insurance of farmers in locust affected areas by January 15. He also said all investigations related to loan waiver complaints should be completed within a month.

The principal secretary informed that video conferencing will be done every month to achieve the expected targets.

A meeting will be held every three months at section offices to be addressed by the principal secretary and registrar, cooperatives. The first such meeting will be held in Ajmer.

Gangwar said all the societies registered under the Cooperative Act will have to upload information on Raj Sahkar portal by March 31, and in case if information is not uploaded, strict action will be taken against the society’s CEO and district deputy registrar.

Pawan directed the officials to generate awareness among farmers who have not yet registered themselves under Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi Yojana and to get them registered. He said 5% of the accounts in the districts will be physically verified. He asked the officials to correct the wrong IFSC code and bank accounts of farmers.

The registrar directed the Cooperative Land Development Banks secretaries to complete the loan disbursement process of farmers by March 31.

Title: After app, Prerna Patrika to highlight good work of teachers
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Meerut: After UP government’s enthusiastic approach to make government facilities at the ground level transparent via Prerna app, the state authorities have now come up with ‘Prerna Patrika’ (magazine) to highlight good work of teachers working at government schools. A description of the kind of work being done by the teachers has been sought from each district.

“This is to bring to your notice that a magazine called ‘Prerna Patrika’ will be printed at the state level to highlight the good work of teachers. In this backdrop, all the basic shiksha adhikaris are instructed to see that details of good schools and good work carried out by teachers in government schools are sent within a week’s time,” said Sarvendra Vikram Bahadur Singh, UP education director (basic), in an order.

This comes at a time when the Prerna app has already been launched to keep a check on government facilities being provided at the ground level – including mid-day meal, school uniforms, furniture and others. Under the Prerna app initiative, the teachers are also instructed to upload pictures of the schools and the facilities in question so that the state government authorities can stay updated and also a transparent framework is made.

“Once the details about the good schools and good work carried out by teachers in these schools are sent, the matter in this regard will be printed in the Prerna Patrika to highlight their good work and get them recognition,” said Singh.

Title: Visakhapatnam: Special teams set up to check cockfights in district
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: Vizag (rural) police have formed special teams to prevent cockfights during the Sankranti festival. The sporting event continues to be a big draw during the festival in coastal areas of the district, despite court orders and police warnings.

Organisers have taken to selecting isolated locations to set up arenas for the bloodsport in order to evade police raids. Police suspect that cockfights may be held at various places in Chodavaram, Ravikamatam, Kothakota, Kasimkota and Narsipatnam , as well as rural pockets in the district.

City task force police led by assistant commissioner of police (ACP) A Trinad Rao have swung into action to prevent cockfights at Arilova, Sagarnagar, Anandapuram and Bheemili under Vizag city limits.

While betting at cockfights is low compared to the Godavari districts, the sport continues till March in rural areas of the district, as part of festivals of local dieties. A senior police officer said cops are gathering information to carry out raids against organisers.

Title: RPF ‘route march’ to keep trespassers off rail tracks
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Photo used for reporesentational purpose only

PUNE: The number of deaths because of illegal trespassing on tracks in the Pune railway division dropped by nearly 19% in 2019 as compared to 2018, but senior Railway Protection Force officers stressed it was still a cause of concern.

The Railway Protection Force (RPF) has initiated a new campaign to bring the number of trespassing further down. “We have started route march at spots vulnerable to trespassing a couple of days ago. Under the initiative, our officers march along the tracks. Most recent route march was carried out in the Pimpri Chinchwad area and we believe it had an impact there. The RPF personnel engaged with people about the problems and tried to comprehend the reasons for trespassing,” Pune's divisional security commissioner Arun Tripathi told TOI.

A source in the railways said they were hopeful that their recent campaign would help in curbing the menace in the Pune rail division.

“The number of deaths and injuries caused because of illegal trespassing on tracks increased suddenly after June last year,” the source said.

Activists, however, remained wary of the initiative. “The officials should get serious and start imposing huge fines on the offenders or put them behind the bars,” said Harsha Shah, the president of the Railway Pravasi Group.

Title: After sugar cane, government advises farmers against cotton cultivation
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The government wants to wean farmers away from water-intensive crops. After discouraging sugar cane cultivation, the government now wants farmers to look beyond cotton.

Addressing a farmers’ workshop on Monday, Union minister of state for water resources Rattan Lal Kataria said the farming community must opt for crop diversification instead of sticking to “water-guzzler” crops.

“Cotton, like sugar cane, is a water-guzzling crop. It takes about 22,500 litre of water to produce just 1 kg of cotton. The countries that are receiving the water-guzzling crops from India are, in fact, saving their own water resources,” he said.

The minister also cited case studies from Haryana , where farmers chose to grow maize and pearl millet — in place of traditional crops — as a part of crop diversification efforts. “The farmers who had adopted the change got good dividends. For instance, those who grew pearl millet made around Rs 2,000 per acre of land cultivated — this is more than what they would have earned growing wheat,” Kataria said.

Later, speaking with reporters, Kataria said the government does not want to enforce any decision on cropping pattern. “However, we will insist that the farming community considers alternatives to sugar cane and cotton. If more farmers respond to our appeal, the government is ready to increase the list of crops covered under the Minimum Support Price (MSP) scheme,” he said.

This appeal to limit the cultivation of cash crops has not gone down well with the farmer activists. Farmer leader Jayaji Suryawanshi said the government must highly subsidise drip, sprinkler and micro-irrigation techniques before coming out with any cropping pattern suggestion. “It is true that judicious use of water is important. But it does not mean that farmers should sacrifice their assured income. The government must offer a 90% subsidy on water conservation techniques first before advocating crop diversification,” he said.

At the workshop, titled ‘Increasing Water-Use Efficiency In Agriculture ’, the minister also administered an oath to farmers about the judicious use of water.

G Ashok Kumar, the additional secretary of National Water Mission, R R Pawar and secretary of Command Area Development Authority, Maharashtra, also addressed the participants.

Title: Plea seeks to conduct indirect poll for Narikudi panchayat union
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has issued notice to the state government on a plea which sought to conduct lot system to elect the chairman and vice-chairman of Narikudi panchayat union in Virudhunagar district, as the election was not conducted following violence.

S Kaleeswari, a resident of A Mukkulam in Virudhunagar district, in her petition stated that she is a DMK member and was elected councillor of ward 3 of Narikudi panchayat union. She decided to contest for the post of chairman in the panchayat union as the chairman seat was reserved for women belonging to the scheduled caste community.

She stated that there are 14 wards in the panchayat union of which there are six DMK councillors, five AIADMK councillors, two independent councillors and one AMMK councillor. She stated that a woman Panchavarnam was fielded as the candidate for the post of chairman with the support of the AIADMK.

When the indirect election was conducted, it ended in a tie as she and Panchavarnam secured seven votes each. She stated that as per the provisions under Tamil Nadu Panchayat Election Rules, lot system should be followed when the election ends in a tie.

She claimed that the ruling party members ransacked the union office before a decision could be taken by the officials. She noted that the Aruppukottai deputy superintendent of police Venkatesan sustained cut injuries in his right hand. Due to the violence indirect election was not conducted.

Hence, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench. When the petition was heard on Monday, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran issued notice to the state government and adjourned the case to January 22 further hearing.

Title: Mechanized forces have role in counter-terrorism: Maj Gen S Jha
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Scene from the integrated firepower and manoeuvre exercise, which was organized at KK Fire Range in Ahmednagar

AHMEDNAGAR: Major General S Jha, Commandant of Armoured Corps Centre and School, on Monday said mechanized forces can provide lethal power to counter-insurgency and counter-terrorism operations.

“The lethality of the enemy’s firepower has been continuously increasing in terrorist-infested areas. Mechanized forces can effectively tackle this threat, as they operate from armoured vehicles that provide the required cover to troops,” Jha told reporters on the sidelines of an integrated firepower and manoeuvre exercise at KK Firing Range here.

“Moreover,” Jha added, “They are able to penetrate speedily, employ ‘shock and awe’ tactics and finish the operation in a clinical manner, just like the infantry and the artillery.”

“One needs to understand certain aspects about tanks which are mobile, have a lot of firepower and provide protection too. They can move speedily and cross any obstacle easily. Thanks can fire three types of ammunition and even protect the fight troops from enemy fire,” Jha said.

Monday’s exercise was aimed at helping officer-students and those from the Defence Services Staff College and Technical Staff Officers course acquaint themselves with the operational capabilities of the mechanized forces. The army’s main battle tank Arjun, the Soviet-make front-line tanks T-90 and T-72, the infantry fighting vehicle BMP-II, carrier motor-tracked platforms and attack helicopters were used in the display.

Jha said mechanized forces will “never die” and that they have played vital role in wars and operations since World War II.

“Mechanized forces are the difference between victory and defeat for the Armed Forces. Any country’s win or loss will be dictated by the quality of its mechanized forces,” he said.

“Mechanized forces have proved their worth in operation in areas like Sopore in Jammu and Kashmir recently. On global scale, the tanks have been used effectively in fighting terror outfits in the Middle East,” he added.

Title: GVMC banks on QR codes to streamline waste management
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC) is planning to popularise its online waste management system. Although efforts are being made to encourage segregation of waste and door-to-door collection of waste, the online system will make efforts more organised, according to GVMC officials.

A Quick Response ( QR ) code generation system will be provided on gates of all apartments in six wards. Once the garbage is collected from an apartment, one of the staff from the sanitation wing will scan the code and upload it on the application or website. This will help keep the civic body informed about the garbage collection on a daily basis from the particular apartment.

Speaking to TOI, GVMC commissioner G Srijana, said, “Enabling QR codes in every apartment is an assured way of garbage collection. This is to encourage door-to-door collection of garbage. The online system will enable us to keep a tab on the staff. If the garbage is not collected, people can upload the pictures on the GVMC mobile application and we will ensure that action is taken.”

She also added, “We have received 25% of the required equipments for online waste management system. On a pilot basis, it will be installed in one ward of every zone. In a few days, we would be receiving the rest of the equipment, the installation of which will be done immediately in most of the apartments in the wards of the city.”

Under the QR coding system for dustbins in tourist places like RK beach, the municipal bins have already been equipped with QR code. If the need arises and the municipality is required to be informed about emptying the dustbins, citizens can scan the QR code through the GVMC mobile application to raise an alert. Sanitary staff of the respective zone will be directed to take necessary action.

Title: Patent on crops new form of colonization: Shiva
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Environmentalist Vandana Shiva said that patent on crops is a new form of colonization and the genetically modified organisms on food will have huge consequences. She was in the city to announce the International Biodiversity Congress ( IBC ) to be held in November.

IBC will be organized by the Centre for Innovation in Science and Social Action in association with Navdanya, an organization engaged in conservation of agriculture biodiversity, at University of Kerala, Kariavattom Campus, from November 25 to 27. The theme of the biannual event is ‘Biodiversity Targets 2020 and Beyond: Status and Aspirations’.

Speaking about the status of agriculture biodiversity, Vandana, founder of Navdanya, said that fake food flooding the market and digital piracy of crops are two threats the country faces. “These fake foods have triggered serious health concerns. There are also widespread attempts to develop new seed varieties through generic mapping. This poses serious threat to the country’s biodiversity. Patents are new forms of colonization, like second coming of Columbus,” she said.

Mentioning the demolition of buildings, which were constructed violating Coastal Regulation Zone norms, in Kochi, Vandana said that there is disconnect in the way we approach biodiversity. “We have to regain our knowledge of biodiversity to create biodiversity economies that allow us to conserve biodiversity and bring prosperity for farmer, so that they will not have to commit suicide and every second child of India will not have to be malnourished,” added Vandana.

A special symposium on biodiversity, development and eco-restoration will also be held as part of IBC. The event will also include seminar, biodiversity expo, youth biodiversity congress, children’s biodiversity congress, civil society meet, national photography exhibition and documentary festival.

Title: Dhariwal gives major infra push to hosp in Kota
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Jaipur: Urban development and housing minister Shanti Dhariwal on Monday announced major infrastructure push in Kota’s J K Lon Hospital, which was recently in the news following a large number of deaths of children in December.

Talking to newspersons, Dhariwal said the state government would spend Rs27 crore for the development of infrastructure of the hospital.

He said that they will spend Rs27 crore for the development of the hospital.

He said that the hospital building façade will be changed completely. Rs 9 crore will be spent for construction of a three-storey building with parking facilities in the basement.

The building will come up on a 40,000 square-feet land. The building will also have separate an out-patient department.

Moreover, the facilities for indoor patients will be improved.

Dhariwal said a three-storey building will come up for indoor patients. It will be constructed on a 93,750 square-feet area at a cost of Rs 18 crore.

He said 156 more beds will be added to the existing 157.

Among 156 beds, 90 will be for general ward, 36 for neonatal ICU and 30 for paediatric ICU. Urban Improvement Trust (UIT) will be the nodal agency for the purpose.

Title: Study finds one in every three persons in Delhi has an unhealthy liver
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: If you are obese, diabetic or drink regularly, it is advisable to get the liver examined. As a large number of persons suffering from lifestyle problems may have an unhealthy liver , even when there are no overt symptoms.Between 2018 and 2019, the Institute of Liver and Biliary Sciences (ILBS), a state-run hospital, organised 200 mobile health camps in the catchment areas of mohalla clinics and polyclinics where middle aged men and women – average age of around 46 years – were screened for liver fibrosis . It denotes build-up of scar tissue in the liver due to repetitive or long-lasting injury or inflammation which can damage the organ.It was found that 35.5% people — one out of every three persons examined — had liver fibrosis. Nearly 14% had an advanced stage of liver fibrosis, which — if not treated — can result in irreversible liver damage, and 3% had probable cirrhosis, end-stage liver disease. “All those who were detected to have liver fibrosis were referred to the medical officer at the nearest mohalla clinic and polyclinics for further treatment and referral,” Dr Archana Rastogi, assistant professor of epidemiology at ILBS, said.The ILBS screening programme involved 7,624 persons. Of this, 804 reported consuming alcohol. The incidence of liver fibrosis was significantly higher in the first group, data revealed.According to Dr S K Sarin, director of ILBS, the study highlights an urgent need for awareness campaigns about chronic liver diseases that increase the danger if having fibrosis or cirrhosis of the liver.“Strategies for early detection of liver diseases especially among the high risk groups like alcohol users, those with diabetes and other metabolic diseases is the need of the hour,” Dr Sarin said.The ILBS director added that chronic liver disease is a serious public health problem which, if left untreated, can turn fatal. “When nearly 80% to 90% of the liver is replaced by scar tissue, the process becomes irreversible and is technically called cirrhosis of the liver. Some of the patients with cirrhosis may further progress to develop liver cancer,” the doctor said.Chronic liver disease occurs due to several causes like viral infections (hepatitis B and C), alcohol use and diabetes among others. “If detected early, liver fibrosis can be reversed by restricting or removing the causative factors, for example limiting alcohol consumption and reducing weight,” Dr Sarin said.Doctors said till about two to three decades ago, hepatitis was blamed for most liver diseases. The incidence of liver diseases due to hepatitis has not decreased but there has been an increase in the disease due to obesity and alcohol, they add.

Title: SOU included in ‘Eight Wonders of the SCO’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Ahmedabad: The Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO), an international alliance of eight member states from Eurasia, has included the Statue of Unity among the ‘Eight Wonders of the SCO’. The eight member states of the SCO are India, Pakistan, China, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzsthan, Russia, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan.

Secretary general of SCO, Vladimir Norov, met external affairs minister S Jaishankar and reviewed progress in co-operation between member states of SCO as India prepares to take up the responsibility of chairing the council of SCO heads of government.

Jaishankar tweeted, “Appreciated the #SCO’s efforts to promote tourism among other member states. The ‘8 Wonders of SCO’ which includes the #StatueofUnity will surely serve as an inspiration.” The Statue of Unity, the world’s tallest statue, was declared open on October 31, 2018 by PM Narendra Modi and has emerged as one of the world’s top tourist destination since. tnn

Title: 800 kids in Round II of School Super League
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Pune: Over 800 students from the city participated in the second round of the School Super League, organised by Byju’s The Learning App, in association with Times NIE, on Sunday.

The top two students from the city will compete in the national finals in Mumbai. The national winners will be awarded an all-expenses paid trip to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (Nasa) headquarters in the US, along with other prizes.

The School Super League is one of India’s largest event that aims to equip students for competitive global challenges. The event, which witnessed high energy participation from students, was held at The Pride Hotel in Shivajinagar. The competition is held in three stages in two categories — classes IV-VI and VII-IX.

The School Super League offers a canvas that covers a range of parameters such as verbal, numeric ability, critical thinking, mechanical reasoning, abstract and special reasoning to help understand the learning footprints of the students. More than 17,000 schools from across the country took part.

The second round witnessed an overwhelming participation, featuring the two toppers from each school battling it out for a spot in the finals. Speaking about the event, Siddhesh Joglekar, assistant vice president, marketing, Byju’s The Learning App, said, “It is very heartening to see students participating in School Super League Season 2, an event which has become India’s biggest platform for students to showcase their Maths and Science skills.”

Byju's The Learning App is India’s largest ed-tech company. The app focuses on application and conceptual way of learning using visualization and personalization. Till date, the application has over 4 crore downloads and around 30 lakh users.

Title: Rahul dares PM to visit any univ, explain why economy had become a ‘basket case’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

NEW DELHI: Congress leader Rahul Gandhi on Monday challenged PM Narendra Modi to visit any Indian university without his security cover and infrastructure and tell students why the economy had “become a basket case”, and what he was doing with the country.

Accusing the Modi government of being an “absolute blanket disastrous failure” on the economic front and on the employment front, Rahul said, “Narendra Modi should stand up and have the courage to speak to the youngsters of these universities on why the economy has become a disaster, why has it become a basket case and why unemployment in India is at its highest in 50 years.”

Speaking on the sidelines of a meeting of 20 opposition party leaders, the Wayanad MP also claimed that the PM lacked the “guts to do this (meet students)”, which was why he had “crushed them using the police”.

“I challenge the Prime Minister to go to any of the universities, stand over there without his police, without his infrastructure and tell the people what is he going to do with this country,” Rahul said.

Title: Politics hampering river-linking project: Rattan Lal Kataria
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

AURANGABAD: Union minister of state for water resources Rattan Lal Kataria said here on Monday that vote bank politics was hampering the progress of the Centre’s ambitious river-linking project.

Kataria said the proposed legislation aimed at creating a dispute redressal body.

“Even some of the states that have excess water in certain areas are reluctant to give water to the neighbouring states. Local leaders fear that they would lose their votes if the water is shared. Such vote-bank politics has been stalling the river-linking project,” he said.

The minister said the law dealing with inter-state water dispute has been passed in the Lok Sabha and is awaiting the approval in Rajya Sabha. “The legislation will give an effective legal framework to address inter-state water disputes. We believe that solution to every problem can be reached with discussion. The states should come forward and the Centre is ready to act as a mediator,” Kataria said.

He added that of the 30 identified major rivers that can be linked, the detailed project report (DPR) of four natural waterways is ready.

On possible opposition to Maharashtra drawing benefits of the river-linking project, Kataria said certain political elements from states such as Telangana , Andhra Pradesh and Gujarat could create hurdles.

It may be recalled that then Union minister of state for water resources Nitin Gadkari, during the campaigning for the Lok Sabha elections last year, had said that DPR to get water from the basin of Damanganga river for Marathwada was ready. The proposed diversion, which is part of the river-linking project of the Centre, had received a push from the state government in July last year when the state cabinet decided to complete the Nar-Par-Tapi and Damanganga-Pinjal river-linking projects. The Nar-Par-Tapi river-linking project, which was said to be a mix of the lift irrigation schemes, tunnels and canal systems is expected to fetch around 52 TMC water for Marathwada.

Officially termed as the Inter-Linking of River (ILR), the river-linking programme has been received the status of national importance to ensure greater equity in the distribution of water by enhancing the availability of water in drought-prone and rainfed areas. Under the National Perspective Plan (NPP) prepared by the water resources ministry, 14 links have been identified under the Himalayan Rivers Component and 16 links under Peninsular Rivers Component for inter-basin transfer of water-based on field surveys and investigation and detailed studies.

Title: SCB elections: Ticket aspirant flags over 2,000 ‘fake’ voters in six SCB wards
Content:
Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: Ahead of Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB) elections, a ticket aspirant on Monday flagged 2,167 alleged duplicate voters from six wards and sought deletion of these voters from the electoral rolls.Using a mobile application developed by a private party that detects duplicate voters from respective wards, Shravan Kumar, a Bharatiya Janta Party hopeful from ward 4, found that there were over 2,167 duplicate voters. The app verified 1.21 lakh voters from the six wards. Of the total number of duplicate voters identified using the application, 1,123 were detected from ward 4 alone, highest among the six, followed by 342 in ward 5 and 320 in ward 8.For example, the application detected that voter number 500 and voter 511 in ward 3 had same e-voter name, relative name, address and age. Similarly, in ward 4, voter 417 and 483 had the same house number, name and age.In a representation to SCB chief executive officer SVR Chandra Sekhar, Shravan highlighted many examples of multiple entries of an individual of the same family with the same address having different serial numbers. In other cases, even if entries with same address, same relation were found, spelling of the voter’s name and age were changed in different serial numbers. There were multiple entries of a single voter with different serial numbers.“The authorities must delete duplicate/multiple voters from Secunderabad Cantonment electoral rolls (2019-20) pertaining to the respective wards,” Shravan added.The SCB officials said they would try to weed out duplicate voters before the elections. “Percentage of such voters is very less. However, we will verify the data on the ground before the elections and update the list accordingly,” an SCB official, on condition of anonymity, said.Meanwhile, the candidates in fray have already started door-to-door campaigning ahead of the SCB elections likely to be held by February, 2020.

Title: Arrested IS men planned to kill CAA backers: Cops
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Three members of the IS-inspired terror module , who were caught by the Special Cell last week, had allegedly planned to kill senior police officers and Hindu leaders who were vocal against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) protests in Delhi and Uttar Pradesh.

Two of them were affiliated to Popular Front of India and Manitha Neethi Pasarai, its parent organisation. It has been revealed that its leader, Khaja Moideen (52), who was out on bail, had wanted to carry out targeted strikes at multiple locations, said a source. The men, along with associate Zafar Ali who has been arrested in Gujarat, had even procured four weapons and a cache of cartridges to carry out the attacks. Police are looking for three more associates.

The module had specifically zeroed in on western UP as it had seen violent clashes over CAA . Moideen had radicalised several youths in Bengaluru, 17 of whom were named in an FIR filed there last Saturday. The module is suspected to be linked to the murder of a police officer in Kerala on January 8.

Moideen told the cops that he had made a plan to revive the IS network in India. Guided by a foreign-based handler, several meetings were organised at different hideouts to make youths pledge allegiance to slain IS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. Moideen, along with Syed Ali Nawaz (32) and Abdul Samad (28), then went to Kathmandu and came to Delhi after setting up a base in Nepal.

Title: Land hurdles delay 3km Metro line on Tumakuru Road by 3 years
Content:
Residents feel they have been betrayed.

Anchepalya residents demand Metro station

BENGALURU: Metro commuters may be feeling a sense of deja vu after the deadline for extending the northern corridor beyond Nagasandra station by 3km was pushed to January 2022.Construction work on the elevated Nagasandra-Bangalore International Exhibition Centre (BIEC) corridor began in 2017 and was slated to be completed in 27 months (by mid-2019). The deadline was first extended to 2020 and later to 2021. Bangalore Metro Rail Corporation Ltd ( BMRCL ) officials blamed land acquisition issues for the delay .Incidentally, the tip of the currently operational northern section between Peenya Industry and Nagasandra too had witnessed many delays for the same reason: acquisition of a piece of land at Jalahalli Cross.BMRCL records show less than half (44%) of the civil work has been completed so far on Nagasandra-BIEC section. The extension is expected to provide Metro connectivity to thousands of passengers on the city outskirts and ensure smoother access to places like Jindal Naturecure Institute and BIEC.The Rs 298-crore contract to build stations at Manjunathanagar, Chikkabidarkallu (Jindal) and BIEC (Madavara) on the extended stretch under Phase 2 was awarded in February 2017. BMRCL sources said there was a delay in getting the required land from agencies like Jindal, BIEC, NHAI and Nandi Infrastructure Corridor Enterprise (NICE). It is yet to receive land from NICE."This stretch was supposed to be completed before the Mysuru Road and Kanakapura Road extended sections, which will be operational this year. The contractor’s poor financial condition is also a cause of worry," said a BMRCL source.Sources said NICE has approached the high court against the compensation of its land evaluated by Karnataka Industrial Areas Development Board. Chief minister BS Yediyurappa recently asked BMRCL to deposit the amount in court and start work on the NICE land.Tumakuru Road is a major thoroughfare that connects Bengaluru with other parts of the state, besides Maharashtra. It is used by hundreds of intercity bus operators. Earlier, there was a proposal to stop buses on the outskirts.India’s Metro Man and Delhi Metro Rail Corporation’s principal adviserE Sreedharan had said a day’s delay in operationalising Metro would cost BMRCL about Rs 1.5 crore. Regular commuters to areas beyond Nagasandra say the project should be expedited. "Those who come to BIEC from the city have to get down at Nagasandra and rely on illegal shared autos. I don’t know why this small section is still incomplete," said Ramesh Kumar, a commuter.Bengaluru: For two months now, residents of Anchepalya, beyond Nagasandra, on Tumakuru Road, have been protesting in a makeshift tent, demanding construction of a Metro station in their area. The protesters have threatened to halt ongoing work on the 3-km section of Nagasandra-BIEC section and also block Tumakuru Road if their demand is not met.Residents feel they have been betrayed. Mukesh D, a resident, said a Metro station had been earlier planned at Anchepalya. "It would have benefited those living in and around Anchepalya and Totadaguddadahalli," he said."The distance between Nagasandra and Madavara (BIEC) is 3.5km and the first two stations planned — Manjunathanagar and Chikkabidarakallu — are within one km. Normally, there should be a Metro station every 1km. BIEC station is more than 2km from Chikkabidarakallu," said Khadar Pasha, another resident. T Srinivas, who is leading the protest, said, "We will soon approach the high court and also block the highway if they continue to ignore our demand."Srikantapura panchayat president Venkatesh M said, "Sufficient land is available at Anchepalya to set up a station. We want to know whether BMRCL’s priority is common people or private real estate firms. Most Anchepalya residents are daily-wage employees."A senior BMRCL official said: "The detailed project report never envisaged a station at Anchepalya. The station planned at the playground of Jindal school was shifted towards the east to save the playground and school buildings."

Title: Call to protect ASI sites from vandalism
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Visakhapatnam: In view of the damage done to ASI monuments – the hilltop Buddhist shrines of Bojjanakonda and Lingalakonda — during Kanuma Jatara in recent years, Indian National Trust for Art and Cultural Heritage (Intach) representatives have requested the district administration and other authorities to provide police protection at archaeological sites against rampage and vandalism by drunken locals.

Intach convener Mayank Kumari Deo said, “Every year, a Jatara (village fest) is held wherein thousands of people descend on these two Buddhist sites on Kanuma, most of them in high spirits. They pull out the bricks and throw them into the caves as well as throw stones onto the stupas. The people also litter these sites with liquor bottles and vast amounts of trash. The stupas have been damaged in the past due to a superstitious ritual of the Vajrayana period that has no relevance any more.”

“These sites which have been documented in the world heritage encyclopedia are of vital importance to Visakhapatnam as heritage and tourist attractions. We, therefore, request the police to provide protection. In the past, district collectors have responded by sending a strong police force to protect the site and this year too we request that these sites be protected,” the convener added.

The twin sites of Bojjanakonda and Lingalakonda, near Anakapalle, date to the third century BC. All three forms of Buddhism—Mahayana, Hinayana and Vajrayana--were prominent at the site.

Title: FTII’s screenplay course from Feb 8
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Pune: The Film and Television Institute of India (FTII) has rolled out the registration process for its 20-day screenplay-writing course as a part of the Union government’s Skilling India in Film and Television (SKIFT) programme.

The course will begin on February 8 and go on till April 12 this year. Sessions will be held only on weekends. The institute has been offering this course for three years now, an official said.

“The course has been spread over 10 weekends, that is, a 20-day course. Weekends have been chosen for the sessions because it is a boon for professionals who sign up for the course,” FTII director Bhupendra Kainthola said.

Like other short-term courses the institute conducts, all registrations would have to be done online and the seats will be limited. The screenplay course will admit 15 students on a first-come first-served basis. The screenwriter and FTII alumna Vaidehi Sancheti will be the course director. The registration deadline will be January 21, the FTII stated.

Kainthola added the flagship summer film appreciation course, in collaboration with NFAI, would be announced in the coming weeks along with the relevant details.

Title: 700kg of gutka products seized, one held
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Trichy: The city police have arrested a man for smuggling banned gutka products and seized 700kg including gutka and other banned chewable tobacco products from a godown here on Monday evening. Police sources said that city police commissioner V Varadharaju had received a tip-off about the gutka and other banned tobacco products stored in Palpannai.

A special police team on Monday carried out vehicle inspection near Thanjavur main road and adjoining areas in Palpannai, during which they intercepted Siva, 40, of Tharanallur, on a two-wheeler. On checking his belongings, police found banned gutka products being smuggled in the vehicle. On interrogating him, police got information about the godown near Tharanallur.

Around 700kg of gutka and banned chewable tobacco products packed in several bundles were confiscated by the city police. Gandhi Market police have registered a case and are investigating to identify the source.

In a similar incident in June 2018, city police seized Rs 15 lakh worth banned tobacco products from a private godown in Viswas Nagar near Palpannai.

Title: Diamond jubilee celebrations of governmet engineering college from January 23
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: To mark the diamond jubilee of Government College of Engineering, a range of activities involving students, alumni, and other stakeholders will be carried out from January 23.

Addressing a press conference here on Monday, chairman of Board of Management of GCE Vivek Bhosale said the celebrations will take place for three days from January 23.

“The college has carved a niche for itself in the 60-year journey. The institution has produced several illustrious alumni, which is a matter of pride for the entire region.,” he said.

The State Higher and Technical Education Minister Uday Samant and head of the State Directorate of Technical Education (DTE) Abhay Wagh are among the key personalities who will be a part of the celebrations.

College principal P B Murnal that efforts were on full swing for the diamond jubilee celebrations. “We appeal to all stakeholders, especially alumni to join us in the celebrations. The event will give new energy for the college authorities to take the college to further new heights,” he said.

A play titled ‘Matric’ will be performed at 8pm on the inaugural day along with symposiums start-ups and Industry 4.0 along with alumni meet.

The Government College of Engineering, established in 1960, was initially affiliated to Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University and later received autonomy in keeping with the government policy.

Title: Demand for harmful nylon manja persists in Pune
Content:
Shopkeepers claimed that they were flooded with requests for glass-coated nylon manja despite a nationwide ban... Read More

Kite-flying enthusiasts continue to be keen on glass-coated nylon manja, despite its ban

PUNE: With Makar Sankranti on Tuesday, shopkeepers claimed that they were flooded with requests for glass-coated nylon manja despite a nationwide ban on it.Kite-flying enthusiasts continue to be keen on glass-coated nylon manja, despite its ban. Shopkeepers selling in kites and manja said many of their customers simply don’t care about the ban.“People come to (our shop), asking for such manja, but we have stopped selling it for many years ago. We have displayed a notice outside our shop, stating that we don’t sell nylon manja, but that doesn’t stop people from asking,” Akbar Menon, who runs Royal Patang Depot in Raviwar Peth, said.Menon said like every year, this year too inspections were conducted by police and civic officials. “This year, forest department officials too were a part of random inspections,” he said.Animal rights activist and bird rescuer Anil Avchite said he comes across 15-20 cases of injured birds in the aftermath of Makar Sankranti each year.“People need to understand that manja kills birds. We appeal to people to use regular thread or normal manja. Kites trailing manja often get stuck on buildings or trees, putting birds at risk,” Avchite said.Avchite said there was a need for a stricter implementation of the ban. “Despite their denials, many shopkeepers sell nylon manja under the counter. Ask any children and they will point you to shops that sell them. The authorities need to make an example out of violators by suspending the shop license,” he said.“We did conduct checks at kite shops this year, mainly to spread awareness among people about the harmful effects of manja. It was required because birds are getting injured. Birds do get entangled in normal threads too, but it is easier to free them. The festival must be celebrated, but not at the cost of birds,” A Srilakshmi, deputy conservator of forests, Pune, said.

Title: VFS wants ‘Chhapaak’ to be tax-free in Andhra Pradesh
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: Vizag Film Society ( VFS ) has requested chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy to make the film on acid attack survivors—‘ Chhapaak ’—entertainment tax-free in Andhra Pradesh similar to a few other states in northern India.

States such as Rajasthan , Chhattisgarh and Madhya Pradesh and the Union territory of Puducherry have exempted the film from entertainment tax .

Narava Prakasa Rao, secretary of the society, in a letter addressed to the chief minister, stated, “In view of the importance of the film ‘Chhapaak,’ VFS requests you to intervene and grant entertainment tax exemption so as to enable women to watch the film and get inspired, which is the need of the day. It is a sensitive film with delicate yet powerful handling of a heinous crime against women.”

The film is directed by Megha Gulzar in which Deepika Padukone plays the lead role. Based on a real-life incident, the film portrays how a woman tries to rebuild her life after a man throws acid on her.

Title: Rallies across state backing 3 capitals
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Mangalagiri MLA Alla Ramakrishna Reddy being detainedduring the rally at Penumaka in Guntur district on Monday

Guntur: Demanding the trifurcation of the capital city, Mangalagiri MLA Alla Ramakrishna Reddy took out a rally in Guntur on Monday.

Scores of YSRC cadre joined the rally in support of decentralisation of development. Police however prevented the legislator and cadres from going ahead with the march keeping in view of the prohibitory orders. The police detained MLA and his followers before taking them to the local police station.

Speaking to reporters, Alla said farmers, farm labourers and commoners in his constituency were backing the chief minister’s plan to decentralise development. He said that agriculture labourers in the capital city were supporting the chief minister for mooting the development of all regions.

He said Naidu had coerced farmers in the capital city area when he was at the helm and made attempts to take over green fields. He said that Naidu and his benamis purchased massive extent of land in the capital city area before the official announcement and made huge gain.

Alla said that Naidu had started pooling donations to run the movement for Amaravati after making all farmers, particularly the Dalits, paupers.

He asked the DGP to immediately remove the tents laid in the capital city area if they wanted to implement the Section 144 of CrPC without bias.

Meanwhile, Tirupati legislator Bhumana Karunakar Reddy flagged off a massive rally in the temple city of Tirupati in support of the state government’s three capitalproposal on Monday. Holding ‘Thank you CM’ placards, a large contingent of students and locals took part in the rally.

Addressing the crowd after the rally, the YSRC legislator lashed out at former chief minister Nara Chandrababu Naidu for trying to politicize the government’s 3-capital proposal.

“Naidu never focused his attention on the development of the state during his tenure. The fact that even the farmers of the Amaravati region did not vote for the TDP in the 2019 general elections establishes the fact that they were all against the anti-development policies of the then chief minister,” Bhumana said.

Title: Pune: Won’t proceed till accused get all copies as per chargesheet, says Court
Content:
Representative image

he judge directed an elaborate verification process of the documents on January 21 but clarified that the exercise was not aimed at establishing their genuineness

PUNE: Special UAPA judge S R Navander on Monday said the court would not proceed any further in the Elgar Parishad case till it was verified that the nine arrested accused got the copies of the seized documents the prosecution submitted with the chargesheet.The judge directed an elaborate verification process of the documents on January 21 but clarified that the exercise was not aimed at establishing their genuineness. The verification would be only to ensure that the accused got copies of all the documents, he said in a packed courtroom.Copies of the seized documents are crucial for the accused to prepare their defence in the case. It is now at the stage of framing of charges, after the prosecution recently filed draft charges against them.The prosecution had earlier claimed to “have provided cloned copies of the entire data”, but Gadling and Ferreira disputed the claim by submitting that the documents were incomplete and far less than the 25 TB data claimed. On December 18, the court had asked the accused to appoint an expert to examine if the copies provided to them were the same as submitted to the court with the chargesheet.Defence lawyers Gaurav Jachak, Rahul Deshmukh and Rohan Nahar submitted a plea to the court naming Mumbai-based cyber law expert Supratik Chakravorty, Jachak himself, and Gadling and Ferreira as “experts” for verifying the documents. Special public prosecutor Ujjwala Pawar made a written submission on behalf of the investigating officer, ACP Shivaji Pawar, opposing the plea claiming the two accused cannot be experts in their own case.The prosecution also submitted the remainder of the documents as per the chargesheet and the FSL’s final report in the presence of two FSL (forensic science laboratory) representatives. The court then directed verification of all these documents at the next hearing on January 21.

Title: 24x7 mobile rescue service till January 31 in Pune
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: City-based animal rights non-government organization ( NGO ) Sarv Jeev Mangal Prathisthan has launched a round-the-clock ambulance service for those injured by nylon or Chinese manja this year.

The ambulance, launched on the eve of Makar Sankranti (on Wednesday), will be staffed by a doctor, a veterinarian, volunteers and activists. They will treat injuries to people and animals, and will be in operation till January 31.

The NGO’s founder-director, cardiologist Kalyan Gangwal, said they had decided to launch the initiative this year, considering the number of injuries caused by the banned kite string. “In the past 17 years, our team has been at the forefront, trying to ensure that the ban on nylon and Chinese manja is being properly implemented and sufficient action is taken on the sellers,” Gangwal said on Monday.

He said many have lost their lives to this manja over the past few years, and more were injured. “In July 2017, the National Green Tribunal imposed a blanket ban on nylon and synthetic manja, as it posed a serious threat to humans and animals. However, many small vendors still sell it openly,” he said.

Gangwal claimed that around 2,000 people have been killed by nylon manja over the years. “We try to hold awareness sessions among schoolchildren to not use this manja. We have also launched this initiative. We have told residents from slums to bring us the manja they find entwined in tree branches. If they bring us half a kilo of this manja, we reward them with Rs500. We have been running this initiative for a few years,” he said.

Title: Nizam-era press closure triggers job loss fears
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Secunderabad: As the date of railway printing presses being shut down nears, there is unrest among employees and railway unions, who are claiming that 98% of travel is still done by unreserved tickets despite the upgradation of the ticketing system.

The decision has not gone down well with members of several railway unions and employees. Before the Nizam-era railway press in Secunderabad shuts down in March 2020, the printing press staff is not only expected to print extra tickets for creating a buffer but they need to employ more people on a temporary basis.

“Nearly 70% of the people working there are underqualified men, women and differently-abled people, and employees are finding it hard to find further employment. Until the digitisation of tickets reaches close to even 50%, there is no need to close down the printing presses,” a source told TOI. “Even at those nice presses which have already been shut down, the Machinery and Plant (M&P) stand in a dilapidated condition without any buyers. The land is also not in the best of locations to have enough takers,” he added.

Railway unions fear that this is another step towards privatisation of the Railways.

“Passenger Reservation System (PRS), Unreserved Ticketing System (UTS) tickets and money value items should be continued in the above five printing presses till complete closure of the presses. The passes and the privilege ticket orders (PTOs) should be printed covering the requirements upto the year 2020-21. However all the printing activities should be stopped by March 31, 2020,” states the letter by the Railway Board to the general managers of Indian Railway (IR) zones in June 2019.

The statement talked about shutting down of five presses including the press at Secunderabad (South Central Railway), Central Railway press in Byculla, Howrah (Eastern Railway), Delhi (Northern Railway) and Chennai (Southern Railway).

“While maximum passengers using train services are not equipped to handle digital platforms, how will the railway suddenly stop printing paper tickets? A few private companies will get business worth several crores. We are still against this move,” K Sivakumar, divisional secretary, SCR Mazdoor union told TOI.

According to the employees in distress, the major chunk of travel is done in the unreserved category where passengers are issued tickets manually.

Across the country, more than 340 crore unreserved tickets are being issued annually, which means 10 lakh tickets are being issued per day.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Four youths get life term in Kumbakonam rape case
