Title: Infra upgrade at two corpn schools to begin this month
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Trichy: Trichy Corporation has floated a tender for refurbishing the infrastructure of two corporation schools in Ariyamangalam zone here. The work, which will include strengthening the existing buildings and adding new infrastructure, is scheduled to commence in a month and completed in three months.

Utilising the education fund for 2018-19, the corporation has planned to improve infrastructure in 74 schools in a phased manner. The tender has been fixed at Rs 16 lakh to redevelop Varaganeri (north) corporation middle school and Majlis-ul-Ulama Corporation elementary school on Madurai road.

Apart from renovating and strengthening the ceiling and flooring of the buildings, the civic body has planned to paint social messages and graffiti on the compound walls of the two schools. To overhaul the school’s appearance, the walls facing the front portion of the school will be clad with aluminium sheets.

“Announcement system in all classrooms and a microphone in the headmaster’s room will be provided. We have planned for a uniform exterior colour for all schools,” a corporation official said. The civic body said the proposal was a follow-up of a consultative meeting conducted with headmasters of all 74 corporation schools to hear their requirements to improve infrastructure. “Smart classrooms proposal is also on the cards for corporation schools to increase enrolment of students,” the official added.

Title: HRF lauds government decision to shift capital
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Vijayawada: Civil society group Human Rights Forum lauded the government on Monday over its decision to shift the capital from Amaravati, even as it criticised the opaque manner in which it was going about deciding the future of the capital city.

“The decision has merit. This is because the social and environmental costs of a mammoth capital city like the one proposed by the erstwhile TDP government are too high. We stated this at the time of the release of the Sivaramakrishnan report in 2014 and we reiterate it now. The city (Amaravati) was to be constructed on an abundantly fertile river floodplain, on wetlands and in an area that is also a seismic zone. It was a veritable nightmare in the making,” A Chandrasekhar and VS Krishna, members of the HRF’s coordination committee for AP and Telangana, said in a statement.

HRF, however, cautioned the YSRC government against treading the path of its predecessor in the matter of responding to agitations. “Section 144 is being clamped and prohibitory orders under section 30 of the Police Act are being promulgated the moment there is a protest. We condemn the use of excessive and unwarranted force by police on farmers in the Amaravati area,” they added.

They urged the government to initiate a dialogue with the agitators instead of adopting an adversarial position. “We understand that the entire exercise of reverting the land to landowners is a cumbersome process and in some instances next to impossible. However, that does not diminish the responsibility of the government to find an amicable and just solution to the issue,” they said.

They also criticised the government for lack of transparency and added thata centralised secretariat in Visakhapatnam, or for that matter anywhere else, is undesirable. “Rather, there must be several mini-secretariats dispersed across the state. We feel the high court must come up in Rayalaseema and ideally in a relatively central location,” Krishna and Chandrasekhar said in the statement.

The HRF cautioned the government against treading the path of its predecessor in responding to agitations and urged them to initiate a dialogue with the agitators

Title: IKDRC completes India’s longest cross-transplant chain
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Of the 10 donor-recipient pairs, six are from Gujarat, three from Rajasthan and one from Madhya Pradesh, said ... Read More

AHMEDABAD: In a first, medical experts at Institute of Kidney Diseases & Research Centre ( IKDRC ) carried out a single-centre kidney exchange (swap or cross) transplant chain of 10 recipients and 10 donors from January 5 to 13.

Dr Vineet Mishra, director of IKDRC, said that often the potential kidney donors are not the exact match for the patient.

“In such a case, we try to find the closest match among the other donors and find whether the organs can be transplanted in pairs. This is the best way for patients with incompatible donors to be transplanted quickly with the best results,” he said. “Kidney transplant chain is more effective in saving lives for difficult to match donor-recipient pair.”

Out of 10 donor-recipient pairs, six are from Gujarat , three from Rajasthan and one from Madhya Pradesh, said IKDRC officials.

The officials claimed that it’s the longest such chain in India and perhaps in Asia.

Vivek Kute, the transplant coordinator, said that when a donor-recipient pair is incompatible because of differences in blood type or other tissue sensitivities, donors within the exchange are swapped among incompatible pairs to allow for more transplants.

“Allocating donated kidneys to deserving patients with end-stage renal disease is an important challenge in today's health care system. Patients typically must wait as long as 2 to 5 years to receive a kidney from a deceased donor,” he said. He added that having a living donor can eliminate the wait. But in one-third of such cases, a transplant can’t be done because the immune systems of the patient and a willing donor don’t match. “The last of the cases would be performed on Saturday, completing the chain. All the patients are healthy and are responding well,” he said.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: ‘Let’s talk development, degree row vendetta’
Content:
Jitender Singh Tomar was arrested by Delhi Police on June 8, 2015, on charges of fraud. (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Former Delhi law minister Jitender Singh Tomar and MLA from Tri Nagar assembly constituency has been fielded by AAP from the seat for the third time Tomar has been embroiled in an alleged fake degree controversy after he was arrested by Delhi Police on June 8, 2015, on charges of cheating and fraud in obtaining the degree from Tilka Manjhi College in Bhagalpur. An FIR was registered against him at the Hauz Khas police station, and on July 24, 2015, he was granted conditional bail by a court with a direction to join the police investigation. Police filed a chargesheet in March 2018 at a Saket court .Coming at a time when the AAP government was locked in a tussle with the then lieutenant governor Najeeb Jung over its powers, Tomar’s arrest led to AAP alleging political vendetta.Tomar was first fielded by AAP from Tri Nagar during the 2013 Delhi assembly elections but lost to Nand Kishore Garg of Bharatiya Janata Party by a margin of 2,809 votes. In the 2015 assembly election, however, he defeated Garg by a margin of 22,311 votes.“In the last election, I had won by nearly 23,000 votes, and this time, I will win by a margin of 40,000,” Tomar told TOI. When asked if the alleged fake degree controversy might affect his electoral prospects this time, Tomar said he preferred to talk about the developmental work he has done in his constituency. “It was complete political vendetta against me. The case is now in a fast-track court and is going in my favour,” said Tomar. He said he hoped to be acquitted in about six months to a year.“I have executed around 600 developmental work in my constituency in the past five years. These include development of roads, improvement of water supply and sewerage, setting up of community centres and mohalla clinics, construction of foot overbridges and open gyms and installation of 2,000 CCTV cameras, etc.,” he said. Tomar said people of Delhi were very happy with the work done by the AAP government and would vote for the party everywhere overwhelmingly.Tomar had resigned from the party in June 2015. In July 2018, a Delhi court ordered framing of charges against him stating that submitting “forged” certificates seemed to be part of a larger conspiracy. Tomar had claimed in his defence that the court did not have jurisdiction in the case since the admission to LLB course had been taken in Bihar. But the court went ahead saying the marksheet was used in Delhi.

Title: Gujarat HC to cops: Take timely call on CAA protest permission
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Some protesters of Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) on Monday approached the Gujarat high court complaining that the city police do not grant them permission to protest peacefully.

To the petition seeking direction to cops to grant permission to protest against the new law, Justice A Y Kogje said that police should take decision on the application in time.

Petitioners Mudita Vidrohi and Mujahid Nafees contended that while the state administration has granted permission on 62 occasions to the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to hold programmes in support of CAA, it has been denying permission to protesters. Denial of permission to protest peacefully is in violation of people’s fundamental rights.

The petitioners want to stage a protest on January 19 in Jamalpur area and for this they applied for permission on January 5. They met the Gaekwad Haveli police inspector on January 7, but he did not reply to their request. The next day, they went to see the city police commissioner, who redirected them to the police inspector. However, they did not hear anything from the authority with regard to permission.

The petitioners argued that the ruling party has applied for and received permission on the very same day for 62 public meetings across the state. On the other hand, the petitioners were denied permission on various occasions, though they had protested against CAA peacefully last month.

The petitioners also complained that the continuous imposition of Section 144 of CrPC prohibiting meeting of more than four persons in public automatically makes the protesters offenders if the protest without police permission.

They also complained that the cops take action only against the protesters and not against the supporters of the law.

Since, the city police did not respond to their request for permission for a protest programme, they approached the HC. The court directed the authorities to take a decision on the application in accordance with law and ensure that the decision is taken in time, so that the application does not become infructuous. The police, thus, will have to decide before January 19.

Title: Ahmedabad: Kitists pray for good wind, clear sky on Monday
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

With overcast sky almost the entire day on Monday and strong winds, the kitists — waiting for the big day for ... Read More

AHMEDABAD: With overcast sky almost the entire day on Monday and strong winds, the kitists — waiting for the big day for almost the entire year — prayed for a good weather on Uttarayan. India meteorological department (IMD) forecast is the clouds will vanish after passing of the western disturbance.

City kite markets were busy till late night as Amdavadis shopped for panja, gundarpatti and dhal by bargaining hard. The roads leading to Raipur were choc-a-block despite Monday witnessing an overcast sky.

“Uttarayan is not just a festival for the city, it’s a ritual for the residents of the Walled City with friendly rivalries across the terraces and almost the entire area living a day basking in the sun. We have planned to visit Khadia with our friends in the afternoon to make the most of the festival,” said Jayesh Shah, a resident of Vejalpur.

Jayanta Sarkar, regional director, IMD, said that morning’s induced cyclonic circulation resulted in light showers in some parts of north Gujarat on Monday and also caused the dense cloudy weather in a few pockets. “But by Tuesday, the sky will clear up and there is no possibility of rain. We expect the wind to be also moderate which is good for kite-flying,” he said.

The city, which witnessed 24.9°C and 17.5°C maximum and minimum temperatures on Monday — 2.8 degrees lower and 5.3 degrees higher than the normal — is likely to record minimum temperature of 14°C on Tuesday.

Across the state, minimum temperature is likely to fall by 3°C to 4°C on Tuesday and Wednesday. ‘Thereafter further fall in minimum temperature over the region very likely,’ mentioned the forecast. Despite rise in minimum temperature, strong cold winds forced the citizens to don the woollens.

“Uttarayan is the festival of the sun. We were surprised to see the weather on Monday where clouds almost covered the sun for the most of the morning. We hope that it’s not the case on Tuesday as we have already made all the grand preparations for the big day, complete with the terrace feast, music and of course lots of kites,” said Sujay Trivedi, a professional and resident of Vastrapur.

Title: Andhra Pradesh high court asks cops to allow peaceful demonstrations
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: The Andhra Pradesh high court on Monday passed an interim order directing police to permit peaceful public demonstrations in Amaravati capital region.

The high court, on Monday, expressed its displeasure at the police for continuing with Section 144 of Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) in the region.

The HC said it was issuing an interim order to protect the fundamental rights of individuals. The HC also directed the police to permit the public to perform customary temple rituals. Additionally, the HC directed the police to also not enter people’s houses and conduct searches, except by adhering to the procedure contemplated in the Code of Criminal Procedure.

Based on newspaper and video clippings, the HC had suo motu registered a petition into the issue. The HC, which heard nine other petitions, filed against the implementation of the Section 30 of the Police Act and Section 144 of CrPC, and asked the police to explain their actions as well as mention the disciplinary action taken against the cops who misbehaved with protesting women.

The high court directed the Vijayawada police commissioner and Guntur urban and rural superintendents of police to hold an inquiry against police officials regarding the arrests and detention of people at police stations.

The high court also directed the state government to file an affidavit on the issue and posted the case to January 15.

Title: Pune: Colleges to assign admission coordinators to guide pupils
Content:
Savitribai Phule Pune University

The coordinator should have a minimum of five years of experience and should know the workings of the college as well as the university to guide the students properly

PUNE: The Savitribai Phule Pune University has directed all its affiliated colleges to appoint an admission coordinator each to guide students about courses, scholarships and also address their issues during the enrolment period.As per the university guidelines, the coordinator should have a minimum of five years of experience and should know the workings of the college as well as the university to guide the students properly, while issuing notifications on time and coordinating between various departments.Their appointment will be for a term of three years and the appointee will also be secretary of the admission committee.The role of the coordinators become vital considering the stress among students during the admission period.The rules of cancelling admission, getting repayment of fee or changing the course are some of the issues faced by the students who mostly rely on the wisdom of clerks and other staffers, who may not know the latest notifications.“This is a good decision if implemented well. Students always face problems during the admission period. Many a time, students don’t know what scholarships are available and how to apply for them. Even when it comes to admissions, students need guidance when it comes to applying for one and cancelling the admission in a college if one gets allotment in a better college. There are also doubts about how much money will be refunded during if one goes for cancelling the admission in a college. With a single point of contact, the entire process will become easier,” Jahnvi Nair, who is hoping to take admission for a postgraduate (PG) course this year in the city, said.In the absence of admission coordinators, students have to run from pillar to post to get their doubts cleared, she said, citing the work pressure on college staffers to properly guide students.The admission coordinators will also be responsible for spreading awareness of circulars issued from university among students, besides declaring the admission schedule in the colleges and coordinating in the admission process.Dilip Sheth, principal of SP College, said, “This is a good initiative to help students during the admission period. We generally appoint vice-principals as coordinators during the admissions. I think a better move will be to have one coordinator and then faculty-wise coordinators. Because professor of one stream will know more about his/her own discipline than the professor from other streams.”

Title: Delhi assembly elections: ‘Let’s talk development, degree row vendetta’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Jitender Singh Tomar was arrested by Delhi Police on June 8, 2015, on charges of fraud. (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Former Delhi law minister Jitender Singh Tomar and MLA from Tri Nagar assembly constituency has been fielded by AAP from the seat for the third time .

Tomar has been embroiled in an alleged fake degree controversy after he was arrested by Delhi Police on June 8, 2015, on charges of cheating and fraud in obtaining the degree from Tilka Manjhi College in Bhagalpur. An FIR was registered against him at the Hauz Khas police station, and on July 24, 2015, he was granted conditional bail by a court with a direction to join the police investigation. Police filed a chargesheet in March 2018 at a Saket court .

Coming at a time when the AAP government was locked in a tussle with the then lieutenant governor Najeeb Jung over its powers, Tomar’s arrest led to AAP alleging political vendetta.

Tomar was first fielded by AAP from Tri Nagar during the 2013 Delhi assembly elections but lost to Nand Kishore Garg of Bharatiya Janata Party by a margin of 2,809 votes. In the 2015 assembly election, however, he defeated Garg by a margin of 22,311 votes.

“In the last election, I had won by nearly 23,000 votes, and this time, I will win by a margin of 40,000,” Tomar told TOI. When asked if the alleged fake degree controversy might affect his electoral prospects this time, Tomar said he preferred to talk about the developmental work he has done in his constituency. “It was complete political vendetta against me. The case is now in a fast-track court and is going in my favour,” said Tomar. He said he hoped to be acquitted in about six months to a year.

“I have executed around 600 developmental work in my constituency in the past five years. These include development of roads, improvement of water supply and sewerage, setting up of community centres and mohalla clinics, construction of foot overbridges and open gyms and installation of 2,000 CCTV cameras, etc.,” he said. Tomar said people of Delhi were very happy with the work done by the AAP government and would vote for the party everywhere overwhelmingly.

Tomar had resigned from the party in June 2015. In July 2018, a Delhi court ordered framing of charges against him stating that submitting “forged” certificates seemed to be part of a larger conspiracy. Tomar had claimed in his defence that the court did not have jurisdiction in the case since the admission to LLB course had been taken in Bihar. But the court went ahead saying the marksheet was used in Delhi.

Title: SHG members fall for cheap loan bait, lose Rs 3.8 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Pune: Four Nana Peth residents, including two women, were booked on Sunday on the charges of posing as finance firm officials and duping 70 self-help group members of Rs 3.8 lakh on the pretext of providing them cheap loans.

The Samarth police said all the fraud victims were involved in household business and operated from an office on NDA Road. One of the office-bearers of the self-help group (SHG), a resident of Kondhwe village, has lodged a complaint with the police in this regard.

All the SHG members belonged to economically backward section of the society, the police said.

According to the FIR, the suspects approached the SHG office in 2016. “They told the members that they had their offices in Nana Peth and Hadapsar. They then promised them loans at cheaper interest rates,” an officer of the Samarth police said.

After the members agreed to take the loans, the suspects charged members Rs 1,200 each for the loan form and Rs 2,000 each in loan-processing fee. In all, the suspects took Rs 3.80 lakh from the women, the officer said.

When their loans were not processed, the SHG members approached both the offices of the finance firm, but found them locked, prompting them to lodge a complaint.

Title: Nizam-era press closure triggers job loss fears
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Nearly 70% of the people working there are underqualified men, women and differently-abled people, and employe... Read More

SECUNDERABAD: As the date of railway printing presses being shut down nears, there is unrest among employees and railway unions, who are claiming that 98% of travel is still done by unreserved tickets despite the upgradation of the ticketing system.

The decision has not gone down well with members of several railway unions and employees. Before the Nizam-era railway press in Secunderabad shuts down in March 2020, the printing press staff is not only expected to print extra tickets for creating a buffer but they need to employ more people on a temporary basis.

“Nearly 70% of the people working there are underqualified men, women and differently-abled people, and employees are finding it hard to find further employment. Until the digitisation of tickets reaches close to even 50%, there is no need to close down the printing presses,” a source told TOI. “Even at those nice presses which have already been shut down, the Machinery and Plant (M&P) stand in a dilapidated condition without any buyers. The land is also not in the best of locations to have enough takers,” he added.

Railway unions fear that this is another step towards privatisation of the Railways.

“Passenger Reservation System (PRS), Unreserved Ticketing System (UTS) tickets and money value items should be continued in the above five printing presses till complete closure of the presses. The passes and the privilege ticket orders (PTOs) should be printed covering the requirements upto the year 2020-21. However all the printing activities should be stopped by March 31, 2020,” states the letter by the Railway Board to the general managers of Indian Railway (IR) zones in June 2019.

The statement talked about shutting down of five presses including the press at Secunderabad (South Central Railway), Central Railway press in Byculla, Howrah (Eastern Railway), Delhi (Northern Railway) and Chennai (Southern Railway).

“While maximum passengers using train services are not equipped to handle digital platforms, how will the railway suddenly stop printing paper tickets? A few private companies will get business worth several crores. We are still against this move,” K Sivakumar, divisional secretary, SCR Mazdoor union told TOI.

According to the employees in distress, the major chunk of travel is done in the unreserved category where passengers are issued tickets manually.

Across the country, more than 340 crore unreserved tickets are being issued annually, which means 10 lakh tickets are being issued per day.

Title: Three arrested for poaching peafowls
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

PUDUKOTTAI: The forest department arrested three men for hunting three peafowls near Annavasal in Pudukottai district on Monday. A country-made unlicensed gun, a motorcycle and carcasses of the three peafowls were seized from them.

The arrested have been identified as C Perumal, 25, P Moorthy, 26 and S Arumugam, 26. Inquiry has brought to light that the three had poached the peafowls for meat and this was not their first attempt.

They were caught by the Annavasal police during a vehicle check near Vayalogam village on Sunday night. The trio were handed over to the forest officials on Monday morning.

Peafowls are protected under Schedule – I of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972. Poaching them is a non-bailable offence.

Pudukottai district forest officer M Anand Kumar said they had secured one more person who had supplied raw materials to the trio to make ammunition for poaching.

“Unlike these habitual offenders, people living close to the forest areas indulge in poaching without knowing that such acts can put them behind bars. We have been sensitizing them to keep away from such activities,” said Anand.

A case has been booked under Section 9 of the Wildlife Protection Act against the three.

Title: Visakhapatnam: Passengers jostle at stations ahead of Sankranti
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Close to 60 per cent, or around 23 lakh, of the city’s populations comprises migrants from neighbouring Srikak... Read More

VISAKHAPATNAM: Several city roads and the 20-km-long stretch of National Highway (NH)-16 that passes through Vizag wore a deserted look on Monday as residents left for home ahead of Sankranti .

Close to 60 per cent, or around 23 lakh, of the city’s populations comprises migrants from neighbouring Srikakulam, Vizianagaram, East and West Godavari districts.

While Sankranti will be celebrated on Wednesday, Bhogi—the first day of the festival—is on Tuesday.

Crowds, however, converged at railway and bus stations with passengers in a rush to reach home. An official of the public transport department said, “A total of 300 special buses along various routes, including 100 buses to Hyderabad, have been pressed into service to meet the demand this year.”

An official spokesperson of Waltair division of East Coast Railway said that nearly 40 special trains are being operated to clear the rush of passengers at Visakhapatnam, Vizianagaram, Srikakulam and Parvathipuram in north-coastal AP.

Meanwhile, junctions at Maddilapalem, Dwarakanagar bus station, Visakhapatnam railway station , NAD Junction, Hanumanthwaka Junction and Madhurawada were packed with passengers

“My family has already left for home town at Palasa. I will join them on Tuesday night,” said B Sridhar, a faculty member of Andhra University at Sivajipalem.

The harvest festival marks the transition of the sun into Capricorn (‘Makara Rasi’) .

Title: AP: Government asks farmers to submit grievances to CRDA
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

AMARAVATI: The high-level committee comprising cabinet ministers and senior officials held another round of deliberations on decentralisation of the administration on Monday.

The committee, which is looking into the experts committee reports on the capital city and comprehensive development of the state, chalked out plans to put developmental activities on fast track. The committee also discussed issues of farmers in the capital city area.

Speaking to media after the meeting, transport, I&PR minister Perni Venkataramaiah (Nani) appealed to farmers in the Amaravati region to submit their concerns, suggestions or complaints to the CRDA Commissioner before January 17.

He said the government would go through all suggestions and complaints at the committee’s next meeting on January 17. “We are advising farmers either to visit the CRDA office or reach out to CRDA commissioner through mails,” Nani suggested. He said the YSRC government is farmer-friendly and would not do injustice to real farmers.

Perni Nani said that the government was ready to discuss any issue to be raised by farmers. He said the government would consider issues of farmers in the capital city area with compassion. “We are appealing to them not to fall into the political trap laid by Chandrababu Naidu. Except Naidu and his benamis, every genuine farmer will get justice under the YSRC regime,” said Nani.

He said several delegations of farmers have met municipal administration minister Botcha Satyanarayana and submitted their grievances. He said the ministers were giving patient audience to all those who are genuinely raising their grievances. He said the committee had discussed major development projects to be initiated in every district.

Agriculture minister Kurasala Kannababu lambasted Naidu for creating uncertainty in the Amaravati region for his political gains. “It is quite sad that he is not leaving farmers in peace even for Sankranti. How sad it is to appeal to people not to celebrate the festival. People should celebrate festivals when Naidu is happy and should not when Naidu is on the streets,” said Kannababu. He also condemned Naidu describing DGP Sawang as a northeast person.

Meanwhile, farmers from the capital villages met municipal administration minister Satyanaraya at his residence in Vijayawada and explained their apprehensions. They detailed their fears regarding the shifting of the capital. The farmers requested the minister to return land that was not in use for the capital region.

And within 10 days of her debut on the micro-blogging site, Kangana has clocked 1 million followers. Title: Docu crisis for NT women, says study
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Pune: At a time when protests mount against CAA, NRC and the documentation required for both, a study has found that women belonging to nomadic tribes in Maharashtra face extreme difficulties in getting documents and all women above the age of 25 in the rural areas are illiterate. This was revealed by the Status of Women in India report released on Monday at Balgandharva Rangmandir .

The survey for the report, prepared by Drishti Stree Adhyayan Prabodhan Kendra, an RSS affiliate women’s organisation in Pune, was conducted in 29 states and five union territories and over 70,000 women across India were interviewed. The report said 55.2% of the women in India are unemployed while arthritis affects 44%.

The report also spoke about 78% women of Jammu & Kashmir’s border areas feeling insecure about the cross border firing and shelling while 39% women from the border area of West Bengal feel insecure due to communal atrocities, hooliganism and torture stemming from religious tension.

Talking about school curricula from gender perspective, Maneesha Kothekar, project director said, “The percentage of women academicians involved in curriculum committee is poor, non-significant and non-influential. The percentage of women authors or women related content is very less and portrayal of women and leaders and contributors is also poor.”

Vocational training, in-depth study on better health, prevention and treatment of menstrual health, leadership training, gender sensitisation programmes were the recommendations made by the study.

Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh joint general secretary Krishna Gopal, who was the chief guest at the function, said, “The report says that Aadhaar has reached 90.6% of women, yet there is a huge gap in the northeastern region. The literacy rate in northeastern region is high yet Aadhaar has reached only 54% population.” Krishna Gopal added that the status of women in ancient India was higher than that of men and emphasised on the importance of families to teach young boys to respect women.

Title: Solar power helps South Central Railway save Rs 1 crore on energy bills
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: While implementing measures aimed at harnessing renewable energy and conserving energy, the South Central Railway (SCR) is reducing energy costs through the installation of solar panels at stations, service buildings and Level Crossing gates across the zone.

According to SCR, over 55 railway stations are being provided with solar plants across the zone, including at Secunderabad, Hyderabad and Kacheguda and in each region alone, the SCR has saved over Rs 1 crore per annum with solar power since December last year. “One of the significant actions taken in this direction has been the installation of solar panels at stations and service buildings across the zone,” read a statement from the Indian Railways.

SCR is also focusing on providing solar roofs to small establishments and wayside railway stations which in turn helps save energy and costs while ensuring uninterrupted power supply. “The eco-friendly initiatives will be extended to major stations where power consumption is high. The use of star-labelled electrical equipment, LED fittings, energy-efficient pumps, provision of occupancy sensors, etc has helped in saving energy,” said SCR.

Title: BDU halts direct recruitment to 54 regular teaching posts
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Trichy: Coming under heavy criticism over the reservation policy adopted for direct recruitment to 54 regular teaching positions, Bharathidasan University (BDU) has postponed the process indefinitely.

The university has circulated an internal communication to the staff and the selection committee to stop the recruitment process. The university was set to conduct interviews on January 21 for around 1,400 applicants.

The move comes after higher education minister K P Anbalagan directed the university to get clearance from the personnel and administrative reforms (P&AR) department before going ahead with the recruitment.

“We received a few complaints pointing flaws in the recruitment process adopted by the university about the reservation policy. I have asked the university to get clearance from the personnel and administrative reforms department to verify the claims of disparity in the roster system adopted for the recruitment,” higher education minister K P Anbalagan told TOI.

“There is no second thought that the university must go ahead only if they get clearance from P&AR. That is the procedure or else they will have to postpone the recruitment process until they get clearance,” he added.

The university is unlikely to get clearance from P&AR as the roster system adopted by it was against the policy of the state government. “P&AR being an advisory department will not take a stand against the state policy. Therefore, the university needs to mend its way,” said a senior official from the higher education department.

The university had called for applications in July last year. It followed the Union government ordinance introduced in March last year restoring 200-point roster for recruitment by considering the whole university as a single unit for calculating vacancies.

A letter dated August 28 from the higher education secretary had asked all the 13 state universities to treat each department as single unit to reserve teaching posts for professors, associate professors and assistant professors.

Former president of the AUT, K Pandiyan said that a state-run university cannot have an exclusive reservation policy. Only the state government can decide on what policy has to be adopted. “AUT all along wanted a uniform policy adopted by other state universities. But vice-chancellor P Manisankar unilaterally changed the policy of reservation without consulting any stake holder,” he said.

Title: Sankranti special: Multiplexes hike ticket price in Vijayawada
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

VIJAYAWADA: This Sankranti season, moviegoers in the city have complained that they are being fleeced by multiplexes.

Usually, a movie ticket at a multiplex costs between Rs 150 to Rs 175. But following the state government’s permission to hike ticket prices during festivals, theatres have increased the rates by up to 50%. So now, a regular moviegoer has to pay anywhere between Rs 225-Rs 260 to watch a movie. And that’s just the price of admission!

This year though, a few multiplexes have made ‘combo offers’ compulsory, also charging for the food they have on offer. Multiplexes are charging Rs 250 for two samosas and a soft drink or popcorn and soft drink, over and above the cost of a movie ticket. Consequently, a film buff ended up paying about Rs 500 for a ticket.

“While online a few multiplexes showed housefull, the same multiplexes sold tickets at the counter on combo offer. We were forced to by popcorn and soft drink for Rs 180 along with the movie ticket,” said K Nagendra Kumar, a BTech student.

Title: Farmers want tripartite meet ahead of paddy procurement
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Trichy: The state government continues to evade the demand for a tripartite meeting to discuss paddy procurement policy, allege farmers in the state. While both the ministers for food and agriculture hail from delta districts, they have not shown any interest in convening the same for long, they add.

Before announcing the procurement policy for the kharif season, the state government would usually convene a tripartite meeting where agriculture and food ministers, Tamil Nadu Civil Supplies Corporation (TNCSC) MD, collectors of delta districts, officials from the agriculture department, TNCSC regional managers and representatives of farmers’ associations would participate.

“After the demise of chief minister J Jayalalithaa, the meeting has not been convened to discuss paddy procurement,” secretary of Thanjavur District Cauvery Farmers Protection Association, Swamimalai S Vimalnathan said.

“Every year, tripartite meeting would be conducted in any one of the districts in the delta before the commencement of DPCs. This year cultivable lands have gone up to 11 lakh acres following good monsoon and continuous flow in the Cauvery. Now, harvest has commenced in many parts of the districts. There are a number of issues revolving around DPCs across the delta districts that need to be resolved. In this situation it is unfair that the meeting is not convened,” he said.

“Even agriculture minister R Doraikannu from Thanjavur and food minister R Kamaraj from Tiruvaur have not instructed officials to convene the meeting. The tripartite meeting should be conducted and farmers’ grievances with regard to paddy procurement should be heard,” he added.

Farmers would be given Rs 1,835 per quintal for A-grade paddy with Rs 70 as state government’s incentive. In case of common variety, Rs 1,815 will be disbursed to the farmers along with Rs 50 as an incentive.

Title: Pune Municipal Corporation's plan to run parking lots hits manpower hurdle
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Pune Municipal Corporation

PUNE: Manpower crunch can crush the civic body’s wish to operate some of the parking lots in the city to curb complaints about rude behaviour of contractors .

According to the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC)’s rough estimate, nearly 10 people are required to look after the operations of a parking lot . Besides, two supervisors and a clerk are also required. The PMC is mulling over issuing tenders afresh to run the trouble-hit parking lots because of non-availability of staffers.

A PMC official said the civic administration had decided to take over the pay and park facilities and operate them with civic staffers if the contractors concerned did not pay the dues. The PMC even sealed parking lots over unpaid dues. “The parking facilities that are not being operated properly will be taken over by the PMC. The civic administration has taken over a parking lot near Phule market and it is being run successfully. We shall decide about the other lots if manpower is available,” said Rajendra Muthe, the head of the PMC’s estate and management department.

Nearly 26 pay and park lots, including the mechanised parking lot on J M Road, have been set up in the city. Many of the private operators running them have not paid the rent to the PMC and the arrears is pegged at Rs2 crore.

The PMC had approached the Lok Adalat to recover the pending rent of the civic properties, including the parking lots. The corporation subsequently recovered Rs30 lakh from the operators.

Civic activists said people with political connections were running the parking lots and creating obstacles in their smooth functioning. “Most of the parking lots have been given to political workers for operation, who charge exorbitant fees. The staff members working at these facilities misbehave with citizens, but action is hardly taken,” said Vijay Kumbhar of Surajya Sangharsha Samittee, a citizens’ group.

Title: Exchange programme for tribal youth
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Visakhapatnam: In an attempt to check efforts by Maoists to attract tribal youth, the CRPF is conducting various programme in the agency areas. As part of the paramilitary force’s tribal youth exchange programme in coordination with Nehru Yuva Kendra Sangathan (NYKS), the 234 battalion of the CRPF sent 60 boys and girls to Kolkata on Tuesday.

R S Balapurkar, commandant of 234 battalion, said the exchange programme will help the boys and girls get exposure in various aspects of life which they don’t get in the remote villages. “The objective of this program is to orient, sensitize and provide opportunities to tribal youth of Visakha agency. They will get to visit different places of cultural, individual, historical, religious and educational importance. We will organise more programmes like this to provide opportunity to others in the agency area in the coming days,” Balapurkar said.

He added that such programmes will help them understand the socio-economic development, cultural ethics, language, and lifestyle of people depicting the unity in diversity aspect of our social fabric, besides making them aware of the social and financial inclusion programmes of the government,” he said, while adding that they earlier organised a similar programme for 30 boys and girls aged below 22 years age in Jaipur.

Title: PM Narendra Modi’s ‘political speech’ draws Ramakrishna Mission alumni ire
Content:
Narendra Modi

By: Swarnali DuttaKOLKATA: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s pro-CAA statements from the Ramakrishna Mission’s Belur headquarters have evoked sharp response from the RKM alumni.Iterating that RKM has always stayed away from politics, retired RBI officer Asoke Chattopadhyay said: “Anyone who has read Swami Vivekananda’s writings knows he has always valued inclusivity. Vivekananda has always stressed that it is a person’s work and action that define them, nothing else. RKM should have been kept above politics.” Kamalesh Dasgupta, who teaches in Jodhpur Park Boys’ School, added: “If the PM truly believes in the ethos RKM stands for, he could have never used that platform to say what he did on CAA . Speaking on politics is also disrespecting RKM. One shouldn’t use it to further a political agenda. He could have said those anywhere, but certainly not Belur Math. I am pained.”Author Ranjan Roy, 69, felt it would have been good if the PM had not spoken about CAA in Belur Math. “Delivering a speech on CAA in a place where Vivekananda has always propagated thought of inclusiveness is not only misplaced but wrong. The RKM defended itself saying it was the PM’s opinion and they did not have much say on what guests say. But I find it hard to understand.”Spine surgeon Sanjoy Biswas said: “I don’t understand why the PM visited Belur Math. If he had been there to be a part of 150th birth anniversary of Swami Vivekananda, why did he speak on CAA? Instead he could have spoken on what steps are being taken to curb unemployment, and use the platform to motivate the young generation. As an ex-student of the Mission I don’t support that my alma mater be used as a base to further political agendas at all. Ramakrishna Mission has always been inclusive and stayed away from politics,” Biswas said.For private engineering college teacher Himadri Ghosh, it was an “utter disgrace and shameful”. “The PM should never propagate his political ideologies from a place like Ramakrishna Mission, Belur Math. We learned a different definition of ‘religion’ during our days in Mission and whatever is happening in the name of religion in our country is shocking. I was also pained by the fact that RKM endorsed Modi as the best prime minister. It hurts us because the bond we have with the Mission is still very strong.” Debjit Maiti, who works for a pharmaceutical company, added: “The PM could have spoken on CAA somewhere else but not in Ramakrishna Mission, Belur Math. He should not have brought politics inside the mission premises.”Sharp reactions also poured in on social media in which a letter purportedly addressed to the RKM president and questioning the PM’s statement and presence in Belur Math is doing the rounds. Several social media users, who are also RKM alumni, have commented on the letter.

Title: Andhra Pradesh high court gets four new judges
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Four new high court judges took oath of office on Monday. With this the Andhra Pradesh high court has 18 judges against a sanctioned strength of 37.

The Andhra Pradesh high court chief justice J K Maheswari administered the oath of office and secrecy to R Raghunndana Rao, Battu Devanand, Donadi Ramesh and Nainala Jayasurya.

R Raghunandan Rao has a degree in commerce from Acharya Nagarjuna University and law degree from Osmania University. He worked as a senior counsel in the Supreme Court for more than three decades. He worked as standing counsel for Indian Oil Corporation, Gas authority of India Limited and other reputed companies.

Battu Devanand, a native of Gudivada completed graduation from ANR College Gudivada and law degree from Andhra University. He served as a member of bar counsel and worked as government pleader for transport department from 2014.

Ramesh, a native of Chittoor, graduated from SV College, Tirupati . He practised for more than two decades in the AP high court and served as government pleader from 2000 to 2004. He earlier served as a standing counsel for Sarva Siksha Abhiyan.

Nainala Jayasuriya served as senior assistant public prosecutor in Krishna district. He studied Bachelor of Law (BL) at Siddhartha Law College of Vijayawada.

Title: Power connection for 50k ryots soon
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Vijayawada: The government has decided to issue 50,000 more agriculture power connections to farmers in the next two months. This is in addition to the existing 17.67 lakh connections across the state.

Energy minister Balineni Srinivas Reddy, at a review meeting held on Sunday, directed officials to expedite the process of issuing the new power connections. Enerdy department officials informed the minister that out of 6,663 agriculture feeders in the state, 5,200 are now capable of supplying free power with augmentation of feeders.

Balineni told officials to give top priority to supply of nine hours of free power to farmers. “Uninterrupted power to the farming sector will help in boosting productivity and will make agriculture a profitable activity,” he said, while asking them to be ready to meet the demand which is likely to increase from the month of February. “Increase in ground water levels this year may contribute to higher demand from the agriculture sector as more farmers may go for Rabi crop across the state depending on the rise in ground water level,” he added. APTransco (Andhra Pradesh transmission corporation) has also taken up a Rs 286.3 crore project to upgrade the existing infrastructure of agriculture feeders, under which substations and other infrastructure works in East and West Godavari, Krishna, Guntur and Nellore districts will be upgraded. The government has already spent Rs 7,779.5 crore towards free power subsidy to the agriculture sector and Rs 475 crore for aquaculture to supply power at a subsidised price of Rs 1.5 per unit.

As many as 54,098 power connections have been given to aquaculture farmers across the state, officials said, while adding that efforts are being made to put in place a high-voltage distribution system with an aim to reduce distribution losses in agriculture sector by 25 per cent.

Title: NIN study finds exposure to lead can cause Alzheimer’s disease
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Hyderabad: Scientists at the ICMR- National Institute of Nutrition (NIN) have established the possible link between exposure to lead and Alzheimer’s disease. Lead is a common pollutant present in a number of commonly used materials like paints, cosmetics, batteries, glass and low-grade toys.

Experts said the current findings could be a way forward in understanding the intracellular mechanism of Alzheimer’s disease.

In Alzheimer’s disease, brain cells that process, store and help recollect the information degenerate and slowly die.

A team lead by ICMR- NIN’s senior scientist Dr Suresh Challa worked on the molecular mechanism involved in the development of lead induced Alzheimer's disease through in-vitro (outside a living organism) studies.

Dr Suresh Challa said that Alzheimer’s disease has a complex patho-physiology which involves initially; formation of beta amyloid plaques and tangles in the brain.

“Oxidative stress and inflammation are known to be involved in the progression of the disease, with loss of memory and neuronal cell death. In this scenario, our study investigated the basic molecular mechanism behind the involvement of lead in Alzheimer’s disease,” said Dr Challa.

The scientists also studied various biochemicals available in food which can slow down the progression of the disease. “Foods like green tea, guava leaves, apples, cherries, pears and black berries, which possess antioxidant, anti-inflammatory and metal chelant properties were studied. Their ability to effectively permeate brain and modify several cell survival signalling pathways shows they have preventive and therapeutic potential,” he added.

Moreover, the effects of environmental exposure to lead can also be passed onto a child from a pregnant mother.

“Maternal exposure to lead during pregnancy can cause developmental reprogramming which can lead to higher risk and early onset of Alzheimer’s disease in later life of the child,” said Dr R Hemalatha, director, ICMR-NIN, and added that the study is a step forward in understanding Alzheimer’s disease and developing preventing strategies for the elderly.

Title: Madurai PEW SP takes addl charge of Kanyakumari
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Madurai: M Rajarajan, superintendent of police, prohibition enforcement wing, Madurai, who has been entrusted with the additional charge of Kanyakumari superintendent of police, took charge on Sunday.

He has been given additional charge as the district superintendent of police N Shreenath is busy with the inquiry into the murder of special sub-inspector of police Wilson, who was murdered by a couple of youth at Kaliyakkavilai on the Kerala-Kanyakumari border on January 8. While 10 teams have been formed by the south zone IG Shanmuga Rajeswaran, Shreenath is leading the inquiry and coordinating with various special teams from Tamil Nadu and Kerala. Meanwhile, Rajarajan will take care of day to day affairs of Kanyakumari including maintenance of law and order, police sources said. Sources said that a few people have been picked up by the Kerala police based on suspicion and handed over to TN police for interrogation. Apart from Kanyakumari police, other special branches including Q branch conducted inquiries with them. The main accused involved in the murdered are suspected to have stayed in Neyyattinkara in Kerala and masterminded the cold-blooded attack.

Title: DJS secretary Khalid convicted
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Hyderabad: Nampally metropolitan criminal court on Monday convicted Shaikh Saifullah Khalid, secretary Darsgah-E-Jihad-O-Shahadat ( DJS ) and a practising lawyer for allegedly assaulting a policeman.

In August 2009, during an Eid Milap meeting of DJS activists under the leadership of its former chief Shaikh Mahboob Ali, Khurshid Hussain, the then-head constable attached to Special Branch tried to cover the meeting upon which Shaikh Mahboob Ali and his son Shaikh Saifullah Khalid objected to his presence and allegedly used force to make him leave the place.

The special branch cop had filed a complaint with the Moghalpura police upon which a case under IPC sections 353 (Assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty) and 506 (Criminal intimidation) was registered against Khalid. The police later filed a chargesheet in 8th Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate against DJS secretary for abated action against former DJS chief Shaikh Mahboob Ali since he died in August 2013. After the trial, the magistrate on Monday sentenced Khalid to 2 years imprisonment and imposed fine of Rs 1,000. “I will file an appeal against the lower court order before the sessions court,” said Khalid.

Title: Delimitation of corpn wards full of discrepancies: MLA
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Madurai: Delimitation of corporation wards in Madurai has been done without following the rules, in connivance with some politicians, and elections to the Madurai Corporation council should not be held with setting it right, said Madurai Central DMK MLA P T R Palanivel Rajan.

Speaking to reporters here on Monday, he alleged that the delimitation exercise of the 100 wards seemed to have been done in a planned and partial manner to benefit some people. “This is not about the elections. We want the elections to be conducted as much as the others, because an MLA can serve the people of his constituency only with the help of councillors in the wards,” he said.

Rules of the Delimitation Act of 2003 of the central government specify that the delimitation should be done only after the five-year period of an MLA is completed. If it is done before, the people who voted would not be able to enjoy the development works from that particular MLA’s funds, as they would move to another assembly constituency. Each corporation ward should be within the same assembly constituency, but under the current delimitation process, there are some wards which are in two assembly constituencies.

There were a lot of discrepancies in the population of a ward, when compared to the 2011 census and the latest voter list. For Madurai Central, the population as per the 2011 census is 21,02,35 but according to the latest voter list the number is 236,039. The delimitation has been done based on the census data, which is a big mistake, he said. In this constituency, the population is higher than the census data in 16 wards.

As per delimitation rules, the population in the wards should be uniform with a 10% increase or decrease, but in this delimitation process, 35 wards had very less population.

Reservation for women and dalits should be done in wards which have more women or dalit populations. But, this rule had not been followed in the wards reserved for women.

In some wards where the delimitation favoured the ruling party, they got more wards. For instance, Madurai West constituency only had 15 wards earlier but now has 22 while Madurai Central has lost six wards.

Title: Hosp opens network of advanced labs
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Madurai: The Madurai-based Meenakshi Mission Hospital and Research Centre (MMHRC) has unveiled a network of advanced diagnostic labs in various parts of the state, especially in tier II and III towns and villages, to help more people get timely and accurate diagnosis.

Music director Yuvan Shankar Raja, chairman of Meenakshi Mission Hospital and Research Centre, Madurai, Dr S Gurushankar, and film director Ike Rathe unveiled the logo for the labs at a function held on January 8. The event also marked the inauguration of Meenakshi Labs in Karaikudi, Kumbakonam, Madurai, Mayiladuthurai, Rajapalayam, and Thanjavur.

The labs are fully equipped to perform all kinds of medical investigations and have well-calibrated instruments. The labs also enable house visits for the collection of samples and delivery of reports.

Title: BJP likely to bank on youth brigade
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

New Delhi: Several sitting municipal councillors are likely to contest the assembly polls on a BJP ticket. Sources said the party has decided to field “as many” young candidates and might place its bet on councillors who have gained exposure in electoral politics over the past two years.

With the growing influence of Poorvanchalis in Delhi, BJP is likely to give them a larger representation this time. Sources said several constituencies, which have a large number of unauthorised colonies, might get Poorvanchali candidates. The ruling AAP has over a dozen MLAs with their roots in eastern UP and Bihar. Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari is from Poorvanchal.

In the 2017 municipal polls, BJP had fielded new candidates on all 272 wards. The effort paid off as the party won 181 seats.

“The committee has already held several rounds of meetings and the candidature of 50 councillors was discussed. About 30 sitting councillors may get the final nod to contest,” said a party functionary.

Six serving councillors had contested the 2013 assembly polls, of which three had won. In 2015, 18 sitting and former councillors had contested, but only one — Vijender Gupta from Rohini — had managed to win.

The committee will also have to decide on finalising the seat-sharing arrangement with Shiromani Akali Dal (Badal), its old ally. While SAD (Badal) has sought four seats, sources said BJP might give it three. Another party functionary said the election committee has shortlisted one candidate on about 25 seats, while 2-3 potential names have been decided for 10-15 more seats. “The final list will be announced only after the central election committee takes a call. We hope to come out with the first list in a couple of days,” he added.

From the thousands of applications, about 1,400 have been shortlisted by the state committee. Sources said the list was further brought down to 450 and sent to the central committee.

The initial decision-makers include Union minister and Delhi election in-charge Prakash Javadekar, co-in-charges Hardeep Singh Puri and Nityanand Rai, general secretary (organisation) BL Santosh, Rajya Sabha MP Vijay Goel, Manoj Tiwari and Vijender Gupta.

Title: Celebrities vow not to show papers in protest video
Content:
Konkona Sen Sharma

KOLKATA: When comedian and lyricist Varun Grover swept social media by first tweeting a video with his poem ‘Kagaz Nahi Dikhayenge’ (We Will Not Show Our Papers), he had mentioned being inspired by Bangla slogans. Less than a month later, filmmaker Ronny Sen roped in 13 actors, directors, author, designer, model, academic and singer-songwriter to shoot a video where they lend their voice to a Bengali translation of Grover’s poem titled ‘Kagoj Amra Dakhabo Na’.Featured in viral video are Sabyasachi Chakrabarty, Manoranjan Byapari, Swastika Mukherjee, Debalina Majumder, Konkona Sen Sharma, Nandana Sen, Ayushman Mitra, Sneha Ghosh, Chitrangada Satarupa, Madhuja Mukherjee, Tillotama Shome, Rupam Islam, Suman Mukhopadhyay and Dhritiman Chaterji.According to Chaterji, the idea behind this video was to show that “there is a large cross section of people who feel angry at what is happening”. Majumder, who was attacked by a group of men in her locality on December 22 after having organised a rally, said, “Now, we have been pushed to the wall. We have to protest.” Describing this video as a result of a “snowball” effect, Mukherjee added, “Our version of this song is a way of participating in the larger version of protest.”Actor Chitrangada Satarupa, who has attended three protest meetings, said, “The basis of this Act itself is problematic the moment religion comes in. I have grown up believing that India is a secular country. How can a law take decision on the basis of religion?”Speaking to TOI, Grover said, “I am delighted to see so many respected people lending their voice to the cause. I believe some new lines have been added and from my very limited knowledge of Bangla, I could understand that they have given it some more context and energy. I am grateful.”In his poem, he had used a line that a Bengali friend of his had WhatsApp-ed: “Wo jaat paat bolenge tum bhaat bhaat bolna” before going on to underline that “there is no copyright on these words - feel free to use them, adapt, sing, modify, create”. “I wanted the poem to be free of any restriction because at its heart, it’s a poem about freedom,” Grover said.This freedom from copyright prompted Sen to translate it and shoot the video over last two-three days.Delighted to see how youngsters have joined veterans to be a part of this movement, Chaterji said, “They are spontaneously doing it without being under the umbrella of political affiliations because they are angry at what’s happening. The ‘Kagoj Amra Dakhabo Na’ module is trying to take alternative routes to quickly generate relevant messages and put them out as quickly as possible.”

Title: FASTag eases Sankranti rush traffic on NH65
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

On Saturday and Sunday, while cops did find several vehicles stalled at a toll plaza to a malfunctioning FASTa... Read More

VIJAYAWADA: This time last year, the toll plazas between Vijayawada and Hyderabad on NH65 were choked with with traffic due to the festive season. With the introduction of FASTag technology, toll plazas are noticing a paradigm shift and there are barely any queues in the plazas.

On Saturday and Sunday, while cops did find several vehicles stalled at a toll plaza to a malfunctioning FASTag scanner, by Monday, there was a huge dip in traffic.

With two highways — NH16 and NH65 — cutting across Vijayawada, major junctions like Benz Circle, NTR Circle and Ramavarapadu Ring had traffic choked up to a km long. In Panthangi toll plaza on Hyderabad-bound NH65A, a 6-km long traffic jam was seen while there was a traffic jam on the Gudur toll plaza on the Hyderabad-Warangal highway in Yadadri-Bhongir district from Friday night itself.

Traffic also came to a halt due to thick fog in areas such as Kanchikacherla, Nandigama and Keesara . Subsequently, the police put out an advisory to commuters on the route regarding the fog situation. Speaking to TOI, deputy superintendent of police (Nandigama sub-division) Ramana Murthy said that while the FASTag system has made a remarkable change in the traffic scenario, there were occasional technical problems while reading them.

“At the Keesara toll plaza, there are seven lines where four of them have been reserved for fast tag. The boom barrier automatically lifts after scanning the FASTag from a distance. There was some traffic on Saturday and Sunday morning due to heavy inflow of trucks,” Ramana Murthy told TOI. The cops also issued an advisory to the toll management that if a technical issue or if traffic is being caused because of their slow process, then they shall automatically allow that vehicle to leave without charging toll.

Meanwhile, the Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) saw good response from the public for their Sankranti Sambaralu. The most popular event was the rangoli competition held at Indira Gandhi Municipal Stadium (IGMS) in the city. Arrangements were made with a theme that reflected a village atmosphere. The VMC commissioner Prasanna Venkatesh inaugurated the fest by lighting the Bhogi campfire.

There was a Bommala Koluvu (exhibition of dolls) which was a huge attraction. The rangoli competition saw participation from over 100 people.

Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy is expected to participate in the closing ceremony of Sankranti Yedla Pandelu (Bull Race) at Gudivada.

Title: Probe team awaits Prudhvi’s consent for voice sample test
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Tirupati: The vigilance wing of the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD) has intensified its probe into the infamous episode involving Tollywood actor Prudhvi Raj , who stepped down as chairman of TTD-run Sri Venkateswara Bhakti channel ( SVBC ) on Sunday after an audio clip of his alleged intimate talk with a female employee of the channel went viral.

TTD trust board chairman Y V Subba Reddy, who has asked the vigilance wing to probe the SVBC episode, said voice samples from the audio clip would be sent to the forensic lab for analysis. On Monday, vigilance wing sleuths questioned the channel’s CEO Yelamanchili Venkata Nagesh and other staff.

Sources said two woman hair stylists associated with the film industry were engaged on assignment basis by the SVBC ahead of the annual Tirumala Brahmotsavams in September 2019. Both were reportedly recommended by Prudhvi Raj. While SVBC normally pays Rs 15,000 per month to staff engaged on assignment basis, the two hair stylists were offered Rs 18,000 per month.

However, their services were terminated in November after the TTD management found irregularities in some of the appointments carried out at SVBC. It has been learnt that the voice of the woman in the audio clip belongs to one of the hair stylists. The vigilence wing sleuths are now trying to contact the woman to check the authenticity of the audio clip and also to find out if she was being harassed by Prudhvi Raj, as is being alleged.

Meanwhile, the vigilance wing is waiting for Prudhvi Raj’s consent to send his voice sample for forensic test. Though the actor said he’s ready for a vigilance enquiry into the episode, while also claiming that the voice in the audio clip was not his, there’s a legal angle to the whole thing as no police complaint has been filed yet, neither by the actor nor by the aggrieved party, and till that happens, the vigilance wing can send his voice sample only after the actor’s consent.

While stepping down as SVBC chairman on Sunday, Prudhvi Raj claimed that he had lodged a complaint with the Tirupati urban police over the issue, but sources in the police department said no complaint has been received yet, neither from him nor from the woman whose voice can be heard in the audio clip.

Title: Book him under Disha Act: N Chandrababu Naidu
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

N Chandrababu Naidu

TIRUPATI: TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu on Monday asked the government to slap cases under the stringent Disha Act against actor Prudhvi Raj.

“The SVBC office is a devotional place but this man misused the office premises for his sleaze acts which is unpardonable. His resignation is not sufficient. The government should book him under the Disha Act which it had enacted very recently to ensure more stringent punishment for crimes committed against women,” Naidu demanded.

Title: Solid waste mgmt: Officials told to prepare report
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Hyderabad: Chief Secretary Somesh Kumar directed officials of line departments to prepare a report on implementation of solid waste management. He also instructed them to prepare a report on bio-medical waste rules and polluted river stretches, to be submitted to NGT , by January 31. tnn

Title: 15k students participate in NMC’s Swachh slogan contest
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Nagpur: Over 15,000 students participated in the slogan contest under the ‘Mummy Papa You Too’ campaign organized by the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) and city police. Over one lakh slogans were prepared by students from 926 schools, including those run by the civic body.

Some of the slogans are ‘Khoobsurat hoga Nagpur har chhor kyonki mummy papa ko mil raha karne safai charon aur’, ‘Ao mil kar sabko jagayen, gandagi ko swacchata se dur bhagayen’, ‘Kadam se kadam aur haath se haath milana hai, Nagpur ko sabse shresth aur sundar banana hai’.

The students will form a human chain at 8.30am on January 17 to highlight the importance of cleanliness. They will raise slogans in favour of cleanliness.

Title: Kolkata Municipal Corporation plans special pass to lodge civic complaints
Content:
Passes will be issued from this chamber at the KMC headquarters

KOLKATA: In an effort to give relief to those living in areas under Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC), the civic body will issue special passes from the mayor’s office at the KMC headquarters to those who have been victims of harassment by staffers in the borough level. The exercise is likely to begin from next month.The passes, to be issued by the mayor’s department, will allow a citizen to meet the head of departments (HoDs) of essential services at the KMC headquarters on SN Banerjee Road.“Going through the nature of complaints, the department heads will offer solutions to the aggrieved complainants. In case no prompt action can be taken, the HoD concerned will have explain the reasons and give it in writing. Under no circumstances a genuine complainant should feel neglected,” mayor Firhad Hakim said on Monday.A sources in the mayor’s office said the civic brass wanted citizens, who had been victims of ill-treatment by KMC employees, to register their protests with senior officials to the rank of director-general or chief manager. “We have taken up the matter with KMC senior officials posted at the headquarters. They have been asked to offer practical solutions to long-pending problems. We invite them to take advantage of our new system in large numbers,” said an official associated with the mayor’s office.According to plans, a citizen who has long been suffering from civic apathy, needs to appear before the mayor’s office at the KMC headquarters and register his/her name with the officer-in-charge of the grievance cell. Once the name is registered, the complainant will be handed over a slip where he/she needs to write down specific complaints, stating address, date and the nature of the complaint. Once this is done, the complainant will be sent to the head of the department concerned for a solution.The decision to introduce the step was taken following mayor’s direct interaction with a section of citizens over the last five months. “Some of the departments where we need to improve on include assessment, building, market, roads and drainage. We will encourage top-ranking officials of these departments and other essential departments like water supply to take note of citizens’ grievances and suggest remedial measures,” a KMC official said.

Title: Kite sales decline 20% against last year in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Shopkeepers and kite manufacturers have attributed the decline to recession

AHMEDABAD: Except for the last-minute rush to the traditional kite markets in the Walled City of Ahmedabad, seasonal kite stores bore a deserted look ahead of the festival. Kite traders say sales have declined by a significant 20% against last year. Shopkeepers and kite manufacturers have attributed the decline to recession.

“The market is overstocked with kites and there’s little sales. Recession has hit the industry. We have few orders from corporate houses that usually spend big for kites branded with their company logo and names,” said Pappubhai Patangwala, a manufacturer based in Kalupur Tower area of the city.

Retailers say that the demand has picked up only in the last two-three days. “Normally, the rush is at its peak on January 13, i.e. a day before Uttarayan. However, this time the sudden change in weather has also deterred several people from buying kites. As there was unseasonal rain in several parts of Gujarat; and the weather went cloudy on Monday, many were unsure whether they will be able to fly kites. The footfalls were much lower than normal,” said Mahendra Soni, a trader in the Raipur kite market.

Even as the demand remained lukewarm, vendors and kitemakers have put their best foot forward to woo customers with catchy, contemporary and popular slogans and prints on kites. Prints ranging from pictures of political leaders and cartoons to those with social messages were seen in the market.

In addition to kites, threads and sunglasses, masks and visors were equally popular.
