Title: TNSTC’s spiritual tour aims to cash in on tourist arrivals
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Madurai: The Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC), Madurai division has started a spiritual tour service for the convenience of visitors and tourists thronging the city. Visitors will be taken from Ellis Nagar parking lot to places like Thirupparankundram temple, King Thirumalai Nayak Mahal, Mariamman Teppakulam, Gandhi Museum and World Tamil Sangam and dropped back at the same place.

The service was started on Sunday for Pongal festival anticipating a large number of visitors and Ayyappa devotees. Officials said that apart from catering to the visitors, the initiative will help promote tourism in the city.

Officials from TNSTC said that they are operating 10 to 15 buses to Meenakshi temple on a regular basis, depending on the demand. Three of them have been allocated for the spiritual tour. Fare has been fixed at a nominal price of Rs 125 per person. The first trip will start at 8am and conclude at 1pm, whereas the second tour will start at 2pm and conclude at 7pm.

A higher official said visitors can stop the bus at their desired place if they want to have some snack during the tour. “We have introduced this service on a pilot basis and depending on the demand, it will be expanded further. Meenakshi Amman temple has been excluded from the tour since exclusive services connecting Ellis Nagar and the temple are already available,” he said.

About 2.09 domestic and 2.44 lakh foreign tourists visited Madurai in 2018. While most of them visit Meenakshi temple, only a fraction of them visit other tourist attractions in the city. The city tour facility will help promote such tourist destinations.

The tourism department had operated city tours some years ago, which was stopped due to various issues. Initially, the TNSTC and district tourism officials planned to start a joint tour, with the latter proposing to take permission from the Hindu religious and charitable endowment (HR&CE) department to help visitors to have a speedy darshan. But, TNSTC has launched the service on its own. The buses can be booked on 9894996142 and 9994520520.

Title: 16 corpn school girls get spl training for IIT, NEET exams
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Madurai: Sixteen Class XII girls belonging to Madurai Corporation schools are undergoing free special coaching for Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) and National Eligibility cum Entrance Test (NEET) entrance exams for a year, which is sponsored by the civic body.

Alongside their regular classes, the students are being trained for these entrance exams in the two newly-constructed smart classrooms with air-conditioners at the Avvai Corporation Girls Higher Secondary School.

“It was suggested to handpick students who are really interested in pursuing medicine or engineering and bring them together to provide special training with facilities equal to that of a private coaching centre. This is the first time we are doing this at our school. We hope to have more students next year,” said Poongavanam, headmistress of Avvai school.

All expenses, including transport for the special coaching are being borne by the corporation. The students are trained by qualified teachers appointed by the corporation during weekends between 10am and 3pm.

“We are planning to intensify the classes in the following months, especially after board exams are over. Now, their focus is slightly more towards boards. We will soon be setting up computers with superfast internet connection for students to practice online mock tests,” said Balu Mani, assistant headmaster and co-ordinator for the special class.

The students said that they are highly hopeful of clearing the entrance exams and secure admission into good colleges. “We find chemistry to be the toughest subject. However, the new Class XII syllabus that was introduced this year is far more helpful for the entrance exams so we think it is easier this time,” they said.

Title: More showers expected this week in Delhi, but minimum temperature to rise
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Rain is expected on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday too, a Met official said

NEW DELHI: The city witnessed an overcast day with trace rain in some parts in the first half of Monday. However, in the evening, very light rain was witnessed all over the city. Rain is expected on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday too, a Met official said.

Due to the change in wind direction from north-westerly to south-westerly and cloudiness, the minimum temperature will rise by 4 degrees Celsius by Friday, more than 2-3 degrees above normal. But the maximum temperature may dip to nearly 17-18 degrees Celsius between January 14 and 18, which is slightly less than normal, an official said.

Track the pollution level in your city

The minimum temperature on Monday was 8 degrees Celsius, a notch above normal, while the maximum was 19.9 degrees Celsius, normal for this time of the year. From 5.30pm to 8.30pm, Palam recorded 1mm rain while Safdarjung, considered the base for Delhi, witnessed 0.8mm.

Two back-to-back western disturbances (WD) are likely to bring snow to the western Himalayas and rain or hail to the north-western plains, which is affecting Delhi, too. On Tuesday, partly cloudy sky is expected with moderate fog in the morning. The maximum and minimum temperatures may be around 18 and 9 degrees.

Delhi’s air quality on Monday remained ‘very poor’ at 366, worse than Sunday’s 348, according to Central Pollution Control Board. According to SAFAR, a central forecast body, “A fresh WD in quick succession is likely to influence the region by Thursday and AQI is likely to stay in better conditions.”

Title: Satya Nadella on CAA: After tweet quoting him, Satya Nadella posts on CAA
Content:
Microsoft chief Satya Nadella (File photo)

NEW DELHI: A couple of hours after BuzzFeed News’ editor-in-chief Ben Smith posted a tweet quoting him on the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, Microsoft ’s global CEO Satya Nadella issued a more nuanced statement on the subject.“Every country will and should define its borders, protect national security and set immigration policy accordingly. And in democracies, that is something that the people and their governments will debate and define within those bounds. I’m shaped by my Indian heritage, growing up in a multicultural India and my immigrant experience in the US. My hope is for an India where an immigrant can aspire to found a prosperous start-up or lead a multinational corporation benefitting Indian society and the economy at large,” said the statement issued by Nadella.Earlier, Smith’s tweet quoted Nadella as saying, “I think what is happening is sad ... It’s just bad .... I would love to see a Bangladeshi immigrant who comes to India and creates the next unicorn in India or becomes the next CEO of Infosys .” Smith said Nadella made the comment in response to a question at a meeting with editors during a Microsoft event.The Centre last week issued a gazette notification announcing that the CAA has come into effect from January 10, 2020.The CAA was passed by Parliament on December 11.According to the legislation, members of Hindu, Sikh, Buddhist, Jain, Parsi and Christian communities who have come from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan till December 31, 2014 due to religious persecution will not be treated as illegal immigrants but given Indian citizenship.There have been widespread protests against the Act in different parts of the country.In Video: What Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella has to say on CAA

Title: Regn of bulls, tamers completed in Madurai
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Madurai: More than 1,000 bulls and an equal number of young men were passed fit to participate in Avaniapuram, Palamedu and Alanganallur jallikattu, where the preparatory works are in full swing for the much-awaited spectacle.

Though the Avaniapuram jallikattu is the first to be held on January 15, the registration for bull tamers was carried out on Monday after uncertainty loomed over the conduct of the game this time.

While men were checked for their weight, age, BMI index and health condition, the bulls were screened for age, height and health. Owners had to bring an application with the photograph of the animal, copies of their Aadhaar card, ration card and written application.

Bulls should be more than 120cm tall and aged between three to eight years. Only the native breeds with a hump would be allowed to participate and owners have to bring copies of necessary documents and a photograph of the bull to obtain the fitness certificate. A team of veterinarians led by assistant of animal husbandry Dr N R Saravanan screened the bulls at Avaniapuram.

In Alanganallur and Palamedu, a large number of women were seen queuing up for registration of bulls. Pandiammal R of Palamedu, who was in the queue, said she was submitting the documents on behalf of her son who would participate in the games. She took the bull also with her for registration. “It is women like us who usually take care of the bulls at home and it is easier for us to handle them when we go for certification process,” she said. Meanwhile, traditional “muhurthakal” was planted in Alanganallur as the first step of the jallikattu on Monday. Collector T G Vinay was present.

Title: BBMP staffers spark NRC scare in HRBR Layout
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Two BBMP employees allegedly went around an east Bengaluru locality last week, dropping the name of the controversial National Register of Citizens, demanding property documents from residents belonging to minorities, and marking their names in the voters’ list they carried with them.

The duo triggered panic in HRBR Layout ’s Kacharakanahalli ward on January 9, prompting locals to picket them. While one of the two men took to his heels, the other one was taken to Banaswadi police station where he was later released.

“My mother and I were at home when two men came and said they were from BBMP. They marked a cross against our names in the voters’ list they had brought and walked into neighbouring streets,” said Halima Sadiya, a private sector employee.

A few hours later, the two men returned and asked Halima to show her property documents. By then a large number of residents had gathered at the spot as several of their names too were marked in the sheets.

On being questioned, they said they were tasked with identifying ineligible voters in the electoral rolls in view of the proposed National Register of Citizens.

Dissatisfied with the reply, the residents asked the officials to show their ID cards. The men identified themselves as election officer SR Ramesh and computer operator Harish.

“The duo visited at least 30-40 houses in the area, asking for property papers. As people began shooting videos, Harish ran away but Ramesh stayed back,” Halima added.

“As we checked his list, we found that he had marked a black cross only against names of voters from a certain community, a resident said. Ramesh later claimed he had come to check if the residents had paid their property tax, he added. “We asked him why he was carrying a voters’ list to check property tax details. But he did not have an answer to that,” he said.

Ramesh also made his superior officer speak to the agitated residents. A woman, identifying herself as Jaya, spoke to them over phone and asked them to comply with Ramesh’s request. The residents immediately took Ramesh to Banaswadi police station, where he was allowed to go after police verified his credentials.

BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar told TOI they had sent block-level supervisor SR Ramesh to HRBR Layout in connection with residents’ complaints about some civic issues but did not know why the officer went around asking for property documents. Kumar said he will send the jurisdictional revenue officer to the spot on Tuesday to speak to the residents.

SR Ramesh could not be reached for comments.

Title: IVR system cuts down no. of plaints at grievance meets
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Madurai: The number of direct petitions received during the weekly grievance meetings conducted by the Madurai Corporation has come down by half as people prefer to raise their grievances through the new IVR complaint system introduced by the civic body a month ago, officials have said.

A team led by corporation commissioner S Visakan receives grievance petitions by taking part in the weekly grievance day meetings on Tuesdays. There are four zones in Madurai and the meeting is conducted once a week in each of them. While 60 to 80 petitions are submitted each week, it has come down to 30 to 40 in the last couple of weeks.

Meanwhile, the number of complaints received through IVR-based complaint system introduced a month ago has increased. A source from the complaint cell said that while they received 100 complaints a day on an average last month, it has increased to 120 calls a day. Between January 1 and January 10, the civic body has received 1,191 complaints, of which 511 were related to water supply and sewage. It was followed by street lights with 318 complaints and public health sanitation with 305 complaints.

A higher official from the corporation said the processing time given for complaints received through the new complaint system is just three days for street lights, sewage, water supply and other minor works. Works like laying roads and patch works will naturally take more time to follow the due process. But, one-week time is given for rectification of the complaint received during grievance meetings.

“People find it easy to raise complaints through the new system, where one can just dial the given number and record their grievance. Commissioner reviews the complaints raised and action taken time to time. The new system also makes officials concerned more accountable as a complaint once raised can be closed only when the complainant is satisfied and gives feedback,” the official added.

Title: 98% card holders receive Pongal gift hampers
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Madurai: Though the government has extended the distribution of Pongal gift hampers till January 21, the process is almost complete in Madurai with 98% of the card holders receiving their gifts.

The distribution of pongal gift hampers began on January 9 and the ration shops saw large crowds.

Shopkeepers distributed tokens to help ease the crowds, but some of the beneficiaries said that they had to wait for nearly four hours to receive the hampers.

By Sunday, the crowds began to ease as people had received their gifts in large numbers in the first two days. “Last year, I went late and got only Rs 500. So this year, I stood in the queue on the first day to get the entire amount,” said S Maliga of Thirupalai.

There are a total of 8,50,015 rice card holders in Madurai district. As many as 8,30,021 of them had received the pongal gift hampers by 6pm on Monday. Only 19,994 of the beneficiaries are yet to receive the gifts. This would be completed by Wednesday, said the district administration sources.

Title: NIN study finds exposure to lead can cause Alzheimer’s disease
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Scientists at the ICMR- National Institute of Nutrition ( NIN ) have established the possible link between exposure to lead and Alzheimer’s disease. Lead is a common pollutant present in a number of commonly used materials like paints, cosmetics, batteries, glass and low-grade toys.

Experts said the current findings could be a way forward in understanding the intracellular mechanism of Alzheimer’s disease.

In Alzheimer’s disease, brain cells that process, store and help recollect the information degenerate and slowly die.

A team lead by ICMR- NIN’s senior scientist Dr Suresh Challa worked on the molecular mechanism involved in the development of lead induced Alzheimer's disease through in-vitro (outside a living organism) studies.

Dr Suresh Challa said that Alzheimer’s disease has a complex patho-physiology which involves initially; formation of beta amyloid plaques and tangles in the brain.

“Oxidative stress and inflammation are known to be involved in the progression of the disease, with loss of memory and neuronal cell death. In this scenario, our study investigated the basic molecular mechanism behind the involvement of lead in Alzheimer’s disease,” said Dr Challa.

The scientists also studied various biochemicals available in food which can slow down the progression of the disease. “Foods like green tea , guava leaves, apples, cherries, pears and black berries, which possess antioxidant , anti-inflammatory and metal chelant properties were studied. Their ability to effectively permeate brain and modify several cell survival signalling pathways shows they have preventive and therapeutic potential,” he added.

Moreover, the effects of environmental exposure to lead can also be passed onto a child from a pregnant mother.

“Maternal exposure to lead during pregnancy can cause developmental reprogramming which can lead to higher risk and early onset of Alzheimer’s disease in later life of the child,” said Dr R Hemalatha, director, ICMR-NIN, and added that the study is a step forward in understanding Alzheimer’s disease and developing preventing strategies for the elderly.

Title: Ahmedabad: Five-day weekend leads many to short getaways
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Uttarayan is typically a festival that Amdavadis enjoy within the city. However, this year since the festival falls on Tuesday and Wednesday, many have taken leave on Monday and taken a five-day long weekend off, to enjoy a short getaway. According to tour operators, people have opted for domestic as well as international destinations and bookings are promising.

“Bookings to Dubai and Bangkok were a hit among travellers this time as there is a good five-day break available and many have flown on Friday night itself,” said Manish Sharma, secretary, Travel Agents’ Federation of India (TAFI) – Gujarat chapter.

Several private companies have also given Monday as a compensatory off so that they can enjoy an extended weekend, having made employees work on Saturday.

Destinations such as Goa, and cities in Rajasthan are equally popular among tourists, said Anuj Pathak, secretary, Travel Agents and Tour Operators’ Association of Gujarat (TAG).

Many have also booked private transport vehicles to take a short break. “Destinations within Gujarat are quite popular among tourists, as people can enjoy Uttarayan while taking a break from the daily hustle. We have got a lot of big vehicles including 11- and 14-seater buses and vehicles for destinations such as Gir and Bhuj. Some have also chosen to go to Rajasthan too,” said Paresh Thaker, a city-based travel company owner.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Will charge a token Re 1 for utilities, says Parvesh Singh
Content:
Parvesh Singh said religious structures built on encroached land in the city would be removed

NEW DELHI: Slamming AAP government’s free electricity and water scheme, West Delhi MP Parvesh Sahib Singh on Monday said if elected to power the BJP government would charge a token amount of one rupee to honour the “self-respect” of the residents of Delhi.Addressing a press conference, Parvesh also said that religious structures built on encroached government land in the city would be removed. Title: Hundreds of flyers stuck in Dubai for over 60 hours
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

These passengers flying to the US, the UK and Europe landed in the city on Saturday amid torrential rains that... Read More

HYDERABAD: More than 60 hours after touchdown, hundreds of Indians were still stranded in Dubai , on Monday, majority of them without luggage or clarity about their onward journey. Holed up in hotels – some over an hour or more away from the airport – they kept running from one Emirates counter to the other for information about their connections, but in vain.

These passengers flying to the US, the UK and Europe landed in the city on Saturday amid torrential rains that led to widespread disruption in air traffic in and out of the Dubai International Airport .

“I had to buy fresh clothes today (Monday), because I still don’t know how long I have to stay put here. I am on the waitlist for January 15 and am clueless about where my baggage is,” said Dishanki Nilesh Savla, who is headed to Orlando.

Sharing her ordeal with TOI, over telephone from Dubai, the student of Clinical Psychology at the University of Central Florida added: “Though the airline allotted a hotel, after 10 hours of standing in queue, the next day the staff abruptly called me asking me to check-out and go back to the airport at 1am. I had to fight with them to let me stay back because I still don’t have a ticket for the US.”

Dishanki landed in Dubai from Mumbai on January 11. She said her hotel is lodging scores of other Indians caught in a similar crisis.

“I have been accommodated on a flight for January 15 but that’s the earliest date of departure. Many of those waiting with me in queue on Saturday are booked for January 18 or later,” said Shyam Mehta a software engineer with Google in New York. When TOI spoke to him, Shyam was about to make his fourth trip to the Dubai airport, in search of his luggage. “Each time I go, the staff say they are clueless as thousands of bags have piled up at the counter. They take my baggage details and say they’ll revert. But that hasn’t happened yet,” he said.

Also stuck without luggage is Jyotshna M, from Hyderabad who is on a business trip to San Francisco. So bad was the hotel that she was taken to after waiting in line till midnight on January 11, that Jyotshna decided to return to the airport for the night and book herself a different hotel — on her own expense — the next morning.

While those like Ankit Kumar Gupta were lucky to reach their destination on time, despite the chaos, they are still struggling to track their bags. “It says still tracing bags. Really? I am here for 3 days only and shall I just keep waiting??? (sic)” he tweeted, on Monday.

Title: Fire arms seized from burglary victim’s house
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Madurai: The Madurai city police have seized six fire arms – three revolvers, one pistol and two air guns- all unlicensed, from a civil contractor named Solai Gunasekaran, 59, on Sunday.

A gang of three including a woman looted valuables from Gunasekaran’s house in Appadurai Nagar last month at gunpoint. While a case was registered earlier this month, the Koodalpudur police had arrested the trio and seized the weapon used in the crime. During inquiry, the accused had confessed that the gun used by them was found in Gunasekaran’s house.

Following this, a police team conducted a search in Gunasekaran’s house and unearthed five more fire arms. A case was registered against Gunasekaran, under a couple of sections of the Arms Act on Sunday and he was arrested. He was produced before a judicial magistrate and remanded in judicial custody.

A source said that while six fire arms have been seized so far in this case an inquiry is underway to find out the reasons as to why so many firearms were stashed by him. Apart from the fire arms, more than 100 bullets have been seized. They are yet to find out whether he kept it for his personnel safety or involved in selling them. Inquiry was also pending to find out source of the fire arms. All the police officers remained non-committal in confirming the developments. TNN

Title: IMC marks lane for roadside shops, parking at Patnipura and Kanadia
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Indore: As part of plans to improve condition of traffic on busy routes in city, Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) has now designated on-street parking space for motorists and shopkeepers on Patnipura and Kanadia roads.

Lane marking has been done on roads from Patnipura to Bhamori and from Bengali Square to Patrakar Colony Tri-Circle to divide space for traffic, roadside vendors and parking. Civic body officials said that this arrangement has been made to ensure smooth vehicular movement in these areas as they witness heavy traffic pressure. “We have marked lanes with white lines to designate spaces, where parking is allowed and prohibited. This arrangement has been done to solve traffic congestion in these areas,” said IMC’s additional commissioner SK Chaitanya.

He said that apart from lane marking, they have also formed separate teams of IMC staff to conduct surprise checks in these areas and lift vehicles and pushcarts that are found parked on prohibited lanes. “Pushcarts are seized and sent to trenching ground. People whose vehicles are seized for parking on prohibited lanes will have to pay towing charge,” he added. Officials said that towing charge of Rs100 is collected from owner of two-wheeler and Rs200 is from four-wheeler owners. “So far, more than 50 vehicles and pushcarts have been seized from these two areas. The drive will continue,” they said. The civic body has also hired 13 towing vehicles including eight towing vans for four-wheelers, four towing vans for lifting of two-wheelers and a hydraulic van for towing heavy vehicles. Officials are also in process to identify similar areas, where roadside encroachment by motorists and pushcart vendors hamper vehicular movement.

Title: Rs 4cr revamp of Chhappan area begins
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Indore: Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) is likely to start re-development work of Chhappan Dukaan. The civic body on January 3 had announced to re-develop 56-Dukaan Street from MG Road to Chandni Chowk as ‘Smart Food Street’ and make the area ‘No Vehicle’ zone.

“We are preparing to start redevelopment work of 56-Dukaan from Tuesday,” said IMC’s additional commissioner Sandeep Soni. The entire area will be developed as smart food street with façade development of all shops, LED lightings, designer pavement space, plantation and greenery. The entire project would cost around Rs4 crore and this project would be carried out in a time bound manner with a target to complete it before Holi. TNN

Title: Telangana: Four thieves held, 19 mobiles and auto recovered
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Task Force police on Monday apprehended four thieves and recovered property worth Rs 5 lakh including 19 cellphones and an autorickshaw.

The accused, Md Ibrahim Hussain (28) of Rein Bazar, Md Shareef (26), an auto driver from Yakutpura, Syed Gayaz Hashmi (28), an auto driver from Jahanuma and Syed Rasheed Hussain (39), a cook from Gowlipura were arrested near Secunderabad railway station.

During interrogation, the accused confessed to having committed 11 offences in the past few months at Begumpet , Begum Bazar, Sultan Bazar, Charminar , Banjara Hills and Jubilee Hills.

“The gang members used to lure the passengers to get into the auto by offering to drop them at their destination for less fare. En route, one gang member would divert the attention of the passenger while the others would steal his phone. After committing the theft , the accused would force the victim to get down from the auto and would then escape,” Hyderabad commissioner Anjani Kumar said.

The accused, along with the seized items, were handed over to Begumpet police.

Title: Bhim Army’s Chandrasekhar Azad seeks bail, says charge erroneous
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Chandrasekhar Azad

NEW DELHI: Bhim Army chief Chandrasekhar Azad on Monday sought bail in a Delhi court claiming that the charge against him of being a part of an unlawful assembly is “erroneous”. Azad, currently in judicial custody, has claimed that police invoked “boilerplate” charges against him and arrested him “mechanically” without following the due process of law in connection with violence during anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) protest in Daryaganj.

“Charging the accused with being a part of an unlawful assembly is erroneous, as at no point of time during the alleged incident did the police authorities declare, announce, or proclaim the peaceful protests to be an unlawful assembly, and nor were any warnings issued or announced in this regard,” the plea said. It alleged that “police invoked boilerplate charges against the accused without the same being founded on any allegation of fact, in order to avoid compliance with the mandatory provisions of Sections 41 and 41A of the CrPC and arrested the accused mechanically without following the due process of law which renders the initial and continued detention of the accused completely illegal.”

The court has put up the matter for further hearing on Tuesday. The bail plea has further argued that no specific incriminating role has been attributed to Azad in the FIR, whose contents were “vague” and based on “conjectures and surmises”. The plea further said that Azad was willing to fully cooperate with the investigation in the case and would not tamper with any evidence or influence any witnesses.

Azad, meanwhile, was taken to AIIMS on Monday for “follow-up consultation and treatment”. Azad is suffering from polycythemia, a condition in which the body makes too many red blood cells. “He has been brought for follow-up consultation and treatment. He is undergoing investigations and will be soon sent back,” a source said. A city court had earlier pulled up Tihar jail authorities for acting in a “callous manner” by flouting laws that safeguard a prisoner’s right and asked them to ensure that Azad was treated at AIIMS.

Title: PM criticised by alumni of RK Mission
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

KOLKATA: PM Narendra Modi 's pro-CAA statements from the Ramakrishna Mission's Belur headquarters have evoked sharp response from the RKM alumni.

Iterating that RKM has always stayed away from politics, retired RBI officer Asoke Chattopadhyay said: "Anyone who has read Swami Vivekananda 's writings knows he has always valued inclusivity. Vivekananda has always stressed that it is a person's work and action that define them, nothing else. RKM should have been kept above politics." Kamalesh Dasgupta, who teaches in Jodhpur Park Boys' School, added: "If the PM truly believes in the ethos RKM stands for, he could have never used that platform to say what he did on CAA. Speaking on politics is disrespecting RKM. One shouldn't use it to further a political agenda."

Title: CAIT calls for early roll out of e-commerce policy
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Nagpur: The Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT) has demanded an early roll out of the e-commerce policy and a regulatory authority for the business.

A CAIT press release said the current model adopted by companies like Amazon and Flipkart involves predatory pricing and deep discounting which has driven out traders from the market. It was because of this reason that the Competition Commission of India (CCI) ordered an investigation against Amazon and Flipkart.

“As a part of CAIT’s continuing agitation, a large protest was held at Janntar Mantar in New Delhi where hundreds of protesters had gathered carrying black flags and raising slogans like ‘Amazon ki Jagir Nahin- Ye Hindustan Hamara Hai,’ ‘Amazon follow FDI Policy or leave India’.

CAIT president BC Bhartia said, “After CCI ordered an inquiry into the business model of Amazon and Flipkart, its a fight for survival for traders of the country. The economy of this country has been run by traders since independence and we will continue with this practics in the future too. If any foreign company dreams of occupying the country's e-commerce or retail business through unethical methods, then they are highly mistaken.”

He said CAIT will urge for the inclusion of the conduct of brand manufacturers and banks under the purview of investigation ordered by CCI against Amazon and Flipkart.

_________________________________________________________________________

Title: Demand from NRIs pushes up terrace rents
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

People celebrating Uttarayan in Ahmedabad

AHMEDABAD: The traditional flavour of Uttarayan comes alive in the pols of the Walled City and year after year, the demand has only gone up to celebrate Uttarayan there. Terraces in the pols are in high demand this time among non-resident indians (NRIs) who have come to Ahmedabad for the festival and the rents have gone up significantly.

“There is a significantly high demand from tourists and NRIs and as a result, the rents have increased by an estimated 30%. Unlike last year, when the rents used to be between Rs 10,000 and Rs 12,000; for pol house terraces in Uttaraya, it has now gone up to Rs 15,000 in Khadia,” said Maitri Pasawala, a resident of Khadia.

Similar is the case in Raipur, where several terraces are up for rent. “We typically get a group of 10-15 people at our terrace every year. People enjoy food and snacks while flying kites and listening to music,” said Mukesh, a resident of Raipur.

Enjoying Uttarayan in the pols is a must for many. "We regularly go to the Walled City and this time we will be in Patasa pol. One of my friends who is a local resident has managed to get a terrace of a private bank on rent. We have also hired a cook for the Uttarayan special menu, so that people can enjoy authentic delicacies, while the family can enjoy,” said Snehal Parikh, a Naranpura residence.

Pol homes reflect the flavour of Uttarayan and over the past few years, terraces have been in high demand.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Process kicks off, filing of nominations starts today
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: Hundreds of hopefuls vying for the 70 assembly seats of Delhi would be making a beeline at the 36 election offices from Tuesday. With the issuance of the poll notification, the 11 district election officers will start accepting nominations from candidates belonging to national and regional parties, apart from independents.The last date to accept nominations is January 21, with Sunday (January 19) being a weekly off. The election officials will minutely scrutinise all applications after the week-long process on January 24. Those who want to withdraw their names can do so by January 24.Whole voting will take place on February 8, the results will be announced three days later on February 11. The new assembly has to be finalised by February 22. Election officials said that the offices of the 70 returning officers, one for each assembly constituency, have been set up to receive the nominations. “Since a large number of candidates file their nominations from each seat, elaborate arrangements have been made to ensure applicants do not face any problems,” said a senior election official.In the 2015 assembly elections, 924 candidates had filed their nominations. However, only 673 candidates — the lowest since the reconstituted Delhi assembly had its first election in 1993 — had remained in the fray after the scrutiny and withdrawal process. As many as 1,316 candidates, the highest ever, had contested the 1993 assembly polls.Though the political parties are well-versed with the nomination process, officials said that candidates are being informed how the forms are to be filled and which documents are required.Each candidate will have to deposit a security of Rs 10,000. In the 12 reserved constituencies, the amount is Rs 5,000. The security deposit is forfeited if the candidate gets less than one-sixth of the total valid votes polled in his constituency. “This has been done to discourage non-serious people from filing nominations,” said an official.Each candidate is allowed to spend a maximum of Rs 28 lakh on his election. The district election officers have been asked to form teams to monitor the expenditure incurred by candidates and political parties. Apart from an assistant expenditure officer, each assembly segment will have at least three flying squads and other teams to ensure that the money spent is properly accounted for and services are paid for through cheques so that proper records of expenses are maintained.

The new assembly has to be finalised by February 22. Election officials said that the offices of the 70 returning officers, one for each assembly constituency, have been set up to receive the nominations. “Since a large number of candidates file their nominations from each seat, elaborate arrangements have been made to ensure applicants do not face any problems,” said a senior election official.In the 2015 assembly elections, 924 candidates had filed their nominations. However, only 673 candidates — the lowest since the reconstituted Delhi assembly had its first election in 1993 — had remained in the fray after the scrutiny and withdrawal process. As many as 1,316 candidates, the highest ever, had contested the 1993 assembly polls.Though the political parties are well-versed with the nomination process, officials said that candidates are being informed how the forms are to be filled and which documents are required.Each candidate will have to deposit a security of Rs 10,000. In the 12 reserved constituencies, the amount is Rs 5,000. The security deposit is forfeited if the candidate gets less than one-sixth of the total valid votes polled in his constituency. “This has been done to discourage non-serious people from filing nominations,” said an official.Each candidate is allowed to spend a maximum of Rs 28 lakh on his election. The district election officers have been asked to form teams to monitor the expenditure incurred by candidates and political parties. Apart from an assistant expenditure officer, each assembly segment will have at least three flying squads and other teams to ensure that the money spent is properly accounted for and services are paid for through cheques so that proper records of expenses are maintained.

Title: Field survey of Swachh league 2020 extended
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Swachh Bharat Mission director V K Jindal

INDORE: The ongoing field assessment survey by Centre’s team to verify claims of Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) for seven-star rating under Garbage Free Cities (GFC) component of Swachh Survekshan (SS) League 2020 have been extended for a few more days.

Survey had started last week and was expected to be completed by January 14.

Official sources said that survey work will continue for a few more days and the team will stay in Indore until the job is done.

“The team has to cover each and every wards of city and this process is time consuming. They have to collect pictures as well as feedback from citizens. It will take a few more days for the team to complete work,” they said.

The media attention is also seen as a reason behind delay in survey. The team members were spotted by media during field assessment work on various occasions and they have been instructed to be more cautious while going on the field.

The team members are keeping utmost secrecy and are not even seeking assistance from officials or employee while facing difficulty in finding locations.

This survey holds 1000 out of 6000 marks under SS League 2020. Corporation officials also expect visit by another team from Centre for physical verification of main survey. Swachh Bharat Mission (Urban) director VK Jindal on Monday visited Indore to take stock of preparations for upcoming visit by members of parliamentary committee from Union ministry of housing and urban affairs on Tuesday. Jindal visited Aerodrome Road, Maharaja Pratim, Bapat Square and Malwa Mill, where he inspected public toilets, food outlets and spoke to people about measures taken by IMC. He also lauded efforts of IMC for its ‘Thela Bank’ initiative.

Title: Suggest mantras of change in One MP, One Idea contest
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Indore: MP Shankar Lalwani on Monday launched 'One MP, One Idea' competition, which aims to improve three sectors including health, water and sanitation, and energy and environment based on suggestions of local public, organizations.

“Through One MP, One Idea, we are inviting suggestions for improvement in sectors by overcoming challenges. Any person, group or NGO can participate in the competition and can win prizes of Rs 2.5 lakh, 1.5 lakh and 1 lakh based on selection of their ideas by a committee of subject experts. The ideas can be sent at onemponeidaindore@gmail.com or can be submitted at district collectorate by February 10,” Lalwani said.

He added that its first-kind-of-initiative in India for him to prepare an agenda of working based on public’s suggestions.

“We, the country’s cleanest city, are aiming to become the healthiest city too. We will develop open gym in 100 public gardens of Indore,” the MP said. Lalwani added that Prime Minister Narendra Modi wants India to become a fit and healthy nation. On the same line, open gym facility, starting from Palsikar Colony, will be made available in 100 public gardens of city.

He added that proposals to create wrestling arenas, kabaddi and other such facilities to promote outdoor games and sport activities.

As part of the project, gazebos will also be constructed in public gardens for senior citizens. Lalwani said that such facilities will also result in social gathering and increasing harmony in the society.

“During summer and rainy season, people, especially senior citizens and women, face difficulties to find a suitable place to seat. Facility like gazebos will help in reestablishing dialogues among people, which will help in eradicating many bad things through talk, discussing ideas and other ways,” the MP said.

Title: After movie horror: 15 stuck in Empress Mall lift for 30 mins ‘without help’
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Nagpur: Around 15 people, including women, children and two salespersons, reportedly remained stuck in a lift at Empress Mall for over 30 minutes late on Saturday evening allegedly without getting any help from the mall’s administration.

In a written complaint lodged with the municipal commissioner, Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) fire officer and commissioner of police, the aggrieved people accused the mall administration of playing with their lives by neglecting maintenance and proper functioning of the lift.

The incident occurred around 10.30pm when the complainants took the lift after watching the 7.30pm show at PVR multiplex, which is on the third floor of the mall. The users pressed the ‘G’ button but the lift malfunctioned before getting locked and jumping to the fourth floor, the complainants stated. They finally got out of the lift after a traumatizing 30 minutes, that too in two batches.

The industries, energy and labour department (Nagpur section) assistant electrical (Lifts) Uday Dambhe told TOI that an inspection of the lift will be done on Tuesday and he will also check its maintenance contract.

“The mall has permanent licence to operate the lift. The lift has been installed by a reputed company. The error, if any, must have been logged in the lift system,” Dambhe said.

No helpline or phone is available in the lift, the complainant stated. When TOI visited the mall on Monday, the mandatory lift inspection certificate and licence too was not pasted in the lift.

The in-charge of mall operations blamed overloading by the complainants for the malfunction. Representatives of KSL Industries, which operates the mall, refused to comment saying that they will “reply only to the authorities”.

Besides the movie goers, two salesperson working in the mall were in the lift when the incident took place. One of the aggrieved women, who has written the letter, told TOI that the salespersons tried to call security and mall staff but nobody responded.

“The kids and women started feeling suffocated. We all started crying and fearing for our lives,” she said.

As per the complaint, when the lift reached the fourth floor, its glass door opened but the users couldn’t get out due to a wooden door which was locked.

The wooden door opens into the mall office and the lift is its only entry point. The door is locked from outside at 9pm by the staff after they enter the left while leaving the office.

“Four men in the lift forced opened the wooden door but the mall office had no other exit. We recollected ourselves and again went inside the lift. Fortunately, it worked and we came out badly traumatized. We didn’t know where to complain so we submitted a letter to the police and NMC,” the woman said.

Confirming that he has received the complaint, acting chief fire officer Rajendra Uchake said that they will inspect the mall building on Tuesday and take appropriate action.

Title: 3,916 constructions in violation of CRZ rules detected in Koz
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Kozhikode: Regional country and town planning department here on Monday evening submitted a report on the detection of 3,916 illegal constructions carried out violating Coastal Regulation Zone (CRZ) rules in Kozhikode district to district collector Sambasiva Rao.

The report on illegal construction of houses and buildings was conducted covering 35 local self-government bodies in the district which comes under the purview of the CRZ. The list was prepared based on the direction given by the state government to prepare a list of illegal constructions across the state in the wake of the SC order to demolish four illegal apartments at Maradu in Ernakulam. Out of 35 LSG bodies in Kozhikode district, illegal construction violating CRZ was detected in the limits of 28 LSG bodies. The list was prepared on illegal constructions carried out violating CRZ norms near the sea and the river. According to the officials, out of 3,916 illegal constructions, 1,657 illegal constructions were detected in the limits of Kozhikode corporation. The team could detect only one illegal construction in the limits of Ramanattukkara municipality. The second-highest number of illegal constructions of 486 were detected in the limits of Kadalundy grama panchayat followed by Chemmenchery (406), Azhiyur (286); Onchiyam (267); Moodadi (227); Chengottukkavu (142) and Thalakulathur (103), Thurayur (34); Payyoli municipality (39); Koyilandy municipality (24) Vadaakara municipality (9); Feroke Muncipality (6) Chorode (64) ; Edacheri (44): Thurayur (34) ;Ulliyeri (22); Maniyur(22); Peruvayal (21); Thikkodi (13); Chelannur (10). The team of coastal district committee couldn’t detect illegal construction activities in the limits of Naduvannur, Thiruvallur, Balussery, Cheruvannur, Velom , Mavoor, and Kottur grama panchayats. The detected illegal constructions comprised apartments, residential, homestay, resorts, and commercial buildings. The report was prepared by a panel of officials comprising officials of LSG and revenue departments with district collector as chairman and regional town planner as convener.

Regional town planner P A Isha said that the collector will submit the report to chief secretary to take necessary action against the illegal constructions. “Lack of awareness about CRZ norms made many house owners to carry out constructions violating the norms,” said the regional town planner.

Title: Honeytrap media gag plea: State gets a week to reply
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Indore: High court on Monday granted a week to state government to file reply in an interim application of suspended IMC engineer Harbhajan Singh demanding stay over media coverage of honeytrap case.

State government during hearing before a division bench of Justice SC Sharma and Justice Shailendra Shukla sought time to reply. The court fixed next hearing on January 20. Singh through his counsel Avinash Sirpurkar on December 19 moved an application in the petition of Digvijay Singh Bhandari and said that his reputation was damaged by media coverage.

Earlier, a similar application was moved by accused Monica Yadav demanding media gag. The court is yet to pronounce judgement on application.

Singh was made respondent in a petition by Digvijay Singh Bhandari demanding to make him accused in the case under Section 376 of IPC for raping a minor.

Three petitions were filed in the court demanding inquiry from an independent agency in the case under monitoring of the court. Five women accused and one driver, who were arrested after police busted a honeytrap racket in September last year on complaint of IMC’s executive engineer, were in jail. TNN

Title: 17-year-old girl raped in cane field
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Bareilly: A 17-year-old girl was allegedly raped by a youth and his friend in Fatehganj East area of Bareilly district. An FIR has been registered by cops against the accused.

The crime occurred on January 7 when the girl was on her way to work in a field. She was forcefully dragged by one Sunil and his unidentified friend. Sunil had allegedly crammed his mobile phone into the girl’s mouth. She was later sent for medical examination. Police have seized Sunil’s mobile phone and are now searching for the accused.

The girl’s father told police that his daughter had never seen the accused before and the only clue they have is Sunil’s mobile phone. The complaint also said that the survivor was thrashed for resisting the assault and Sunil crammed his mobile phone into her mouth to ensure that she didn’t shout for help.

The accused, on hearing footsteps of a few locals near the cane field, fled the scene leaving behind his mobile phone. The family initially remained quiet as they didn’t have any information about the accused, but when they received a phone call on the accused mobile, they decided to contact the police.

SHO Fatehganj East police station, Ashwini Kumar, told TOI on Monday, “We have registered an FIR under IPC section 376 (rape) and POCSO Act against both the accused. The second accused did not rape the girl but helped his friend in the crime. We have recorded the statements of the survivor and her parents. She was also sent for medical examination. She doesn’t know any of the accused and only heard the name of the person who raped her from his friend, who accidentally made a call on Sunil’s phone without realising that the phone was left with the girl.”

The SHO added, “We have now sought for call detail records (CDRs) from the service provider and have taken a suspect in our custody. The accused will be arrested soon.”

Title: Rajasthan: Time curbs on flying kites imposed, collector tells bikers to be careful
Content:
The collector has also advised people to wear helmets and cover themselves completely while riding two-wheeler... Read More

JAIPUR: Ahead of Tuesday’s kite festival, collector Joga Ram has requested people to not fly kites from 6am to 7am and from 5pm to 7pm as birds are most active during these hours.The collector has also advised people to wear helmets and cover themselves completely while riding two-wheelers as Chinese manjha strings could lead to injuries. Riders have also been advised not to speed to avoid grievous injuries.Deaths and injuries due to Chinese manjha had put the administration on its toes this Makar Sankranti . Apart from banning the Chinese manjha, special instructions have been issued by the district and police administration to make people aware about the dangers of it.On Sunday, two people were arrested from Vdihyadhar Nagar Sector 8 for using Chinese manjha. Both of them, residents of Suratgarh in Jhunjhunu district, purchased manjha from there and were using it in Jaipur while they were visiting relatives. Chinese manjha was seized and police informed the Jhunjhunu police.DIG Ashok Kumar Gupta said, “We have issued directions under Section 144 CrPC that action will be taken against any person found using Chinese manjha. Banners have been put up in all the markets asking people not to use Chinese manjha. Around 10 days ago, we arrested a person in Ramganj selling Chinese manjha. We are prepared and hope the kite festival passes off peacefully.”Traders have to give affidavits that they are not using Chinese manjha and more than 2 lakh pamphlets have been distributed in the city by police.Chinese manjha is made of plastic and fibre and it smells like plastic burn if put on fire. To make it more deadly, manjha is coated with crushed glass or powdered metal that can conduct electricity. Due to their long stay and ability to cut other kite strings easily, people prefer it over other varieties.When asked from where this manjha finds its way inside state boundaries even after being banned, Ashok Kumar Gupta said it enters Delhi from Nepal before reaching Rajasthan .

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Notices to AAP, BJP for poll code violation
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The Delhi poll panel on Monday served three legal notices — two to AAP and one to BJP –— for allegedly violating the model code of conduct. While BJP was accused of making “unsubstantiated” allegations against AAP on Twitter, the ruling party has been asked to reply on saffron party’s charge of circulating a video containing short clips of Manoj Tiwari’s albums with AAP’s theme song playing in the background.

AAP has also been served a notice on a campaign song showing a child singing and dancing allegedly in violation of the instructions from the Election Commission and National Commission for Protection of Child Rights, said an official.

Delhi election office on Monday said it registered 21 FIRs so far in connection with the violation of model code of conduct, while 84 cases under the Arms Act.

Nalin Chauhan, nodal officer (Media), said 97 unlicensed weapons and 154 cartridges had been seized in past week. “Over 3.8 lakh hoardings, banners and posters have been removed from across the city,” he added.

The static surveillance team seized Rs 49.2 lakh from a vehicle in Krishna Nagar on Monday. The cash was handed over to police and an FIR will be registered.

Title: Civic staff keep haat bazaar vendors of Pipliyahana at bay
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Indore: After shifting weekly haat market from Pipliyahana to a plot in Scheme 94, Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) on Monday deployed a team of removal wing staff to prevent them from coming back to the area. The civic body with help of police and district administration had on January 6 shifted about 150 vendors and shopkeepers, who operated shops at Pipliyahana to an open space near gas godown behind Pipliyahana pong as their presence near the square has been affecting vehicular movement.

A team of some 50 staff and officials reached the area early morning and started making rounds to check if any vendor or shopkeeper is trying to come back to previous location.

Some of the vendors had reportedly reached the area, but after noticing presence of officials and staff, they went to their designated area.

Civic officials that each vendor has been allotted 6x6 sq ft space at designate area to operate business. They have also been provided with an option to get extra space. Vendors were also asked to raise complaint in case if anyone raises objection or demands money as rent for running their business. “We have also made basic arrangements like water for vendors at the new location. Vendors have adequate space to run their business without any hassle,” said civic body’s removal wing in charge MS Chouhan. TNN

Title: Please give me PhD on Jan 18, says cancer patient
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Nagpur: She is already fighting cancer and now faces another battle for receiving the coveted Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) from the Nagpur University (NU) during its 107th convocation on January 18. The NU has refused to award the degree to Arti Chaurasia because she failed to appear for the viva-voce before the deadline of January 1.

Chaurasia, who is working with the National Bank For Agriculture & Rural Development (NABARD), is suffering from cancer from last few years. She had completed her thesis on the subject ‘food and nutrition’ and appeared for the viva-voce examination on January 4.

As per NU, candidates who appeared for the viva-voce before January 1 are eligible for receiving the degree at the convocation to be held at Suresh Bhat Hall. Chief Justice of India Sharad Bobde is the chief guest for the ceremony.

According to Chaurasia, she couldn’t appear earlier due to her ailment. After she came to know about the deadline, Chaurasia approached senior NU authorities through her lawyer brother, requesting them to consider hers as a special case.

Chaurasia told the NU officials that though she was under treatment and recuperating, nothing can be said about a deadly disease like cancer. She apprised them of the pain she was undergoing during treatment and stated that she would be relieved if her name as a PhD recipient was announced in front of a legal luminary like CJI Bobde and other dignitaries.

“It’s a dream of every student to receive the degree during convocation and she conveyed the same to NU authorities, but they refused,” Chaurasia’s brother told TOI.

Justifying NU decision, pro-vice chancellor Vinayak Deshpande told TOI that her case came up for discussion at the meeting of senior officials, including vice-chancellor SP Kane and Board of Examination and Evaluation (BoEE) director Prafulla Sabale.

“The exam director told us that over 25 applications of PhD students came after January 1 deadline for awarding the degree. If her application is allowed, all these 25 would have to be accommodated,” the pro-VC said.

NU bestows some prizes on PhD holders and a list was already prepared, he said and added that if these 25 are to be added, it would disrupt the list and authorities will have to make a fresh one at the last moment.

“We have decided to issue a provisional degree to Chaurasia just after the convocation so that her dream could be fulfilled. We have inquired with her about her health and it was found that her case is not serious,” said Deshpande.

NU exam section officials told TOI that the university was unnecessarily dragging its feet on the issue as the rules could have been relaxed for her considering it as a special case. The VC should have allowed her to take the degree, as it would have been a proud moment for the NU to bestow it on a cancer survivor. Other PhD students would have never objected but NU officials acted like robots, they said.

Title: Bareilly: FIR to be lodged against 21 villagers for killing leopard
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: A day after angry villagers allegedly killed a leopard at Jarifpur Gadhiya village in Budaun, the forest department has identified 21 people on the basis of videos and will lodge an FIR in the incident.

After the leopard had mauled two persons, including a teenager, on Sunday, angry villagers had beaten to death the big cat. An inquiry has been ordered against negligence of the forest staff.

This is the third such incident to be reported in a week in west UP. One leopard each was killed in Bijnor on January 6 and Moradabad on January 8.

Chief conservator of forests, Rohilkhand zone, Lalit Verma who visited the spot on Monday told TOI, “The villagers were injured around 4 pm on Sunday and if the forest team had reached the spot on time, the incident could have been averted. We are probing the negligence on part of forest staff. Besides, we have identified 21 persons who were involved in killing the leopard on the basis of a video. We will lodge an FIR against named and unidentified people.”

According to sources, the forest team reached the spot late on Sunday night and they alerted senior officials in Bareilly on Monday morning. No FIR had been lodged till the filing of this report.

Though initial reports said after beating the leopard with sticks, the villagers mowed it down with a tractor, Verma said, “The animal suffered a head injury and we don’t suspect that it was mowed down by a tractor. We have sent the carcass to the Indian Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI) in Bareilly for postmortem.”

Sources said on Sunday, a leopard attacked Sher Singh, 16, while he was playing and it attacked Mohan Lal, 60, on the outskirts of Jarifpur Gadhiya village. On hearing Lal’s cries, his son-in-law and other villagers rushed to the spot. They spotted the leopard and allegedly attacked it with sticks.

According to the purported video, which has been widely shared on social media, the villagers dragged the leopard carcass after killing it. They surrounded the carcass to click pictures. The mob later threw the carcass on the outskirts of the village. The forest department recovered it around 3 am on Monday.

As Budaun is a social forestry area, it is suspected that leopard reached here by moving along banks of the Ganga.

Title: Jaipur: Man who killed 3 peacocks jailed
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Jaipur has earned the dubious distinction of reporting regular incidents of peacock poaching.

On Monday, the forest department arrested a person who killed three peacocks after feeding them with poisonous grain in Amber region.

Accused Cheetar Mal Bagaria was produced in court from where he was sent to jail. Jaipur DFO Kavita Singh told TOI, “The accused was booked under Section 9 (prohibits hunting of any wild animal specified in Schedule I ), Section 39 (wild animal, other than vermin, which is hunted) and Section 51 of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972.” Forest officials said, the poacher can be subjected to a maximum imprisonment of 7 years and fine of Rs 50,000 to Rs 5 lakh or both.

Title: Hyderabad News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

4 juveniles held for bike theft

Malkajgiri police arrested four juveniles in conflict with law on Monday for allegedly stealing two-wheelers. They also recovered two bikes from their possession.

Man found with head injury, dies

A 45-year-old man died under mysterious circumstances in Malkajgiri on Monday. The deceased, identified as Raju, had returned home late after shopping. Later, when his daughter went to the washroom, she found him lying there with a head injury. He was shifted to Gandhi Hospital, where he died while undergoing treatment.

2 arrested with

Chinese manja

South Zone Task Force sleuths raided kite shops under Kamatipura and Mirchowk police stations on Monday and took two persons into custody for selling Chinese manja. The police also seized 100 manja bundles worth Rs 2 lakh.

Title: DDA ‘scam’: AAP, Hardeep Singh Puri up the ante
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Hardeep Singh Puri

NEW DELHI: A day after AAP claimed that DDA had arbitrarily inflated the prices of flats offered for the economically weaker sections under a 2014 housing scheme, party MP Sanjay Singh and Union housing and urban affairs minister Hardeep Singh Puri were locked in a bitter confrontation.

Puri took to Twitter to rubbish the allegations: “Whenever it has nothing sensible to say, AAP always falls back upon a litany of lies, fake narratives and blatant misinformation. Fact remains. They neither have the will, nor capability to do any good for the people of Delhi (sic),” he wrote. “No matter how many times they repeat it, lies will remain lies. On their latest misinformation campaign on the flats in the EWS category... DLF constructed 772 houses, which have all been allotted. This means the people have found the pricing to be reasonable,” he added.

At a press conference, AAP’s Singh responded: “After I highlighted a scam in the construction and sale of flats for people under the EWS category, Puri commented, and the officials of DDA issued a statement from their Twitter handle, which turned out to be a big lie.” Singh claimed that Puri had said that he did not have any information about the 772 EWS-category flats. “It’s a lie. A legal notice by the allottees was sent to a number of people, including LG, PMO and Puri’s ministry,” Singh said.

Title: Bisalpur water pipe leak plugged, supply restored
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: PHED officials plugged the leak in the water pipeline from Bisalpur on Monday, thus restoring supply to Jaipur, which did not get water for three days. The leak was detected in a scour valve near Surajpura filter plant in Bisalpur water transmission line.

Supply was stopped in the city around 11 am on Saturday. According to officials, 70% of the residents did not get water on Monday morning.

Superintendent engineer of PHED Subhanshu Dixit said that the officials worked late night on Sunday to restore the supply. “The gasket of the pipeline broke down due to which the water was leaking. During our routine patrol in the area on Saturday, the leakage came into light and we immediately stopped supply and started repairing work. On Monday morning, only 30% of Jaipur received water but later the supply was regularised,” said Dixit.

According to PHED officials, more than 50 lakh litre had been lost due to the leakage. The sources in the department, however, said that said that more than 80 MLD water was wasted due to the leakage. Water has not been supplied to citizens since Saturday morning which was causing inconvenience to people. Meanwhile, private water tankers have increased their rates from Rs 250 to Rs 400 per tanker. Ashok Parnami , a resident of Raja Park, said that this sudden water cut helped the private water tanker owners.

“We used to buy tanker of Rs 200 but on Sunday price increased to Rs 350 per tanker. I understand that it was due to the leakage but during the time of routine maintenance PHED officials inform the public at the last moment. Tanker owners will increase the rate for that day. If the PHED officials will inform us two days in advance, then only we will be better prepared to deal with the crisis,” further said Parnami.

Title: Corp to float EoI to keep SM Street abuzz at night
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Kozhikode: Kozhikode Corporation is considering a proposal to step up the shopping experience at S M Street, the oldest commercial spot in the district , which would be bustling with activities even at night once the proposal materializes. The civic body will float an expression of interest (EoI) inviting private parties to ensure basic facilities and to carry out beautification so that the old glory of S M Street is restored.

The civic body plans to bring the S M Street under close circuit television cameras. The dysfunctional decorative lamps will be replaced and new lights will be placed on the street to make it more beautiful. To attract more people, including domestic and foreign tourists, beautification works will carried out. Basic facilities like drinking water and adequate number of toilets will be set up. Security will be beefed up with more personnel to prevent any untoward incidents on the street during late hours. To pep up the street-shopping experience, music systems will be installed.

The cost of revamping the street and its further beautification will be borne by the private agency, and in turn, the civic body will allow it to install advertisements. The private agency will also ensure the maintenance of the basic facilities.

The developmental works on S M Street will be a of blend modern style while retaining its heritage charm, and the civic corporation plans to turn it into a major hotspot in Malabar.

The district administration had renovated the street in December 2018 at a cost of Rs 6.26 crore using funds from the district tourism development corporation. The renovation followed a major fire tragedy in a multi-storey building on February 22, 2017. The renovation saw the district administration, Kozhikode corporation and elected representatives arriving at a consensus with the traders after several rounds of discussions.

Deputy mayor Meera Darshak said that the civic body aims to make the S M Street lively even during night hours. “The move aims to attract more shoppers to the spot and providing them basic facilities. The civic body will float an expression of interest soon to entrust a private agency to take up the maintenance and beautification of the street,” she said. TNN

Title: Bareilly: Drawings, slogans to promote cleanliness
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

BMC officials have identified public places such as parks, government offices, boundary walls running along ci... Read More

BAREILLY: In a move that is expected to serve a dual purpose — giving a facelift to prominent city localities and promoting cleanliness among residents — the Bareilly Municipal Corporation (BMC) has started painting graffiti with catchy slogans on boundary walls at public places.

According to BMC officials, the move is — part of Swachh Bharat Abhiyan (or Clean India Mission) — aimed at making the city look beautiful and gain better ranking in the Swachh Survekshan (Cleanliness Survey) 2020, which is likely to begin the next month.

BMC officials have, meanwhile, identified public places such as parks, government offices, boundary walls running along city roads, flyovers and underpasses, among others, for paintings images with catchy slogans delivering messages on cleanliness.

Environment engineer Sanjeev Pradhan told TOI, “The initiative is aimed at making the city look beautiful as well as spreading cleanliness messages through pictures and slogans. The wall paintings will have famous cartoon characters wielding brooms and making their surrounding trash-free; paintings of trees and flowers, underlining the importance of plantation for greenery; wall paintings asking people to shun plastic and polythene for the protection of environment (plastic hataein, aao pariyawaran bachaein); awareness against the practice of open defecation; and dumping trash in dustbins, among others. At some places, walls have already been painted with images of Mahatma Gandhi and bearing messages ‘hum sabka ek hi naara, saaf suthra ho desh humara’, ‘swachhta hi sewa’, etc.”

Giving details, BMC artists said a team comprising eight persons was deputed across the city to paint streets and public places with messages and relevant pictures.

Maujahid Hussain, an artist employed with BMC, said, “Wall paintings have been done near Bareilly College in Kalibadi area and at pubic parks in Rampur Garden and Civil Lines areas. We are now painting walls of Shyamatganj flyover, and thereafter, we will move to Qutubkhana, City Station and Choupla road. It will take around a month to paint the identified locations.”

BMC officials said paintings would also help get rid of unauthorised posters and flexes, which are sore to the eyes.

Hussain added, “The identified locations are dotted with advertisements, posters and flexes. Once painted, people will think twice before sticking posters and putting flexes on the walls.”

Title: Export of soyabean derivatives takes a hit due to skeletal supplies
Content:
This story is from January 14, 2020

Overseas shipment of soyabean derivatives from local exporters has dropped significantly amid peak harvesting ... Read More

INDORE: Overseas shipment of soyabean derivatives from local exporters has dropped significantly amid peak harvesting season owing to skeletal supplies hitting home business, said industry players. According to Container Corporation of India Ltd (CONCOR), export consignment of soyabean derivatives has fallen to nearly half in December as against a year ago in the same period.

A senior official from the container corporation, wishing not to be named said, “Export of soyabean derivatives has not been encouraging this season. We have not seen loads from regular exporters so far this season. Overall exports of soyabean derivatives look weak this year.”

Soyabean derivatives form about 50 per cent of total movement of goods from the region by the container corporation.

According to CONCOR, exports of soyabean derivatives from September to December stood at 3,000 containers as against 3,417 containers during the same period a year ago.

Usually, exports of soyabean derivatives from local exporters picks up with start of fresh harvest in October but this season loads have dropped significantly, said container corporation.

Madhya Pradesh is the leading producer of soyabean with over 60 per cent of the total output. This year, state is estimated to have produced around 40 lakh tonne soyabean as against 58.18 lakh tonne a year ago due to prolong rainfall.

Industry players said besides rail route, a lot of export consignment goes through road directly to the port but volumes have been less through road also due to limited supplies and high prices in international market.

Soybean Processors Association of India (SOPA) has estimated country-wide export of soyabean meal in December at 60,000 tonne as against 4 lakh tonne a year ago.

The industry body has put total export of soyabean meal during October to December 2019 at around 2 lakh tonne as against 8.59 lakh tonne in corresponding period a year ago.
